courses.desc: A studio investigation of theoretical ideas, critical possibilities, historical precedents, and various techniques involving the production of fabricated images. Techniques may include montage, digital, chemical and in-camera manipulations, studio constructions, appropriations, performance, and projected images. Materials fee.

courses.title: Seminar Production Component
courses.desc: Photographic and/or inter-media production course tied to a specific Issues course (for example, Issues in Photography, Issues in Feminism, Issues in New Genres). Critiques, labs, field trips, discussion, demonstrations. Materials fee.

courses.title: Digital Filmmaking Advanced Project II
courses.desc: Directed to the production of individual or collaborative videotapes, using studio, portable camera, editing facilities, and sound and computer elements. Emphasis will be on individually initiated projects. Readings and screenings are assigned. Materials fee.

courses.title: Advanced Studio Topics: Performance
courses.desc: An intensive investigation of the practice of performance art, with an emphasis on the development of individual projects, and the refinement of various technical skills, as well as audiences, spaces, and cultural connections.

courses.title: Advanced Studio Topics: Ceramic Sculpture
courses.desc: Discussion of ideas, techniques, and personal control of form. Clay body, fabrication, glazing, and firing.  Emphasis on development of personal direction. Materials fee.

courses.title: Digital Filmmaking Web Series
courses.desc: Original video projects produced in collaborative teams combining advanced video students with students from other areas, including Dance, Drama, and Music. Shoots may be carried out on the video stage as well as field locations. Materials fee.

courses.title: Advanced Projects
courses.prereqs: ART 150 or ART 150C or ART 151 or ART 152A or ART 152B or ART 152C or ART 152D or ART 152E or ART 152F or ART 153 or ART 166A or ART 190 or ART 190B or ART 190C
courses.desc: Students working in different mediums will focus on ambitious research, planning, development, and experimentation, leading to a single work or focused series that is large in scope. The project will be exhibited and documented at the end of the quarter.  Materials fee.

courses.title: Critical Aesthetics
courses.desc: Surveys critical thought that has influenced twentieth-century art production, preparing the student to engage contemporary art with a critical eye, specifically addressing aesthetic and political debates of the historical avant-garde, the neo-avant garde, and postmodern culture.

courses.title: Senior Project and Critique
courses.desc: Directed-study critique class in preparation for final project and life after graduation; documentation and portfolio preparation for graduate school. Investigation of exhibition spaces and funding opportunities, participation in artists' communities outside the university, and artists' rights issues.

courses.title: Senior Projects and Critique in Photography
courses.prereqs: ART 1A and ART 1B and ART 1C and ART 71A and ART 71B
courses.desc: Directed group study focused on production of photographic projects of significant scope and ambition. Emphasis on preparation for continued study and/or practice in photography in advanced settings beyond the undergraduate university experience. Materials fee.

courses.title: Art Internship
courses.desc: Under faculty supervision, students participate directly in a variety of art institution settings, including museums, galleries, and nonprofit organizations.

courses.title: Honors Exhibition
courses.desc: Preparation, installation, and participation in the annual honors exhibition. Materials fee.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Individual study or directed creative projects as arranged with faculty member. Materials fee.

courses.title: First-Year Graduate Seminar
courses.desc: Introductory theory class to contemporary art: intellectual history, theoretical antecedents, and current critical concerns.

courses.title: Graduate Seminar Topics
courses.desc: In-depth discussion of contemporary art production in relation to a variety of theoretical, cultural, and historical topics. Material is determined by the given instructor's current research interest. Topics vary.

courses.title: Graduate Seminar: Issues in Contemporary Art
courses.desc: Classroom interaction with artists, curators, critics, lecturers from fields outside of the arts or from cross-disciplines. Includes recommended readings, discussions, panel participation, writing assignments.

courses.title: Graduate Group Critique
courses.desc: Focus on studio production. Students are expected to help foster and develop an environment in which serious and sophisticated peer critique can take place.

courses.title: Graduate Topics in Studio Production
courses.desc: Graduate group study of a specific medium or art practice (e.g., painting; video, installation, photography, sculpture/3D, performance, digital media, public art, sound art; film). Includes consideration of technical, theoretical, historical, and/or formal issues.

courses.title: Interdisciplinary Projects
courses.desc: Intensive faculty-led discussion of in-progress graduate studio projects--can be discipline driven or working across fields in a rigorous interdisciplinary studio environment where students meet with the professor both individually and in small groups.

courses.title: Directed Reading and Research
courses.desc: Independent study with a supervising faculty member to direct academic research, develop bibliographies, and discuss assigned readings.

courses.title: Special Topics Seminar
courses.desc: Directed reading and/or study group on a given research topic. Agreed-upon meeting structure may be flexible in order to accommodate off-campus field trips and travel.

courses.title: Graduate Interdisciplinary and Collaborative Projects
courses.desc: For graduate students working collaboratively across the School of the Arts or cross-university. May be team taught with one of the faculty members based in the Department of Art.

courses.title: Graduate Thesis Writing Seminar
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: ART 262
ART 210 and ART 215 and ART 220
courses.desc: Seminar for writing as a component of the thesis. Different models of writing, text, and spoken word will be discussed. Required second year.

courses.title: Graduate Thesis Independent Study
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: ART 261
ART 210 and ART 215 and ART 220
courses.desc: Tutorials and directed study in thesis writing, research and/or studio production with thesis committee chair and/or thesis committee members to be taken during final quarters of study.

courses.title: Graduate Thesis, Exhibition Critique
courses.prereqs: ART 210 and ART 215 and ART 220 and ART 230 and ART 240 and ART 261 and ART 262
courses.desc: Group critique required for matriculating M.F.A. students during the quarter in which their thesis exhibitions are scheduled. Public presentation/lecture on student's work required.

courses.title: Critical and Curatorial Thesis Exhibition
courses.desc: Intensive tutorial geared toward execution of professional gallery exhibition, which is one half of the degree requirement for the M.F.A. concentration in Critical and Curatorial Studies. Must be taken under direction of Committee Chair.

courses.title: Contemporary Exhibition Systems
courses.desc: Investigates contemporary case studies of curatorial practice. Sometimes taught in collaboration with a host institution. The history, theory and criticism or curatorial practice are tested through the explication of real exhibitions.

courses.title: Introduction to Exhibition Systems
courses.desc: Introduces the basics of curating, covering the fundamentals of collection, research, fundraising, publicity, and installation. Also introduces the related categories of public programming and art criticism.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Associates working under the active guidance and supervision of a regular rank faculty member responsible for curriculum and instruction at the University.

courses.title: Ancient Greek and Roman Art, and Architecture
courses.desc: An overview of Greek and Roman art, and related ancient visual cultures. Considers how and why the peoples of antiquity created art and architecture, as well as the significance of these works within their social, religious, and historical contexts.

courses.title: Arts of Europe: Medieval and Renaissance
courses.desc: Focuses on the art of the Mediterranean area and Europe between ca. A.D. 350 and 1600. By means of movements and artists, examines the cultural identities of the Christian, Islamic, and Early Modern worlds.

courses.title: Early Modern and Modern Art in Europe and America
courses.desc: The visual arts from the seventeenth to the twenty-first centuries. Explores the purposes and meaning of painting, sculpture, and architecture in relation to artists, viewers, and historical events.

courses.title: History of Asian Art: Arts of India
courses.desc: Emphasizing Hindu, Buddhist, and Islamic art of greater India (Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka) from proto-historic to modern times. Themes include art as a source of history, commercial and religious pan-Asian connections, nationalism, and modern versus historical identities.

courses.title: History of Asian Art: Arts of China
courses.desc: An introduction to the arts and visual culture of China from Neolithic to modern times. Themes includes the representation of power, death and the afterlife, popular culture and elite arts, landscape and women's painting, and concludes with contemporary China.

courses.title: History of Asian Art: Arts of Japan
courses.desc: Examines compelling images and objects of spirit and power created in Japan over many centuries. Themes include Buddhist icons, narative illustration, popular prints, architecture, manga, and the avant-garde. Japanese interactions with Korean, Chinese, and European culture are emphasized.

courses.title: History of Asian Art: Arts of Islam
courses.desc: Examines past and present Islamic art, spanning 1,500 years and extending from the Americas through Indonesia. Themes include Islam as a globalizing force, the definition of "Islamic," and the competing roles of religion and politics in making art.

courses.title: Art and Archaeology of Ancient Persia, Egypt, and Mesopotamia
courses.desc: An introduction to the art and archaeology of ancient Egypt, Mesopotamia, Anatolia, Persia, and the wider Iranian world from the Neolithic to the coming of Islam. Considers wider impact on the ancient and early medieval worlds and their present legacy.

courses.title: Image Collision: A Multicultural Approach to Images and Their Users
courses.desc: Comparisons between present-day visual culture and pre-modern art to re-evaluate the ways in which one understands the contemporary histories of underrepresented groups in the United States.

courses.title: Studies in Ancient Art
courses.desc: Topics in Egyptian, Prehistoric, and Etruscan art of the Mediterranean area treated with specific reference to relevant cultural and historical settings.  Specialized courses in Greek and Roman art are also taught.

courses.title: Studies in Greek Art
courses.desc: Topics in Greek art, architecture, and topography from the Prehistoric period through the end of the fourth century B.C.E.

courses.title: Studies in Roman Art
courses.desc: Topics in Hellenistic and Roman art and architecture; stresses historical and political background.

courses.title: Studies in Medieval Art
courses.desc: Specialized topics in Medieval art and architecture in Europe, the Mediterranean area, and the Near East between the fourth and fifteenth centuries.  Examples:  the Art of the Migration Period, Medieval City.

courses.title: Byzantine Art: 650-1450
courses.desc: Studies in the development of the art and architecture of the Byzantine Empire between ca. 650 and 1450.

courses.title: Studies in Early Christian and Byzantine Art
courses.desc: Selected topics on the development of the art and architecture of the Later Roman and Byzantine Empires between ca. 300 and 1453. Examples: Early Christian architecture, Byzantine painting.

courses.title: Studies in Western Medieval Art
courses.desc: Selected topics on the development of art and architecture in Western Europe between ca. 700 and 1400. Examples: Romanesque painting, Gothic architecture.

courses.title: Studies in Renaissance and Baroque Art
courses.desc: Selected topics on the art and architecture of Europe between the fifteenth and eighteenth centuries. Examples: Renaissance and Baroque prints, Bruegel to Rubens.

courses.title: Studies in Southern Renaissance Art
courses.desc: Selected topics determined by individual faculty members exploring historical developments and individual artists of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries in Italy and Spain. Examples: Renaissance Venice, Age of Michelangelo.

courses.title: Studies in Northern Renaissance Art
courses.desc: Selected topics determined by individual faculty members exploring historical developments and individual artists of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries in Northern Europe. Examples: Late Medieval art, painting from Van Eyck to Bosch.

courses.title: Studies in Southern Baroque Art
courses.desc: Selected topics determined by individual faculty members exploring historical developments and individual artists of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries in Italy and Spain. Example: Rome in the seventeenth century.

courses.title: Studies in Northern Baroque Art
courses.desc: Selected topics determined by individual faculty members exploring historical developments and individual artists of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries in Northern Europe. Example: the Age of Rembrandt.

courses.title: Modern European Art: From Impressionism to the Fauves
courses.desc: History of European painting and urban transformation from 1851 to 1907, when Paris stood strong as the unquestioned cultural capital of the nineteenth century.

courses.title: Modern European Art: From Cubism to Surrealism
courses.desc: History of European painting, sculpture, and design from 1907 to 1940, when Paris and painting lost their dominance as other cultural centers and other media claimed renewed importance.

courses.title: Topics in Modern European Art
courses.desc: Selected topics within the period 1643 to 1940.

courses.title: History of Contemporary Art
courses.desc: Selected topics exploring historical developments of contemporary art from 1945 to the present. Examples: American Art 1945-1989, European Art 1945-1989, Art After 1989. Works of art are studied as cultural, social, and political practices.

courses.title: Topics in Contemporary Art
courses.desc: Selected topics exploring artistic movements, artists, and/or issues in contemporary art from 1945 to the present. Examples include Junk Art, Countercultures, Art and Politics Now. Works of art are studied as cultural, social, and political practices.

courses.title: Studies in Modern Architecture
courses.desc: Architecture and related design practices from the late eighteenth century through 1945 are studied in relation to social, aesthetic, technological, and political questions.

courses.title: Studies in Architecture after 1945
courses.desc: Architecture and related design practices from 1945 through present are studied in relation to social, aesthetic, technological, and political questions.

courses.title: Topics in the History of Modern and Contemporary Architecture
courses.desc: Varying topics from the late eighteenth century to the present. Architecture and related design practices are studied in relation to social, aesthetic, technological, and political questions.

courses.title: Studies in Asian Art
courses.desc: Topics include visual studies in China, Japan, Korea and India.

courses.title: Later Imperial China
courses.desc: Investigates the uses, subjects, styles, and social contexts of art made in the later Imperial dynasties, whether court art, religious art, women's painting, scholar painting, or art for the market.

courses.title: Modern China
courses.desc: Examines the evolution and media of Chinese art and visual culture in the context of modern China's sweeping historical, social, and political changes.

courses.title: Ancient India
courses.desc: Examines the visual and religious history of the region defined as "India" today, but necessarily encompassing modern Bangladesh and Pakistan.  Culminates with the supposed Golden Age of the Gupta empire and its far-reaching legacies.

courses.title: Medieval India
courses.desc: Begins with the Gupta period's aesthetic legacies in South Asia's architecture, sculpture, and painting. Explores the dispersal of Islam throughout South Asia, including the Muslim communities of southern India.

courses.title: Modern India
courses.desc: Examines the imperial patronage of the Mughal emperors, covering their territorial holdings extending from Afghanistan through western Bangladesh.  Continues with the "aftermath" of the Mughal empire and the rise of British commercialism and colonialism.

courses.title: Topics in the Art and Architecture of India
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Art and Architecture of India. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Art and Globalization, Modern
courses.desc: Study of modern art as a cause and expression of increasing contacts between cultures. Focusing on regions in Asia and the Americas, adoption of European oil painting, indigenous art movements, and national capital architecture are explored.

courses.title: Modern Japan
courses.desc: Explores artistic developments during the tumultuous modernization of Japan from 1868-1945, with a focus on painting, commercial art, and architecture. Topics include arts of the Japanese Empire, neo-traditional arts, responses to European modernism, and war propaganda.

courses.title: Contemporary Japan
courses.desc: Study of various media of Japanese art from the time of war defeat in 1945 until the present. Topics include artists' responses to the nuclear bomb, the aesthetics of the "economic miracle," avant-garde groups, manga, and innovations in architecture.

courses.title: Asian American Art, Contemporary
courses.desc: Study of the Asian American experience in contemporary art and visual culture. Art by Asian Americans of diverse backgrounds as well as the history of visualization of Asian identities in American art/visual culture.

courses.title: Modern African American Art
courses.desc: Investigates the history of modern African American art; emphasis on the politics of representation. Examines art in a variety of media from material culture and textiles to painting and photography. Issues of migration, nationalism, gender, sexuality, and hybridity are discussed.

courses.title: Contemporary African American Art
courses.desc: Investigates the history of contemporary African American art; emphasis on the politics of representation. Explores art in a variety of media: painting, sculpture, photography, installation, and new media. Cultural politics, appropriation, identity, gender, sexuality, hybridity and civil rights issues discussed.

courses.title: Topics in African American Art
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of African American Art. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: African American Women in Art
courses.desc: Examines depictions of and by African American women in art and popular culture through a variety of media including textiles, painting, sculpture, photography, and installation. Focuses on African American women's experiences, perspectives, and strategies for contemporary representation.

courses.title: African Americans and Photography
courses.desc: Explores depictions of and by African Americans through photography. Examines the history of photography in relationship to African American culture through a variety of media from early daguerreotype processes to digital imagery.

courses.title: Early American Art
courses.desc: An examination of American visual culture from 1620 to 1860 from the era of European exploration and colonization of the New World to the beginning of the Civil War.

courses.title: Nineteenth Century American Art
courses.desc: An exploration of American visual culture from 1860 to 1900, including paintings, sculpture, and photographs produced during the Civil War and during the decades of prosperity that followed.

courses.title: Modern American Art
courses.desc: Focusing on the period from 1900 until 1965, this course considers the emergence and institutionalization of modern art in the United States.

courses.title: Topics in American Art
courses.desc: Varying topics within the period 1620 to 1970. Works of art are studied in their cultural, social, and political contexts.

courses.title: Latin American Art History
courses.desc: Historical periods vary with each offering and may range from pre-Columbian societies, through the colonial era, to developments in modern and contemporary art.

courses.title: Studies in Native and Tribal Art
courses.desc: Varying topics on the art and culture of native and tribal societies. For example, North American Indians.

courses.title: Topics in the Criticism of Art
courses.desc: Selected topics discussed on the theoretical and/or practical dimensions of art historical criticism.

courses.title: Topics in Museum Studies
courses.desc: Addresses the historical and contemporary function of the museum as an instructional device.  The function of exhibitions in the public sphere, and the roles of curators, educators, and the public are analyzed.

courses.title: 20th Century Photographic History
courses.desc: Varying topics within the history of photography in the 20th century. Photographic practice studied in relation to art history, cultural history, and social history.

courses.title: Selected Topics in Photographic History
courses.desc: Varying topics within the history of photography from the early 19th century to the present. Photographic practice studied in relation to art history, cultural history, and social history. Examples include documentary; pictorialism and art photography; photomontage, photographic books.

courses.title: Topics in Visual Studies
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary topics on the cultural analysis of visual artifacts and practices.

courses.title: Art History Methods
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Theory and practice of art history, with an emphasis on formal and social models of analyzing and writing about art.

courses.title: Ethics, Law, and Art
courses.desc: Addresses a broad range of ethical and legal issues pertaining to art, ownership, looting and theft, museum policies, and cultural heritage.

courses.title: Advanced Seminar: Topics in Art History
courses.desc: Discussion and report-oriented seminar with emphasis on reading, writing, and thinking about problems in art history. Examples: Gothic Cathedral, Portraiture East and West.

courses.title: Independent Study in Art History
courses.desc: Supervised, but independent reading or research on art historical topics.

courses.title: Ethics, Law, and Art
courses.prereqs: Background in Art History or Legal Studies.
courses.desc: Addresses a broad range of ethical and legal issues pertaining to art, ownership, looting and theft, museum policies, and cultural heritage.

courses.title: Master's Seminar: Topics in Art History
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Art History. Examples include Gothic Cathedral, Portraiture East and West.

courses.title: Master's Thesis Research
courses.desc: Research and writing of the Master's thesis.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to teaching assistants.

courses.title: ArtsCore
courses.desc: An introduction to the arts in general, and to the arts at UCI. Concentration on (1) the interdisciplinary nature of the arts, and (2) the content of particular arts disciplines.

courses.title: Digital Media: Exhibition
courses.desc: A discussion and critique course in all media arts. Includes a review of key media arts concepts and the preparation of an end-of-quarter exhibition.

courses.title: Improvisation and Modes of Research / Creative Expression
courses.desc: Through immersion, readings, analysis, and observation, students are trained to recognize, build, and engage a set of “improvisatory” cognitive skills in order to enhance artistic creation, the generation of language, data analysis, and the application of the scientific method.

courses.title: Athletics Bands
courses.desc: Bands support athletics events. Includes Pep Band: Rehearsal and performance of band standards; Marching Band: Exercises and performance involving marching fundamentals, formations, and half-time pageantry; and, Drumline: Study and rehearsal of rudiments, cadences, and arrangements.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Individual study or directed projects as arranged with faculty member.

courses.title: Asian American Histories
courses.desc: Examines and compares diverse experiences of major Asian American groups since the mid-nineteenth century. Topics include origins of emigration; the formation and transformation of community; gender and family life; changing roles of Asian Americans in American society. Formerly ASIANAM 60A.

courses.title: The U
courses.desc: Explores the historical and contemporary transnational linkages between the U.S. and regions in Asia and their resultant flows of people, goods, and ideas. Attention given to the role of militarism and processes of globalization, and the histories of cultural contact/conflict.

courses.title: Asian American Communities
courses.desc: Examines the renewal of Asian immigration following World War II. Explores contemporary Asian American populations and communities in the U.S., and the impact of contemporary Asian immigration on the U.S. political economy and social order.

courses.title: Asian Americans and Race
courses.desc: Analyzes the Asian American experience in comparative perspective, which includes comparisons of different ethnic and racial groups, and across gender and class. Possible topics include labor, economy, politics, migration, nation, popular culture, gender, family, sexuality, and multiraciality.

courses.title: Asian American Stories
courses.desc: Examines stories from Asian American communities through literary texts and other media. Selected themes may include the following: dislocation/relocation, finding/inventing a usable past, poetics/politics in language, identities/ethnicities.

courses.title: Asian Americans and the Media
courses.desc: Investigates popular representations of and cultural productions by Asian Pacific Americans and Asians in the Americas from the late-nineteenth century to the present. Cultural media may include political cartoons, film/television, popular music, visual art, blogs/Web sites, and performance.

courses.title: Research Methodologies for Asian American Studies
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Explores various research methodologies for Asian American Studies combining theoretical knowledge with field research. Goals: conduct field research about immigrants and refugees from Asia. Topics vary: migration and labor, assimilation and cultural preservation, cultural expressions in the diaspora.

courses.title: Asian American Writers
courses.desc: Literary analysis of Asian American writers' representations of issues of identity, class, history among others. Variety of literary forms—novel, poem, drama, essay—included in a study of a variety of Asian American ethnic groups.

courses.title: Asian American History
courses.desc: Introduction to important themes in the history of people of Asian ancestry in the United States from the nineteenth century to the present.

courses.title: Asian American Art History
courses.desc: Investigation of Asian American experience expressed by art and visual culture throughout the twentieth century. Art by Asian Americans of diverse backgrounds as well as the history of cultural visualization of Asian identities in American art/visual culture.

courses.title: Asian American Film and Video
courses.desc: Topics include histories of Asian American film and video, including documentaries, experimental, short subjects, feature-length independent film, and other forms of cinematic expression. Explores issues of identity (national, racial, gendered, among others).

courses.title: Asian Americans and Popular Culture
courses.desc: Focuses on Asian Americans' relationship to popular culture as both producers and consumers. Topics include consumer cultures and subcultures, cyberspace and public space, popular music, indy comics and other print media.

courses.title: Race and Performance
courses.desc: Focuses on new ways of understanding race, ethnicity, class, and gender issues through performance.

courses.title: Asian American Politics
courses.desc: Provides various overviews of politics within Asian American communities. May compare with African American and/or Latino politics.

courses.title: Comparative Minority Politics
courses.desc: Examines the political experiences of Blacks, Latinos, and Asian Americans in the United States from roughly 1950 to the present. Focuses on how each group has pursued political empowerment via both conventional political channels and social movements.

courses.title: Asian American Labor
courses.desc: Explores history of Asian Americans and work from the nineteenth century to the present. Areas of study include migration, colonialism, family, social organization, and work culture.

courses.title: Race and Urban Space
courses.desc: Examines how ethnic and racial processes shape and structure interactions in urban settings, such as schools, housing, employment, and public spaces, with attention to the international impact of globalization and postcolonial forces.

courses.title: Muslim Identities in North America
courses.desc: Explores multiple identities of Muslims in North America, including indigenous Muslims  and immigrants of many national origins. Explores religious, political, cultural, ethnic, class differences among American Muslims, turning to Islamic institutions or events near UCI to conduct fieldwork projects.

courses.title: Religious Traditions of Asian Americans
courses.desc: Studies the religious traditions of Asian Americans, focusing on the transplantation of religious institutions, establishment of sacred spaces, celebration of religious holidays, socialization of children, as well as birth, marriage, gender relations, death, family.

courses.title: The Politics of Protest
courses.desc: Examines the Civil Rights, Black Power, and women’s movements in relationship to the Asian American movement. Uses social movement theories to illuminate the cases, and the cases to critique and revise the theories.

courses.title: Special Topics in Asian American Studies
courses.desc: Analyzes a variety of themes in Asian American Studies—identity, history, culture—from various interdisciplinary perspectives in humanities, arts, social sciences.

courses.title: Asian American Ethnic Groups
courses.desc: Topics include study of the history, culture, and social formations of diverse Asian American subgroups such as Pacific Islanders, Hmong, Thai, Indonesian, Indian subcontinental, among others.

courses.title: Korean American Studies
courses.desc: Explores the factors that have distinctly shaped the Korean American experience, including patterns of racial domination, the profile of immigrant flow, immigrant roles in the urban political economy, politics in Korea, and the role of the church.

courses.title: Vietnamese American Studies
courses.desc: Studies the resettlement of Vietnamese in the United States following their exodus from Southeast Asia. Topics include the Vietnam War, the 1975 evacuation, boat and land refugees, the shaping of Vietnamese communities, and Vietnamese American literature.

courses.title: Japanese American Studies
courses.desc: Studies the settlement of Japanese in Hawaii and the continental United States since the late 19th century. Topics include sugar plantations, development of rural Japanese America, World War II internment, post-War community development, and persistence of Japanese American identity.

courses.title: South Asian American Studies
courses.desc: Examines and compares the experiences of South Asian immigrants in the U.S. over time. Looks at the economic, political, and social positions of the immigrants, with special emphasis on religious changes and the changes in the second and later generations.

courses.title: Southeast Asian American Studies
courses.desc: Analyzes experiences of refugees and immigrants from Southeast Asia, which may include those from Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, and the Philippines. Examines political and economic factors for their exodus and how they reconstruct their identities, histories, and communities.

courses.title: Chinese American Studies
courses.desc: Analyzes the experiences of Chinese in the United States. Immigration, Chinese exclusion, racial and gender identity. Historical overview and contemporary issues covered.

courses.title: Filipina/Filipino American Studies
courses.desc: Explores the experience of Filipina/Filipino Americans from the era of Spanish colonization of the Philippines to present-day community formations in the United States, with special emphasis on the 20th century. Topics include colonialism, nation, migration, gender, and culture.

courses.title: Asian American Women
courses.desc: Examines the representations and experiences of Asian American women from diverse perspectives. Explores the commonalities and differences among various groups of Asian American women, with particular focus on history, culture, values, and family roles.

courses.title: Topics in Intersectionality
courses.desc: Topics include intersectional analysis of various themes related to ethnicity, gender, sexuality, and race within Asian American communities.

courses.title: Race and Citizenship
courses.desc: Explores historical and contemporary patterns of racialization in relation to citizenship. Topics may include racial categorization, immigration, and comparative racialization.

courses.title: Asian American and African American Relations
courses.desc: Addresses relationships of Asian American and African American communities in the United States. Topics include race, class, gender, labor, economic systems, political mobilization, community, civil rights, activism, cultural expression.

courses.title: Politics of Animal Rights
courses.desc: Examines animal rights/welfare movement’s efforts to transform moral, practical, and legal standing of nonhuman animals in contemporary U.S. Explores intersection of racism, sexism, and speciesism informed by theories of race and ethnicity, including Asian American Studies.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Directed reading and research in consultation with a faculty member. Substantial written work required.

courses.title: Theory and Methods in Asian American Studies
courses.desc: Introduction to the intersection of the social sciences, humanities, and other fields that constitute the theory and methodology of Asian American Studies. Focuses on the interventions and contestations within Asian American Studies that have transformed the discipline in recent years.

courses.title: Contemporary Issues in Asian American Studies
courses.desc: Examines the interrelations between history, theory, and race in the aftermath of the twentieth-century decolonial movements, offering an account of race through postcolonial and postnationalist approaches in comparative contexts. Considers the interventions made by transnational feminist and racialized queer critiques.

courses.title: Leadership and Social Change in Asian American Communities
courses.desc: Introduces students to models of community-engaged learning and leadership that are central to the field of Asian American studies. Designed to expose students to histories and models of organizing in Asian American communities and forms of community-based research.

courses.title: Introduction to Asian American Studies Research
courses.desc: Introduces students to research topics and methods within the field of Asian American studies. Aims to expose students to core and affiliated faculty to help them identify possible advisors for master's research projects or members of doctoral committees.

courses.title: Graduate Topics in Asian American Studies
courses.desc: Seminars on various topics in Asian American Studies.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Asian American Studies
courses.desc: Seminar covering various areas of research within Asian American Studies as an interdisciplinary field. Recommended for advanced graduate students.

courses.title: Directed Research
courses.desc: Directed graduate study/research in Asian American Studies.

courses.title: Directed Reading
courses.desc: Readings focused on specialized topics in consultation with, and with the consent of, a faculty member.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to teaching assistants.

courses.title: Research in Biological Chemistry
courses.desc: Individual research under the supervision of a professor.

courses.title: Research in Biological Chemistry
courses.desc: Individual research under the supervision of a professor.

courses.title: Research in Biological Chemistry
courses.desc: Individual research under the supervision of a professor.

courses.title: Research in Biological Chemistry for First-Year Students
courses.desc: Independent research within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in the Department of Biological Chemistry for first-year Ph.D. students.

courses.title: Laboratory Seminar Series
courses.desc: Study within a laboratory group including research and journal presentations.

courses.title: Laboratory Seminar Series
courses.desc: Study within a laboratory group including research and journal presentations.

courses.title: Laboratory Seminar Series
courses.desc: Study within a laboratory group including research and journal presentations.

courses.title: Advanced Molecular Genetics
courses.desc: Literature-based discussion of molecular principles in genetics and functional genomics, with focus on cancer and stem cell biology.

courses.title: Medical Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
courses.desc: Covers the following topics from a biomedical perspective: protein and nucleic acid biochemistry, carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids, purines and pyrimidines, genome structure, molecular mechanisms of development, and signal transduction.

courses.title: Mouse Developmental Genetics
courses.desc: Introduction to using the mouse in contemporary biomedical research. The biology and development of the laboratory mouse, methods for manipulation of the mouse genome and embryos, and examples of application of these methods to understand mammalian development and homeostasis.

courses.title: Human Evolution and Behavior
courses.desc: Covers theories and empirical research concerning the evolutionary origins of human behaviors and their variations. An interdisciplinary course emphasizing both evolutionary psychology (e.g., mating strategies, kinship, and parenting) and molecular evolution (i.e., evolution of genes for various behaviors).

courses.title: Epigenetics in Health and Disease
courses.prereqs: MOL BIO 203 or MOL BIO 204 or NEURBIO 206
courses.desc: Focuses on the role of chromatin/nuclear structure organization (histone and DNA modification, chromatin remodeling, higher order chromatin structure and nuclear organization) on gene regulation, DNA replication and repair, relevant to development, metabolism, learning and memory, and human disease.

courses.title: New Breakthroughs in Basic and Translational Cancer Research
courses.prereqs: MOL BIO 204 or PHYSIO 252. A gene regulation course is also required.
courses.desc: Highlights breakthroughs in molecular and cellular aspects of cancer biology and emerging therapeutic approaches. Emphasis on new discoveries of critical pathways/processes in cancer etiology, progression, and metastasis. Introduces strategies used in the discovery, design of biological and small molecules-based therapies.

courses.title: Research Seminar
courses.desc: Student research-based colloquium covering current topics in gene organization and expression, cell cycle and differentiation, DNA repair, checkpoint control, and the physical, chemical, and biological properties of macromolecules. Students are encouraged to read critically and analyze recent literature.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Life Sciences
courses.desc: Designed to introduce nonmajors to the basic concepts of modern biology. Discussion of evolutionary biology, ecology, molecular biology, and genetics.

courses.title: Freshman Seminar
courses.desc: Weekly meetings consisting of presentations by faculty, professional staff, and Peer Academic Advisors provide information about the School of Biological Sciences, campus resources, learning skills, and special programs/opportunities.

courses.title: Freshman Seminar
courses.desc: Faculty presentations and readings focused on the structure, function, opportunities, and current issues in the biological sciences.

courses.title: Solutions in Science
courses.desc: Students will be introduced to approaches that can be used to solve scientific problems. These methods can be utilized in introductory to advanced classes and will allow students to become independent thinkers.

courses.title: EASE Seminar
courses.desc: Seminars designed to help students achieve success in STEM courses. Provides collaborative learning environment facilitated by undergraduate mentor. Students develop critical thinking and study skills. Also receive guidance to campus resources that assist acclimation to University.

courses.title: Career Decision Making
courses.desc: An introductory course designed to facilitate the career decision-making process. Decision-making processes, values, and standardized tests of aptitudes, interests, and values are utilized with non-test data in appraising biological sciences career options.

courses.title: Non-Health Sciences Career Exploration
courses.desc: A survey course designed to assist students in exploring non-health science career options. Lectures by professionals in various fields.

courses.title: Tropical Biology: Race to Save the Tropics
courses.desc: Population growth combines with tropical resource consumption by industrialized nations to cause high rates of deforestation, pollution, habitat fragmentation, and extinction of species. Discusses tropical biomes, their population, community,  ecosystem processes, and possible means of conservation of biodiversity.

courses.title: Nutrition Science
courses.desc: An introduction to nutrition science, integrating concepts from biology, biochemistry, microbiology, physiology, and psychology to explain the interaction between nutrients and the human body. Biological basis of nutrient standards is analyzed. Effects of nutrition, behavior, exercises on health/disease.

courses.title: Biology and Chemistry of Food and Cooking
courses.desc: The kitchen is used as a laboratory to introduce fundamental principles of biology, chemistry, and physics. A molecular/cellular analysis of cooking, including concepts such as protein structure, browning reactions, colloids, emulsions, carbohydrate metabolism, and development of flavor/texture through biochemical transformations.

courses.title: Diseases of the Twenty-First Century
courses.desc: Why do we get sick? An introduction to the biological basis of human disease, including diseases of the cardiovascular, respiratory, nervous, and reproductive systems. Case studies present diagnosis, treatment, and prevention protocols. Inheritable and infectious diseases also discussed.

courses.title: Horticulture Science
courses.desc: Scientific principles of horticulture at the UCI Arboretum. Taxonomy, plant life history strategies; experiments with seed dormancy; morphological adaptations for specialized sexual and clonal reproduction; basics of plant propagation and ecological restoration.  Materials fee.

courses.title: Physiology of Fitness
courses.desc: An introduction to the organ systems of the human body, including muscle, cardiovascular, immune, and reproductive systems, with an emphasis on how the body responds to exercise, diet, and disease.

courses.title: Biology of Oriental Medicine
courses.desc: With lectures, demonstrations, and hands-on learning, the theory and practice of herbal medicine, acupuncture, qigong, and manipulative therapies are explained in Western biomedical terms. The latest basic and clinical research advances in each area are also described.

courses.title: Global Change Biology
courses.desc: Field trips and lectures that address ways in which humans are altering the global environment, with consequences for the ecology of animals, plants, and microbes.

courses.title: The Biology of Human Diseases
courses.desc: Introduction to concepts of diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of major human infectious diseases. Covers some aspects of epidemiology. Scope and impact of infectious diseases in the present and past experiences in controlling infectious disease. Reviews biology of human organ systems.

courses.title: Topics in Biological Sciences
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of biological sciences.

courses.title: Molecular Basis of Human Disease
courses.desc: Describes the cause and treatment of human diseases at the cutting edge of modern molecular understanding for non-science majors, including history, interviews, and stories.

courses.title: California Teach 1: Introduction to Science and Mathematics Teaching
courses.desc: First in a series for students interested in becoming middle or high school teachers of mathematics or science. Students gain an understanding of effective, research-based teaching strategies. Includes supervised field experience in a K-12 classroom.

courses.title: Evolutionary Psychology
courses.desc: Introductory overview of the field of evolutionary psychology. Surveys topics operating at the interface of social sciences, i.e. behavioral psychology and evolutionary biology, while developing select aspects of the history of this developing field.

courses.title: Sustainable Landscaping: Design and Practices
courses.desc: Through lectures and hands-on work, students learn how to design habitats around dwellings, within cities, and in rural environments. These include traditional/sustainable landscaping, restoration, stormwater/wastewater treatment, xeriscaping, and low impact development design. Sustainable landscape plant materials emphasized.

courses.title: Biology of Cancer
courses.desc: Biological, clinical, and psychosocial nature of cancer through the perspectives of medical researchers, biologists, physicians, and health educators. For students of all majors, designed so that each can increase personal awareness of the biology of cancer.

courses.title: The Brain and Behavior
courses.desc: Introduction to how the brain works. Biological processes underlying perception, movement, sleep-wake cycles, motivation, language, learning, and memory. Changes in the brain associated with sex differences, drug use, aging, seasons, and time of day. Fundamental properties of the nervous system.

courses.title: Drugs and the Brain
courses.desc: Introduction to the actions of drugs on the brain. How studying drug action helps reveal normal functions of neurons. How drugs can correct neural disorders or disrupt neural function. Biological issues related to drug abuse, drug addiction, and drug seeking.

courses.title: Brain Dysfunction and Repair
courses.desc: Introduction to the disruptions in brain function that underlie disorders such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinsonism, schizophrenia, and depression, and the basis for drug therapies. The brain's ability to repair itself after damage and the pros and cons of that repair.

courses.title: Mind, Memory, Amnesia, and the Brain
courses.desc: Introduction to neural mechanisms underlying learning and memory. Emphasis on molecular changes that mediate memory as well as structures involved in different forms of memory. Additionally, examines the biology of memory phenomena, from extraordinary memory to false memory to amnesia.

courses.title: Aspects of Mood Disorder
courses.desc: There are significant differences in response to psychiatric illness across cultures. Delves into the neuroscience underlying mood disorder, investigating current pharmacological treatments and sociocultural influences on treatment outcomes.

courses.title: Media on the Mind
courses.desc: Surveys an ever-increasing collection of research, suggesting modern technology and social media are changing in the way our brains function.

courses.title: Stem Cells and Brain Repair
courses.desc: Students introduced to the field of regenerative neurobiology. Both basic stem cell discoveries and their potential clinical application to brain disorders examined. Discussion of opportunities, challenges, and implications of this research.

courses.title: AIDS Fundamentals
courses.desc: Considers the biological and sociological bases of the AIDS epidemic. Topics include the history of AIDS, current medical knowledge, transmission, risk reduction, and how the community can respond.

courses.title: Discussion and Literature Research in AIDS
courses.desc: Students carry out two activities: (1) leading discussions about HIV/AIDS (predominantly regarding sociological and personal reactions) among students taking the AIDS Fundamentals course and (2) literature research about biomedical aspects of AIDS.

courses.title: Stress
courses.desc: Investigates stress at a psychological, physiological, and molecular level, and provides a current overview of the field of stress research.

courses.title: Introduction to Ecology
courses.desc: Principles of ecology; application to populations, communities, ecosystems, and humans.

courses.title: Life Sciencing from Aristotle to Venter
courses.desc: History of biology from Aristotle through to the scientific revolutions precipitated by Darwin, geneticists, molecular biologists, and now genomics. Introduces the practices and achievements of biological research to both beginning biology students and non-majors.

courses.title: Human Development: Conception to Birth
courses.desc: Processes leading to the birth of a healthy child and the avoidance of birth defects. Male and female reproductive systems, hormonal control of egg-sperm formations, sexual intercourse, contraception, venereal diseases, fertilization, cell division, embryonic development, fetal physiology.

courses.title: The Idiom and Practice of Science
courses.desc: The importance of biological sciences in our world is discussed. Topics may include brain and behavior, health and disease, genetics and society, and conservation biology. Primary goal is to encourage students to understand better the world in which they live.

courses.title: Curriculum
courses.desc: Initiation, planning, and coordination of student-run courses.

courses.title: From DNA to Organisms
courses.desc: Cell biology, biochemistry, genetics, and the biology of organ systems. Covers concepts of building blocks (nucleotides, amino acids, and cells) and of information flow (DNA to proteins, receptors to nuclei, the blood to distant organs, and DNA to offspring).

courses.title: Honors From DNA to Organisms
courses.desc: Cell biology, biochemistry, genetics, and the biology or organ systems. Covers concepts of building blocks (nucleotides, amino acids, and cells) and of information flow (DNA to proteins, receptors to nuclei, the blood to distant organs, and DNA to offspring).

courses.title: From Organisms to Ecosystems
courses.desc: Patterns of diversity, ecology, and evolutionary biology. Emphasis is on the Tree of Life and how its members are distributed and interact.

courses.title: Genetics
courses.desc: Introduction to genetics. Basic features of replication and expression of DNA, cell division, and gene transmission. Recombination and mutation in diploid organisms.

courses.title: Honors Genetics
courses.desc: Introduction to genetics. Basic features of replication and expression of DNA, cell division, and gene transmission. Recombination and mutation in diploid organisms.

courses.title: Biochemistry
courses.desc: Structure and properties of proteins; major biochemical pathways and mechanisms for their control.

courses.title: Molecular Biology
courses.desc: Biochemistry and replication of nucleic acids; molecular genetics; protein biosynthesis; genetic code; regulation of expression of genetic information; biochemical evolution.

courses.title: Scientific Writing
courses.desc: Designed to give an overview of the basic aspects of scientific writing relevant to reporting research in the Biological Sciences.

courses.title: California Teach 2: Middle School Science and Mathematics Teaching
courses.desc: Second in a series for students interested in becoming middle or high school teachers of mathematics or science. Students gain an understanding of effective, research-based teaching strategies for grades 6-8. Includes supervised field experience in a middle school classroom.

courses.title: Cell Biology
courses.desc: Analysis of the basic structure and function of animal cells, with an emphasis on the regulation of cellular processes. The basic features of membranes, cellular compartmentalization, protein trafficking, vesicular transport, cytoskeleton, adhesion, signal transduction, and cell cycle are covered.

courses.title: Developmental Biology
courses.desc: Cellular and molecular analysis of how a fertilized egg develops into an organism consisting of complex structures such as the eye, arms, and brain. Emphasis is on the key concepts of developmental processes underlying pattern formation, growth, and regeneration.

courses.title: Cell, Developmental, and Molecular Biology of Plants
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: BIO SCI 98 and BIO SCI 99
BIO SCI 97
courses.desc: Emphasizes the special features of plant cells and plant development as compared to animals. Two central topics: plants' ability to fuel our planet through photosynthesis, and the interactions of plants with microorganisms in making nitrogen available to other life forms.

courses.title: Processes in Ecology and Evolution
courses.desc: An in-depth study of the mechanisms that drive evolution and ecology including: natural selection, mutation, genetic drift, speciation, extinction, life history patterns, population dynamics, ecosystem and community structure, predator-prey and host pathogen interactions, and social behavior.

courses.title: Habitats and Organisms
courses.prereqs: (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI 194S and BIO SCI E106. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Introduces students to local habitats and organisms through required field trips and applies ecological and evolutionary principles from BIO SCI E106. Students also explore related literature.

courses.title: Seminar in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
courses.desc: Invited speakers, graduate students, and faculty present current research in ecology and evolutionary biology.

courses.title: Research Methods
courses.desc: Explores tools of inquiry for developing and implementing science research projects.  Students undertake independent projects requiring data collection, analysis, and modeling, and the organization and presentation of results.  Additional topics include ethical issues and role of scientific literature.

courses.title: Human Physiology
courses.desc: Functional features of the major organ systems in the human body. Emphasis on homeostasis and the interactions of organ systems in health and disease. (Discussion of behavior and brain function deferred to BIO SCI N110.).

courses.title: Neurobiology and Behavior
courses.desc: Consideration of the evolution of behavior, including ethological and psychological aspects and analysis of neuroanatomical, neurochemical, neurophysiological, and neuroendocrine systems underlying basic behavioral processes.

courses.title: Developmental and Cell Biology Laboratory
courses.desc: Covers the division of cells, isolate cellular organelles (chloroplasts, mitochondria, nuclei), and follows changes in cells undergoing programmed cell death. Development is demonstrated in experiments showing cooperation of individual cells in forming a multicellular organism.  Materials fee.

courses.title: Physiology Laboratory
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 194S and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and (BIO SCI E109 or BME 120) and BME 121.
courses.desc: Laboratory with a focus on the whole organism and its organ systems. Examples of structure-function relationships are drawn from both animal and human physiology. Cellular and molecular aspects are introduced as required.

courses.title: Genetics Majors Seminar
courses.desc: Genetics majors attend a weekly seminar to discuss current research techniques and career opportunities in the field. Students have the opportunity to present their own independent research.

courses.title: Neurobiology Laboratory
courses.desc: An in-depth exploration into biology and physiology of the nervous system. Labs include neuroanatomy, electrophysiology, pharmacology, behavior, experimental design, EEG, and scientific writing.  Materials fee.

courses.title: Developmental and Cell Biology Majors Seminar
courses.desc: Developmental and Cell Biology majors attend a weekly seminar to discuss current research techniques and career opportunities in the field. Students have the opportunity to present their own independent research.

courses.title: Advanced Biochemistry
courses.desc: Physical-chemical properties of macromolecules. Structure-function relationships in nucleic acids, protein, carbohydrates, and lipids. Integration and regulation of metabolism. Biochemistry of organs and biochemistry of diseases.

courses.title: Biochemistry Laboratory
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 99 and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI 194S
courses.desc: Properties of enzymes and the culture and isolation of mutants of microorganisms. Materials fee.

courses.title: Evolution Laboratory
courses.prereqs: (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI 194S and BIO SCI E106. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Students perform experiments which illustrate important concepts in evolutionary biology such as natural selection, random genetic drift, inbreeding, age-specific selection, sexual selection, and phylogenetic reconstruction. Materials fee.

courses.title: Advanced Neurobiology I
courses.desc: In-depth coverage of neurobiology, ranging from molecular neurobiology to functional brain imaging. Discussion of molecular, cellular, and developmental neurobiology.

courses.title: Advanced Neurobiology II
courses.desc: In-depth coverage of neurobiology, ranging from molecular neurobiology to functional brain imaging.

courses.title: Advanced Molecular Biology
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 99 and (BIO SCI M114L or BIO SCI M116L)
courses.desc: Mechanisms of gene expression; special emphasis on regulatory events that occur in Eukaryotic organisms other than initiation of transcription. Chromatin structure and rearrangement, RNA polymerases, cis- and trans-acting elements, RNA processing, transport and stability, protein synthesis, trafficking, and turnover.

courses.title: Molecular Biology Laboratory
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 99 and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI 194S
courses.desc: Students perform experiments which illustrate the chemical and biological properties of nucleic acids. Emphasis is placed on recent techniques in recombinant DNA technology including gene isolation and characterization.  Materials fee.

courses.title: Exercise Sciences Seminar
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI E109 and BIO SCI E112L and BIO SCI E183
courses.desc: Students are introduced to fundamental concepts and topics in exercise science with an emphasis on developing innovative approaches for exploring the biological response to physical activity/inactivity. Interactive course with robust discussion amongst faculty and students.

courses.title: Exercise Sciences Seminar
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI E109 and BIO SCI E112L and BIO SCI E183
courses.desc: Students are introduced to fundamental concepts and topics in exercise science with an emphasis on developing innovative approaches for exploring the biological response to physical activity/inactivity. Interactive course with robust discussion amongst faculty and students.

courses.title: Exercise Sciences Seminar
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI E109 and BIO SCI E112L and BIO SCI E183
courses.desc: Students are introduced to fundamental concepts and topics in exercise science with an emphasis on developing innovative approaches for exploring the biological response to physical activity/inactivity. Interactive course with robust discussion amongst faculty and students.

courses.title: Introduction to Neuroscience Clinical Trials
courses.desc: Provides an overview of the science of clinical development of treatments for neurological disease and injury.

courses.title: Ecosystem Ecology
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI E106 or EARTHSS 51 or EARTHSS 60A or CHEM 51C
courses.desc: A mechanistic perspective on ecosystem processes. Covers ecosystem development, element cycling, and interactions with plants and microbes. The role of ecosystems in environmental change is also addressed.

courses.title: Experimental Microbiology Laboratory
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 99 and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI 194S
courses.desc: Introductory general microbiology designed for preprofessional biology majors. Includes microscopy, cultivation of bacteria, morphological and biochemical characterization of bacteria, microbial metabolism, growth and genetics, microorganisms and human disease, and interactions of microorganisms with the environment.  Materials fee.

courses.title: Clinical Psychophysiology
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI N110 or PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A
courses.desc: Psychophysiology investigates the relationships between physiological processes and psychological phenomena. Technologies examined include reaction times, heart rate variability, EEGs, ERPs, magnetoencephalography, and eye tracking. Applications include diagnosis, the longitudinal assessment, and the identification of individuals at risk of disease onset.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Immunology
courses.desc: Literature-based, interactive discussions focused on review of seminal historic and recent immunology literature. Student responsibilities include reading, critical evaluation, and discussion of manuscripts.

courses.title: History of Neuroscience
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 35 or BIO SCI N110 or PSY BEH 115D or (PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C)
courses.desc: An overview of the conceptual and technical foundations of contemporary neuroscience from ancient times to the present. The subjects include synapses, neurons, brain organization, sensory, motor and regulatory systems, learning and memory, human brain function and dysfunction.

courses.title: Marine Biology
courses.desc: Examines the biotic and abiotic factors influencing the physiology, distribution, abundances, interactions, and evolution of marine organisms and the roles of those organisms in mediating ecosystem services and functions. A field trip is required. Materials fee.

courses.title: Signal Transduction in Mammalian Cells
courses.desc: Introduction to major biochemical pathways that transmit information from extracellular cues into changes in cell behavior. Focuses on kinases, phosphateses, G proteins, second messengers, and protein-protein interactions. Includes discussion of primary research articles and experimental techniques.

courses.title: Human Biology I
courses.desc: Provides an in-depth look at cutting-edge topics in physiology and epidemiology as they relate to global issues of ethics, anthropology, and socioeconomics, providing the student with an understanding of human health beyond basic biological function.

courses.title: Human Biology II
courses.desc: Provides an in-depth look at cutting-edge topics in physiology and epidemiology as they relate to global issues of ethics, anthropology, and socioeconomics, providing the student with an understanding of human health beyond basic biological function.

courses.title: Human Biology III
courses.desc: Provides an in-depth look at cutting-edge topics in physiology and epidemiology as they relate to global issues of ethics, anthropology, and socioeconomics, providing the student with an understanding of human health beyond basic biological function.

courses.title: Immunology with Hematology
courses.desc: Antibodies, antigens, antigen-antibody reactions, cells and tissues of lymphoreticular and hematopoietic systems, and individual and collective components of cell-mediated and humoral immune response.

courses.title: Advanced Immunology Laboratory
courses.prereqs: (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI M116L and BIO SCI M121
courses.desc: Emphasis is placed on learning modern techniques in immunology such as ELISAs, western blotting, and immunofluorescent staining assays.   Materials fee.

courses.title: Drug Addiction
courses.desc: Provides a comprehensive overview of topics in the addiction field, including drug pharmacology, models/approaches to investigate addiction, brain circuits, genetics, epigenetics, and the cellular and molecular biology of drug addiction.

courses.title: Physiology and Pathology of the Kidney
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI E109 and CHEM 1C. CHEM 1C with a grade of C- or better
courses.desc: Examines the structure, function, and pathology of the kidney. Topics include anatomy of the kidney, cellular function, urine formation, and disease states of the kidney.

courses.title: General Microbiology
courses.desc: Comparative metabolism of small molecules and cell structure and relationship to microbial classification. Macromolecule synthesis and regulation, sporulation, cell division, growth, and effect of antibiotics.

courses.title: Introduction to Computational Biology
courses.prereqs: MATH 2D or MATH 3A or STATS 7 or STATS 8
courses.desc: The use of theories and methods based on computer science, mathematics, and physics in molecular biology and biochemistry. Basics in biomolecular modeling. Analysis of sequence and structural data of biomolecules. Analysis of biomolecular functions.

courses.title: Biology of Integrative Medecine
courses.desc: Presentation of biological principles and the latest clinical and basic research on complementary and alternative therapies (e.g., mind-body medicine, energy medicine, herbal medicine, acupuncture, manipulative therapies) and their integration with Western medicine. Lectures supplemented by demonstrations and hands-on learning sessions.

courses.title: Infectious Disease Dynamics
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 96 or BIO SCI 97 or BIO SCI E106
courses.desc: Discusses how the dynamical interactions between pathogens and the immune system can give rise to a variety of outcomes which include clearance of infection, persistent infection, escape from immune responses, and pathology.

courses.title: Virology
courses.desc: Replication of viruses in populations, animals, and the host cell. The effects of viral infection on populations, individuals, and specific molecular effects on the target cell. Role of viral infections in cancer and degenerative diseases.

courses.title: Viral Pathogenesis and Immunity
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI M121 or BIO SCI M124A. Recommended: BIO SCI M122.
courses.desc: The mechanisms of viral pathogenesis and of host resistance to viruses are explored in detail. HIV-1 and Influenza-A are used as examples. In each case, viral replication, cytopathic effects, immune response, and viral evasion are discussed.

courses.title: Molecular Biology of Cancer
courses.desc: Molecular mechanisms of carcinogenesis. Consideration of transformation by DNA tumor viruses, RNA tumor viruses, and chemical carcinogens.

courses.title: Learning to Read Primary Literature in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
courses.desc: An introduction to primary literature focusing on methods to approach, understand, and analyze scientific papers.

courses.title: Physiological Plant Ecology
courses.prereqs: EARTHSS 51 or BIO SCI 94 or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60C)
courses.desc: An examination of the interactions between plants and their environment. Emphasis on the underlying physiological mechanisms of plant function, adaptations and responses to stress, and the basis of the distribution of plants and plant assemblages across the landscape.

courses.title: Chemical Ecology
courses.desc: An introduction to the unspoken chemical language of nature. Emphasis on interactions between insects, plants, and microbes including plant defense, pollination, and microbial warfare.

courses.title: The Transparent Brain
courses.desc: Teaches students how to perform new 3-D histology techniques that reveal the complex circuitry of the brain in unprecedented detail. Students work with real brain samples as part of ongoing neuroscience research projects.

courses.title: Photomedicine
courses.desc: Studies the use of optical and engineering-based systems (laser-based) for diagnosis, treating diseases, manipulation of cells and cell function. Physical, optical, and electro-optical principles are explored regarding molecular, cellular, organ, and organism applications.

courses.title: Forensic Genetics
courses.desc: Covers techniques currently used for forensic identification and paternity testing. Topics include STR, Y-STR and mitochondrial DNA tests, database searches, mixtures, allelic drop out, likelihood ratios, laboratory errors and the interaction of science and the legal system.

courses.title: Advanced Molecular Lab Techniques
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 100 and BIO SCI 194S and (BIO SCI D111L or BIO SCI M114L or BIO SCI M116L or BIO SCI M118L)
courses.desc: Discovery-driven experimentation in the fields of molecular biology, biochemistry, and cell biology. Also involves other aspects of the lab experience including group discussion of results, scientific paper analysis, and student presentations.   Materials fee.

courses.title: Image Analysis in Biological Research
courses.prereqs: (BIO SCI E106 or BIO SCI E109) and (BIO SCI 100 or BIO SCI 108) and BIO SCI 194S
courses.desc: Introduction to scientific image analysis including techniques such as high-speed, time-lapse, thermal imaging, and flow visualization. Students make movies using cameras, edit and analyze images using computers, and do a writing project.

courses.title: Innate Immunity, Infection, and Pathogenesis
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI M121 or BIO SCI M122 or BIO SCI M124A or BIO SCI M124B or BIO SCI M143
courses.desc: Role of the innate immune system in health and disease. Molecular pathways of innate immune recognition, expression, and regulation of immune receptors, signal transduction, pathogen sensors, and detection of microbial ligands. Lecture and discussion of primary research articles.

courses.title: Human Neurodegenerative Diseases
courses.desc: Clinical and epidemiological aspects of neurodegenerative diseases causing dementia are reviewed, including Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, Huntington’s disease, and Frontotemporal Dementia. Seminar format includes student presentation and group discussion.

courses.title: Introduction to Precision Medicine
courses.desc: Introduction to the use of genomic techniques for the study of individual genomes and transcriptomes in healthy and diseased samples. Covers GWAS, current sequencing techniques, cancer genomics, and biomarker discovery.

courses.title: Advances in Regenerative Medicine
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI D103 or BIO SCI D104
courses.desc: Introduces the rapidly growing field of regenerative medicine. New developments in stem cell research are discussed. Cellular, molecular, and engineering aspects of stem cell-based organ replacement strategies are examined, with emphasis on specific regenerative therapies.

courses.title: High-Resolution Structures: NMR and X-ray
courses.desc: Basic principles of magnetic resonance and X-ray crystallography toward the determination of high-resolution biomolecular structures.

courses.title: Microbiomes
courses.desc: Students develop an understanding of microbiomes in the context of both their environment and their impact on host physiology. Discussions on how microbiomes interact with the human body.

courses.title: Cognitive Neuroepigenetics
courses.desc: Current topics in the emerging field of cognitive neuroepigenetics focusing on understanding the underlying epigenetic mechanisms of memory formation and persistence. Primary literature will be used to explore these processes.

courses.title: Cell Biology of Human Disease
courses.desc: Builds on prior biology courses about the underlying cell biological mechanisms and recent treatment advances of several model diseases. Emphasizes literature searches, reading primary literature, and student group work.

courses.title: Human Anatomy
courses.desc: Presents a systems approach to the analysis of human structure. Molecular, cellular, tissue, organ, and organ system levels of structure and organization are integrated throughout.

courses.title: The Physiology of Human Nutrition
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 98 and BIO SCI E109
courses.desc: Examines the biochemical basis of energy metabolism, physiological processes in digestion and uptake, and the biochemical transformation of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins in the human body. The emphasis is on expanding the students' understanding of physiology.

courses.title: Eukaryotic and Human Genetics
courses.desc: Structure and function of genes in eukaryotes with emphasis on special problems of genetic studies in humans. Molecular methods of genetic analysis and gene transfer are discussed. Practical applications and ethical and social issues raised by genetic studies are addressed.

courses.title: Microbial Genetics
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: Recommended: BIO SCI 99.
BIO SCI 97 and BIO SCI 98
courses.desc: Basic principles of microbial genetics are presented as lectures for the first half of the course. The second half is devoted to applications of these principles and requires reading review and original research papers and interactions with guest lecturers.

courses.title: Critical Thinking in Cell Biology
courses.desc: Builds on prior biology courses about cell biology, and works to develop a deeper understanding of experimental techniques and interpretation of experiments. A key focus will be the question of how one moves from specific examples to general.

courses.title: Comparative Animal Physiology
courses.desc: Maintenance aspects of physiology: water balance; feeding and digestion; metabolism; respiration and circulation.

courses.title: Sex Differences in the Brain
courses.desc: Explores the neural bases of sex influences on brain function.

courses.title: Animal Locomotion
courses.desc: The physiology, biomechanics, and neuroscience that determines how animals propel themselves and navigate through the world. Considers the principles that govern the walking, running, flying, and swimming of animals, including exercising humans.

courses.title: Evolution and the Environment Laboratory
courses.desc: Explores basic topics in ecology and evolutionary biology and applications to agriculture, conservation, environmental issues, and public health. Format involves lab activities and discussion of scientific journal articles, with focus on learning to evaluate scientific evidence.

courses.title: Writing/Philosophy of Biology
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Philosophy of biology, e.g., scientific method in biology, the structure of evolutionary theory, teleology, ethics, and evolution. Course work includes one 4,000-word and four 1,000-word papers.

courses.title: Human Parasitology
courses.desc: Introduction to human animal-parasitic diseases including worms and protozoan infections.

courses.title: Cell Organelles and Membranes
courses.desc: Structure, function, and biogenesis of biological membranes and membrane-bound organelles.

courses.title: Genomics, Development, and Medicine
courses.desc: Focuses on the applications of genomics and proteomics to problems in genetics, cell, and developmental biology.  Students will gain a comprehensive understanding of the techniques currently used for genomics analysis and how best to apply these tools to solve problems.

courses.title: Animal Coloration and Vision
courses.desc: Physiological and behavioral mechanisms of color production and vision including crypsis, mimicry, aposematism, masquerade, sexual dimorphism, and predator-prey interactions through the lens of signals, receivers, and receptors; color and polarization vision in mate choice and visual adaptations to aquatic environments.

courses.title: Hearing and the Brain
courses.desc: An overview of brain mechanisms of hearing, including perception of simple sounds, speech, and music. Begins with sound itself, and looks at processing by the ear, auditory pathways, auditory cortex, and beyond. Also auditory development, learning, and clinical issues.

courses.title: Development and Disease
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI D103 or BIO SCI D104
courses.desc: Development of animal embryos from a fertilized egg to a functioning organism. Topics include reproduction, body-axis formation, growth and differentiation of embryonic cells, and organogenesis, with an emphasis on congenital birth defects and diseases that disrupt these processes.

courses.title: Conservation Biology
courses.desc: Genetic and ecological issues in conservation biology, including effects of human population growth, the value of biodiversity, conservation genetics, demography, metapopulation dynamics, community and ecosystem processes, species invasions, global climate change, and reserve design and management.

courses.title: Brain Dysfunction and Repair
courses.desc: Introduction to the disruptions in brain function that underlie disorders such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinsonism, schizophrenia, and depression, and the basis for drug therapies. The brain's ability to repair itself after damage and the pros and cons of that repair.

courses.title: Evolutionary and Ecological Principles in Medicine
courses.desc: Explore the dynamics of populations on an ecological, epidemiological, and medical level. Considers the dynamics of competition, predation, and parasitism; the spread and control of infectious diseases; and the in vivo dynamics of viral infections and the immune system.

courses.title: Neurobiology of Aging
