courses.desc: Principles of quantum chemistry with applications to the elements of atomic structure, energy levels, and spectroscopy.

courses.title: Molecular Structure and Elementary Statistical Mechanics
courses.prereqs: CHEM 132B. CHEM 132B with a grade of C- or better
courses.desc: Principles of quantum mechanics with applications to molecular spectroscopy and structure determination, and chemical bonding in simple molecules. Elements of statistical mechanics.

courses.title: Nuclear and Radiochemistry
courses.prereqs: (CHEM M3C or CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C) and MATH 2D
courses.desc: Advanced treatment of nuclear structure, nuclear reactions, and radioactive-decay processes. Introduction to nuclear activation analysis, isotope effects, radiation chemistry, hot-atom chemistry, nuclear age-dating methods, nuclear reactors, and nuclear power.

courses.title: Nuclear and Radiochemistry Laboratory
courses.prereqs: CHEM 133. CHEM 133 with a grade of C- or better. Prerequisite or corequisite: CHEM 133.
courses.desc: Practical aspects of production, separation, safe handling, detection and measurement of radioactive isotopes. Experiments will use the UCI nuclear reactor and emphasize uses of radioisotopes in chemistry, engineering, biology, and medicine.  Materials fee.

courses.title: Computational Chemistry
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: CHEM 132C
CHEM 51C and (CHEM 131A or CHEM 132B)
courses.desc: Short introduction to programming languages and to representative algorithms employed in chemical research. Students have the opportunity to devise and employ their own codes and also to employ codes which are widely used in various fields of chemistry. Materials fee.

courses.title: Introduction to Computational Organic Chemistry
courses.desc: An introduction to the use of computational chemistry to investigate reaction mechanisms, to calculate structures, and to predict properties of molecules. Students have the opportunity to perform calculations employing computational methods which are widely used in various fields of chemistry. Materials fee.

courses.title: Environmental Chemistry
courses.prereqs: (CHEM 51C or CHEM H52C) and (MATH 2B or AP Calculus BC). CHEM 51C with a grade of C- or better. CHEM H52C with a grade of C- or better. MATH 2B with a grade of C- or better. AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4
courses.desc: Processes that control the fate of chemicals in the environment. Chemistry of the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and soils, especially as it pertains to pollutants.

courses.title: Gas-Phase Atmospheric Chemistry
courses.desc: Sources, chemistry, sinks, and measurements of key atmospheric gaseous species. Chemistry of photochemical oxidant formation, transformation of key inorganic and organic trace gases, and stratospheric ozone cycling. Applications of atmospheric chemistry models to control strategies.

courses.title: Multi-Phase Atmospheric Chemistry
courses.desc: Chemical and physical processes leading to the production, aging, and removal of atmospheric particles. Multi-phase processes involving gases, particles, water droplets, and environmental surfaces. Approaches for modeling these processes with applications to control strategies.

courses.title: Computational Chemistry
courses.desc: Basic concepts, methods, and techniques in computational chemistry: density functional and wavefunction theory, molecular property calculations, analysis tools, potential energy surfaces, vibrational effects, molecular dynamics simulations.

courses.title: Computational Chemistry Laboratory
courses.prereqs: CHEM 150 and (CHEM 5 or PHYSICS 50 or EECS 12). CHEM 150 with a grade of C- or better. CHEM 5 with a grade of C- or better. PHYSICS 50 with a grade of C- or better. EECS 12 with a grade of C- or better
courses.desc: Introduction to the practice of modern computational chemistry through a series of advanced computational experiments.

courses.title: Advanced Analytical Chemistry
courses.prereqs: (CHEM 1C or CHEM M3C or CHEM H2C) and (CHEM M3LC or CHEM H2LC)
courses.desc: In-depth treatment of modern instrumental methods for quantitative analysis of real samples and basic principles of instrument design. Laboratory experiments using spectroscopic, chromatographic, mass spectrometric, and other instrumental methods. Materials fee.

courses.title: Physical Chemistry Laboratory
courses.desc: Introduction to the modern experimental approaches and software tools used in spectroscopy, kinetics, electrochemistry, and other physical chemistry experiments. Basics of interfacing with instruments using LabView. Materials fee.

courses.title: Advanced Laboratory in Chemistry and Synthesis of Materials
courses.prereqs: (CHEM 51C or CHEM H52C) and (CHEM 51LC or CHEM H52LC or CHEM M52LC) and (CHEM 131A or CHEM 132B or PHRMSCI 171)
courses.desc: Modern synthesis and characterization of organic and inorganic materials including polymers, nanomaterials, and biomaterials. State-of-the-art characterization techniques include gel permeation chromatography, dynamic light scattering, thermal analysis, mechanical analysis, electron and scanning probe microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and porosimetry. Materials fee.

courses.title: Organic Synthesis Laboratory
courses.desc: Modern experimental techniques in organic synthesis including experience with thin-layer chromatography, liquid chromatography, and gas chromatography. Modern methods of structure elucidation including FT NMR are employed in the characterization of products. Materials fee.

courses.title: Radioisotope Techniques
courses.prereqs: (CHEM 1C or CHEM M3C or CHEM H2C) and (CHEM 1LC or CHEM M3LC or CHEM H2LC)
courses.desc: Basic theory and practice of production, separation, safe handling, counting, applications of radioactive isotopes with emphasis on applications in chemistry, biology, and medicine. Materials fee.

courses.title: Medicinal Chemistry
courses.prereqs: CHEM 51A and CHEM 51B and CHEM 51C and (BIO SCI 98 or CHEM 128)
courses.desc: An introduction of the basics of drug activity and mechanisms. Strategies used to identify lead compounds such as natural product chemistry, combinatorial chemistry, molecular modeling, and high-through put screening.  Relationship of molecular structure to pharmacological activity.

courses.title: Medicinal Chemistry Laboratory
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: PHRMSCI 177 or CHEM 177.
CHEM 51A and CHEM 51B and CHEM 51C and BIO SCI 100 and (BIO SCI 98 or CHEM 128)
courses.desc: An introduction of the basics of drug activity and mechanisms. Strategies used to identify lead compounds such as natural product chemistry, combinatorial chemistry, molecular modeling, and high-through put screening.  Relationship of molecular structure to pharmacological activity. Materials fee.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.desc: Research for credit arranged with a faculty member to sponsor and supervise work. Student time commitment of 10 to 15 hours per week is expected, and a written research report is required at the end of each quarter.

courses.title: Senior Thesis in Chemistry
courses.prereqs: CHEM 180 or CHEM 199 or PHYSICS 195 or EARTHSS 199 or CBEMS 199 or ENGRCEE 199 or ENGRMAE 199 or BIO SCI 199 or PUBHLTH 199. CHEM 180 with a grade of A or better. CHEM 199 with a grade of A or better. PHYSICS 195 with a grade of A or better. EARTHSS 199 with a grade of A or better. CBEMS 199 with a grade of A or better. ENGRCEE 199 with a grade of A or better. ENGRMAE 199 with a grade of A or better. BIO SCI 199 with a grade of A or better. PUBHLTH 199 with a grade of A or better. Consent of the instructor is also accepted. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Students receive guidance on preparing research papers, proposals, reports, and other forms of scientific writing in chemistry-related fields; on effectively searching for and using chemical information; and on communicating data in poster and platform presentations.

courses.title: Honors Research in Chemistry
courses.desc: Undergraduate honors research in Chemistry. A student time commitment of 10-15 hours per week is required.

courses.title: Honors Research in Chemistry
courses.desc: Undergraduate honors research in Chemistry. A student time commitment of 10-15 hours per week is required.

courses.title: Honors Research in Chemistry
courses.desc: Undergraduate honors research in Chemistry.  A student time committment of 10-15 hours per week is required.

courses.title: Honors Seminar in Chemistry
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: CHEM H180C
CHEM H180A and CHEM H180B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Students will receive guidance in the preparation of oral and written research presentations.  A written thesis will be prepared and a formal research seminar will be presented.

courses.title: Chemistry Outreach Program
courses.desc: Involves intensive participation in the UCI Chemistry Outreach Program, which performs Chemistry demonstrations at local high schools.

courses.title: Tutoring in Chemistry
courses.desc: Enrollment limited to participants in the Chemistry Peer Tutoring Program.

courses.title: Research Methods
courses.desc: Explores tools of inquiry for developing and implementing science research projects.  Students undertake independent projects requiring data collection, analysis, and modeling, and the organization and presentation of results.  Additional topics include ethical issues and role of scientific literature.

courses.title: Professional Internship
courses.prereqs: Enrollment requires completion of an application form. Student selection is made by a selection committee.
courses.desc: Internship program that provides students with opportunity to develop professional skills necessary for competitive placement in their chosen chemical-inspired industry. Students gain new and field-specific skills outside the classroom while participating in a supervised internship.

courses.title: Independent Study in Chemistry
courses.desc: Independent research with Chemistry faculty.  Student time commitment of three to four hours per week per unit is expected, and a written report on the independent study is required at the end of each quarter of enrollment.

courses.title: Conduct of Research
courses.desc: Introduces new graduate students to ethical conduct of scientific research, mentoring, and current research in the Department of chemistry.

courses.title: Organic Reaction Mechanisms I
courses.desc: Advanced treatment of basic mechanistic principles of modern organic chemistry. Topics include molecular orbital theory, orbital symmetry control of organic reactions, aromaticity, carbonium ion chemistry, free radical chemistry, the chemistry of carbenes and carbanions, photochemistry, electrophilic substitutions, aromatic chemistry.

courses.title: Organic Reaction Mechanisms II
courses.desc: Topics include more in-depth treatment of mechanistic concepts, kinetics, conformational analysis, computational methods, stereoelectronics, and both solution and enzymatic catalysis.

courses.title: Organic Spectroscopy
courses.prereqs: (CHEM 51A and CHEM 51B and CHEM 51C) or (CHEM H52A and CHEM H52B and CHEM H52C)
courses.desc: Modern methods used in structure determination of organic molecules. Topics include mass spectrometry; ultraviolet, chiroptical, infrared, and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy.

courses.title: Organic Synthesis I
courses.desc: Fundamentals of modern synthetic organic chemistry is developed. Major emphasis is on carbon-carbon bond forming methodology. Topics include carbonyl annelations, cycloadditions, sigmatropic rearrangements, and organometallic methods.

courses.title: Organic Synthesis II
courses.desc: Fundamentals of modern synthetic organic chemistry will be developed. Major emphasis this quarter is on natural product total synthesis and retrosynthetic (antithetic) analysis.

courses.title: Laboratory Skills
courses.desc: Introduces students to a variety of practical laboratory techniques, including lock-in, boxcar, coincidence counting, noise filtering, PID control, properties of common transducers, computer interfacing to instruments, vacuum technology, laboratory safety, basic mechanical design, and shop skills. Materials fee.

courses.title: Chemistry for Physicists
courses.desc: Introduction to fundamental concepts in molecular structure and reactivity: theory of bonding, valence and molecular orbitals; structure and reactivity in inorganic chemistry; elements in molecular group theory; nomenclature in organic chemistry; and survey of macromolecules.

courses.title: Mathematics for Chemists
courses.desc: Applications of mathematics to physical and chemical problems. Calculus of special functions, complex variables and vectors; linear vector spaces and eigenvalue problems. Differential equations.

courses.title: Chemical Kinetics
courses.desc: Surveys gas phase and organic reaction mechanisms and their relationship to kinetic rate laws; treats the basic theory of elementary reaction rates.  A brief presentation of modern cross-sectional kinetics is included.

courses.title: Inorganic Chemistry I
courses.prereqs: CHEM 107 and CHEM 132A and CHEM 132B and CHEM 132C
courses.desc: Principles of modern inorganic chemistry with applications to chemical systems of current interest. Inorganic phenomena are organized into general patterns which rationalize observed structures, stabilities, and physical properties.

courses.title: Organometallic Chemistry
courses.desc: Synthesis and reactivity of organometallic complexes with an emphasis on mechanisms. Topics include bonding and fluxional properties; metal-carbon single and multiple bonds; metal š-complexes. Applications to homogenous catalysis and organic synthesis are incorporated throughout the course.

courses.title: Physical Inorganic Chemistry
courses.desc: General principles of the spectroscopy and magnetism of inorganic compounds. Characterization of inorganic complexes by infrared, near-infrared, visible, ultraviolet, NMR, EPR, EXAFS, and Mossbauer spectroscopies. Some necessary group theory developed.

courses.title: Metallobiochemistry
courses.desc: A review of the biochemistry of metallic elements emphasizing: methods for studying metals in biological systems; the chemical basis for nature's exploitation of specific elements; structures of active sites; mechanisms; solid-state structures and devices; metals in medicine.

courses.title: Chemical and Structural Biology
courses.desc: A survey of the organic chemistry underlying biological function. Introduction to chemical genetics, receptor-ligand interactions, small molecule agonists and antagonists, combinatorial synthesis, high throughput assays, molecular evolution, protein and small molecule design.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Molecular Biophysics
courses.prereqs: Undergraduate courses in physical chemistry and biochemistry.
courses.desc: An overview of the principles and concepts in molecular biophysics.  Topics covered include energy and entropy in biology, non-equilibrium reaction kinetics, random walks and molecular diffusion, molecular forces in biology.

courses.title: Biological Macromolecules
courses.desc: Introduction to nucleic acid and protein structure, dynamics, and function. Topics include analytical methods, molecular evolution, folding, and catalysis.

courses.title: Molecular and Cellular Biophotonics
courses.desc: Principles underlying the application of photonic technologies to biomolecular and cellular systems. Sample technologies Optical Tweezers, Linear and Nonlinear Optical Microscopy and Fluorescence Lifetime and Correlation Methods, and their use to investigate emergent problems in Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology.

courses.title: Polymer Chemistry:  Synthesis and Characterization of Polymers
courses.prereqs: Undergraduate courses in organic and physical chemistry.
courses.desc: Structure of synthetic and natural polymers.  Survey of modern polymer synthetic methods.  Molecular weight and molecular weight distribution.  Chain conformation and stereochemistry. Introduction to polymer characterization, chain models, and solution behavior.

courses.title: Electromagnetism
courses.desc: Maxwell’s equations, electrodynamics, electromagnetic waves and radiation, wave propagation in media, interference and quantum optics, coherent and incoherent radiation, with practical applications in interferometry, lasers, waveguides, and optical instrumentation.

courses.title: Computational Methods
courses.desc: Mathematical and numerical analysis using Mathematica and C programming, as applied to problems in physical science.

courses.title: Classical Mechanics and Electromagnetic Theory
courses.desc: Fundamentals of classical mechanics and electromagnetic theory are developed with specific application to molecular systems. Newtonian, Lagrangian, and Hamiltonian mechanics are developed. Boundary value problems in electrostatics are investigated. Multipole expansion and macroscopic media are discussed from a molecular viewpoint.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Quantum Mechanics
courses.desc: The postulates of quantum mechanics are discussed and applied to a variety of model problems.

courses.title: Applications of Quantum Mechanics
courses.desc: Approximate methods for solving atomic and molecular structure problems are developed, and the application of quantum mechanics to spectroscopy is introduced.

courses.title: Molecular Spectroscopy
courses.desc: Theory and techniques of spectroscopy as used for the study of molecular and condensed phase properties. Coherent time domain spectroscopies are covered.

courses.title: Thermodynamics and Introduction to Statistical Mechanics
courses.desc: A detailed discussion from an advanced point of view of the principles of classical thermodynamics. The fundamentals of statistical mechanics. Topics include an introduction to ensemble theory, Boltzmann statistics, classical statistical mechanics, and the statistical mechanics of ideal gas systems.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Statistical Mechanics
courses.desc: Continued discussion of the principles of statistical mechanics. Applications to topics of chemical interest including imperfect gases, liquids, solutions, and crystals. Modern techniques such as the use of autocorrelation function methods.

courses.title: Non-Equilibrium Statistical Mechanics
courses.desc: Phenomenology of material processes, including: kinetic theories of transport and continuum, linear response theory, critical phenomena of phase transition, self-assembly, and nucleation.

courses.title: Nuclear and Radiochemistry
courses.desc: Advanced treatment of nuclear structure, nuclear reactions, and radioactive-decay processes. Introduction to nuclear activation analysis, isotope effects, radiation chemistry, hot-atom chemistry, nuclear age-dating methods, nuclear reactors, and nuclear power.

courses.title: Mathematical Methods in Chemistry
courses.desc: Survey of essential math methods in chemistry. Topics may include series and limits, complex analysis, Fourier and Laplace transforms, linear algebra and operators (theory and algorithms), differential equations, and probability concepts for stochastic processes.

courses.title: Current Issues Related to Air Quality, Climate, and Energy
courses.desc: Current issues related to the atmosphere, climate, and air quality in the context of energy conversion and sustainability. Topics include transportation systems; building design; impacts on humans and ecosystems; modeling and meteorology; economics; and application to public policies.

courses.title: Physical and Geometrical Optics
courses.desc: Focuses on the practical aspects of optics and optical engineering, starting at the fundamentals. Topics include geometrical optics, ray tracing, polarization optics, interferometers, and diffractive optics.

courses.title: Advanced Instrumental Analysis
courses.prereqs: CHEM 152 and CHEM 132C. CHEM 152 with a grade of B or better. CHEM 132C with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Theory and applications of modern advanced instrumental methods of analysis. Includes data acquisition, storage, retrieval, and analysis; Fourier transform methods; vacuum technologies; magnetic sector; quadrupole and ion trap mass spectrometry; surface science spectroscopic methods; lasers and optics.

courses.title: Detection and Measurement of Radiation
courses.desc: Basic principles of detection and measurement of ionizing radiation; both theory and practical aspects of measurement techniques for alpha, beta, gamma, and neutron radiation, properties of different detector materials, electronics and data treatments, and analysis.

courses.title: Gas-Phase Atmospheric Chemistry
courses.desc: Sources, chemistry, sinks, and measurements of key atmospheric gaseous species. Chemistry of photochemical oxidant formation, transformation of key inorganic and organic trace gases, and stratospheric ozone cycling. Applications of atmospheric chemistry models to control strategies.

courses.title: Multi-Phase Atmospheric Chemistry
courses.desc: Chemical and physical processes leading to the production, aging, and removal of atmospheric particles. Multi-phase processes involving gases, particles, water droplets, and environmental surfaces. Approaches for modeling these processes with applications to control strategies.

courses.title: Special Topics in Atmospheric Chemistry
courses.desc: The subjects covered vary from year to year.

courses.title: Separations and Chromatography
courses.desc: Introduction to modern separation techniques such as gas chromatography, high-performance liquid chromatography, supercritical fluid chromatography, capillary electrophoresis, and field flow fractionation. Applications of these separation strategies are discussed.

courses.title: Current Problems in Analytical Chemistry
courses.desc: Surveys current research challenges in analytical chemistry. Topics include electrochemistry, chromatography, spectroscopy, and mass spectrometry.

courses.title: Electrochemistry
courses.desc: Fundamentals of electrochemistry including thermodynamics and the electrochemical potential, charge transfer kinetics, and mass transfer. Methods based on controlled potential and controlled current are described; the effects of slow heterogeneous kinetics and the perturbation caused by homogeneous chemistry are discussed.

courses.title: Analytical Spectroscopy
courses.desc: Advanced treatment of spectroscopic techniques and instrumentation. Atomic and molecular absorption, emission, and scattering processes and their application to quantitative chemical analysis are outlined. Puts different spectroscopic techniques in perspective and demonstrates most appropriate applications to analytical problems.

courses.title: Computational Chemistry
courses.desc: Basic concepts, methods, and techniques in computational chemistry: density functional and wavefunction theory, molecular property calculations, analysis tools, potential energy surfaces, vibrational effects, molecular dynamics simulations.

courses.title: Computational Chemistry Laboratory
courses.desc: Introduction to the practice of modern computational chemistry through a series of advanced computational experiments.

courses.title: Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
courses.desc: Advanced topics in organic chemistry.

courses.title: Special Topics in Physical Chemistry
courses.desc: Advanced topics in physical chemistry. Materials fee.

courses.title: Special Topics in Inorganic Chemistry
courses.desc: Advanced topics in inorganic chemistry.

courses.title: Special Topics in Computational and Theoretical Chemistry
courses.desc: Subjects covered vary from year to year.

courses.title: Materials Chemistry
courses.desc: An introduction to crystalline solids, descriptive crystal chemistry, solid-state synthesis and characterization techniques, x-ray and electron diffraction, phase diagrams, electronic band structure of extended solids, semi conductors, and nanoscale inorganic materials.

courses.title: Current Topics in Chemical and Materials Physics
courses.desc: The subjects covered vary from year to year.  Connection between fundamental principles and implementations in practice in science, industry, and technology.

courses.title: Photochemistry
courses.desc: Photochemical and photovoltaic processes in molecules and semiconductors; quantum mechanics; statistical thermodynamics; kinetics; and experimental techniques relevant to photon absorption and emission; photochemical charge separation, recombination, and transport of electrons and ions; and interfacial redox chemistry.

courses.title: NMR Spectroscopy
courses.desc: Students learn the theoretical basis of solid-state or solution NMR (alternate times), including the basics of pulse sequence design. Extensive literature reading is required.

courses.title: Technical Communication Skills
courses.desc: Development of effective communication skills, oral and written presentations, through examples and practice.

courses.title: Research
courses.desc: Supervised original research toward the preparation of a Ph.D dissertation or M.S. thesis.

courses.title: Seminar
courses.desc: Weekly seminars and discussions on general and varied topics of current interest in chemistry.

courses.title: Research Seminar
courses.desc: Detailed discussion of research problems of current interest in the Department. Format, content, and frequency of the course are variable.

courses.title: Graduate Symposium
courses.desc: Students present public seminars on literature-based research topics in contemporary chemistry.  Topics to be chosen by student and approved by instructor.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Independent research with Chemistry faculty.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Required of and limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Introduction to Chicano/Latino Studies I
courses.desc: An introduction to the study of the historical foundations of the Chicano/Latino experience.  Addresses such topics as empire, migration, immigrant settlement, economic integration, race, gender, and the formation of group identities.

courses.title: Introduction to Chicano/Latino Studies II
courses.desc: Provides an introduction to the arts, literature, and culture of Chicano/Latino communities. Analyzes representations of and cultural production in Chicano/Latino communities through such media as folklore, literature, art, film, architecture, dance theatre, performance, music, poetry, mass media, and language.

courses.title: Introduction to Chicano/Latino Studies III
courses.desc: Examines contemporary public policy issues in Chicano/Latino communities. Each offering addresses at least three of the following themes: migration, immigrant incorporation, identity construction, language policy, health policy, politics, sexuality, gender, labor, class, and education.

courses.title: Introduction to Race and Ethnicity in Political Science
courses.desc: Examines major theories that attempt to explain the roles of race and ethnicity in U.S. politics.

courses.title: Ethnic and Immigrant America
courses.desc: Focusing on Asian, Latino, and Black immigrant groups, examines the second generation's experience of straddling two cultures and growing up American. Covers topics such as assimilation, bilingualism, race relations, education, bicultural conflicts, interracial marriage, and multiracial identities.

courses.title: Lower-Division Special Topics in Chicano/Latino Studies
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Latina/o Childhoods: Comparative Approaches to the Study of Children and Youth
courses.desc: Students in this seminar compare the experiences of Latina/o children to other young people in the U.S. and around the world, analyzing the historical, political, economic, and sociocultural factors that have differently structured the life stage we understand as “childhood.”.

courses.title: Research in the Latino Community
courses.prereqs: Two courses from CHC/LAT 61 or CHC/LAT 62 or CHC/LAT 63 and two courses from CHC/LAT 110-189.
courses.desc: Students engage in firsthand research in the local Orange County environment. Students identify a research problem, conduct a literature review, develop questions and/or hypotheses, appropriate methods, and write a proposal.

courses.title: Chicano/Latino Research Seminar
courses.prereqs: CHC/LAT 101. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Taught as a writing and research seminar in Chicano/Latino Studies.  Student develops own project; engages in peer editing; drafts, writes, and presents paper at Spring research conference.  Prior course work in Chicano/Latino Studies helpful, i.e., CHC/LAT 61, 62, 63.

courses.title: Topics in Chicano Literature and Culture
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter. Taught in English.

courses.title: Anthropology of Food
courses.desc: Examines how food communicates ideas about ethnocentrism, disgust, privilege, gender, race, labor, social identities and hierarchies, globalization, power, and the "Western diet" and its health consequences.

courses.title: Peoples and Cultures of Latin America
courses.desc: Surveys the prehistory of Latin America and its indigenous cultures, emphasizing the impact of colonial rule, capitalism, and twentieth-century transformations.  Emphasis on communities from several countries. In some years, emphasis on comparisons between the Latin American and Caribbean experiences.

courses.title: Latina/Latino Pop:  Latina/Latino Popular Culture
courses.desc: With a focus on the politics of language and space/place, prepares students to critically analyze sites of Latina/Latino popular culture including: music, film, performance, sports, media, and varied subcultures.

courses.title: Immigration, Nation, and Media
courses.desc: Examines media shapes and reflects public opinion on immigration and its representation of immigrants, citizens, and ideas about the nation, and who belongs and who is a potential threat; as well as the relationship between scholars and journalists.

courses.title: Special Topics in Literature, Arts, Media, Culture
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Chicana/Chicano History: Pre-Colonial to 1900
courses.desc: Examines social history of the southwest region from antiquity to 1900. Discusses major questions, theory and research methods pertinent to Chicanas/Chicanos. Themes include: indigenous empires, conquest, colonialism, social stratification, ideology, marriage, sexuality, industrial capitalism, accommodation and resistance.

courses.title: Chicana/Chicano History: Twentieth Century
courses.desc: Examines social history of the Southwest with emphasis on Mexican-origin people. Discusses major questions, theory and research methods pertinent to Chicana/Chicano history. Themes explored include: immigration, xenophobia, class struggle, leadership, generational cohorts, unionization, education, barrioization, ethnicity, patriarchy, sexuality.

courses.title: U
courses.desc: Focuses on aspects of literature, art, cultural production, and history of the multifaceted Latino cultures that have developed within the United States.  Focuses on one group, such as Caribbean Americans, Chicanos, Central Americans, or a comparative perspective of several groups.

courses.title: Latinas in the Twentieth Century U
courses.desc: Latinas in the U.S. from 1900 to present, offering a diversity of their cultures, regional histories, sexualities, generations, and classes.

courses.title: Special Topics in Chicano/Latino History
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino History. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Comparative Minority Politics
courses.desc: Examines the political experiences of Blacks, Latinos, and Asian Americans in the United States from roughly 1950 to the present. Focuses on how each group has pursued political empowerment via both conventional political channels and social movements.

courses.title: Racial and Ethnic Relations in the United States
courses.desc: Examines central questions and issues in the field of race and ethnicity; the emergence, maintenance, and consequences of the ethnic and racial stratification system in the United States; the future of racial and ethnic relations; and relevant public policy issues.

courses.title: Racial and Ethnic Relations in the United States
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Examines central questions and issues in the field of race and ethnicity; the emergence, maintenance, and consequences of the ethnic and racial stratification system in the United States; the future of racial and ethnic relations; and relevant public policy issues.

courses.title: U
courses.desc: Explores political, economic, social, and cultural ties that bind Latin America to the United States. Focuses on U.S. intervention and Latin American response from early nineteenth century to present day. Case studies include Mexico, Guatemala, Cuba, Chile, and Central America.

courses.title: Latinos in U
courses.desc: Comparing the political issues facing Latino groups by examining their migration histories, voting behavior, nonelectoral participation, and policy issues.  Latino issues are examined on the national, state, and local levels, including formal representation, immigration, affirmative action, and language policy.

courses.title: Revolution in Latin America
courses.desc: Presents a comparative analysis of the causes, development, and consequences of selected revolutionary movements, focusing on outbreaks in Mexico, Bolivia, Cuba, Chile, Nicaragua, and Grenada.  Explores topics of state formation, economic nationalism, social justice, ethnicity, and role of international affairs.

courses.title: Race, Ethnicity, and Social Control
courses.desc: Provides a historical and sociological survey of racial and ethnic group relations in contexts of crime control, emphasizing the roles of racial ideology, structural racism, and social movements in shaping these dynamic relations, and their significance to American liberal democracy.

courses.title: Community, Social Justice, and Health Equity Research for Action
courses.prereqs: PUBHLTH 1 or PUBHLTH 2 or CHC/LAT 61 or CHC/LAT 62 or CHC/LAT 63
courses.desc: Focuses on community as a unit of identity, community, well-being, and social justice perspectives and initiatives to promote community health. Addresses community change and improvements in community well-being, with a focus on health equity research for action.

courses.title: Cross-Cultural Research on Urban Gangs
courses.desc: Taking an urban policy approach, examines the background and contemporary traditions of gangs in several ethnic groups including African-, Asian-, and Mexican-Americans. Cross-cultural exploration of the varied facets of gang life. The major social-control institutions affecting them.

courses.title: Latino Metropolis
courses.desc: Explores the processes of Latino urbanization in the United States and the spatialization of Latino identities, particularly in the context of Southern California with selected comparisons drawing from other cities.

courses.title: Culture Change and the Mexican People
courses.desc: Reviews culture contact and colonization, innovation diffusion, acculturation, assimilation, culture conflict and marginality, modernization, urbanization, legal transformations. Mexico and the Southwestern U.S. are reviewed through several centuries to better appreciate the indigenous base of the Mexican people.

courses.title: Chicano/Latinos and Labor
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Explores theories that explain the occupational pathways and workplace experiences of Latinos in various work sectors. Investigates jobs such as migrant labor, child street vendors, Latina/Latino professionals, and Latinos migrating to the U.S. South that work in poultry processing plants.

courses.title: Cuban Society and Revolution
courses.desc: Explores the causes, development, and legacy of the 1959 Revolution. Themes include economic dependency, democracy, race, gender, culture, and the always volatile relations between Cuba and the United States.

courses.title: Feminisms of Color
courses.desc: Surveys the development of Chicana feminist thought and practice.  Focuses on historical contemporary writings by and about Chicana feminists.  Draws from interdisciplinary scholarship in order to survey the diversity of Chicana feminisms.

courses.title: Special Topics in Society, Labor, Politics, Law, Gender, Race, Ethnicity
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Transnational Migration
courses.desc: Examines the movement of people across national borders, governmentality and the role of state practices to control populations, and issues of citizenship, belonging, and identity. Examples are drawn from the United States, Europe, Latin America, Asia, and Africa.

courses.title: Urban America
courses.desc: Students examine the historical, social, political, and economic factors that contributed to the construction of the American urban context, one that is poverty concentrated and racially/ethnically segregated. Students also critically assess the consequence of growing up in America's urban neighborhoods.

courses.title: U
courses.desc: Examines selected immigration policy debates since the nineteenth century, rationale and consequences of immigration law since 1965, problems of administration, implementation and enforcement, impact of immigration policy on foreign relations, and contemporary debate regarding the future of U.S. policy.

courses.title: Undocumented Immigrant Experiences
courses.desc: Examines the experiences of undocumented immigrants and the policies that structure their educational, economic, social, and political participation.

courses.title: Chicano Movement
courses.desc: Explores the history of Mexicans in the U.S. with particular attention paid to their integration into the U.S. capitalist economy.  Examines this economic history and the Chicano movement, "El Movimiento," within the wide context of socio-economic change.

courses.title: Latinos in a Global Society
courses.desc: Examines interconnections between diverse Latino groups in the U.S. and the effects of globalization on their social, cultural, and political realities. Topics include immigration, demographics, socioeconomic differentiation, familial relations, political protest/resistance, law and policy, and links to "homeland" issues.

courses.title: Chicano/Latino Social Psychology
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Examines theories, research, and major issues of relevance to understanding social psychological processes in Chicano/Latino populations. Topics include social development, cultural orientations, gender and sexuality, close relationships, happiness and well-being, stereotyping, prejudice and discrimination, and mental and physical health.

courses.title: Special Topics in Globalization, Transnationalism, Immigration, U
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Chicano/Latino Families
courses.desc: Introduction to the research, literature, and issues surrounding the topic of Chicano/Latino families including cultural history, contemporary issues, organization of family, traditions, lifestyles, values, beliefs, generational differences, gender issues, ethnic identity, evolution of demographic patterns, current economic and political standings.

courses.title: Race, Gender, and Science
courses.desc: Perfect for pre-health, science and social science majors wanting to appreciate how science and society interact. Race and gender as biological and socio-cultural constructs are examined. Questions explored: What is disease? What is science? What are social and biological differences.

courses.title: Medical Anthropology
courses.desc: Introduces students to cross-cultural perspectives and critical theories in anthropological studies of medicine. Special attention is given to diverse ways of understanding bodies, illnesses, and therapeutic practices in our changing world.

courses.title: Special Topics in Health, Medicine, and Psychosocial Dynamics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Multicultural Education in K-12 Schools
courses.desc: Provides a theoretical and empirical overview of educational issues affecting low-income immigrant and U.S. born minority student populations in an increasingly diverse and changing society.

courses.title: Special Topics in Educational Policy and Issues
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Honors Research Preparation
courses.desc: Students write a proposal describing their research question, the relevant background literature, and the method of data collection and analysis.  Field work for the project may begin this quarter.

courses.title: Honors Field Research
courses.desc: Students begin or continue their research for their senior honors thesis.

courses.title: Honors Thesis
courses.desc: Student drafts a senior honor thesis (typically) with the following sections:  problem statement, literature review, description of the methods, results, and conclusions.

courses.title: Honors Thesis
courses.prereqs: CHC/LAT H190A and CHC/LAT H190B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Student drafts a senior honor thesis (typically) with the following sections:  problem statement, literature review, description of the methods, results, and conclusions.

courses.title: Directed Group Study
courses.desc: Directed study with Chicano/Latino faculty.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Independent research with Chicano/Latino faculty.

courses.title: Theoretical Issues in Chicano/Latino Research
courses.desc: Introduction to theoretical issues in the scholarship in Chicano/Latino Studies. Theories from social sciences, humanities, critical theory. Topics: immigration, identity, gender and sexuality, globalization, transnationalism, social, political, and economic integration, race theory, labor market participation, social history, cultural productions.

courses.title: Cultural and Historial Precedents for Latinos and Medical Care
courses.desc: Introduction to the history of Latinos, focusing on relevant pre-Columbian, colonial, and modern social and cultural developments, including issues of race, gender, sexuality, religious beliefs, and health beliefs and practices.

courses.title: Cultural and Historical Precedents for Latinos and Medical Care
courses.desc: Introduction to the history of Latinos, focusing on relevant pre-Columbian, colonial, and modern social and cultural developments, including issues of race, gender, sexuality, religious beliefs, and health beliefs and practices.

courses.title: Latinos/Latinas and Medical Care: Contemporary Issues
courses.desc: Introduction to medical anthropological and social science perspectives on Latinos/Latinas in relation to a number of health and medically-related issues, i.e., immigration, gender, reproduction, culture, social structure, political economy, sexuality, utilization of medical services, and health beliefs.

courses.title: Latinos/Latinas and Medical Care: Contemporary Issues
courses.desc: Introduction to medical anthropological and social science perspectives on Latinos/Latinas in relation to a number of health and medically-related issues, i.e., immigration, gender, reproduction, culture, social structure, political economy, sexuality, utilization of medical services, and health beliefs.

courses.title: Transnational Migration
courses.desc: Examines borders and boundaries as material and semiotic constructs. Drawing upon an array of literatures, but loosely situated in U.S. geo/biopolitics, explores transformative troublings of places, spaces, borders, and bodies of all sorts.

courses.title: Ethnography
courses.desc: Explores the theory and practice of ethnography with a focus on anthropology, the discipline most associated with ethnography. Students are exposed to the theoretical underpinnings of ethnographic work, traditional and innovative practices, and sample ethnographies.

courses.title: Theorizing Illegality and the Experiences of Undocumented Immigrants
courses.desc: Examines theories of illegality and citizenship, historical and contemporary undocumented immigrant experiences, and methodological concerns in this area of study.

courses.title: Ethnic America
courses.desc: Examines critically the meaning and measurement of ethnicity, race, and nation in sociological theory and research. Theories of ethnicity are explored, along with empirical studies of the construction of ethnic and pan-ethnic identities in historical and contemporary contexts.

courses.title: Immigrant America
courses.desc: The study of the causes and consequences of international migration has become one of the most vital fields of sociological theory and research. Examines principal theoretical perspectives and empirical research on contemporary immigration flows and the processes of incorporation.

courses.title: Special Topics in Chicano/Latino Studies
courses.desc: Current research in Chicano/Latino Studies.

courses.title: Dissertation Research
courses.desc: Dissertation research with Chicano/Latino faculty.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Independent study with Chicano/Latino Studies faculty.

courses.title: Fundamental Mandarin Chinese
courses.prereqs: Placement into CHINESE 1A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Natural approach emphasizing four fundamental skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing. Specifically designed for students with no previous experience in any dialect of Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin Chinese using the Pinyin system of Romanization, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.

courses.title: Fundamental Mandarin Chinese
courses.prereqs: CHINESE 1A. CHINESE 1A with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 1B is also accepted.
courses.desc: Natural approach emphasizing four fundamental skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing. Specifically designed for students with no previous experience in any dialect of Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin Chinese using the Pinyin system of Romanization, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.

courses.title: Fundamental Mandarin Chinese
courses.prereqs: CHINESE 1B or CHINESE S1AB. CHINESE 1B with a grade of C or better. CHINESE S1AB with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 1C is also accepted.
courses.desc: Natural approach emphasizing four fundamental skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing. Specifically designed for students with no previous experience in any dialect of Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin Chinese using the Pinyin system of Romanization, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Mandarin Chinese - Mandarin Background Track
courses.desc: Natural approach emphasizing four fundamental skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing. Specifically designed for students with previous background in Mandarin Chinese.  Conducted in Mandarin Chinese using the Pinyin system of Romanization, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Mandarin Chinese - Mandarin Background Track
courses.prereqs: CHINESE 1MA. CHINESE 1MA with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 1MB is also accepted.
courses.desc: Natural approach emphasizing four fundamental skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing. Specifically designed for students with previous background in Mandarin Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin Chinese using the Pinyin system of Romanization, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Mandarin Chinese - Mandarin Background Track
courses.prereqs: CHINESE 1MB. CHINESE 1MB with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 1MC is also accepted.
courses.desc: Natural approach emphasizing four fundamental skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing. Specifically designed for students with previous background in Mandarin Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin Chinese using the Pinyin system of Romanization, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Mandarin Chinese
courses.prereqs: Placement into CHINESE 1A or CHINESE 1B or CHINESE 1MA or CHINESE 1MB or CHINESE 1DA or CHINESE 1DB.
courses.desc: First half of first-year Mandarin Chinese in an intensive setting using natural approach with emphasis on listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Mandarin Chinese
courses.prereqs: CHINESE S1AB or CHINESE 1B or CHINESE 1DB or CHINESE 1MB. CHINESE S1AB with a grade of C or better. CHINESE 1B with a grade of C or better. CHINESE 1DB with a grade of C or better. CHINESE 1MB with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 1C or CHINESE 1DC or CHINESE 1MC is also accepted.
courses.desc: Second half of first-year Mandarin Chinese in an intensive setting using natural approach with emphasis on listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

courses.title: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese
courses.prereqs: CHINESE 1C or CHINESE S1BC. CHINESE 1C with a grade of C or better. CHINESE S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 2A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Both authentic and pedagogically-prepared materials are used to further develop students' ability to communicate in culturally, socially, and linguistically appropriate manners. Taught in Chinese using Pinyin romanization system and both traditional and simplified forms of Chinese.

courses.title: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese
courses.prereqs: CHINESE 2A. CHINESE 2A with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 2B is also accepted.
courses.desc: Both authentic and pedagogically-prepared materials are used to further develop students' ability to communicate in culturally, socially, and linguistically appropriate manners. Taught in Chinese using Pinyin romanization system and both traditional and simplified forms of Chinese.

courses.title: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese
courses.prereqs: CHINESE 2B. CHINESE 2B with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 2C is also accepted.
courses.desc: Both authentic and pedagogically-prepared materials are used to further develop students' ability to communicate in culturally, socially, and linguistically appropriate manners. Taught in Chinese using Pinyin romanization system and both traditional and simplified forms of Chinese.

courses.title: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese - Mandarin Background Track
courses.prereqs: CHINESE 1MC or CHINESE S1BC. CHINESE 1MC with a grade of C or better. CHINESE S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 2MA is also accepted.
courses.desc: Authentic and pedagogically prepared materials are used to further develop communication in culturally, socially, and linguistically appropriate manners for students with initial experience in Mandarin Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin using the Pinyin Romanization system, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.

courses.title: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese - Mandarin Background Track
courses.prereqs: CHINESE 2MA. CHINESE 2MA with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 2MB is also accepted.
courses.desc: Authentic and pedagogically prepared materials are used to further develop communication in culturally, socially, and linguistically appropriate manners for students with initial experience in Mandarin Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin using the Pinyin Romanization system, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.

courses.title: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese - Mandarin Background Track
courses.prereqs: CHINESE 2MB. CHINESE 2MB with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 2MC is also accepted.
courses.desc: Authentic and pedagogically prepared materials are used to further develop communication in culturally, socially, and linguistically appropriate manners for students with initial experience in Mandarin Chinese. Conducted in Mandarin using the Pinyin Romanization system, traditional and simplified Chinese characters.

courses.title: Advanced Mandarin Chinese
courses.prereqs: CHINESE 2C or CHINESE 2DC or CHINESE 2MC. CHINESE 2C with a grade of C or better. CHINESE 2DC with a grade of C or better. CHINESE 2MC with a grade of C or better. Placement into CHINESE 3A is also accepted.
courses.desc: A continuation of CHINESE 2A-CHINESE 2B-CHINESE 2C emphasizing conceptualization, self-expression and academic skills in Chinese. Authentic texts from modern Chinese prose and newspapers are used. Taught in Mandarin Chinese using both traditional and simplified forms of Chinese characters.

courses.title: Advanced Mandarin Chinese
courses.prereqs: CHINESE 3A. CHINESE 3A with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: A continuation of CHINESE 2A-CHINESE 2B-CHINESE 2C emphasizing conceptualization, self-expression, and academic skills in Chinese. Authentic texts from modern Chinese prose and newspapers are used. Taught in Mandarin Chinese using both traditional and simplified forms of Chinese characters.

courses.title: Advanced Mandarin Chinese
courses.prereqs: CHINESE 3B. CHINESE 3B with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: A continuation of CHINESE 2A-CHINESE 2B-CHINESE 2C emphasizing conceptualization, self-expression, and academic skills in Chinese. Authentic texts from modern Chinese prose and newspapers are used. Taught in Mandarin Chinese using both traditional and simplified forms of Chinese characters.

courses.title: Peer Tutoring Program
courses.desc: Tutoring Program in which advanced Chinese students provide assistance to students at a lower level. One hour of tutoring per week.

courses.title: Classical Chinese
courses.desc: Introduction to classical Chinese grammar and vocabulary with emphasis on reading basic texts.

courses.title: Classical Chinese
courses.desc: Introduction to classical Chinese grammar and vocabulary with emphasis on reading basic texts.

courses.title: Classical Chinese
courses.desc: Introduction to classical Chinese grammar and vocabulary with emphasis on reading basic texts.

courses.title: Fourth-Year Mandarin Chinese
courses.desc: Continued emphasis on comprehension, grammar, and proficiency in reading, composition, and conversation through intensive study and analysis of specific literary texts.

courses.title: Fourth-Year Mandarin Chinese
courses.desc: Continued emphasis on comprehension, grammar, and proficiency in reading, composition, and conversation through intensive study and analysis of specific literary texts.

courses.title: Fourth-Year Mandarin Chinese
courses.desc: Continued emphasis on comprehension, grammar, and proficiency in reading, composition, and conversation through intensive study and analysis of specific literary texts.

courses.title: Topics in Chinese Literature: Advanced Texts
courses.prereqs: Consent of instructor required to enroll.
courses.desc: Designed for students with near-fluency in reading Chinese. Readings may include both literary and philosophical work by important writers, but the emphasis is on literary texts and writings that interpret those texts.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Investigation of special topics through directed reading in Chinese. Paper required.

courses.title: Readings in Traditional Chinese Narrative and Prose
courses.desc: Close reading of selected premodern prose texts such as historical narratives, novels, short stories, and essays.

courses.title: Readings in Traditional Chinese Poetry
courses.desc: Close readings of selected premodern poetic texts.

courses.title: Readings in Modern Chinese Literature
courses.desc: Close readings of selected modern literary texts.

courses.title: Readings in Chinese Literary and Cultural Theory
courses.desc: Close readings of selected texts in premodern criticism and theory.

courses.title: Studies in Traditional Chinese Narrative and Prose
courses.desc: Two-quarter seminar in traditional Chinese narrative and prose, with topics varying from year to year.

courses.title: Studies in Traditional Chinese Narrative and Prose
courses.desc: Two-quarter seminar in traditional Chinese narrative and prose, with topics varying from year to year.

courses.title: Studies in Traditional Chinese Poetry
courses.desc: Two-quarter seminar in traditional Chinese poetry, with topics varying from year to year.

courses.title: Studies in Traditional Chinese Poetry
courses.desc: Two-quarter seminar in traditional Chinese poetry, with topics varying from year to year.

courses.title: Studies in Modern Chinese Literature
courses.desc: Two-quarter seminar in modern Chinese literature, with topics varying from year to year. Research paper required.

courses.title: Studies in Modern Chinese Literature
courses.desc: Two-quarter seminar in modern Chinese literature, with topics varying from year to year. Research paper required.

courses.title: Studies in Chinese Literature and Cultural Theory
courses.desc: Seminar in Chinese literature and cultural theory, with topics varying from year to year. Research paper required.

courses.title: Topics in Chinese Literature and Culture
courses.desc: Seminar in Chinese literature and culture, with topics varying from year to year. Research paper required.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Directed research on topic determined in consultation with faculty member. A term paper or project is required.

courses.title: Dissertation Research
courses.desc: Dissertation research with Chinese faculty.

courses.title: Methods II: Probability and Statistics
courses.desc: Modeling and analysis of engineering problems under uncertainty. Engineering applications of probability and statistical concepts and methods.

courses.title: Introduction to Computational Problem Solving
courses.desc: Introduction to computer programming within a numerical computing environment (MATLAB or similar) including types of data representation, graphical display of data, and development of modular programs with application to engineering analysis and problem solving.  Course may be offered online.

courses.title: Computational Problem Solving
courses.desc: Engineering analysis and problem solving using MATLAB (or similar), including matrix algebra, solving systems of linear and nonlinear equations, numerical integration of ordinary differential equations (ODEs) and coupled ODEs, and analysis of numerical errors.  Course may be offered online.

courses.title: Statics
courses.desc: Addition and resolution of forces, distributed forces, equivalent system of forces centroids, first moments, moments and products on inertia, equilibrium of rigid bodies, trusses, beams, cables.  Course may be offered online.

courses.title: Contemporary and Emerging Environmental Challenges
courses.desc: Introduces contemporary and emerging environmental challenges, illustrates links between human behavior, environmental policy, and engineering practices, examines policy options in the context of current institutions, and introduces tools and frameworks to reach sound economic, social, and environmental solutions.  Course may be offered online.

courses.title: Dynamics
courses.desc: Introduction to the kinematics and dynamics of particles and rigid bodies. The Newton-Euler, Work/Energy, and Impulse/Momentum methods are explored for ascertaining the dynamics of particles and rigid bodies. An engineering design problem using these fundamental principles is also undertaken.

courses.title: Civil Engineering Practicum I
courses.desc: Introduction to civil engineering through presentations on structural, environmental, water, and transportation systems. Introduction to graphics. Graphical visualization and communication using hand and computer sketching. Fundamentals of Computer Aided Design (CAD) using AutoCad. Laboratory sessions. Materials fee.

courses.title: Civil Engineering Practicum II
courses.desc: Principles of surveying; fundamentals of Geographic Information Systems (GIS); introduction to the state-of-the-art and future areas of the profession, including applications of advanced technology and computers; Introduction to visualization and communication of design concepts; laboratory sessions.   Course may be offered online. Materials fee.

courses.title: Methods III:  Modeling, Economics, and Management
courses.desc: Analysis, modeling, and management of civil engineering systems. Statistics and system performance studies, probabilistic models and simulation, basic economics and capital investments, project elements and organization, managerial concepts and network technique, project scheduling. Emphasis on real-world examples. Laboratory sessions.

courses.title: Methods IV: Systems Analysis and Decision-Making
courses.desc: Analysis and optimization for decision-making in civil and infrastructural systems. Topics include linear programming formulations and solution algorithms, network models, and logistical models. Emphasis is on project-level and managerial decision-making and selection from alternative designs.

courses.title: Transportation Systems I: Analysis and Design
courses.desc: Introduction to analysis and design of fundamental transportation system components, basic elements of geometric and pavement design, vehicle flow and elementary traffic, basic foundations of transportation planning and forecasting. Laboratory sessions.

courses.title: Transportation Systems II:  Operations & Control
courses.desc: Introduction to fundamentals of urban traffic engineering, including data collection, analysis, and design. Traffic engineering studies, traffic flow theory, traffic control devices, traffic signals, capacity and level of service analysis of freeways and urban streets. Laboratory sessions.

courses.title: Transportation Systems III: Planning and Forecasting
courses.desc: Theoretical foundations of transportation planning, design, and analysis methods. Theory and application of aggregate and disaggregate models for land use development, trip generation, destination, mode, and route choice. Transportation network analysis. Planning, design, and evaluation of system alternatives.

courses.title: Transportation Systems IV: Freeway Operations and Control
courses.desc: Fundamentals of traffic on urban freeways, including data collection analysis, and design. Traffic engineering studies, traffic flow theory, freeway traffic control devices, capacity, and level of service analysis of freeways and highways. Laboratory sessions.

courses.title: Soil Mechanics
courses.desc: Mechanics of soils, composition and classification of soils, compaction, compressibility and consolidation, shear strength, seepage, bearing capacity, lateral earth pressure, retaining walls, piles.

courses.title: Soil Mechanics Laboratory
courses.desc: Laboratory procedures of soil testing for engineering problems.  Materials fee.

courses.title: Introduction to Earthquake Engineering
courses.desc: Plate tectonics. Structural dynamics. Earthquake magnitude, intensity, and frequency. Seismic damage to structures. Earthquake load prediction including response spectra, normal mode, and direct integration techniques. The basis of building code earthquake load requirements for buildings.

courses.title: Mechanics of Materials
courses.desc: Stresses and strains, strain-stress diagrams, axial deformations, torsion, bending and shear stresses in beams, shear force and bending moment diagrams, combined stresses, principal stresses, Mohr's circle, deflection of beams, columns.

courses.title: Mechanics of Materials Laboratory
courses.desc: Experimental methods and fundamentals for mechanics of materials analysis.  Materials fee.

courses.title: Structural Analysis
courses.desc: Fundamentals of structural analysis and loading. Deformation of statically determinate and indeterminate structures. Influence lines. Structural systems.

courses.title: Structural Timber Design
courses.desc: Design of timber structures. Beams, columns, beam-columns, roof, and connections.

courses.title: Reinforced Concrete Design
courses.desc: Ultimate strength design. Design of reinforced concrete beam sections. Design for shear and deflection. Design of columns. Design of isolated and combined footings. Laboratory sessions.   Materials fee.

courses.title: Computer Methods in Structural Analysis and Design
courses.desc: Matrix techniques for indeterminate framed structures. Computer implementation using the stiffness method. Software packages for design of reinforced concrete, steel, and/or timber structures.

courses.title: Structural Steel Design
courses.desc: Design in steel of tension members, beams, columns, welded and bolted connections; eccentrically loaded and moment resistant joints; plate girders. Plastic design; load and resistance factor design. Composite construction; introduction to computer-aided design.

courses.title: Foundation Design
courses.desc: Applications of soil mechanics principles to the analysis and design of shallow foundations, retaining walls, pile foundations, and braced cuts. Design criteria: bearing capacity, working loads and tolerable settlements, structural integrity of the foundation element. Damage from construction operations.

courses.title: Environmental Processes
courses.desc: Introduction to environmental processes in air and water, mass balances, and transport phenomena. Fundamentals of water-quality engineering including water and wastewater treatment.

courses.title: Introduction to Environmental Chemistry
courses.desc: Basic concepts from general, physical, and analytical chemistry as they relate to environmental engineering. Particular emphasis on the fundamentals of equilibrium and kinetics as they apply to acid-base chemistry, gas solubility, and redox reactions. Laboratory sessions.  Materials fee.

courses.title: Wastewater Treatment Process Design
courses.desc: Design of biological treatment processes. Topics include attached and suspended growth, aeration, anaerobic systems, process control, and economics. Design projects included.   Materials fee.

courses.title: Carbon and Energy Footprint Analysis
courses.desc: Process design for wastewater treatment. Mass- and energy-balance analysis applied to water and wastewater treatment systems. Case studies include analysis of water supply, treatment, reclamation, and reuse.

courses.title: Physical-Chemical Treatment Processes
courses.desc: Theory and dynamics of physical and chemical separation processes in water and wastewater treatment. Topics include coagulation, sedimentation, filtration, gas-transfer, membrane separations, and adsorption.

courses.title: Environmental Microbiology for Engineers
courses.desc: Fundamental and applied principles of microbiology. Structures and functions of microorganisms, the microbiology of water, wastewater and soil used in environmental engineering, and the impact of microorganisms on human and environmental health.

courses.title: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics
courses.desc: Thermodynamic and mechanical fluid properties; fluid statics; control volume and differential approaches for mass, momentum, and energy; dimensional analysis and similarity.

courses.title: Water Resources Engineering
courses.desc: Principles governing the analysis and design of water resource systems including pressurized pipelines, pipe networks, channels, and ground water. Coverage of fluid mass, momentum and energy conservation, flow resistance, and related laboratory measurements in different systems. Materials fee.

courses.title: Groundwater Hydrology
courses.desc: Topics include conservation of fluid mass, storage properties of porous media, matrix compressibility, boundary conditions, flow nets, well hydraulics, groundwater chemistry, and solute transport. Design projects and computer applications included.

courses.title: Watershed Modeling
courses.desc: Basic principles of hydrologic modeling are practiced. Concepts of watershed delineation, land use change impact, design studies, and GIS tools are discussed. Focus on the USACE (HEC) software tools (HEC-HMS, and HEC-RAS) along with their associated GIS interfaces.

courses.title: Hydrology
courses.desc: Elements of the hydrologic cycle including precipitation, infiltration, evapotranspiration, ground water, and runoff. Unit Hydrograph theory and routing methods. Introduction to precipitation/runoff relationship and watershed modeling. Statistical methods and flood frequency analysis.

courses.title: Fluid Mechanics of Open Channels
courses.desc: Fundamentals of fluid motion in open channels. Navier-Stokes equations and one-dimensional momentum and energy principles. Topics include rapidly varied flow, flow resistance and turbulence, gradually varied flow, unsteady flow, and computational methods for channel flow modeling.

courses.title: Senior Design Practicum I
courses.desc: Team designs land development project including infrastructural, environmental, circulation aspects. Focus on traffic impact studies, design of roads, geometry, signals, geotechnical and hydrological analysis, design of structural elements, economic analysis. Oral/Written interim and final design reports. Laboratory sessions.

courses.title: Senior Design Practicum II
courses.desc: Team designs land development project including infrastructural, environmental, circulation aspects. Focus on traffic impact studies, design of roads, geometry, signals, geotechnical and hydrological analysis, design of structural elements, economic analysis. Oral/Written interim and final design reports. Laboratory sessions.

courses.title: Senior Design Practicum III
courses.desc: Team designs land development project including infrastructural, environmental, circulation aspects. Focus on traffic impact studies, design of roads, geometry, signals, geotechnical and hydrological analysis, design of structural elements, economic analysis. Oral/Written interim and final design reports. Laboratory sessions.

courses.title: Special Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Civil and Environmental Engineering. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Group Study
courses.desc: Group study of selected topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.desc: For undergraduate Engineering majors in supervised but independent reading, research, or design. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.desc: Supervised independent reading, research, or design for undergraduate Engineering majors. Students taking individual study for design credit are to submit a written paper to the instructor and to the Undergraduate Student Affairs Office in the School of Engineering.

courses.title: GIS for Civil and Environmental Engineering
courses.desc: GIS for CEE provides an introduction to Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and their various applications in civil and environmental engineering. Topics include GIS data formats, data queries, spatial and attribute data, spatial data analysis, coordinate systems, raster data analysis.

courses.title: Travel Demand Analysis I
courses.desc: Fundamentals of transportation systems analysis. Theoretical aspects of travel demand. Travel behavior. Modeling of performance characteristics and costs of transportation modes. In-depth presentation of travel demand modeling techniques. Development of travel choice models including mode, route, and destination choice. Equilibrium.

courses.title: Travel Demand Analysis II
courses.desc: Methods of discrete choice analysis and their applications in the modeling of transportation systems. Emphasis on the development of a sound understanding of theoretical aspects of discrete choice modeling that are useful in many applications in travel demand analysis.

courses.title: Travel Demand Analysis III: Activity-based Approaches
courses.desc: The methodological underpinnings of activity-based travel demand modeling.  Presents methodologies within the context of a generalization of discrete choice modeling approaches, emphasizing the distinctions that separtate these two approaches and presenting appropriate mathematical and statistical tools to address these distinctions.

courses.title: Transportation Systems Analysis I
courses.desc: Introduction to mathematical methods and models to address logistics and urban transportation problems. Techniques include stochastic models, queueing theory, linear programming, and introductory non-linear optimization.

courses.title: Transportation Systems Analysis II
courses.desc: Advanced mathematical methods and models to address logistics and urban transportation problems. Topics include network flows, advanced optimization techniques, network models, and heuristic algorithms.

courses.title: Transit Systems Planning
courses.desc: Planning methods for public transportation in urban areas. Technological and operating characteristics of vehicles, facilities, and systems.  Short-range planning techniques: data collection and analysis, demand analysis, mode choice, operational strategies, financial analysis.  Design of systems to improve performance.

courses.title: Transportation Systems III: Planning and Forecasting
courses.desc: Theoretical foundations of transportation planning, design, and analysis methods. Theory and application of aggregate and disaggregate models for land use development, trip generation, destination, mode, and route choice. Transportation network analysis. Planning, design, and evaluation of system alternatives.

courses.title: Transportation Data Analysis I
courses.desc: Statistical analysis of transportation data sources. Analysis of categorical and ordinal data. Regression and advanced multivariate analysis methods such as discriminant analysis, canonical correlation, and factor analysis. Sampling techniques, sample error and bias, survey instrument design.

courses.title: Transportation Planning Models II
courses.desc: Design and application of comprehensive transportation models. Network development, demand modeling, and equilibrium assignment. Model calibration, validation, prediction, and evaluation. Regional modeling, site impact analysis, and circulation studies. Design of transportation alternatives.

courses.title: Traffic Flow Theory I
courses.desc: Traffic measurement and fundamental speed-density-flow relationships. Kinematic models. Shock waves. Statistical-kinetic theory of traffic. Introductory car-following principles and stability. Gap acceptance. Platoon dispersion.  Two-fluid model. Queueing process. Multi-regime and catastrophe models.  Higher-order continuum models. Microscopic and macroscopic simulation.

courses.title: Traffic Flow Theory II
courses.desc: Advanced mathematical analysis of vehicular flow. Detailed treatise on car-following models. Fourier and Laplace analysis of stability problems. Perturbation analysis. Derivation of macroscopic traffic flow relationships from microscopic considerations. Advanced hydrodynamic theory.

courses.title: Urban Transportation Networks I
courses.desc: Analytical approaches and algorithms to the formulation and solution of the equilibrium assignment problem for transportation networks. Emphasis on user equilibrium (UE) comparison with system optimal, mathematical programming formulation, supply functions, estimation. Estimating origin-destination matrices, network design problems.

courses.title: Urban Transportation Networks II
courses.desc: Advanced analysis, optimization, and modeling of transportation networks. Topics include advanced static and dynamic traffic assignment algorithms, linear and nonlinear multi-commodity network flow optimization, network simplex, and network control problems.

courses.title: Traffic Systems Operations and Control I
courses.desc: Introduction to operation, control and analysis of arterial and freeway traffic systems.  Control concepts, traffic stream principles, detectors, local controllers, system masters, traffic signal and ramp metering timing principles, traffic measurement technologies, traffic delay principles.

courses.title: Traffic Systems Operations and Control II
courses.desc: Advanced topics related to operation, control, and analysis of arterial and freeway traffic systems. Control concepts, traffic stream principles, detectors, local controllers, system masters, traffic signal and ramp metering timing principles.

courses.title: Foundation Engineering
courses.desc: Essentials for design and analysis of structural members that transmit superstructure loads to the ground. Topics include subsurface investigations, excavation, dewatering, bracing, footing, mat foundations, piles and pile foundations, caissons and cofferdams, other special foundations.

courses.title: Geotech Earthquake Engineering
courses.desc: In-situ and laboratory determination of dynamic soil properties, liquefaction of soil, cyclic softening of clays, seismic compression and settlement analyses, ground improvement methods, seismic slope stability, introduction to soil structure interaction.

courses.title: Advanced Strength of Materials
courses.desc: Beams on elastic foundations. Combined axial and lateral loads. Curved beams. Unsymmetric bending. Shear center. Stresses and strains. Basic equations for theory of elasticity. Energy principles. Theory of torsion. Combined bending and torsion.

courses.title: Mechanics of Composite Materials
courses.desc: Stress-strain relationship for orthotropic materials; invariant properties of an orthotropic lamina; biaxial strength theory for an orthotropic lamina; mechanics of materials approach to stiffness; elasticity approach to stiffness; classical lamination theory; strength of laminates; statistical theory of fatigue damage.

courses.title: Structural Dynamics
courses.desc: Vibration of discrete and continuous mass elastic systems. Isolation and transmissability. Dynamic recording instruments. Introduction to nonlinear theory of vibration. Response of structures to earthquake, traffic, and wind loads. Response spectra concepts. Normal mode analysis. Numerical integration techniques.

courses.title: Earthquake Engineering
courses.desc: Earthquake magnitude, intensity, and frequency. Seismic damage to structures. Earthquake load prediction including response spectra, normal mode, and direct integration techniques. The basis of building code earthquake load requirements for buildings. Seismic response of special structures. Lifeline engineering.

courses.title: Finite Element Method in Structural Engineering
courses.desc: Finite element concepts in structural engineering including variational formulations, shape functions, elements assembly, convergence and computer programming. Stiffness of truss, beam, and frame members, two- and three-dimensional solids, plate and shell elements. Static, vibration, stability, and inelastic analysis.
