courses.desc: Traces the anthropological and comparative cultural study of law from the nineteenth century to the present; briefly surveys the diversity of recorded legal cultures and critically examines key concepts which have been used to describe and classify them.

courses.title: US Legal Thought
courses.desc: Evolution of legal thought in socio-historical context from 19th century to present; emphasizes the rise and fall of legal classicism and modern socio-legal critiques, including the law and society movement, critical legal studies, feminist legal theory, and critical race studies.

courses.title: Sociology of Law
courses.desc: Examines law creation and law enforcement in their social and political context. Discusses the major theories of law and the modern state, and presents case studies in order to evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of these theoretical perspectives.

courses.title: Psychology and the Law
courses.desc: Psychological assumptions of the American legal system and mental health aspects of provision of criminal justice services. Civil commitment, insanity defense, competence to stand trial, jury selection, eyewitness identification. Use of police, courts, correctional institutions in prevention of behavior disorder.

courses.title: Crime and Public Policy
courses.desc: Explores nature and dimensions of crime in America and uses and limits of various strategies to control it. Topics include growth of imprisonment, the problem of domestic violence, the death penalty, gun control, and the potential of crime prevention programs.

courses.title: Deviance
courses.desc: Perspectives on deviance and criminality in behavior, institution, community, and myth. The suitability of contemporary theories of deviant behavior.

courses.title: Criminological Theory
courses.desc: Explores the question of crime causation from a number of theoretical perspectives in the social sciences. Schools of thought examined include utilitarianism, positivism, human ecology, social structural approaches, social process (learning) theories, labeling, and radical-critical (political) perspectives.

courses.title: Juvenile Delinquency
courses.desc: Patterns of delinquent behavior, theories that explain behavior, current research aimed at enhancing exploratory power. Attempts to prevent and control delinquency are put in historical perspective. Development of the current juvenile justice system and evolution of modern juvenile law.

courses.title: Community Context of Crime
courses.desc: Examines the social context of high-crime communities, with special emphasis on the problems of poverty, joblessness, economic inequality, and racial discrimination. Assesses debates on the causes of these problems, and on the most effective policies to combat them.

courses.title: Theories of Punishment
courses.desc: Survey of the various schools of thought regarding formal punishment theory. The purposes of legal sanctions are examined, including those of deterrence, rehabilitation, retribution, and incapacitation. Considers problems in realizing formal goals of punishment in practice.

courses.title: Legal Sanctions and Social Control
courses.desc: Examination of criminal sanctions as mechanisms of social control. Includes the nature, function, and organization of courts as sanction generating institutions, and problems associated with punishing white-collar and corporate illegalities.

courses.title: Gender and Social Control
courses.desc: Examines the legal system's use of sex as an organizing characteristic, focusing particularly on sameness and difference feminism, and tracing the evolution of equal treatment of men and women in the areas of constitutional rights, employment, education, and military service.

courses.title: Miscarriages of Justice
courses.desc: Systematically describes, explains, and analyzes the causes and consequences of the wrongful accusation, prosecution, incarceration, and sometimes even execution, of the innocent in the American criminal justice system.

courses.title: Prisons, Punishment, and Corrections
courses.desc: A review of how the U.S. punishes and rehabilitates convicted law violators. The conflicts among the major purposes of sentencing—rehabilitation, deterrence, incapacitation—are discussed, as well as the effects of different sanctions on public safety, offender rehabilitation, and justice system costs.

courses.title: Race, Ethnicity, and Social Control
courses.desc: Provides a historical and sociological survey of racial and ethnic group relations in contexts of crime control, emphasizing the roles of racial ideology, structural racism, and social movements in shaping these dynamic relations, and their significance to American liberal democracy.

courses.title: Imprisonment and Reentry
courses.desc: Offers an overview of imprisonment and reentry in the contemporary United States. Examines the development of the prison in the United States and explores changes in its composition, structure, and purpose over time.

courses.title: Domestic Violence
courses.desc: General perspectives about domestic violence and theoretical accounts about what causes such behavior.

courses.title: Violence in Intimate Relationships
courses.desc: Responses to various forms of domestic violence, such as intimate partner violence and child abuse. Covers barriers to reporting to the police, and prosecutors and courts. Human services, such as safety planning for victims, treatment programs, and restorative justice approaches.

courses.title: Law and Inequality
courses.desc: Various aspects of the law as related to three specific areas of inequality: immigration and immigrants, race, and gender. The role of law as a tool of social reform and limitations of the legal system historically in resolving inequality issues.

courses.title: Constitutional Law
courses.desc: Examines the First and Fourteenth Amendments, focusing on freedom of speech and religion, and the incorporation of the Bill of Rights. Topics include political, symbolic, offensive, and obscene speech, student speech rights, and the free exercise and disestablishment of religion.

courses.title: Family Law
courses.desc: Examines legal issues surrounding marriage, cohabitation, divorce, child custody and support, adoption, and the rights of parents and children in the family context. The findings of social science research are used to illuminate the legal issues.

courses.title: Mental Health and the Justice System
courses.desc: Covers the history of criminalization of persons with mental illness; challenges and needs; civil and outpatient commitment; law enforcement responses; mentally ill in jails and prisons; community supervision strategies; and reentry strategies for offenders with mental illness.

courses.title: Child Development, the Law, and Social Policy
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C. Recommended: PSCI 111D or PSCI 112D.
courses.desc: Examines the rights of children and adolescents in the U.S. and internationally; law and policy with regard to the family, government services, health care, education, juvenile justice and the labor market; and the connection between child development, law and policy.

courses.title: Hate Crimes
courses.desc: Examines the causes, manifestations, and consequences of hate crimes and the larger social context within which they occur. The politics and dynamics of intergroup violence born of bigotry and manifested as discrimination; social policy designed to control bias-motivated violence.

courses.title: Environmental Law and Policy
courses.desc: Environmental law as a combination of traditional legal principles and newly created statutes, rules, and decisions applied to environmental protection. Investigates roles of courts, legislature, executive branch and administrative agencies, and private citizens attempting to regulate environmental quality.

courses.title: Seminar on Gangs
courses.desc: An overview of gangs, including the nature and definition of gangs; types of gangs; diversity of membership; theoretical explanations; criminal behavior; drug use and sales; law enforcement responses; gangs in correctional institutions; intervention and prevention strategies; and public policy issues.

courses.title: Organized Crime and American Society
courses.desc: Examination of the phenomenon of American organized crime from a sociological perspective. Explanation of methods by which organized crime is tolerated at various levels of society. Emphasis on ways in which "underworld" interests interact with legitimate economic and political institutions.

courses.title: Forensic Science, Law, and Society
courses.desc: Examines use of "forensic science" to resolve issues arising in criminal cases including crime scene analysis, DNA testing, fingerprints, trace evidence comparisons, profiling, lie detectors, other forensic techniques; evaluation, statistical characterization, and legal admissibility of evidence; regulation of forensic laboratories.

courses.title: Homicide and Suicide
courses.desc: Examines similarities and differences among homicide and suicide, two major causes of death.

courses.title: Victimless Crimes
courses.desc: Examines major theoretical, empirical, and policy-oriented research related to the design, implementation, and analysis of government intervention, through the criminal sanction, in the spheres of vice and morality.

courses.title: Mass Incarceration and Social Inequality in America
courses.desc: Explores the origins and consequences of mass incarceration; extraordinarily high incarceration rates within particular demographic groups above and beyond historical levels in the U.S. Theoretical explanations for, and current policy debates around, mass incarceration are covered.

courses.title: Forensic Psychology: Advanced Seminar
courses.prereqs: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C) and PSCI 102C and (PSCI 178S or CRM/LAW C149)
courses.desc: Focuses on the psychology of criminal offending, particularly violent behavior. Examines violence, sexual offending, and mental disorder related to crime with regard to clinical assessment and treatment; mental health services within forensic institutions.

courses.title: Police and Change
courses.desc: Organizational efforts to modify police conduct are addressed by focusing on the history of policing in the United States including training, education, and the contributions of women.

courses.title: Surveillance and Society
courses.desc: Explores the development and deployment of surveillance technologies in contemporary society. The social and legal impact of surveillance technologies, in such areas as crime control, privacy, trust, community, democracy, and the war on terror.

courses.title: White-Collar Crime
courses.desc: Examines criminal activity in business and corporate enterprise, organizations, and the professions. Theories regarding the causes and control of white-collar and corporate crime are covered as well as the numerous definitions of these terms.

courses.title: Criminal Law
courses.desc: Deals specifically with the substantive nature of criminal law and its historical development. Focuses on understanding the development of fundamental doctrinal principles upon which criminal law is based, including mens rea, actus reus, homicide, causation, group criminality, and exculpation.

courses.title: Government Crime
courses.desc: Examines the legal, organizational, and political issues involved in the generation and control of government lawlessness. Readings present historical and theoretical perspectives in the abuse of government authority and the ability of the legal system to control such behavior.

courses.title: Violence in Society
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Current theory and research on aggression; anger and violence as problems in individual and social functioning. Process and functions of anger examined with regard to normal behavior and psychopathology. The determinants, prevalence, and implications of violence in society are analyzed.

courses.title: The Legal Profession
courses.desc: Role of the legal profession in modern society, the diverse professional roles lawyers play, the American legal profession compared with that of other societies. "Litigation explosion," ethical problems, interactions between lawyers and other professionals, training and socialization of new lawyers.

courses.title: Cross-Cultural Research on Urban Gangs
courses.desc: Taking an urban policy approach, examines the background and contemporary traditions of gangs in several ethnic groups including African-, Asian-, and Mexican-Americans. Cross-cultural exploration of the varied facets of gang life. The major social-control institutions affecting them.

courses.title: Forensic Psychology
courses.desc: Forensic psychology is the interface between clinical psychology and the law. Emphasizes clinically relevant legal topics (insanity defense; competency to stand trial) and includes critical thinking about issues that arise when psychologists are involved in legal proceedings.

courses.title: Crime Hotspots
courses.desc: Criminological theories of local public safety hazards or hotspots are introduced. Spatial statistics are developed for different types of hotspots. Hotspot policing theories are introduced and research on the effectiveness of policing strategies is reviewed.

courses.title: Ethics and Politics of Justice
courses.desc: Theoretical perspective on how ethics and politics relate to criminal justice through an introduction to moral philosophy; consideration of specific theories of punishment and justice; and consideration of practical and empirical illustrations of the intersection of ethics, politics, and justice.

courses.title: Social Control of Delinquency
courses.desc: Assumes familiarity with theories of delinquency, the juvenile justice system, and elements of juvenile law. Explores socio-historical origins and evolution of juvenile justice, current research and policy on delinquency prevention and treatment, and future directions of law, policy, and practice.

courses.title: The Death Penalty
courses.desc: Examines why the U.S. continues to have a death penalty when so many other countries have abandoned it. Arguments for and against the death penalty are covered.

courses.title: Crime Measurement
courses.desc: The strengths and weaknesses of three crime measures (police reports, victim surveys, and offender self-reports) are illustrated through analyses of research articles. Common measurement problems are analyzed with a focus on reliability and validity.

courses.title: Extreme Punishment
courses.desc: Explores the history and law of America’s Eighth Amendment prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment, examining the death penalty, long prison sentences, harsh confinement conditions, and other punishments. Students debate practical, legal, and moral arguments for and against these punishments.

courses.title: Culture Change and the Mexican People
courses.desc: Reviews culture contact and colonization, innovation diffusion, acculturation, assimilation, culture conflict and marginality, modernization, urbanization, legal transformations. Mexico and the Southwestern U.S. are reviewed through several centuries to better appreciate the indigenous base of the Mexican people.

courses.title: Maritime Piracy, Law and Society
courses.desc: Explores the historical and contemporary images and reality of pirates and piracy since the 16th century across the globe through an analysis of primary sources, key historiographical and legal debates, and criminological theories.

courses.title: Immigration and Crime
courses.desc: Examines immigration and crime in the global context, highlighting immigrants as criminals and victims; immigration and crime control; immigrants’ perceptions of the criminal justice system; public discourse and public perception on immigration and crime; and human rights issues.

courses.title: Issues in Policing
courses.desc: Lectures and readings focus on the history and strategies of policing, measuring the quality of policing, and police misconduct. Strategies for enhancing the quality of policing for controlling misconduct are covered.

courses.title: Classics in Crime Cinema
courses.desc: A multidimensional understanding of crime films and how they shape public thinking about crime and criminals.

courses.title: Eyewitness Testimony
courses.desc: Faulty eyewitness testimony is a major cause of wrongful convictions. Covers the fast-growing topic of eyewitness testimony and memory for real-world events, both how psychologists study eyewitness capacity, and how the legal system has dealt with eyewitness issues.

courses.title: Critical Race Theory
courses.desc: Introduction to Critical Race Theory and key American cases on racial inequality. Using this literature, examines the possibilities and pitfalls of legal claims of race, gender, and sexuality discrimination in the age of colorblindness.

courses.title: Race and Incarceration
courses.desc: Examines the racial politics of mass incarceration through historical, empirical, theoretical, and legal frameworks. Focuses on race, gender, and sexual differences to develop a critique on policing, incarceration, and other forms of punishment.

courses.title: Power, Constructions of Deviance, and Social Control
courses.desc: Examines the forms and limits of power in the construction of social deviants. Theories of state power are covered to understand the prison system as a contemporary driver of social inequality. The collateral consequences of mass incarceration are discussed.

courses.title: Illegal Economics
courses.desc: How illegal firms function in illegal markets, why individuals participate in these groups and markets, and what federal, state, and local governments do to disrupt organized illegal activity.

courses.title: Controversies, Courts, Cultures: The Anthropology of Law
courses.desc: Assesses the contributions anthropology has made to legal scholarship, reviewing historical and contemporary themes. Considers both comparative questions of law’s norms, structures, and practices around the globe, and the specific insights anthropology offers about contemporary U.S. law.

courses.title: Social Media and The Law
courses.desc: Examines legal and policy issues raised by the rise of social media. Surveys how social networking platforms and other emerging technologies impact the right to privacy, public perceptions of judicial systems, and the law generally.

courses.title: Law and Modernity
courses.desc: The rise and spread of Enlightenment legal traditions, social contract theory, individual rights, ideologies of "liberty, equality, fraternity"; contradictions of liberal law, its understandings of "primitive" and "civilized"; pervasive myths of property, difference, race, and rights. Reading- and writing-intensive.

courses.title: Research Seminar in Criminology, Law and Society
courses.desc: Special topics research seminar. Content varies with interest of instructor. Capstone research opportunity with Criminology, Law and Society faculty members.

courses.title: Research Methods
courses.desc: An introduction to techniques of inductive methodologies, including qualitative interviewing and participant observation, and deductive methodologies, including survey research and experimental and quasi-experimental design. Provides a sound overview of research methodology with tools to pursue specific methods in greater depth.

courses.title: Land-Use Law
courses.desc: Investigates legal and institutional frameworks for development control. Review of constitutional issues implicated in land-use regulation. Traces development control historically and analyzes contemporary approaches to land-use control which reflect environmental and economic development concerns.

courses.title: Introduction to Criminology, Law and Society
courses.desc: Familiarizes students with the interrelated fields of criminology, law and society studies, and criminal justice studies. Organized around three well-established interdisciplinary literatures: criminology, sociolegal studies, and criminal justice studies.

courses.title: Legal Institutions and Society
courses.desc: Acquaints students with the institutions of U.S. legal system and its operations, as well as with the constitutional framework undergirding this system, and defines the relationship between U.S. citizens and government at a variety of levels.

courses.title: Police, Courts, and Corrections
courses.desc: Focuses on basic policy issues in the administration of the criminal justice system. The key elements of the criminal justice system are police, courts, and corrections. Prepares students for continued study of these organizations.

courses.title: Crime and Social Deviance
courses.desc: Examines the major social scientific perspectives on criminal and deviant behavior. Specific deviant and criminal activities are described and explained using established theoretical frameworks.

courses.title: Research Methods
courses.desc: Structures research methodology, the approach to developing and evaluating knowledge of the sciences for use in criminal justice professional activities. Special emphasis on differentiating scientific approaches from pseudo-science.

courses.title: Applied Statistics
courses.desc: Provides a basis for the use of fundamental statistical analysis techniques for solving public policy and management problems through a series of assignments, examinations, and online discussions and demonstrations.

courses.title: Public Policy, Crime, and Criminal Justice
courses.desc: Increases understanding of crime, violence, and the criminal justice system. Assesses the state of knowledge on key policy issues of our time. Discusses the contribution of communities, schools, employment, drugs, guns, and alcohol to crime and violence.

courses.title: Leadership
courses.desc: Introduces concepts, ideas, and theories about leadership and its operation. Explores leadership concepts through interviews with leaders from the community and fellow classmates.

courses.title: Social Problems, Law, and Policy
courses.desc: Capstone course for M.A.S. program in Criminology, Law and Society. Students choose a social problem related to crime, criminal justice, and law; relate the problem to legal and social issues; and devise a plan of action to research the problem.

courses.title: Hate Crime
courses.desc: Examines the causes, manifestations, and consequences of hate crimes, as well as the larger social context within which they occur, are reacted to, and seem to be proliferating.

courses.title: Sentencing and Corrections
courses.desc: Reviews U.S. attempts to punish and rehabilitate convicted law violators. Conflicts among major purposes of sentencing (rehabilitation, deterrence, incapacitation, and retribution) are discussed, as well as effects of different sanctions on public safety, offender rehabilitation, and justice system costs.

courses.title: Ethnography
courses.desc: Explores the theory and practice of ethnography with a focus on anthropology, the discipline most associated with ethnography. Students are exposed to the theoretical underpinnings of ethnographic work, traditional and innovative practices, and sample ethnographies.

courses.title: Organizational Perspectives on the Legal System
courses.desc: Familiarizes students with organization theory and research as ways to make sense of, navigate, and act on the legal system. Acquaints students with major frameworks in organization theory and their application to the system of legal organizations.

courses.title: Criminology: Micro Approaches
courses.desc: Introduces students to the dominant theories in modern criminology, their theoretical antecedents and extensions, major empirical tests and implications for programs, policy and practice, and focuses on micro-level, individual theories of crime causation. Formerly Criminology, Law and Society C233A.

courses.title: Criminology: Macro Approaches
courses.desc: Introduces students to the dominant theories in modern criminology, their theoretical antecedents and extensions, major empirical tests and implications for programs, policy and practices, and addresses macro-level theories of crime causation. Formerly Criminology, Law and Society C233B.

courses.title: Crime and Gender
courses.desc: Examines the legal, political, social, economic, and policy implications of making gender (primarily) and race (secondarily) the focus in the study of crime, criminal law, and the criminal justice system.

courses.title: Juvenile Delinquency
courses.desc: Examines the major theoretical perspectives regarding the onset, persistence, and desistance of juvenile delinquency, and examines empirical evidence for each perspective.

courses.title: Anthropology of Law
courses.desc: Law has been a key site of anthropological inquiry since the discipline's nineteenth-century origins. Course introduces and critically assesses the contributions anthropology has made to sociolegal lytic trends.

courses.title: White-Collar Crime
courses.desc: Examines the illegal behavior of individuals who commit crimes in the course of their employment. Special attention will be paid to ways in which power and organizational structure affect the behavior of the white-collar offenders.

courses.title: Law and Society I
courses.desc: Provides an introduction to the law and society field from its origins in social scientific, legal, and philosophical scholarship during the eighteenth, nineteenth, and early-twentieth centuries. Formerly Criminology, Law, and Society C239.

courses.title: Law and Society II
courses.desc: Building on Law and Society I, addresses contemporary issues in the field from mid-twentieth century to the present with emphasis on the degree to which the field's foundational assumptions are being challenged, refined, or confirmed through current research.

courses.title: Crime Hotspots
courses.desc: Focuses on the criminological theory of hotspots, beginning with the “when, where, and why” questions and ending with the practical policing strategies that have been developed to mitigate hotspot public safety hazards.

courses.title: Geographic Information Systems
courses.desc: Prepares students to become proficient in the basic GIS functionality including visualization, data management, and spatial analysis.

courses.title: Preventing Errors of Justice
courses.desc: Examines the types of errors that are made in the U.S. criminal justice system and how we might prevent these errors, including failures to convict guilty offenders as well as wrongful convictions of the innocent.

courses.title: Issues in Environmental Law and Policy
courses.desc: Treatment of legal and policy strategies for promoting environmental protection and deterring environmental degradation within the context of other societal objectives. Topical approach with a focus on problems of special interest to criminologists and to environmental policy specialists.

courses.title: Cybercrime, Cybersecurity, and Society
courses.desc: Introduces students to the world of cybercrime in the age of globally networked digital, and information and communication technologies (ICT). Presents a socio-legal approach to the study of cybercrime, cybersecurity, and how it relates to society.

courses.title: Immigration in the US: Economic, Fiscal, and Social Outcomes
courses.desc: The changing patterns of immigration in the U.S. and the role that immigrants play in our society. In particular, the economic and social outcomes of immigration, as well as the relationship between immigration, crime, and criminal justice policy.

courses.title: Public Policy
courses.desc: Explores different approaches to public policy analysis, the diverse conceptions of the goals and objectives that should be served by policy, and the appropriate role of the policy analyst.  Policy consequences are traced to indirect and subtle incentives and disincentives.

courses.title: Race and Justice Studies Proseminar
courses.desc: A year-long proseminar conducted by a team of instructors specializing in race and justice studies. Conceived as a reading and peer mentor group focusing on intellectual and professional development. Required for students pursuing the Race and Justice Studies emphasis.

courses.title: Race and Justice Studies Proseminar
courses.desc: A year-long proseminar conducted by a team of instructors specializing in race and justice studies. Conceived as a reading and peer mentor group focusing on intellectual and professional development. Required for students pursuing the Race and Justice Studies emphasis.

courses.title: Race and Justice Studies Proseminar
courses.desc: A year-long proseminar conducted by a team of instructors specializing in race and justice studies. Conceived as a reading and peer mentor group focusing on intellectual and professional development. Required for students pursuing the Race and Justice Studies emphasis.

courses.title: Race and Justice Studies Writing Seminar
courses.desc: A required writing-intensive seminar conducted by an instructor affiliated with the Race and Justice Studies emphasis. Students with manuscripts on relevant topics will read and critique peer manuscripts, and revise manuscripts toward completion of articles, dissertation chapters, and other publications.

courses.title: Special Topics in Race and Justice Studies
courses.desc: A seminar focused on special issues in race and justice studies.

courses.title: Eyewitness Testimony
courses.desc: Examines the evidence that shows that faulty eyewitness memory is the major cause of wrongful convictions. Explores what the legal system thinks of eyewitness testimony and how the legal system has dealt with eyewitness issues.

courses.title: Memory and the Law
courses.desc: Examines the controversial topic of repressed memory, or perception and memory of real-world events.

courses.title: Psychology and the Law
courses.desc: Overview of how psychology is applied to the civil and criminal justice systems, how case law shapes this application, and how legal decisions affect the direction of psychological research. Interdisciplinary approach to research in psychology, law, and/or  criminology.

courses.title: Contemporary Issues in Crime and Justice
courses.desc: Intensive reading and discussion of several recent works that raise critical issues for criminology and criminal justice policy, with a special emphasis on issues of inequality, diversity, and social justice.

courses.title: Special Topics in Criminology, Law and Society
courses.desc: Topics covered vary with interests of instructor.

courses.title: Professionalization Proseminar
courses.desc: Focuses on two areas that are key to scholarly and professional success in graduate school but are rarely discussed in a structured setting: 1) publishing in peer-reviewed academic journals; and 2) preparing for the academic job market.

courses.title: Professionalization Proseminar
courses.desc: Focuses on two areas that are key to scholarly and professional success in graduate school but are rarely discussed in a structured setting: 1) publishing in peer-reviewed academic journals; and 2) preparing for the academic job market.

courses.title: Professionalization Proseminar
courses.desc: Focuses on two areas that are key to scholarly and professional success in graduate school but are rarely discussed in a structured setting: 1) publishing in peer-reviewed academic journals; and 2) preparing for the academic job market.

courses.title: Doctoral Dissertation Research and Writing
courses.desc: Dissertation research with Criminology, Law and Society faculty.

courses.title: Directed Study
courses.desc: Directed study with Criminology, Law and Society faculty.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Independent research with Criminology, Law and Society faculty.

courses.title: Political Economy: Methods and Critique
courses.desc: Introduction to canonical texts in Marxism coupled with an examination of the questions of race, gender, ethnicity, and sexuality that distend the calculus of the canon’s assumptive logic. May be taken after CLT&THY 200B.

courses.title: Studies in Literary Theory and Its History
courses.desc: Introduction to criticism and aesthetics for beginning graduate students. Readings from continental, English, and American theorists.

courses.title: Advanced Theory Seminar
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Criticism Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Political Economy: Methods and Critique
courses.desc: Introduction to canonical texts in Marxism coupled with an examination of the questions of race, gender, ethnicity, and sexuality that distend the calculus of the canon’s assumptive logic. May be taken after CLT&THY 200B.

courses.title: Libidinal Economy: Methods and Critique
courses.desc: Introduction to canonical texts in psychoanalysis coupled with an examination of the questions of race, gender, ethnicity, and sexuality that distend the calculus of the canon’s assumptive logic. May be taken before CLT&THY 200A.

courses.title: Theory from Below
courses.desc: Introduction to systems of thought understudied or undervalued in academic canons--for instance, systems constituted in communities' practices or theories that do not seek permanence or generality.

courses.title: A Critical Theory of Subalternity
courses.desc: Examines the importance of subaltern studies for the study of modern history, postcolonial studies, social theory, and cultural studies. Also considers subaltern studies within a larger set of debates in structuralism, post-structuralism, Marxism, and post-Marxism.

courses.title: Crossing Borders: Empire and Im/migration
courses.desc: Utilizes historically-based intersectional analysis to explore the connections between U.S. empire and migration; border formation and incarceration; as well as identity and structural forms of hierarchy.

courses.title: Freedom Dreams: Subaltern Forms of Resistance
courses.desc: Explores how subjugated peoples have creatively and collectively resisted oppression. Explores how individuals and communities envision a more just society, experiment with political strategies, and create meaningful legacies.

courses.title: Resistance Spaces
courses.desc: Examines the relationship between the production of space and the operation of power in cultural studies and critical social theory.

courses.title: Ethics, Erotics, and Will: Gendered Black Politics, Sexualized Racisms, and the Humanities
courses.desc: Introduces doctoral students to an interdisciplinary conversation about black queer sexuality and black heteropatriarchy. Uses disciplinary formations as a tool for understanding knowledge formations about the shifting relations that constitute sexuality, gender, and racial blackness.

courses.title: Afro-Pessimism and the Status of the Subject
courses.desc: Afro-Pessimism theorizes the Black as a being against which all other beings become legible as human subjects. Focuses on either the subject of psychoanalysis or the subject of capital accumulation in their explorations of the antagonism between Blackness.

courses.title: Introduction to Performance Studies
courses.desc: Introduces students to key issues and critical methods within the field of performance studies. These include performance/performativity, liveness, everyday life, auto-ethnography, archive/repertoire, affect and performance, and disidentificatory practices.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Limited to students who have not yet received the M.A. degree.

courses.title: Topics in Culture and Theory
courses.desc: Seminars on various topics in Culture and Theory.

courses.title: Directed Reading
courses.desc: Directed readings on a specific topic agreed upon by students and their instructors. Limited to students who have completed their M.A. degree and are preparing for their qualifying exam.

courses.title: Dissertation Research
courses.desc: Dissertation research in Culture and Theory.

courses.title: Dance Health and Injury Prevention
courses.desc: An overview of factors that affect the health of dancers. Includes evaluation of general health measures and prevention and management of common dance injuries.

courses.title: Scientific Concepts of Health
courses.desc: Introduction to the scientific foundations of health, emphasizing those pertaining to success in college and lifetime wellness. Includes principles of cardiorespiratory, musculoskeletal, flexibility, and nutritional fitness. A variety of learning experiences will be offered to apply science to real life.

courses.title: Social Dance
courses.desc: Contemporary and historical forms.  Current ballroom, disco, and Western square dance forms; Latin ballroom dances; dances from the 20s, 30s, and 40s.

courses.title: Music for Dancers
courses.desc: Emphasis on the development of musical skills most pertinent to the dancer: vocabulary, notational literacy, rhythmic and melodic acuity, score reading, and fundamental analysis; working with live accompaniment.

courses.title: Studio Workshop in Ballet I
courses.desc: Beginning ballet: fundamentals and principles of classical ballet with an emphasis on technique.

courses.title: Studio Workshop in Ballet I
courses.desc: Beginning ballet: fundamentals and principles of classical ballet with an emphasis on technique.

courses.title: Studio Workshop in Ballet I
courses.desc: Beginning ballet: fundamentals and principles of classical ballet with an emphasis on technique.

courses.title: Men's Studio Workshop in Ballet
courses.desc: Emphasis on men's traditional ballet, techniques, and movements.

courses.title: Studio Workshop in Modern I
courses.desc: Fundamentals of modern dance:  principles of modern tradition developed from Graham, Humphrey, and Wigman.

courses.title: Studio Workshop in Modern I
courses.desc: Fundamentals of modern dance:  principles of modern tradition developed from Graham, Humphrey, and Wigman.

courses.title: Studio Workshop in Modern I
courses.desc: Fundamentals of modern dance:  principles of modern tradition developed from Graham, Humphrey, and Wigman.

courses.title: Studio Workshop on Jazz I
courses.desc: Fundamentals of jazz:  principles of jazz dance and contemporary forms incorporating the personal point of view of the instructor.

courses.title: Studio Workshop on Jazz I
courses.desc: Fundamentals of jazz:  principles of jazz dance and contemporary forms incorporating the personal point of view of the instructor.

courses.title: Studio Workshop on Jazz I
courses.desc: Fundamentals of jazz:  principles of jazz dance and contemporary forms incorporating the personal point of view of the instructor.

courses.title: Workshop in Tap I
courses.desc: Beginning tap:  principles of rhythm and basic tap steps.

courses.title: Workshop in Tap I
courses.desc: Beginning tap:  principles of rhythm and basic tap steps.

courses.title: Workshop in Tap I
courses.desc: Beginning tap:  principles of rhythm and basic tap steps.

courses.title: Choreography
courses.desc: Beginning-to-intermediate study of principles of dance composition.  May include composition assignments for stage and video.  By audition, works may be shown quarterly in public studio performances.

courses.title: Choreography
courses.desc: Beginning-to-intermediate study of principles of dance composition.  May include composition assignments for stage and video.  By audition, works may be shown quarterly in public studio performances.

courses.title: Choreography
courses.desc: Beginning-to-intermediate study of principles of dance composition.  May include composition assignments for stage and video.  By audition, works may be shown quarterly in public studio performances.

courses.title: Introduction to Ballet and Modern Dance
courses.desc: Survey of nineteenth and twentieth-century ballet, modern dance, and theatre dance.

courses.title: American Ballet and Modern Dance since 1900
courses.desc: A survey of American ballet and modern dance in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. Lectures are supplemented by video.

courses.title: Topics in World Dance
courses.desc: Various topics in world dance studies focusing on historical, social, and cultural contexts.

courses.title: Dance in Feature Film
courses.desc: Dance in film musicals and commercial dance films, concentrating especially on films from the 1930s through the 1970s.

courses.title: What Dance Does: From Ballet to Hip-Hop
courses.desc: Explores the way dance reflects culture and embodies new ideas. Examples for viewing and analysis come from ballet (with roots in Europe) and hip-hop (with roots in the African diaspora). Themes include gender, perceived racial difference, identity.

courses.title: Dance History I
courses.desc: Global perspectives.  Topics and histories of dance and movement practices from various parts of the world.

courses.title: Dance History II
courses.desc: The history of dance in the western tradition from the Renaissance through the 19th century.

courses.title: Dance History III
courses.desc: The history of dance in the western tradition in the the 20th and 21st centuries.

courses.title: Kinesiology for Dance
courses.desc: The study of the production of dance movement by the musculoskeletal system. Anatomical and dynamic analysis of dance movement.

courses.title: Pilates
courses.desc: Basics of technique emphasizing alignment, breath control, correction of muscular imbalances.

courses.title: Pilates Reformer
courses.desc: Utilizes the Universal Reformer apparatus, aiding the student in core stabilization, correcting muscular imbalances, increasing flexibility, and improving strength.

courses.title: World Dance
courses.desc: Studio workshop of dances and movement sources of specified countries or areas.

courses.title: Teaching of Dance
courses.prereqs: DANCE 133A and DANCE 133B and DANCE 133C and DANCE 143A and DANCE 143B and DANCE 143C
courses.desc: Pedagogy.  The methods and theory of teaching dance forms.

courses.title: Costume Design for Dance
courses.desc: Costume design and construction specific to the body in motion. Theoretical study and practical execution.

courses.title: Pointe Class
courses.desc: Beginning and intermediate pointe work; principles of classical ballet with an emphasis on technique.

courses.title: Studio Workshop in Ballet II
courses.prereqs: (DANCE 30A and DANCE 30B and DANCE 30C) or audition. Prerequisites are for non-Dance majors only.

Course encourages freedom of exploration.

courses.desc: Overview of dance for film and choreography for the camera. Aesthetics of creating dance for the screen. Approaches for delivery of dance films to an audience, including projection, DVD, Web, and mobile devices. A final dance film project is required.

courses.title: Arts Management

courses.title: Independent Study

courses.title: Senior Thesis
courses.desc: Directed research or creative activity for senior Dance majors.  Research consists of a substantial essay on dance history, research in dance science, or the creation of original or reconstructed choreography.

courses.title: Seminar in Kinesiology for Dance

courses.title: Graduate Studio: World Dance

courses.title: Musical Resources
courses.desc: Detailed study of music as it relates to dance. Historical overview of musical form, style, and other elements.  Analysis of various affinities between music and dance.  Practical applications.

courses.title: Seminar in the Teaching of Dance Techniques
courses.desc: Principles and theories of teaching dance techniques. Supervised presentation and teaching of technique class.

courses.title: Mouse Developmental Genetics
courses.desc: Introduction to using the mouse in contemporary biomedical research. The biology and development of the laboratory mouse, methods for manipulation of the mouse genome and embryos, and examples of application of these methods to understand mammalian development and homeostasis.

courses.title: Topics in Systems Biology
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Systems Biology.

courses.title: Scientific Skills
courses.desc: Addresses and promotes the development of essential skills required in scientific and research careers, including scientific writing, effective presentation and communication, and mentoring skills.

courses.title: Principles of Genomics
courses.desc: A survey course of the principal subfields of genomics and their applications to biological and health sciences that will cover genome assembly and annotation, genome structure, comparative genomics, population genomics, functional genomics, and medical genomics.

courses.title: Cell Biology
courses.desc: A broadly based course including topics in extracellular matrix, cytoskeleton, organelle biogenesis, receptor-mediated endocytosis, signal transduction, cell cycle, and developmental biology.

courses.title: Systems Cell and Developmental Biology
courses.desc: Introduces concepts needed to understand cell and developmental biology at the systems level, i.e., how the parts (molecules) work together to create a complex output. Emphasis on using mathematical/computational modeling to expand/modify insights provided by intuition.

courses.title: Stem Cell Biology
courses.desc: The basic characteristics and development roles of embryonic, adult, and cancer stem cells in the human body and in model systems and the use of experimental and genetic methods to analyze and manipulate their properties.

courses.title: Colloquium in Developmental and Cell Biology
courses.desc: Contemporary research problems. Research students, faculty, and other invited speakers introduce research and review topics.

courses.title: Colloquium in Developmental and Cell Biology
courses.desc: Contemporary research problems. Research students, faculty, and other invited speakers introduce research and review topics.

courses.title: Colloquium in Developmental and Cell Biology
courses.desc: Contemporary research problems. Research students, faculty, and other invited speakers introduce research and review topics.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Introduction to Theatre
courses.desc: An interactive introduction to the world of theatre that serves to develop an appreciation of theatrical arts, to establish an awareness of landmarks within the performance history, and to create an understanding of the collaborative roles and departments that exist.

courses.title: The Rock and Roll Spectacle Show
courses.desc: A thorough overview to the development and cultural significance of the Rock 'n' Roll Spectacle show. Focus on historical and recent developments of the spectacle show, trends in the aesthetics of the field, and various sub-genres.

courses.title: Performing Rock 'N' Roll
courses.desc: Explores major movements in the history of rock 'n' roll in terms of performance, not virtuosity necessarily of the performers as musicians, rather as performances of aesthetics in modes of embodied ideology, iconoclastic spectacle, mixed media fashion, and subcultural formation.

courses.title: Performance Now
courses.desc: Exposes students to what is most current in the world of performance and theatre.  Begins with a series of lectures on the idea of performance, and the various theories that frame it.

courses.title: Performing Culture
courses.desc: Culture, aesthetics, and ideology (combined in the concept "subculture") work to fashion social identities. Using theories and methodologies of performance studies, with an emphasis on American culture, this course explores why and how culture is reinforced through performance.

courses.title: Culture in Performance
courses.desc: A three-quarter foundation series exploring the rich depth of theatre, drama, and other genres of performance across a wide variety of worldwide forms, for performer and audience.

courses.title: Culture in Performance
courses.desc: A three-quarter foundation series exploring the rich depth of theatre, drama, and other genres of performance across a wide variety of worldwide forms, for performer and audience.

courses.title: Culture in Performance
courses.desc: A three-quarter foundation series exploring the rich depth of theatre, drama, and other genres of performance across a wide variety of worldwide forms, for performer and audience.

courses.title: Acting
courses.desc: Focuses on Stanislavski-based terminology and technique through theatre exercises and improvisation. The first part of a one-year series in basic acting technique and discipline.

courses.title: Acting
courses.desc: Focuses on scene work and character development. The second part of a one-year series in basic acting technique and discipline.

courses.title: Acting
courses.desc: Focuses on monologues, auditions, callbacks, and the profession of acting. The third part of a one-year series in basic acting technique and discipline.

courses.title: Movement for Actors
courses.desc: A studio course in fundamentals of stretch, strength, and alignment; exploring spatial awareness and physical control through mime isolations, techniques, and related improvisation.

courses.title: Speech for the Theatre
courses.desc: An introductory course in voice and speech for actors, combining the body-based approach to voice developed by Fitzmaurice, and speech work of Knight and Thompson. Designed for the needs of actors and is not a public speaking course.

courses.title: Development of Drama
courses.desc: The development of Western Drama, concentrating on the drama’s intellectual, social, and artistic foundations. About 10 plays and supplementary critical material are read each quarter. Greek Drama through Shakespeare.

courses.title: Development of Drama
courses.desc: The development of Western Drama, concentrating on the drama’s intellectual, social, and artistic foundations. About 10 plays and supplementary critical material are read each quarter. Restoration Drama through Ibsen.

courses.title: Development of Drama
courses.desc: The development of Western Drama, concentrating on the drama’s intellectual, social, and artistic foundations. About 10 plays and supplementary material are read each quarter. Contemporary Drama. Post Naturalistic theatre.

courses.title: Introduction to Costume Design
courses.desc: Introduction to the process and procedures employed by the costume designer for the theatre. The elements of design are discussed in the context of character development, historical period, and style. Exercises extend to drawing, rendering, and investigation of human proportions.

courses.title: Introduction to Scenic Design
courses.desc: Introduction to the principles and practice of scenic design. Weekly problems include research into various periods and styles of production with an emphasis on the conceptual idea. Perspective drawing, rendering, and model building are covered in studio exercises and assignments.

courses.title: Introduction to Lighting Design
courses.desc: Introduction to the principles, theories, and equipment employed by the lighting designer for the stage.  Areas of investigation include history, technology, and script analysis. Detailed studio attention is given to the theory and practice of design.

courses.title: Introduction to Sound Design
courses.desc: Principles, theories, equipment use, and terminology employed by the sound designer for the stage.  Areas of study include history, technology, and script analysis.  Focuses on the theory and practice of design.

courses.title: Introduction to Stage Management
courses.desc: A basic study of theatrical, dance, and opera stage management practices, forms, and methods, from first script reading to closing night.  Opportunity to observe professionals at work in regional and touring situations as available.

courses.title: Topics in Advanced Stage Management
courses.desc: Nurtures a greater appreciation for the stage manager and his or her process, and supports students who are interested in pursuing a career in professional stage management.

courses.title: Music Theatre Workshop I
courses.desc: Basic vocal technique and characterization of musical theatre repertoire explored.

courses.title: Directing I
courses.desc: Introduction to comprehensive directing process from pre-production to opening. Focus on fundamental skills: analysis, staging, action, actor coaching, and elements of design. Skills applied to scripted theatrical material. Develop a language for commenting on theatrical production. Attending and critiquing productions.

courses.title: University Theatre
courses.desc: Rehearsal and performance in a faculty-directed.

courses.title: Theatre Production:  Costume
courses.desc: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.

courses.title: Theatre Production:  Scenic
courses.desc: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.

courses.desc: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.

courses.desc: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.

courses.title: Theatre Production:  Audio
courses.desc: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.

courses.desc: The production courses are offered to give students the opportunity to participate in departmental productions. Students engage in the production and construction of designed work as well as its applied execution during performance.

courses.title: Lectures in Dramatic Literature
courses.desc: Courses include Medieval and Tudor Drama, Elizabethan and Jacobean Drama, Shakespeare, Restoration and Eighteenth Century Drama, Modern British Drama, Modern American Drama, Tragedy, and Comedy.

courses.title: Lectures in Dramatic Literature
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Courses include Medieval and Tudor Drama, Elizabethan and Jacobean Drama, Shakespeare, Restoration and Eighteenth-Century Drama, Modern British Drama, Modern American Drama, Tragedy, and Comedy.

courses.title: Special Topics in Theory and Criticism
courses.desc: Discussion of recent major trends and ideas in critical theory, concentrating on in-depth readings and lectures in particular facets of theory and criticism: Derrida, Butler, Lacan, Deleuze, and others.

courses.title: Special Topics in Theory and Criticism
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Discussion of recent major trends and ideas in critical theory, concentrating on in-depth readings and lectures in particular facets of theory and criticism: Derrida, Butler, Lacan, Deleuze, and others.

courses.title: Special Topics in Classical Dramas
courses.prereqs: DRAMA 40A and DRAMA 40B and DRAMA 40C. Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Designed to introduce students to various classical traditions-early Greek and Roman theatres, to be sure, but also, by way of comparison, the classical traditions of non-European cultures.

courses.title: Special Topics in Classical Dramas
courses.prereqs: DRAMA 40A or DRAMA 40B or DRAMA 40C. Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Designed to introduce students to various classical traditions-early Greek and Roman theatres, to be sure, but also, by way of comparison, the classical traditions of non-European cultures.

courses.title: Special Topics in Early Modern and Neoclassical Theatre
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Investigates aspects of European theatre and culture in the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries; individual courses may focus on specific topics within this broad expanse.

courses.title: Special Topics in Early Modern and Neoclassical Theatre
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Investigates aspects of European theatre and culture in the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries; individual courses may focus on specific topics within this broad expanse.

courses.title: Special Topics in Nineteenth-Century Dramas
courses.prereqs: DRAMA 40A and DRAMA 40B and DRAMA 40C. Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Looks at the various trends and conventions of theatres in the nineteenth century, both Euro-American and beyond, paying special attention to the culture and political milieu within which these various traditions appeared.

courses.title: Special Topics in Nineteenth-Century Dramas
courses.prereqs: DRAMA 40A and DRAMA 40B and DRAMA 40C. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Looks at the various trends and conventions of theatres in the nineteenth century, both Euro-American and beyond, paying special attention to the culture and political milieu within which these various traditions appeared.

courses.title: Special Topics in Modern and Contemporary Drama
courses.prereqs: DRAMA 40A and DRAMA 40B and DRAMA 40C. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: An investigation into the many forms and permutations of modern (1880-1945), and contemporary (since 1945) drama, paying special attention to the historical and philosophical interpretations of text and performance.

courses.title: Special Topics in Modern and Contemporary Drama
courses.prereqs: DRAMA 40A and DRAMA 40B and DRAMA 40C. Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
courses.desc: An investigation into the many forms and permutations of modern (1880-1945), and contemporary (since 1945) drama, paying special attention to the historical and philosophical interpretations of text and performance.

courses.title: Introduction to Asian Theatre
courses.desc: An introduction to some of the major traditional theatrical forms and dramatic texts from India, China, and Japan.  Other than dramatic texts (in English translation), attention is also paid to theory, history, and performance styles of traditional Asian theatre.

courses.title: Asian American Theatre
courses.desc: An introduction to the history and development of Asian American theatre and drama. Besides play analysis, special attention is also paid to the history and politics of Asian American identity and experience, as well as to aspects of theatrical performance.

courses.title: Multicultural Theatres
courses.desc: A study of the history, culture, aesthetics, and literature of various traditional performing arts and their connections to the contemporary multicultural society.

courses.title: African American Film and Drama
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
courses.desc: A critical investigation of films and plays written by African Americans, with emphasis on dramaturgical and cinematic strategies, individual and collective representation, and the legacy of African American political struggle.

courses.title: African American Film and Drama
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
courses.desc: A critical investigation of films and plays written by African Americans, with emphasis on dramaturgical and cinematic strategies, individual and collective representation, and the legacy of African American political struggle.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Performance
courses.desc: Addresses particular issues in theatre and performance that typically lie outside of regular course offerings. May address such issues as the theatre of the Avant Garde, performing gender, transversality and performance, body art, installation and performance art, among other topics.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Performance
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Addresses particular issues in theatre and performance that typically lie outside of regular course offerings. May address such issues as the theatre of the Avant Garde, performing gender, transversality and performance, body art, installation and performance art, among other topics.

courses.title: Intermediate Acting
courses.prereqs: DRAMA 30A and DRAMA 30B and DRAMA 30C with an average grade of B or better. For transfer students: one year of beginning acting with an average grade of B or better.
courses.desc: Rehearsal and presentation of scenes from contemporary material. Focus on connection with scene partner, playing actions, and text analysis. Introduction to the credibility and theatricality of characterization and style.

courses.title: Writing for Performance
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Completion of a full-length play or its equivalent; discussion of student writing and of relevant literary texts.

courses.title: Studio for Advanced Movement for Actors
courses.prereqs: DRAMA 34. DRAMA 34 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Studio course in conditioning and partnering techniques to the practice of contact improvisation. Contact improvisation is explored and applied in scene study.

courses.title: Master Classes in Acting
courses.prereqs: DRAMA 130. DRAMA 130 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Advanced acting in specialized areas including acting for the camera: situation comedy, commercials; auditioning and industry preparation; Shakespeare; Molière; Chekov; improvisation; advanced movement and voice and speech for the actor; self-starting; stage combat; repertory acting, singing; comedy; clowning; and masks.

courses.title: Music Theatre Acting
courses.desc: An acting class exclusive to the students in the B.F.A. in Music Theatre program.

courses.title: Music Theatre Workshop II
courses.desc: A workshop in audition technique and song interpretation.

courses.title: Music Theatre Workshop III
courses.desc: Scene study and song repertoire examined by era for the advanced Music Theatre student. 1800s-1940.

courses.title: Music Theatre Workshop III
courses.desc: Scene study and song repertoire examined by era for the advanced Music Theatre student. 1940s-1970s.

courses.title: Music Theatre Workshop III
courses.desc: Scene study and song repertoire examined by era for the advanced Music Theatre student. 1970's-present.

courses.title: Music Theatre Workshop IV
courses.prereqs: For B.F.A. students: DRAMA 143A, DRAMA 143B, DRAMA 143C, and audition. For Drama graduate students: audition required.
courses.desc: A performance class concentrating on role building. Work culminates with in-class performances of abbreviated versions of musicals.

courses.title: Music Theatre Singing
courses.desc: Private weekly voice lessons for the advanced Music Theatre student.

courses.title: NYSP-Preparation
courses.prereqs: Admission is by audition and the following prerequisites: DRAMA 30C and two quarters of DRAMA 148A, DRAMA 148B, or DRAMA 148C (if the 148 prerequisite is not complete at the time of auditions, student must enroll during the fall and winter quarters in the same year as the trip to New York); senior Drama majors must have successfully completed DRAMA 40C and DRAMA 120C; non-Drama majors must have sophomore standing or higher and must carefully plan their course schedule as many spring quarter classes cannot be taken while part of the NYSP.
courses.desc: Class preparation for the New York Satellite Program (NYSP) - an immersion experience in New York City for the musical theatre performer.

courses.title: History of American Musical Theatre
courses.desc: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1700s-1940s.

courses.title: History of American Musical Theatre
courses.desc: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1940s-1970s.

courses.title: History of American Musical Theatre
courses.desc: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1970s to present day.

courses.title: Music Proficiency for Actors
courses.desc: A musicianship class introducing basic musical terminology, theory, and sight singing skills.

courses.title: Costume Production Techniques
courses.desc: Studio instruction in pattern making, draping, millinery, and construction techniques.

courses.title: Lighting Composition
courses.desc: Provides an opportunity for students to pursue stage lighting composition in a studio atmosphere.  Laboratory practice includes weekly exercises in style and genre. Emphasis is placed on the realization of conceptual ideas.

courses.title: Topics in Theatre Design
courses.desc: Examines the various functions of scenery and costume: locale, historical period, mood, and atmosphere, with special assignments in each area. Discussion of problems in scenic metaphors and visualization, emphasizing techniques of planning and presentation (e.g., floor plans, models, and rendering).

courses.title: Proseminar in Theatre Design
courses.desc: Topics in theatre design.

courses.title: History of Costume
courses.desc: A study of the development of dress and the influence of cultural factors on clothing from the time of Egyptians to Early Baroque.

courses.title: History of Costume
courses.desc: A study of the development of dress and the influence of cultural factors on clothing from late Baroque to World War I.

courses.title: Script and Score
courses.prereqs: Two courses from DRAMA 148A or DRAMA 148B or DRAMA 148C.
courses.desc: A form and analysis seminar discussing the libretto and score of landmark musicals.

courses.title: Song Repertoire
courses.desc: A song coaching class culminating in a song recital or showcase. Each quarter will feature a different composer, lyricist, or musical style.

courses.title: Contemporary Dramatic Criticism and Theory
courses.desc: Reading and analysis of theories and critical approaches to contemporary theatre: Brecht, Artaud, and others who have contributed to the form and idea of the modern theatre. Writing of assigned exercises in dramatic criticism.

courses.title: Contemporary Dramatic Criticism and Theory
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Reading and analysis of theories and critical approaches to contemporary theatre:  Brecht, Artaud, and others who have contributed to the form and idea of the modern theatre. Writing of assigned exercises in dramatic criticism.

courses.title: Dance Technique, Level I
courses.desc: Advanced beginner and intermediate dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.

courses.title: Dance Technique, Level I
courses.prereqs: (DRAMA 65 or DRAMA 142) and DRAMA 182A. Audition required.
courses.desc: Advanced beginner and intermediate dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.

courses.title: Dance Technique, Level II
courses.desc: Intermediate and advanced dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.

courses.title: Dance Technique, Level II
courses.prereqs: (DRAMA 65 or DRAMA 142) and DRAMA 183A. Audition required.
courses.desc: Intermediate and advanced dance training including musical theatre, ballet, jazz and contemporary modern techniques and repertoire.  Body conditioning is also a major component of the course.

courses.title: Directing II
courses.prereqs: DRAMA 30A and DRAMA 30B and DRAMA 40A and DRAMA 40B and DRAMA 40C and DRAMA 80
courses.desc: The principles of stage directing, covering the director's functions in the areas of interpretation, composition, coaching, and styling a theatrical production. Directing exercises and projects; the final project is the preparation of a hypothetical proposal for a play production.

courses.title: Advanced Directing
courses.desc: A seminar in directorial organization and research.  Student prepares a textual and dramaturgical analysis, a production timetable, and a hypothetical production book of an assigned play.

courses.title: NYSP-Acting
courses.desc: New York Satellite Program acting classes taught by guest faculty in New York.

courses.title: NYSP - Dance
courses.desc: New York Satellite Program dance classes in ballet, tap, jazz, and musical theatre styles taught by guest faculty in New York.

courses.title: NYSP - Singing
courses.desc: New York Satellite Program private and group lessons in musical theatre singing taught by guest faculty in New York.

courses.title: NYSP - Performance
courses.desc: New York Satellite Program rehearsals and public, staged readings of original musicals in New York.

courses.title: NYSP-UCI Residency
courses.desc: New York Satellite Program follow-up classes and performances back on Irvine campus upon the return from New York.

courses.title: Music Theatre Dance - Special Topics
courses.prereqs: DRAMA 182A or DRAMA 182B or DRAMA 183A or DRAMA 183B. Audition required.
courses.desc: Advanced dance classes in specialized areas including the dance styles of a choreographer (de Mille, Fosse, Robbins, Tune, Stroman), genre (tap, ballroom, jazz, swing, hip-hop), or in musical theatre choreography.

courses.title: Director Class Project
courses.desc: For students who are involved in the Director Class Projects at UCI as actors, directors, designers, stage managers and their assistants. M.F.A. Directors and the Head of Directing (HoD) supervise the projects.

courses.title: Honors Director Class Project
courses.desc: For graduate student actors and undergraduate directors who are candidates for Honors in Directing and involved in the Director Class Projects. The Head of Directing (HoD) supervises these students.

courses.title: Project in Theatre
courses.desc: Independent theatre projects with Drama faculty.

courses.title: Graduate Studio: Acting
courses.desc: Work in graduate studio taken in tandem with graduate studios in stage voice (DRAMA 201), stage speech (DRAMA 202), and stage movement (DRAMA 203).

courses.title: Graduate Studio: Voice
courses.desc: Graduate studio in vocal production for actors.

courses.title: Graduate Studio: Speech
courses.desc: Graduate studio in speech for actors.

courses.title: Graduate Studio: Movement
courses.desc: Work in graduate studio: stage movement taken in tandem with nine graduate studios in acting (DRAMA 200), voice (DRAMA 201), speech (DRAMA 202), and voice/movement dynamics (DRAMA 206).

courses.title: Graduate Studio: Voice/Movement Dynamics
courses.desc: Daily conditioning exercises.

courses.title: Graduate Studio: Directing
courses.desc: Graduate studio in directing.

courses.title: Graduate Studio: Playwriting
courses.desc: Completion of a full-length play or its equivalent and production of a staged reading of the play at the end of the spring quarter.  Discussion of relevant literary texts and student writings.

courses.title: Graduate Master Class
courses.desc: Various topics such as Shakespeare, comedy, Molière, improvisation, Kabuki, television acting.

courses.title: Seminar in Dramatic Literature
courses.desc: Topics in Dramatic Literature.

courses.title: Seminar in Criticism
courses.desc: Topics in criticism.

courses.title: Seminar on Theatre Pedagogy
courses.desc: A seminar on the major teaching systems in the dramatic arts with particular attention to professional arts training. Required prior to applying for Teaching Assistantships in studio areas.

courses.title: Graduate Projects
courses.desc: Various projects depending on student’s concentration (acting, design, musical theatre, directing).

courses.title: Singing Pedagogy
courses.desc: Learning how to teach voice lessons and coach musical theatre singing. Experiences include both private voice lessons and observing the lessons given to the B.F.A./Music Theatre students.

courses.title: Conducting
courses.desc: Private conducting instruction to develop freedom of movement/expression, baton technique, ear training, and tempo memory for both rehearsal and performance situations in musical theatre.

courses.title: Script and Score
courses.desc: A form and analysis seminar discussing the libretto and score of landmark musicals.

courses.title: Dramaturgy: Theory and Methods
courses.desc: Examines the practice, place, and theory of dramaturgy.  Explores plays in terms of how they work: dramatic form and structure, historical context, and more. Study includes dramaturgy as a theatrical practice.

courses.title: Musical Scene Study I
courses.desc: Musically directing scenes from musicals of various time periods. Features works from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including songwriters Gilbert and Sullivan, Irving Berlin, George Gershwin, Rodgers and Hart, and Cole Porter.

courses.title: Musical Scene Study II
courses.desc: Musically directing scenes from musicals of various time periods. Features works from the middle of the 20th century including songwriters Rodgers and Hammerstein, Lerner and Loewe, Julie Styne, Kander and Ebb, and Jerry Herman.

courses.title: Musical Scene Study III
courses.desc: Musically directing scenes from musicals of various time periods.  Features works from the late 20th and early 21st centuries including songwriters Stephen Sondheim, Andrew Lloyd Webber, Stephen Schwartz, Flaherty and Ahrens, and Jeanine Tesori.

courses.title: Musicals Abridged
courses.desc: Musically directing abridged versions of musicals from various time periods and genres.

courses.title: History of American Music Theatre
courses.desc: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct, and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1700s-1940s.

courses.title: History of American Musical Theatre
courses.desc: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1940s-1970s.

courses.title: History of American Musical Theatre
courses.desc: A survey of the influential artists who produce, write, direct and perform on America's musical stages. Surveys 1970s to present day.

courses.title: Graduate Music Direction
courses.desc: Various musical direction activities including the vocal direction, accompanying, and conducting of musical theatre performances.

courses.title: Foundations of Theatre
courses.desc: Seeks to create greater understanding in the roots and theories of theatrical models, aesthetics, action vs. reaction of differing thoughts in theatrical doctrine, and art, architecture, music, and fashion that contributed to the style and practice of theatre.

courses.title: Foundations of Theatre
courses.desc: Seeks to create greater understanding in the roots and theories of theatrical models, aesthetics, action vs. reaction of differing thoughts in theatrical doctrine, and art, architecture, music, and fashion that contributed to the style and practice of theatre.

courses.title: Foundations of Theatre
courses.desc: Seeks to create greater understanding in the roots and theories of theatrical models, aesthetics, action vs. reaction of differing thoughts in theatrical doctrine, and art, architecture, music, and fashion that contributed to the style and practice of theatre.

courses.title: Graduate Stage Management
courses.desc: Studio exercises and projects in stage management.

courses.title: Graduate Design Seminar
courses.desc: Projects, lectures, and critical discussion in costume, scenery, lighting, and sound design.

courses.title: Survival and Professional Practice in Design
courses.desc: Provides an in-depth examination of business skills needed to survive as a theatrical designer. Required 'Bridge' course in the Design MFA programs, relevant to all disciplines.

courses.title: Costume Thesis Project
courses.desc: Development of thesis project with focus on organization, research, timeline, and execution.

courses.title: Scenic Thesis Project
courses.desc: Development of thesis project with focus on organization, research, timeline, and execution.

courses.title: Thesis Writing Project-Stage Management
courses.desc: Development of thesis topic with focus on organization, research, timeline, and execution.

courses.title: Drawing for Designers
courses.desc: A multi-skill level course in drawing technique focusing on skills essential to stage designers including line, proportion, perspective and creating dynamic compositions. Focus will primarily be in figure drawing but may include still-life, landscape, and architectural drawings. Materials fee.

courses.title: Theatre Colloquium
courses.desc: Exposes students to a wider range of theatrical practitioners, theories, and topics through guest lecturers, special projects, and cross-disciplinary dialogue.

courses.title: Digital Costume Rendering
courses.desc: A studio course in costume rendering for the theatre using computer image manipulation. Instruction in compositing and painting techniques and performance design conventions.

courses.title: Digital Textile Design and Printing
courses.desc: A studio course in textile design using digital printing and embossing techniques. Instruction in state-of-the-art software and output manipulation for artistic expression.

courses.title: Digital Design: Drawing/Painting/Rendering
courses.desc: A studio course in scenic or costume rendering for the theatre using the computer for drawing/painting through the use of the digital pen/tablet.

courses.title: Digital Design: 2D/3D Modeling
courses.desc: A studio course in CAD's 2D drafting and 3D modeling capabilities for theatrical design. Instruction in state-of-the-art software for 2D and 3D object creation and theatrical presentation conventions.

courses.title: Digital Design: 3D Rendering
courses.desc: A studio course in theatrical design through 3d modeling on computer and use of state-of-the-art rendering software. Instruction emphasizes collaborative design process through the use of scenic designer/lighting designer teams for all projects.

courses.title: Lighting Graphics
courses.desc: A studio course in the various graphic methods employed by lighting designers in the theatre.  Projects include manual and CAD techniques for Light Plot and Paperwork creation.

courses.title: Digital Design: 2D CAD
