courses.desc: A studio course in theatrical design and architectural lighting design on the computer.  Instruction in state-of-the-art software for 2D object creation.  Theatrical and architectural standards implemented in performance design.

courses.title: Digital Design:  Digital Audio Systems
courses.desc: Comprehensive tutorial on digital audio including hard disk recording, editing, data compression, and ethernet audio distribution.  Focus is on recording, editing, and delivery of audio as used by the sound designer in the digital domain.

courses.title: Digital Design: Creating Sounds from Scratch
courses.desc: The process of analyzing sounds for their core timbral components and using that data to create new sounds - from realistic to fantastic - by means of digital manipulation.

courses.title: Conceptual Sound Design
courses.desc: An intensive, project-based seminar for exploring relationships between sound and sight.  Synesthesia, creative intent vs. audience perception, and sound/movement are typical of the many topics to be explored.  A series of creative projects are assigned and critiqued in peer review.

courses.title: Musical Theatre Sound/Concert Sound
courses.desc: A concept-to-opening study of the process of designing sound systems for musicals and live/touring sound.  Special attention given to the paperwork and documentation required to package, build, and mix these shows.

courses.title: Critical Listening
courses.desc: Exploration of the many variables that affect (and effect) the audio chain.  Perceiving and understanding these parameters unlocks the art of controlling sound and stylizing cues.  Also includes the process of equalizing/aligning sound systems and the art of audio mastering.

courses.title: Advanced Sound Design
courses.desc: An in-depth investigation into sound design for the theatre. Special emphasis is placed on text analysis, design conception, content creation, content delivery, and design organization. Class projects include creating paper designs and paperwork for different texts.

courses.title: Techniques in Costume Design
courses.desc: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of costume design.

courses.title: Techniques in Scenery Design
courses.desc: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of scenic design.

courses.title: Techniques in Lighting Design
courses.desc: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of lighting design.

courses.title: Techniques in Sound Design
courses.desc: Student exercises in the techniques and implementation of sound design.

courses.title: Stage Electronics/Introduction to Show Control
courses.desc: Using computers and dedicated hardware to cue, control or automate sound, scenery, and lighting for live performance and themed entertainment applications.

courses.title: Dramatic Literature and Theatre History Prior to 1900
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of dramatic literature and theatre history prior to 1900. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Dramatic Literature and Theatre History, 1900 to Present
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of dramatic literature and theatre history, 1900 to present. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Cultural and Critical Theory
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of cultural and critical theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Directed Studies
courses.desc: Directed study with Drama faculty.

courses.title: Dissertation Research
courses.desc: Dissertation research with Drama faculty.

courses.title: Professional Internship
courses.desc: An arranged internship at the South Coast Repertory Theatre, or other equity theatre company, for qualifying M.F.A. students. A stipend and equity points are provided by the theatre company.

courses.title: Dramaturgy Practicum
courses.desc: Requires doctoral students to identify two plays from the Drama Department's season to work as dramaturges. Students write a Dramaturgy Booklet recording their research and interactions with director, actors, and the design team. Students will work with doctoral faculty.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Introduction to Earth System Science
courses.desc: Covers the origin and evolution of the Earth, its atmosphere, and oceans, from the perspective of biogeochemical cycles, energy use, and human impacts on the Earth system.

courses.title: Oceanography
courses.desc: Examines circulation of the world oceans and ocean chemistry as it relates to river, hydrothermal vent, and atmospheric inputs. Geological features, the wide variety of biological organisms, and global climate changes, such as greenhouse warming, are also studied.

courses.title: The Atmosphere
courses.desc: The composition and circulation of the atmosphere with a focus on explaining the fundamentals of weather and climate. Topics include solar and terrestrial radiation, clouds, and weather patterns.

courses.title: Physical Geology
courses.desc: Introduction to Earth materials and processes. Topics include rocks and minerals, plate tectonics, volcanoes, earthquakes, Earth surface processes, Earth resources, geologic time, and Earth history. Laboratory work involves hands-on study of geologic materials, maps, and exercises pertaining to geologic processes. Materials fee.

courses.title: Introduction to Global Climate Change
courses.desc: Introduction of scientific, technological, environmental, economic, and social aspects underlying the threat and understanding of global climate change. Human and natural drivers of climate. Impacts of climate on natural, managed, and human systems, including their vulnerability and ability to adapt.

courses.title: Hurricanes, Tsunamis, and Other Catastrophes
courses.desc: Introduction to the basic science and state of predictability of various natural catastrophic events including earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, tsunamis, landslides, floods, hurricanes, fires, and asteroid impacts and their interactions and implications with human society in the U.S. and globally.

courses.title: Introduction to Modeling the Earth System
courses.desc: Simulate the Earth's system using computer models. Covers the interaction of the air, land, and ocean, and explores how changes to one part of the environment affect the complete Earth system. Utilizes technological tools to understand scientific principles.

courses.title: On Thin Ice: Climate Change and the Cryosphere
courses.desc: Introduction of the basic science that governs the cryosphere and its interaction with the climate system. Covers some of the significant economic, sociological, and political consequences of the recent melting of the cryosphere driven by anthropogenic climate change.

courses.title: Air Pollution: From Urban Smog to Global Change
courses.desc: Air pollution occurs on regional to global scales. A wide range of air pollution sources and physical, chemical, and meteorological sciences behind air pollution are introduced. The consequences of air pollution to our society are also discussed.

courses.title: The Sustainable Ocean
courses.desc: An introduction to sustainability as it relates to marine resources and conservation. Topics include the scientific basis of our understanding of marine ecosystems, and the political, social, and cultural principles that govern resource protection.

courses.title: Environmental Issues Affecting the Sustainability of Societies I
courses.prereqs: CHEM H30A. CHEM H30A with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Focuses on several environmental challenges facing the world today, and explores the problem, possible solutions, and their scientific, technical, and social constraints. Models for systems, their assumptions, predictive uncertainty, and interpretation, play a large role.

courses.title: Environmental Issues Affecting the Sustainability of Societies II
courses.prereqs: EARTHSS H30B. EARTHSS H30B with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Focuses on how we can use Earth’s resources, e.g., food and water, in a more sustainable way, exploring their scientific, technical, and social constraints.

courses.title: Earth System Chemistry
courses.desc: To understand the cycling of matter on Earth, we need to learn about the chemistry of elements and molecules in the environment. Introduces students to the understanding of how chemical principles apply in context to their everyday lives.

courses.title: Earth System Biology
courses.desc: Earth System Science is a highly interdisciplinary field that requires knowledge of various components of the Earth as a system, including the biosphere. Students are introduced to several fundamental principles of biology, from the smallest cells to the largest ecosystems.

courses.title: Earth System Physics
courses.prereqs: EARTHSS 40A or CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M3C
courses.desc: Covers the fundamental physical forces and laws that affect the Earth system, such as electromagnetic radiation and energy transfer, atmospheric and ocean dynamics. Also covers aspects of physics related to environmental issues, such as electricity generation and transmission.

courses.title: New Student Seminar
courses.desc: Weekly meetings led by faculty, current students, and staff, to provide information on the Department of Earth System Science, campus resources, and special programs and opportunities. Designed for students who recently joined the Earth System Science and Environmental Science majors.

courses.title: Land Interactions
courses.desc: The role of terrestrial processes in the Earth system. Provides an introduction to ecosystem processes that regulate the cycling of energy, water, carbon, and nutrients. Analysis of the impact of human activities. Materials fee.

courses.title: Ocean Biogeochemistry
courses.desc: Overview of oceanography for those interested in Earth System Science. Focus is on physical, chemical, and biological processes that drive biogeochemical cycling in the oceans. Coastal systems are also reviewed, with an emphasis on California waters.

courses.title: Earth's Atmosphere
courses.prereqs: (MATH 2B or MATH 5B or AP Calculus BC) and (PHYSICS 3B or PHYSICS 7C or AP Physics C: Electricity and Magnetism). AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4. AP Physics C: Electricity and Magnetism with a minimum score of 5
courses.desc: Composition, physics, and circulation of Earth's atmosphere with an emphasis on explaining the role of atmospheric processes in shaping the climate system. Topics include atmospheric composition, the global energy balance, radiative transfer and climate, atmospheric circulation, and climate sensitivity.

courses.title: Fundamental Processes in Earth and Environmental Studies
courses.desc: An introduction to the physical environment, biological systems, and human-environment interactions. Explores physical principles such as fluid transport and reaction rates using environmental examples as well as principles of populations, ecosystems, carrying capacity, and sustainable use of resources.

courses.title: Local and Regional Environmental Issues
courses.desc: An introduction to common environmental issues using case studies from Orange County and California. Studies natural hazards as well as human-caused problems with air quality, water quality, coastal pollution, ecosystem degradation, and urban climate.

courses.title: Global Environmental Issues
courses.desc: An overview of global environmental changes including climate change, sea level rise, biodiversity loss, land and ocean degradation, and resource depletion. Discusses scientific, cultural, historical, and policy dimensions of these issues as well as possible solutions.

courses.title: Sustainable Energy Systems
courses.desc: Addresses how modern energy services can be provided sustainably and the challenges and barriers that must be overcome. Major environmental issues are discussed, such as climate change, air pollution, and resource demands.

courses.title: Sustainable Food and Water Systems
courses.desc: Explores the biophysical underpinnings of food production, the history of agricultural development, and a range of environmental issues facing agricultural systems, including water management, climate change, and land use.

courses.title: Special Topics in Earth System Science
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B and EARTHSS 60C)
courses.desc: Devoted to current topics in the field of Earth System Science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Paleoclimatology
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B and EARTHSS 60C) or (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55)
courses.desc: Explores past changes in Earth's climate. Topics include tools and techniques used to reconstruct past climate from natural archives; records and mechanisms of past climate changes throughout Earth history; and lessons learned from the paleo-record for predication of future climate.

courses.title: Global Climate Change and Impacts
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B and EARTHSS 60C) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
courses.desc: Observations over the 20th century show extensive changes in atmospheric composition, climate and weather, and biological systems that have paralleled industrial growth. Evidence of globally driven changes in these biogeochemical systems is studied, including projected impacts over the 21st century.

courses.title: Earth System Science Laboratory and Field Methods
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B and EARTHSS 60C)
courses.desc: Introduction to methods used to measure exchange of gases and energy between the atmosphere and terrestrial ecosystems. Laboratories include data acquisition and isotopic and chromatographic analysis. Field measurements at UCI's Marsh Reserve include microclimate, hydrology, trace-gas exchange, and plant growth. Materials fee.

courses.title: Aquatic Field Methods
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B and EARTHSS 60C)
courses.desc: Students design sampling plans, conduct field research techniques, and carry out data analyses that are relevant to aquatic field research. Aquatic field sites covered in the course include marine, estuarine, and fluvial systems. Materials fee.

courses.title: Data Analysis for Earth Sciences
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B and EARTHSS 60C) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
courses.desc: Analysis and interpretation of geophysical data, including functional fitting, probability density functions, and multidimensional time-series methods, with applications in atmospheric, oceanic, and biogeochemical sciences.

courses.title: Programming for Earth System Science and Ecology
courses.prereqs: IN4MATX 41 or I&C SCI 31 or (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B and EARTHSS 60C)
courses.desc: Students learn programming and numerical methods in Python with applications in Earth System Science and ecology. Topics include regression, uncertainty and significance, the development of simple box models, and the visualization of multi-dimensional climate and satellite datasets.

courses.title: Weather Analysis
courses.desc: Provides an overview of weather systems in midlatitudes and tropics. The fundamental dynamics possible for these weather systems are described. Elementary weather analysis and forecasting techniques are introduced.

courses.title: Physical Oceanography
courses.prereqs: MATH 2D and PHYSICS 7C and (EARTHSS 53 or EARTHSS 60A)
courses.desc: Physical processes that determine the distribution of water properties such as salt and temperature. Fluid-dynamical underpinnings of physical oceanography. Wave motions. The wind-driven and thermohaline circulation. Similarities and differences between ocean and atmosphere dynamics.

courses.title: Terrestrial Hydrology
courses.prereqs: EARTHSS 60A or (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 40C and EARTHSS 70B)
courses.desc: Comprehensive treatment of modern conceptual and methodological approaches to hydrological science. Combines qualitative understanding of hydrological processes with quantitative representation, approaches to measurement, and treatment of uncertainty. Components of the hydrological cycle and their linkages within the coupled Earth system.

courses.title: Soil: It's the Good Dirt
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B) or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B and EARTHSS 60C)
courses.desc: An introduction to the critical role soils play in sustaining land ecosystems and humans. Covers how soils form and how human actions contribute to the pollution and loss but also the health and productivity of soils.

courses.title: Fundamentals of GIS for Environmental Science
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B) or (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
courses.desc: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems (GIS). Topics include fundamentals of cartography, creating/editing GIS data, linking spatial and tabular data, georeferencing, map projections, geospatial analysis, spatial statistics, and the development of GIS models. Examples from hydrology, ecology, and geology.

courses.title: Satellite Remote Sensing for Earth System Science
courses.prereqs: EARTHSS 51 or EARTHSS 53 or EARTHSS 60A or EARTHSS 60C
courses.desc: Satellite remote sensing data are increasingly used to study the Earth system. Provides an overview of the principles behind remote sensing, and the types of satellite data available for study of the oceans, land, and atmosphere.

courses.title: Advanced Geology
courses.desc: Introduces students to the geological processes which have formed and continue to shape the Earth. Topics will include geological time, minerals and the rock cycle, plate tectonics and associated geological hazards, earth resources, and earth surface processes. Materials fee.

courses.title: Atmospheric Chemistry
courses.prereqs: (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M3C) and (PHYSICS 3C or PHYSICS 7E) and (MATH 2B or MATH 5B or AP Calculus BC). AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4
courses.desc: Chemistry of the troposphere and stratosphere. Topics include processes controlling the lifetime and reaction pathways of chemicals in the atmosphere, the role of the atmosphere in biogeochemical cycles, and interactions between atmospheric chemistry and the physical climate system.

courses.title: Marine Geochemistry and Biogeochemistry
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 53 or EARTHSS 60A or CHEM 51C) and (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C or CHEM M3C)
courses.desc: Processes controlling the major and minor element composition of seawater and element distributions in the ocean. Gas exchange, carbon dioxide system, stable isotopes, radionuclides as tracers and chronometers, particle fluxes, organic geochemistry, sediment geochemistry, global cycles of biogeochemically important elements.

courses.title: Consequences of Air Pollution
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B and EARTHSS 60C) or (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or EARTHSS 40C
courses.desc: From public health to the global climate system, this course explores the impacts of air pollution from the beginning of human history to current and emerging issues. Scientific concepts behind air pollution and solutions will be discussed.

courses.title: Marine Ecosystems and Global Change
courses.desc: Presents an overview of marine ecosystem structure, diversity, and processes in the context of global change, including the impacts of climate warming, ocean acidification, marine fisheries, and anthropogenic additions of nutrients and pollutants.

courses.title: Environmental Isotope Geochemistry
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B and EARTHSS 60C)
courses.desc: Topics include the fundamentals of stable, radioactive, and radiogenic isotope variability in the Earth System. Focuses on theory, measurement techniques, biogeochemistry, hydrology, ecology, and climate related applications.

courses.title: Research Methods for Sustainable Systems Analysis
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Develops students' analytical skills that are necessary to engage and assess the sustainability of coupled human and natural systems and effectively communicate their findings.

courses.title: The Impact of Climate Change on California's Landscape
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B and EARTHSS 60C) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
courses.desc: Overview of anticipated impacts of climate change on California's landscape. Includes projections of future climate; anticipated impacts on ecology, hydrology, wildfire, coastal environment, and agriculture; and efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions or adapt to climate change through land management.

courses.title: Ecosystem Ecology
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI E106 or EARTHSS 51 or EARTHSS 60A or CHEM 51C
courses.desc: A mechanistic perspective on ecosystem processes. Covers ecosystem development, element cycling, and interactions with plants and microbes. The role of ecosystems in environmental change is also addressed.

courses.title: Physiological Plant Ecology
courses.prereqs: EARTHSS 51 or BIO SCI 94 or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60C)
courses.desc: An examination of the interactions between plants and their environment. Emphasis on the underlying physiological mechanisms of plant function, adaptations and responses to stress, and the basis of the distribution of plants and plant assemblages across the landscape.

courses.title: Environmental Microbiology
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 53) or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60C) or (BIO SCI E106 and BIO SCI M122)
courses.desc: Establishes a fundamental understanding of microbes living in the environment, including their distribution, diversity, and biochemistry, and discusses how they attribute to global biogeochemical cycles.

courses.title: Microbial Biogeochemistry
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B)
courses.desc: Develops an understanding of microorganisms in the context of their environment, environmental impact, and role in the global cycles of C,N,P, etc. Focuses on tools used to evaluate microbial diversity and function, and applications of microbial ecology.

courses.title: Ice in the Climate System
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B and EARTHSS 60C) or (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55)
courses.desc: Examines the major components of the Earth’s cryosphere. Characteristics, volume, extent, remote sensing observations, long-term trends, mass balance, key physical processes, relevance and importance to the climate system, responses and feedbacks, future evolution, and key uncertainties will be discussed.

courses.title: Marine Conservation, Policy, and Society
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B and EARTHSS 60C) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Conservation of marine ecosystems is important yet challenging due to competing physical, ecological, social, and regulatory issues. Students explore the principles of marine conservation, the scientific basics of marine ecosystems, and political and social processes involved with resource protection.

courses.title: Documenting and Understanding Earth System Change
courses.prereqs: (EARTHSS 51 and EARTHSS 53 and EARTHSS 55) or (EARTHSS 60A and EARTHSS 60B and EARTHSS 60C) or (EARTHSS 70A and EARTHSS 70B). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Students select a time series of key environmental interest as the focus for their writing.They become familiar with common writing practices for the Earth Sciences, and exercise their ability to use the scientific method to produce reports.

courses.title: Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability I
courses.desc: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability. Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum is also required. Seminar utilized to analyze forum presentations.  Prepare bibliography.

courses.title: Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability II
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 191A or SOCECOL 186A or EARTHSS 190A
courses.desc: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability. Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum is also required. Seminar utilized to analyze forum presentations.  Prepare research proposal.

courses.title: Writing/Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability III
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 191B or EARTHSS 190B or SOCECOL 186B. BIO SCI 191B or EARTHSS 190B or SOCECOL 186B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability.  Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum also is required.  Seminar utilized to analyze Forum presentations and to prepare senior research paper.  Prepare/write research paper under direction of faculty member.

courses.title: Introduction to Research in Earth System Science
courses.desc: Weekly presentations by Earth System Science faculty describing ongoing research in their laboratories. Students are introduced to the range of research topics and methods in Earth System Science and to the research opportunities available within the Department.

courses.title: Careers in Earth System Science
courses.desc: A weekly seminar course designed to help students transition to post-graduation career paths. Topics include designing effective resumes, applying to graduate school, and seeking employment. Also includes presentations by faculty, business, and government leaders describing potential environmental science career trajectories.

courses.title: Independent Study in Earth System Science
courses.desc: Field study, educational outreach, or other independent projects under faculty direction. Interested students should arrange with an ESS faculty member to supervise and support an independent study project. A written summary is required at the end of each quarter.

courses.title: Senior Thesis in Earth System Science
courses.prereqs: Two quarters of EARTHSS 199. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Students receive guidance on the effective oral and written communication of research results. Students prepare and present a seminar, a poster, and a written thesis describing their research in Earth System Science.

courses.title: Honors Thesis in Earth System Science
courses.desc: Students receive guidance on effective written and oral communication of research results.  Students prepare and present a seminar, poster, and written thesis describing their honors research in Earth System Science.  Submission of the thesis and successful completion of this course will also satisfy the UCI upper-division writing requirement.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.desc: For undergraduates with majors in science or engineering. Interested students should arrange with an ESS faculty member to supervise and support a research project. A written summary is required at the end of each quarter.

courses.title: Honors Research in Earth System Science
courses.desc: Undergraduate honors research in Earth System Science. A student commitment of 10-15 hours a week is expected, and a written report is required at the end of the quarter.

courses.title: Honors Research in Earth System Science
courses.desc: Undergraduate honors research in Earth System Science. A student commitment of 10-15 hours a week is expected, and a written report is required at the end of the quarter.

courses.title: Honors Research in Earth System Science
courses.desc: Undergraduate honors research in Earth System Science. A student commitment of 10-15 hours a week is expected, and a written report is required at the end of the quarter.

courses.title: Global Physical Climatology
courses.desc: A descriptive overview of Earth’s climate system and energy budget. Large-scale circulations, key physical processes, and climate sensitivity of the atmosphere, ocean, land surface, and cryosphere.

courses.title: Paleoclimatology
courses.desc: Explores past changes in Earth's climate. Topics include tools and techniques used to reconstruct past climate from natural archives; records and mechanisms of past climate changes throughout Earth history; and lessons learned from the paleo-record for predication of future climate.

courses.title: Climate Change
courses.desc: Explores past, present, and projected changes in Earth's climate. Topics include paleoclimate records and mechanisms of natural climate variability at a range of timescales (orbital to seasonal); General Circulation Models; and IPCC observations and projections of future climate change.

courses.title: Humans in the Earth System
courses.desc: Focuses on the human systems of energy and food production which have the greatest effects on the Earth system. Assess the physical mechanisms and feedbacks of human-nature interactions and consider approaches of mitigation, interventions, and adaptation.

courses.title: Geoscience Modeling and Data Analysis
courses.desc: Computer-based course. Fundamental statistical techniques needed to analyze Earth system data and models. Basic numerical techniques to solve Earth system models. Focuses on linear and non-linear ordinary differential equations, as well as simple partial differential equations.

courses.title: Ocean Processes
courses.desc: Introduction to the physics, chemistry, and biology of the oceans. Offers a mechanistic perspective of the structure and functioning of marine ecosystems, nutrient cycles, and role of ecosystem dynamics in local and global biogeochemistry.

courses.title: Marine Biogeochemistry
courses.desc: Overview of ocean biology and biogeochemistry, with a focus on lower trophic levels and the roles of biota in the marine biogeochemical cycles of key elements.

courses.title: Land Surface Processes
courses.desc: A mechanistic perspective of the structure and functioning of terrestrial ecosystems. Includes processes such as nutrient cycling, biogeochemical cycling, mass balance, energetics, terrestrial hydrology, and water cycle.

courses.title: Geophysical Fluid Dynamics
courses.desc: Introduces fluid dynamical processes that determine the large-scale flow of the atmosphere and ocean, with particular emphasis on the interactions between the stable density stratification and the Coriolis force associated with Earth's rotation.

courses.title: Satellite Remote Sensing for Earth System Science
courses.desc: Satellite remote sensing data are increasingly used to study the Earth system. Provides an overview of the principles behind remote sensing, and the types of satellite data available for study of the oceans, land, and atmosphere.

courses.title: Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics
courses.desc: Examines the physical/chemical processes which determine the structure and composition of Earth's atmosphere and its role in the climate system.

courses.title: Advanced Atmospheric Chemistry
courses.desc: Chemistry of the troposphere and stratosphere.  Topics include: processes controlling the lifetime and reaction pathways of chemicals in the atmosphere, the role of the atmosphere in biogeochemical cycles, and interactions between atmospheric chemistry and the physical climate system.

courses.title: Marine Ecosystems and Global Change
courses.desc: Presents an overview of marine ecosystem structure, diversity, and processes in the context of global change, including the impacts of climate warming, ocean acidification, marine fisheries, and anthropogenic additions of nutrients and pollutants.

courses.title: Environmental Isotope Geochemistry
courses.desc: Covers the fundamentals of stable, radioactive, and radiogenic isotope variability in the Earth System. Focuses on theory, measurement techniques, biogeochemistry, hydrology, ecology, and climate related applications.

courses.title: Paleoclimatology and Paleoceanography
courses.desc: Explores past changes in Earth's climate. Topics include tools and techniques used to reconstruct past climate from natural archives; records and mechanisms of past climate changes throughout Earth history; and lessons learned from the paleo-record for prediction of future climate.

courses.title: Ecosystem Ecology
courses.desc: A mechanistic perspective on ecosystem processes. Covers ecosystem development, element cycling, and interactions with plants and microbes. The role of ecosystems in environmental change is also addressed.

courses.title: Global Biogeochemical Cycles
courses.desc: Global biogeochemical cycling of the elements. Topics include global cycling of carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and sulfur; impact of human activities on biogeochemical processes.

courses.title: Special Topics in Earth System Science
courses.desc: Each quarter is devoted to current topics in the field of Earth System Science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Earth System Science
courses.desc: Each quarter is devoted to current topics in the field of Earth System Science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Earth System Science
courses.desc: Each quarter is devoted to current topics in the field of Earth System Science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Climate
courses.desc: Each quarter is devoted to in-depth analysis of an important and rapidly developing area in the field of climate dynamics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Atmospheric Chemistry
courses.desc: Each quarter is devoted to current topics in the field of Atmospheric Chemistry. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Atmospheric Chemistry
courses.desc: Each quarter in devoted to current topics in the field of Atmospheric Chemistry. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Atmospheric Chemistry
courses.desc: Each quarter is devoted to current topics in the field of Atmospheric Chemistry. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Biogeochemistry
courses.desc: Each quarter is devoted to in-depth analysis of a subarea in biogeochemistry which is undergoing rapid development.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Biogeochemistry
courses.desc: Each quarter is devoted to in-depth analysis of a subarea in biogeochemistry which is undergoing rapid development.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Biogeochemistry
courses.desc: Each quarter is devoted to in-depth analysis of a subarea in biogeochemistry which is undergoing rapid development.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Ecosystems
courses.desc: Each quarter is devoted to current topics relating to Ecosystems. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Ecosystems
courses.desc: Each quarter is devoted to current topics relating to Ecosystems. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Ecosystems
courses.desc: Each quarter is devoted to current topics relating to Ecosystems. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Seminar
courses.desc: Weekly seminars and discussions on topics of general and current interest in Earth System Science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Practicum in Earth System Science
courses.desc: Designed to introduce first-year graduate students to research. Students explore research opportunities and develop a proposal for a summer research project under the direction of a faculty mentor.

courses.title: Research
courses.desc: Supervised original research in areas of Earth System Science.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Introduction to Classical Chinese Literature
courses.desc: Introduces students to major genres and themes in the Classical Chinese literary tradition from the early Zhou Dynasty (1200 BCE) to the end of the Song Dynasty (1300 CE). Course is taught in English.

courses.title: Foundations of Classical Chinese Thought
courses.desc: Introduces students to the three main philosophical traditions of China from the Zhou Dynasty (1200 BCE) to the end of the Song Dynasty (1300 CE). Taught in English.

courses.title: Introductory Topics in Chinese Literature and Society
courses.desc: Introductory studies in Chinese texts in their social and cultural context(s). Conducted in English.

courses.title: Introductory Topics in Chinese Literature
courses.desc: Introduces students to major themes in Chinese literature and culture through the close reading, discussion, and analysis of selected texts in English translation.

courses.title: Introductory Topics in Japanese Literature
courses.desc: Introduces students to major themes in Japanese literature and culture through the close reading, discussion, and analysis of selected texts in English translation.

courses.title: Introductory Topics in Korean Literature
courses.desc: Introduces students to major themes in Korean literature and culture through the close reading, discussion, and analysis of selected texts in English translation.

courses.title: Topics in Asian Religions
courses.desc: An introduction to Asian religions (Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Taoism, Shamanism) including both elite doctrinal aspects and forms of more popular religiosity.

courses.title: Introductory Topics in East Asian Philosophy
courses.desc: Selected introductory topics in the philosophies of East Asia, e.g., Yoga, Buddhism, Vedanta, Confucianism, Taoism, and Shinto.

courses.title: Topics in East Asian Popular Culture
courses.desc: Selected topics in the popular cultural traditions of East Asia designed to introduce students both to problems in situating culture in a specific time and place and to contemporary theories of popular culture and their application to East Asian contexts.

courses.title: Introduction to East Asian Cultures
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary courses organized each year around a broad theme designed to introduce students to the cultures of East Asia. Topical organization of courses addresses issues that have been of importance historically and are reshaping East Asia today.

courses.title: Traveling East/West
courses.desc: Traveling East/West presents a wide range of travel writings by Chinese, Indian, and Euro-American authors in which they contemplate the complexities of cross-cultural encounters and how knowledge about others and knowledge of ourselves are closely intertwined.

courses.title: Topics in Chinese Literature and Society
courses.desc: Studies in Chinese texts in their social and cultural context(s). Conducted in English.

courses.title: Topics in East Asian Religions
courses.desc: Selected topics in the religions of East Asia, e.g., Buddhism, Daoism, Shintô, Christianity, popular religions.

courses.title: Topics in East Asian Philosophy
courses.desc: Selected topics in the philosophies of East Asia, e.g., Yoga, Buddhism, Vedanta, Confucianism, Taoism, and Shinto.

courses.title: Topics in Japanese Literature and Society
courses.desc: Studies in Japanese texts in their social and cultural context(s). Conducted in English.

courses.title: Structure of Japanese
courses.desc: An overview of the linguistic features of modern Japanese. Provides students with a systematic introduction to the nature and characteristics of the language.

courses.title: Topics in East Asian Applied Linguistics
courses.desc: In-depth examination of selected topics in applied linguistics, with a particular emphasis on language acquisition and language pedagogy.

courses.title: Topics in East Asian Linguistics
courses.desc: In-depth examination of selected topics in the linguistics of East Asian languages, including Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Vietnamese.

courses.title: Topics in Korean Society and Culture
courses.desc: Studies of the social and cultural forces that affect the lives of the Koreans, including those in the United States. Considers traditional values and contemporary issues within a historical framework.

courses.title: Topics in Korean Literature and Society
courses.desc: Studies in Korean texts in their social and cultural context(s). Conducted in English.

courses.title: Topics in East Asian Literature in Translation
courses.desc: East Asian literary works in translation. Taught in English.

courses.title: Topics in Cultural Studies in East Asia
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary and theoretical introduction to issues in cultural studies that are pertinent to the study of East Asia. All readings in English.

courses.title: Topics in East Asian Cinema
courses.desc: Study of East Asian cinema from historical, theoretical, and comparative perspectives. Taught in English.

courses.title: Topics in Gender in East Asia
courses.desc: Explores the construction of gender in East Asian cultures and literatures. Pays close attention to the specificity of historical, cultural, and literary contexts of East Asia as it investigates various theoretical and critical perspectives on gender and sexuality.

courses.title: Junior-Senior Colloquium
courses.desc: Specialized courses dealing with primary sources; required reports and papers. Each colloquium reflects the instructor's intellectual interest and is conducted as a discussion group. Limited to 15 students.

courses.title: Junior-Senior Seminar
courses.prereqs: EAS 190. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Analysis of a literary or cultural topic or problem through research and writing of two short and one long research paper for a minimum of 4,000 total words. Seminar follows EAS 190; related to the colloquium's subject.

courses.title: Directed Group Study
courses.desc: Directed group study on special topics.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Investigation of special topics through directed reading in translation. Paper required.

courses.title: Topics in East Asian Religions
courses.desc: Selected topics in the religions of East Asia, e.g., Buddhism, Daoism, Shintô, Islam, shamanism.

courses.title: Topics in East Asian Cultural Studies
courses.desc: Seminar, with topics varying from year to year. Research paper required.

courses.title: Topics in East Asian Applied Linguistics
courses.desc: In-depth examination of selected topics in applied linguistics, with a particular emphasis on language acquisition and language pedagogy.

courses.title: Topics in East Asian Cinema
courses.desc: An examination of the possibilities of East Asian cinematic narrative. Possible topics: cinematic history; cinema in popular culture; comparisons with literary texts; major auteurs. Emphasis on technical as well as on thematic aspects. Includes readings in film theory.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Directed research on topic determined in consultation with faculty member. A term paper or project is required.

courses.title: Dissertation Research
courses.desc: Dissertation research for students who are advanced to doctoral candidacy.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Research in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
courses.desc: Individual research with Ecology and Evolutionary Biological faculty.

courses.title: Research in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
courses.desc: Individual research with Ecology and Evolutionary Biological faculty.

courses.title: Research in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
courses.desc: Individual research with Ecology and Evolutionary Biological faculty.

courses.title: Seminar in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
courses.desc: Invited speakers, graduate students, and faculty present current research in ecology and evolutionary biology.

courses.title: Graduate Tutorial in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
courses.desc: Advanced study in areas not represented by formal courses. May involve individual or small group study through reading, discussion, and composition.

courses.title: Graduate Tutorial in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
courses.desc: Advanced study in areas not represented by formal courses. May involve individual or small group study through reading, discussion, and composition.

courses.title: Graduate Tutorial in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
courses.desc: Advanced study in areas not represented by formal courses. May involve individual or small group study through reading, discussion, and composition.

courses.title: Writing Grant Proposals
courses.desc: Provides students with hands-on experience writing proposals in the research areas of ecology, evolution, or physiology.

courses.title: Special Topics in Ecology
courses.desc: Survey of special topics in Ecology.

courses.title: Special Topics in Evolution
courses.desc: Extensive introduction to the primary literature of evolutionary biology. Topics include population genetics, quantitative genetics, neutralism, molecular evolution, evolution of genetic systems, genetic architecture of fitness, speciation, and macroevolution.

courses.title: Quantitative Methods in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
courses.prereqs: Completion of at least one quarter of statistics including regression and analysis of variance.
courses.desc: Statistics for ecologists and evolutionary biologists. Emphasis on specific applications and underlying assumptions rather than on methods of calculation. Topics include experimental design, parametric and nonparametric methods, analysis of variance and covariance, and multiple regression.

courses.title: Ecological and Evolutionary Physiology
courses.desc: A summary of information in organismal biology, comparative and ecological physiology, and the biophysical basis of organismal function. Course offered every other fall.

courses.title: Foundations of Physiology
courses.desc: Physical and functional principles common to many living forms. Course forms a basis for subsequent specialization in any of the subdisciplines of physiology. Course offered in even years.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Evolutionary Biology
courses.desc: Content and instructor will vary from quarter to quarter. Possible topics include quantitative genetics, experimental methods of evolutionary studies, mathematical modeling in evolutionary studies, and the evolution of genetic systems.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Ecological Genetics
courses.desc: Content and instructor will vary from year to year. Possible topics include coevolution, sex-ratio evolution, evolution senescence, plant population biology, and density-dependent selection.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Ecology
courses.desc: Weekly discussion of current topics in ecology at the graduate level.

courses.title: Statistical Learning in Ecology and Evolution
courses.prereqs: ECO EVO 207. ECO EVO 207 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Reviews basic principals of variance/bias trade-offs. Topics include models for prediction and classification, variable selection methods, cross-validation, tree based methods, unsupervised learning. Applications in ecology and evolution using R.

courses.title: Plant Physiological Ecology
courses.desc: Provides a summary of information on plant organismal biology, comparative and ecological physiology, and functional ecology. Offered every other fall.

courses.title: Seminar in Conservation Biology
courses.desc: Devoted to the application of basic ecological principles to the understanding and resolution of environmental problems of both local and global natures. Current problems approached through a combination of readings, group discussions, and visiting speakers.

courses.title: Topics in Microbial Ecology
courses.desc: Weekly discussion of current topics in ecology, biogeochemistry, evolution, and physiology of microbial organisms.

courses.title: Experimental Evolution
courses.desc: Explores experimental evolution, which is now a well-established part of evolutionary biology. With the advent of genomics, it is now one of the most powerful tools for studying the genetic foundations of biology.

courses.title: Seminar in Ecology and Evolution Education
courses.desc: Weekly discussion of teaching techniques and challenges that are specific to courses in ecology and evolutionary biology.  Emphasis will be on using evidence-based pedagogy techniques.  There will be a combination of readings, group discussions and speakers.

courses.title: Evolutionary and Ecological Principles in Medicine
courses.desc: Explore the dynamics of populations on an ecological, epidemiological, and medical level. Considers the dynamics of competition, predation, and parasitism; the spread and control of infectious diseases; and the in vivo dynamics of viral infections and the immune system.

courses.title: Functional and Structural Evolutionary Genomics
courses.desc: Function and organization of genomes analyzed from an evolutionary perspective. Review of some of the most recent experimental approaches in genome analysis and comparative genomics. Relevant software to analyze DNA and expression data is used.

courses.title: Professional Workshop
courses.desc: Identify and attend professional or technical skill workshops to gain professional knowledge and certifications related to conservation and restoration science.

courses.title: Conservation Biology
courses.desc: Explores concepts in ecology with potential for conserving biological diversity. Identifies creative applications of ecological research that mitigate impacts of rapid human population growth and habitat destruction on biodiversity.

courses.title: Restoration Ecology
courses.desc: Study of principles and practices that help recover degraded ecosystems  including restoration in different ecological systems, restoration motives and intensities, implementation and monitoring, and scope and success of case studies.

courses.title: Field Methods in Restoration
courses.desc: Laboratory experience performing field methods that help recover degraded ecosystems  in different ecological systems.  Emphasis on the plant community composition, soil, irrigation, maintenance, and monitoring of a project.

courses.title: Science Communication
courses.desc: Develops students' abilities to convey information related to conservation and restoration in a way that has broad appeal and/or effective messaging for non-scientific audiences by assessing the audience, developing effective storytelling, and deploying a persuasive information campaign.

courses.title: Technical Writing
courses.desc: Practice developing key documents for restoration projects including a response to a request for proposal (RFP), a restoration project plan, and a monitoring and maintenance plan.

courses.title: Project Management
courses.desc: Discover the planning, design, implementation, and aftercare phases of managing a conservation or restoration project.  Students will project cost, manage risk, analyze sites, evaluate and review projects, and become familiar with common permitting and consultation requirements.

courses.title: GIS for Environmental Science
courses.desc: Introduction to the fundamental principles of GIS. Topics include cartography, creating/editing GIS data, georeferencing, map projections, geospatial analysis, spatial statistics, and development of GIS models. Focuses on theory and practice.

courses.title: Marine Research and Conservation Methods
courses.desc: Field-based introduction to marine ecology and conservation management through the study of the ecology, resource management, and conservation of marine habitats and species, and the use of a variety of marine field research methods.

courses.title: Plant Diversity in a Changing World
courses.desc: Investigation of plant diversity in California and throughout the world, including basic systematic concepts, introduction to major groups of flowering plants, and the effects of global biological change on plant diversity. Students carry out a phylogenetic analysis using appropriate software.

courses.title: Wildlife Ecology and Sampling
courses.desc: Field-based introduction to wildlife management through the study of the ecology, physiology, population biology management, and conservation of vertebrate wildlife species, and the use of a variety of different wildlife sampling techniques.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Informatics for Biologists
courses.desc: Students learn the fundamentals of bioinformatics and the unix operating system (including the shell and Sun Grid Engine) in order to assemble a eukaryotic genome.

courses.title: Advanced Informatics for Biologists
courses.desc: Students learn advanced informatics including the analysis of: Poolseq, RNAseq, ATACseq, and ChiPseq datasets using programs such as bwa, tophat, cufflinks, DEseq, Trinity, Agustus, etc., in a unix high-performance computing environment. Statistical tests carried out and publication quality.

courses.title: Topics in Evolutionary Genetics
courses.desc: Weekly discussion of recent research on evolutionary genetics.

courses.title: MCRS Capstone
courses.desc: Apply knowledge and skills in a practical professional setting, working with practitioners to identify a conservation or management problem and then to plan, implement, and evaluate a solution.

courses.title: Communicating Research Through Video
courses.desc: Students explore videography to develop basic production skills through practice with high interest special topics, such as laboratory experimental evolution and educational interdisciplinary field events, and then develop media to communicate their own research or other topics of interest.

courses.title: Documenting Research Through Cinematic Production
courses.desc: Students gain advanced media expertise by conceptualizing investigative research into publicly engaging video projects. Popularly accessible research topics will be adapted into documentary, television, or cinematic pieces that provide opportunities for developing professionally marketable skills in educationally effective media production.

courses.title: Curriculum and Methods for Elementary School Science
courses.desc: Prospective elementary teachers learn how to teach science in grades K-8. Covers States science requirements, a variety of teaching methods, criteria for selecting science curriculum materials, and how to plan science lessons, units, experiments, projects, and demonstrations.

courses.title: Teaching Science in Secondary School
courses.desc: Prospective secondary science teachers learn how to teach science in grades 7-12. Covers State science requirements, a variety of teaching methods, criteria for selecting science curricular materials, and how to plan science lessons, units, experiments, projects, and demonstrations.

courses.title: Teaching Assistant Seminar
courses.desc: Readings, lectures, workshops, and student presentations designed to help develop teaching skills of graduate students teaching university-level biology classes. Topics vary and may include: course organization, presentation styles, exam design, grading, motivating students, and commonly encountered problems.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Mandatory course for Ecology and Evolutionary Biology Teaching Assistants, required in each quarter in which student has a Teaching Assistant position. Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Introduction to Economics
courses.desc: An analysis of the problems society faces in organizing itself to provide goods and services. How decisions of government, business, and the individual relate to current economic problems such as unemployment, inflation, poverty, and environmental pollution.

courses.title: The Internet and Public Policy
courses.desc: How the Internet works. Current public policy issues concerning the Internet. Introductory economics. Communications law. Interactions between information technology, economics, and law. Case studies about Internet and communications policy.

courses.title: Federal Reserve: Past, Present, and Future
courses.desc: Studies central banking in the United States from colonial times to the present. Focuses on the past, present, and future of the Federal Reserve and precursors to that system, which was established in 1913.

courses.title: Global Economy
courses.desc: Acquaints students with the fundamental patterns of the global economy. Emphasizes the historical roots and political implications of economic choices.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics in Economics I
courses.desc: An introduction to probability, statistics, and econometrics. Emphasis on a thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Examples from economics.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics in Economics II
courses.desc: An introduction to probability, statistics, and econometrics. Emphasis on a thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Examples from economics.

courses.title: An Economic Approach to Religion
courses.desc: Introduction to how basic economic concepts such as demand, supply, consumption, production, competition, free-riding, innovation, regulation, and rent-seeking can be applied to understand observed religious behavior.

courses.title: Basic Economics I
courses.desc: The fundamentals of microeconomics. The behavior of firms and consumers: markets, supply/demand, utility maximization, resource allocation, and efficiency.

courses.title: Basic Economics II
courses.desc: The fundamentals of macroeconomics. Government behavior: monetary and fiscal policy, inflation, and unemployment. Effective fall 2006, the content of Economics 20B is macroeconomics. This course cannot be taken to repeat Economics 20B taken prior to fall 2006.

courses.title: Basic Economics for Engineers
courses.desc: The fundamentals of microeconomics. The behavior of firms and of consumers: markets, supply/demand, utility maximization, resource allocation, and efficiency.

courses.title: The Economics of Accounting Decisions
courses.desc: Introduction to accounting concepts and principles, including the accounting model and accounting style, transaction analysis, and preparation of financial statements. An analysis of the similarities and differences between accounting and economic concepts (e.g., value, profits).

courses.title: Intermediate Economics I
courses.prereqs: ECON 20A and ECON 20B and MATH 2A and MATH 2B
courses.desc: Determinants of supply and demand; operation of competitive and monopolistic markets; imperfections of the market system, explanations of unemployment, inflation, recessions; public policy for macroeconomic problems.

courses.title: Intermediate Economic II
courses.desc: Determinants of supply and demand; operation of competitive and monopolistic markets; imperfections of the market system, explanations of unemployment, inflation, recessions; public policy for macroeconomic problems.

courses.title: Intermediate Economic III
courses.desc: Determinants of supply and demand; operation of competitive and monopolistic markets; imperfections of the market system, explanations of unemployment, inflation, recessions; public policy for macroeconomic problems.

courses.title: Intermediate Quantitative Economics I
courses.prereqs: ECON 20A and ECON 20B and MATH 2A and MATH 2B and MATH 3A
courses.desc: An advanced and mathematical version of ECON 100A for students in the Quantitative Economics major.

courses.title: Intermediate Quantitative Economics II
courses.desc: An advanced and mathematical version of ECON 100B for students in the Quantitative Economics major.

courses.title: Intermediate Quantitative Economics III
courses.desc: An advanced and mathematical version of ECON 100C for students in the Quantitative Economics major.

courses.title: Economics of Asymmetric Information
courses.desc: Focuses on the effects of asymmetric information in the markets for traditional economic goods and resources, such as labor, insurance, used cars, credit, and in auctions and bargaining problems. Prerequisite:.

courses.title: Special Topics in Economic Theory
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Economics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Behaviorial Economics
courses.desc: Studies the behavioral and psychological biases in economics settings. Both individual decisions and games are discussed.

courses.title: Game Theory I
courses.desc: Extensive form games with perfect information, and coalitional games. The key solution concepts are Nash Equilibrium, Backward Induction, and the Core. Substantive examples include public good production, oligopoly, electoral competition, auctions, holdup, market entry, and voting.

courses.title: Game Theory II
courses.desc: Two-quarter sequence on game theory. Bayesian games, extensive form games with imperfect information, zero-sum games.

courses.title: Applied Econometrics I
courses.desc: Introduction to econometrics emphasizing practical applications in microeconomics and macroeconomics.

courses.title: Applied Econometrics II
courses.desc: Introduction to econometrics emphasizing practical applications in microeconomics and macroeconomics.

courses.title: Data Analysis Writing
courses.prereqs: ECON 15A and ECON 15B and ECON 122A and ECON 122B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Research writing course in econometrics focusing on individual research projects. Students employ econometric analysis to address an economic question in a 20-page paper and present their findings to the class in a short presentation.

courses.title: Econometrics I
courses.prereqs: MATH 2A and MATH 2B and MATH 3A and STATS 120A and STATS 120B and (STATS 120C or MATH 131C) and (ECON 100A and ECON 100B and ECON 100C) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B and ECON 105C)
courses.desc: Specification, estimation, and testing of econometric models. Applications in various areas of microeconomics and macroeconomics.

courses.title: Econometrics II
courses.desc: Specification, estimation, and testing of econometric models. Applications in various areas of microeconomics and macroeconomics.

courses.title: Econometrics III
courses.desc: Seminar course in which students do an original econometric research project.

courses.title: Econometrics III
courses.prereqs: ECON 123B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Seminar course in which students do an original econometric research project.

courses.title: Business Forecasting
courses.desc: Students learn how to produce forecasts of the behavior of economic (and other) variables. The techniques examined are linear regression, nonlinear regression, and nonparametric kernel regression; AR, MA, ARMA, ARIMA, and Box-Jenkins.

courses.title: Computational Macroeconomics
courses.desc: Introduction to the computational methods for studying economic growth and the business cycle. Students learn how to write computer programs to simulate macroeconomic models, download and manage data from internet resources, and to do basic statistics.

courses.title: Experimental Economics
courses.desc: Students will learn what constitutes proper experimental design and what laboratory experiments teach us about human behavior and the economy. Students will participate in a sample experiment, evaluate the results, and discuss experiment design and larger issues. Formerly ECON 117.

courses.title: Machine Learning for Economists
courses.desc: Develops the theory and computation of recent methods at the intersection of econometrics and machine learning as used in economics and business. Building on intermediate econometrics, it introduces causal random forests, double machine learning, and neural networks.

courses.title: Special Topics in Quantitative Methods
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Quantitative Methods. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: The Economics of Risk and Uncertainty
courses.desc: The theory of insurance and joint-ownership of risky enterprises; optimal procedures for the allocation of uncertain payoffs.

courses.title: Introduction to Financial Investments
courses.desc: Modern theories of investment and their application to the study of financial markets. The relation between risk and return, diversification, asset pricing, efficient markets hypothesis, and the market valuation of stocks, bonds, options, and futures.

courses.title: Corporate Finance
courses.prereqs: (ECON 100A and ECON 100B and ECON 100C) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B and ECON 105C) and (ECON 15A or MATH 130A or STATS 120A) and (ECON 15B or STATS 120B)
courses.desc: Provides an overview of the modern theory and practice of corporate finance and focuses on two fundamental financial decisions; investment as well as financing. Beginning with discounted cash flow analysis, basic theory will be applied to the valuation of stocks.

courses.title: Mathematics of Finance
courses.desc: After reviewing tools from probability, statistics, and elementary differential and partial differential equations, concepts such as hedging, arbitrage, Puts, Calls, the design of portfolios, the derivation and solution of the Blac-Scholes, and other equations are discussed.

courses.title: Financial Markets and the Macroeconomy
courses.prereqs: ECON 122A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Students are required to write a paper on a research question related to.

courses.title: Special Topics in Financial Economics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Financial Economics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Managerial Economics
courses.desc: A collection of concepts and methods for effective decision making. Explores how the tools of microeconomics, including game theory and industrial organization theory, can be used to make better managerial decisions, particularly those involving allocation of resources within firms.

courses.title: Public Economics I
courses.desc: Examines the role of the government in the economy and its impact on individuals and firms.

courses.title: Public Economics II
courses.desc: Theory of public goods, externalities, voting models, analysis of bureaucracy, the Tiebout model, income redistribution, intergovernmental grants.

courses.title: Industrial Organization I
courses.prereqs: (ECON 15A and ECON 15B) and (ECON 100A and ECON 100B) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B)
courses.desc: The theory of market structure. Imperfect markets, government policies, and industry performance.

courses.title: Industrial Organization III
courses.prereqs: (ECON 100A and ECON 100B) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Research in industrial organization.  Satisfies the honors research requirement.

courses.title: Energy Economics
courses.desc: The economics of markets for oil, natural gas, electricity, and renewable energy, and their interactions with each other and the rest of the economy. Effects of government intervention, policy measures, economic policy issues arising between energy use and the environment.

courses.title: Urban Economics I
courses.desc: Why cities exist, economics of urban land-use, housing demand and tenure choice, traffic congestion.

courses.title: Urban Economics II
courses.desc: Housing policy analysis, urban public goods and services, crime, pollution, urban amenities.

courses.title: Economics of the Environment
courses.desc: Surveys economic aspects of natural resources, pollution, population, and the environment. Examines the causes of pollution; analysis of public policies regarding these problems. Emphasis on microeconomic aspects of environmental problems.

courses.title: Economics of the Environment II
courses.prereqs: ECON 145E. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Applications of the tools covered in ECON 145E to topics such as global warming, destruction of the ozone layer, and emissions trading. Emphasis on independent research papers. Syllabus and classes include writing technique.

courses.title: Economics of Law
courses.desc: Examination of several economic concepts which are useful in understanding legal rules: externalities, the assignment of property rights, and Coase's theorem. Examples are drawn from the fields of pollution control, no-fault insurance, medical malpractice, and product liability.

courses.title: Illegal Economics
courses.desc: How illegal firms function in illegal markets, why individuals participate in these groups and markets, and what federal, state, and local governments do to disrupt organized illegal activity.

courses.title: Corporate Governance
courses.desc: Studies topics in the internal organization of firms, including rent seeking, incentive contracts, principal-agent problems, internal labor markets, contests, and herd behavior.

courses.title: Economics of Strategy
courses.desc: Uses tools of economics, game theory in particular, to develop an understanding of business decision-making. Deals with questions such as how the firm decides what kind of business to be in, how large should it be, and others.

courses.title: Business Decisions
courses.prereqs: (ANTHRO 10A and ANTHRO 10B and ANTHRO 10C) or (SOCIOL 10A and SOCIOL 10B and SOCIOL 10C) or (SOC SCI 10A and SOC SCI 10B and SOC SCI 10C) or (MATH 2A and MATH 2B and (STATS 7 or MGMT 7))
courses.desc: Surveys normative and descriptive models of decision-making behavior, with an emphasis on organizational and policy contexts. Topics include rational choice theory, biases and heuristics, framing effects, and overconfidence. Management fads, panics, and herd behavior are also discussed.

courses.title: Special Topics in Economics of Public and Private Organizations
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Economics of Public and Private Organizations. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Economics of Public and Private Organizations
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Economics of Public and Private Organizations. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Labor Economics and Human Resources I
courses.prereqs: (ECON 15A and ECON 15B) and (ECON 100A and ECON 100B) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B)
courses.desc: Labor demand, labor supply, human capital, personnel economics, and other topics.

courses.title: Economic Anthropology
courses.prereqs: One course in general science, anthropology, economics, geography, or sociology.
courses.desc: Economic systems in comparative perspective: production, distribution, and consumption in market and non-market societies; agricultural development in the third world.

courses.title: Voting and Political Manipulation
courses.desc: Introduction to social choice and cooperative games. Topics include majority rule, types of voting methods, apportionment and proportional representation, agenda manipulation, coalition formation, voting power, political consequences of electoral laws.

courses.title: Current Issues in Political Economy
courses.prereqs: ECON 20A or ECON 20B or ECON 13 or INTL ST 13
courses.desc: Political economy seeks explanations that combine insights from both economics and politics. Topics include the interaction of government and markets, the causes of the Great Recession, and the sources of income and wealth inequality.

courses.title: Economic Development
courses.desc: Considers the process of economic development across the globe and why some countries are rich and others poor. Discusses the major problems facing developing countries, such as population growth, education, capital formation, environmental protection, and international trade.

courses.title: Economics of Education
courses.desc: Arms students with tools, concepts, and evidence that can be used to analyze complex policy questions in education, enabling students to arrive at their own reasoned judgments about how to improve education.

courses.title: Special Topics in Economics in Human Resources
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Economics in Human Resources. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Money and Banking
courses.desc: Basic elements of money and banking: institutional features and economics of financial markets and, in particular, the U.S. banking system; determinants of interest rates; the Federal Reserve and its role in money supply; effects of money on output and inflation.

courses.title: International Money
courses.desc: Open economy macroeconomics and determination of exchange rates. Asset-market approach to the balance of payments. Internal and external balance in the economy. Macroeconomic policies under fixed and floating exchange rates. The international monetary system and institutions.

courses.title: Advanced Money and Banking
courses.desc: Studies business cycles in the United States during the last century. The first portion of the course reviews the theoretical models employed to study economic fluctuations and empirical methods used to measure fluctuations.

courses.title: Poverty, Growth, and Development
courses.prereqs: (ECON 15A and ECON 15B) and (ECON 100A and ECON 100B and ECON 100C) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B and ECON 105C)
courses.desc: Examines India as a case study for each of the topics studied: growth experience of India along with its poverty eradication record, aspects of poverty, and the policies that have been undertaken to tackle poverty.

courses.title: The Industrial Revolution in Western Europe
courses.prereqs: (ECON 100A and ECON 100B and ECON 100C) or (ECON 105A and ECON 105B and ECON 105C) and ECON 122A and ECON 122B
courses.desc: How do economists explain the process of economic development during the past three centuries? How has the process of industrialization affected living standards? In focusing on these questions, students will learn how to apply economic theory and quantitative methods.

courses.title: The Industrial Revolution in Western Europe
courses.desc: How do economists explain the process of economic development during the past three centuries? Has the process of industrialization affected living standards? Focusing on these questions, students learn how to apply economic theory and quantitative methods.

courses.title: American Economic History from Colonization to the Present
courses.desc: Examines how the American economy evolved from colonization to the post-war era. Topics include relations with foreign countries, the emergence of manufacturing and big business, railroads, slavery, war, the Great Depression, the rise of fiscal and monetary policies.

courses.title: Economics of International Business
courses.desc: Students learn to understand and analyze the principal economic issues in the international business arena. Covers topics such as trade theory, foreign direct investment, foreign exchange market, and strategy of international business.

courses.title: International Trade and Commercial Policy
courses.desc: Determination of trade flows and the relative prices. Gains from trade, the terms of trade, and income distribution. Imperfect competition and international trade. The effect of tariffs, export subsidies, and import quotas. The effects of free and restricted trade.

courses.title: Special Topics in Development Economics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Development Economics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Senior Thesis
courses.desc: Students work with faculty to complete their honors thesis.

courses.title: Economics Honors Colloquium II
courses.prereqs: ECON H190A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Colloquium required for honors students in Economics, Quantitative Economics, and Business Economics. Introduces students to independent research and helps students plan a research program. Students complete their thesis.

courses.title: Economics Honors Colloquium I
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Colloquium required for honors students in economics, quantitative economics, and business economics. Introduces students to independent research. Helps students plan a research program. Prepares students for thesis writing.

courses.title: Field Study
courses.desc: Not listed in Catalogue.

courses.title: Directed Group Study
courses.desc: Not listed in Catalogue.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Independent research with Economics faculty.

courses.title: Graduate Colloquium for Economics I
courses.desc: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors. Supplemented by class discussion of these presentations and other material on current research methodology.

courses.title: Graduate Colloquium for Economics II
courses.desc: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors. Supplemented by class discussion of these presentations and other material on current research methodology.

courses.title: Graduate Colloquium for Economics III
courses.desc: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors. Supplemented by class discussion of these presentations and other material on current research methodology.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics
courses.desc: Provides lectures on probability theory and the beginning of mathematical statistics (continued in ECON 220A-ECON 221A) necessary to prepare students for the required econometrics sequence. Topics include probability, distributions, mathematical expectation, sampling, and point estimation.

courses.title: Mathematics for Economists
courses.desc: Gives students the mathematical background required for graduate work in economics. Topics covered include multivariate calculus, differential equations, and linear algebra.

courses.title: Microeconomic Theory I
courses.desc: Theoretical microeconomics. Emphasis on the meaning and empirical interpretation of theoretical models. Topics include theory of the firm, theory of the market, theory of the consumer, duality theory, application to econometrics, general equilibrium and welfare economics, uncertainty, game theory.

courses.title: Microeconomic Theory II
courses.desc: Theoretical microeconomics. Emphasis on the meaning and empirical interpretation of theoretical models. Topics include theory of the firm, theory of the market, theory of the consumer, duality theory, application to econometrics, general equilibrium and welfare economics, uncertainty, game theory.

courses.title: Microeconomic Theory III
courses.desc: Theoretical microeconomics. Emphasis on the meaning and empirical interpretation of theoretical models. Topics include theory of the firm, theory of the market, theory of the consumer, duality theory, application to econometrics, general equilibrium and welfare economics, uncertainty, game theory.

courses.title: Macroeconomic Theory I
