courses.desc: Research and writing course for Global Middle East Studies majors. The primary focus is to refine the skills necessary for students to engage in independent research and writing in Global Middle East Studies.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Greek
courses.desc: Elements of Classical Greek grammar, syntax, and vocabulary.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Greek
courses.prereqs: GREEK 1A. GREEK 1A with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Elements of Classical Greek grammar, syntax, and vocabulary.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Greek
courses.prereqs: GREEK 1B. GREEK 1B with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Introduction to reading texts.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Greek
courses.desc: First half of first- year Greek in an intensified form.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Greek
courses.prereqs: GREEK S1AB or GREEK 1B. GREEK S1AB with a grade of C or better. GREEK 1B with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Second half of first- year Greek in an intensified form.

courses.title: Special Studies in Greek
courses.desc: Lower-division level independent research with Greek faculty.

courses.title: Topics in  Attic Greek
courses.prereqs: GREEK 1C. GREEK 1C with a grade of C or better. Placement into GREEK 100 is also accepted.
courses.desc: Selected readings in Attic Greek prose and poetry. Authors may include Xenophon, Lysias, Antiphon, Euripides, and others. Selections from prose and poetry will be read each quarter. Grammar and syntax review included.

courses.title: Seminar in Greek Prose
courses.desc: Specialized and focused study of a particular Greek prose author or topic.

courses.title: Seminar in Greek Poetry
courses.desc: Specialized and focused study of a particular topic or author of Greek poetry.

courses.title: Reading of Selected Portions of the New Testament
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of the New Testament. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Directed Group Study
courses.desc: Special topics in Greek culture and civilization through directed reading and research.

courses.title: Independent Studies in Greek
courses.desc: Independent research with Greek faculty.

courses.title: Responding to Dynamic Times: Thinking Strategically for Healthcare Executives
courses.desc: Focuses on the strategic and organizational challenges that a rapidly changing environment poses to the firm’s management and frames them according to Merage’s strategic emphasis on analytical decision making, innovation, and information technology.

courses.title: Statistics for Healthcare Executives
courses.desc: Methods of statistical inference, emphasizing applications to administrative and management decision problems. Topics include classical estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, correlation, analysis of variance, decision analysis, and forecasting.

courses.title: Operations Analytics for Healthcare Executives
courses.desc: An introduction to computer-based models for decision making. Topics include optimization (linear programming, integer programming, network flow models) and computer simulation. Uses spreadsheets extensively, including Excel built-in and add-in packages. Once a month weekend course format.

courses.title: Organizational Behavior for Healthcare Executives
courses.desc: Develops a better understanding of individual and group behavior in and across organizations, the frameworks by which to analyze and understand behavior in complex organizations; enhances the skills required to manage collaboration and lead. Once a month weekend course format.

courses.title: Financial Reporting for Healthcare Executives
courses.desc: Involves the development, analysis, and interpretation of financial accounting information for external reporting purposes. Emphasis on measurement and valuation issues in decision-making problems and cases.  Once a month weekend course format.

courses.title: Managerial Accounting for Healthcare Executives
courses.desc: Involves developing and using internal financial and non-financial information to help organizations make planning, budgeting, control, operating, and performance evaluation decisions.  Once a month weekend course format.

courses.title: Microeconomics for Healthcare Executives
courses.desc: Provides basic tools for analyzing economic decisions of consumers and firms. Topics include demand and supply analysis, production and cost theory, perfect competition, monopoly, market failures, and introductory game theory. Once a month weekend course format.

courses.title: Marketing for Healthcare Executives
courses.desc: Introduction to marketing. Develops familiarity with fundamental marketing concepts, theories, and techniques, and acquainting students with the type of decisions made by marketing managers, including customer targeting, product, pricing, place, promotion, and research. Once a month weekend course format.

courses.title: Business and Government for Healthcare Executives
courses.desc: Introduces students to the many non-market issues that affect today's managers: environment protection, health and safety, intellectual property protection, antitrust, and lobbying. Takes an interdisciplinary approach using economics, political science, public policy, and law. Once a month weekend course format.

courses.title: Competing with Digital in Healthcare: Analytics, Platforms, and Business Models
courses.desc: Focuses on how information technology is used to create value in healthcare-related organizations through product, process, and strategy innovation. Aims to help managers and healthcare professionals understand the strategic role of technology. Every other weekend course format.

courses.title: Managerial Finance for Healthcare Executives
courses.prereqs: MGMT HC 201A and MGMT HC 203A and MGMT HC 204A
courses.desc: Introduces students to financial theory and concepts. Topics include time value of money, valuation of stocks and bonds, capital budgeting, portfolio theory, capital structure choice. Once a month weekend course format.

courses.title: Investments for Healthcare Executives
courses.desc: Foundations of investment management. Theory and empirical evidence related to portfolio theory, market efficiency, and valuation models for equities, bonds, and options.  Emphasis on practical applications, including optimal investment strategies. Once a month weekend course format.

courses.title: Strategic Management for Healthcare Executives
courses.prereqs: MGMT HC 200 and MGMT HC 202 and MGMT HC 205 and MGMT HC 209A
courses.desc: Provides conceptual frameworks and techniques to analyze and develop firm strategies. Through case analysis and discussion, helps students improve analytical and strategic thinking by which to assess, evaluate, and respond to different business situations. Once a month weekend course format.

courses.title: Negotiations For Healthcare Executives
courses.desc: Using a combination of theory and practice via negotiation simulations, students expand their repertoire of negotiating skills and develop their ability to analyze different negotiation situations and contexts. Once a month weekend course format.

courses.title: Understanding Managed Care
courses.desc: This course is designed to increase understanding of the various concepts of managed health care with an emphasis on the organizational processes required to make it work, and explore the economics and financial pressures these organizations face.

courses.title: Special Topics in Business
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of business. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Federal Policy in Health Care
courses.desc: National/international one-week residential course exploring political analysis as related to management of health care organizations.  Topics include political environment of management, concepts, and processes central to political analysis, bureaucratic politics, politics, and the manager.

courses.title: Leadership for Healthcare Executives
courses.desc: Focuses on the conceptual, practical, and personal dimensions of executive leadership. Past and current leadership theories are addressed. Individual personal assessment and diagnosis. Once a month weekend course format.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.desc: Individual study under the direction of a selected faculty member.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Hebrew
courses.prereqs: Placement into HEBREW 1A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Hebrew. May focus on Biblical Hebrew and/or modern Hebrew. Students learn the writing system and basics of grammar via latest pedagogical materials. Topics in Jewish culture are also included.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Hebrew
courses.prereqs: HEBREW 1A. HEBREW 1A with a grade of C or better. Placement into HEBREW 1B is also accepted.
courses.desc: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Hebrew. May focus on Biblical Hebrew and/or modern Hebrew. Students learn the writing system and basics of grammar via latest pedagogical materials. Topics in Jewish culture are also included.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Hebrew
courses.prereqs: HEBREW 1B. HEBREW 1B with a grade of C or better. Placement into HEBREW 1C is also accepted.
courses.desc: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Hebrew. May focus on Biblical Hebrew and/or modern Hebrew. Students learn the writing system and basics of grammar via latest pedagogical materials. Topics in Jewish culture are also included.

courses.title: Hebrew Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program
courses.desc: Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program in which student mentors work with student mentees to increase the language skills of both participants. One hour weekly meetings. HEBREW 10A is for language mentors.

courses.title: Hebrew Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program
courses.desc: Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program in which student mentors work with student mentees to increase the language skills of both participants. One hour weekly meetings. HEBREW 10B is for language mentors.

courses.title: Jewish and Israeli Culture
courses.desc: Examination of subjects relevant to the culture of Israel and Judaism in their historical and modern day contexts through the study of film, literature, religious texts, artistic representations, etc.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Research paper required.

courses.title: The Holocaust
courses.desc: Introduction to the history of European Jewish communities before the Holocaust; the origins of Nazi antisemitism; the implementation of the "Final Solution"; Jewish resistance to the Nazis; and attempts in film and literature to represent the Holocaust since 1945.

courses.title: Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity Since WWII
courses.desc: Investigates instances of genocide since 1945 (including Cambodia, Bosnia, Rwanda, and others); explores the history behind these mass murders; considers why people kill, how victims survive, and questions whether international agreements are enough to prevent crimes against humanity.

courses.title: Introductory Topics in History
courses.desc: Introduces methods and premises of historical study. Topics include introductions to cultural, political, economic, social, and religious history.

courses.title: Native American History
courses.desc: An overview of major developments in Indian-white relations from the American Revolution to the present with an emphasis on political and legal history. How tribal sovereignty has been redefined over time is a central theme of the course.

courses.title: Asian American Histories
courses.desc: Examines and compares diverse experiences of major Asian American groups since the mid-nineteenth century. Topics include origins of emigration; the formation and transformation of community; gender and family life; changing roles of Asian Americans in American society. Formerly ASIANAM 60A.

courses.title: History of Sexuality in the US
courses.desc: Explores intertwined histories of sexuality, race, and gender in the US. By examining how different cultures and times viewed sexuality, race and gender, it analyzes relationships between regulation of bodies/behaviors and construction of cultural, economic, and political norms.

courses.title: What to Eat? Immigrants and the Development of American Cuisines
courses.desc: Relationship between immigration and changing American foodways; impact of several major culinary traditions of immigrants and racial minorities, such as African Americans, Asian Americans, Mexican Americans, Italian Americans, Irish Americans, and Jewish Americans, on America’s gastronomical and socioeconomic landscape.

courses.title: Racial Segregation in Modern U
courses.desc: Explores the history of racial segregation in the United States from the late 19th century to the present.

courses.title: World Religions I
courses.desc: An introduction to the history, doctrine, culture, and writing of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

courses.title: World Religions II
courses.desc: An introduction to various religious traditions in selected areas of the world—including India and South Asia, East Asia, Africa, and the Americas.

courses.title: Religious Dialogue
courses.desc: Lectures and discussion on controversial topics in religion: sexual morality; religious violence; science; treatment of women and girls; religious truth, American Constitutional matters; secularization; the future of religion, and other topics.

courses.title: Major Jewish Texts
courses.desc: Introduction to the diversity of Jewish cultures from ancient to modern times. Surveys the Jewish experience in various societies and civilizations: ancient Mediterranean, Middle East and North Africa, Europe, and the Americas.

courses.title: World:  Innovations
courses.desc: Treats major themes of world historical development through the mid-seventeenth century, focusing on the Eurasian world, but with secondary emphasis on Africa and the Americas.

courses.title: World: Empires and Revolutions
courses.desc: Examines three major transformations that made the world of 1870 dramatically different from that of 1650: e.g., the scientific revolution, industrialization, and the formation of modern states and nations.

courses.title: World: Nation, War, and Rights
courses.desc: Considers several major currents of modern history: technological change and its social effects; changes in gender relations; totalitarianism; peasant revolutions and the crisis of colonization; international migration; and ecological problems.

courses.title: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society: Early Greece
courses.desc: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from its origins in the Bronze Age to the mid-Archaic period. Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, religion, and archaeological remains.

courses.title: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society:  Late Archaic and Classical Greece
courses.desc: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from the Late Archaic period to the Classical period. Focuses on major institutions and cultural phenomena as seen through the study of ancient Greek literature, history, archaeology, and religion.

courses.title: The Formation of Ancient Greek Society: Fourth-Century and Hellenistic Greece
courses.desc: A survey of ancient Greek civilization from the fourth century BCE through to the Hellenistic period. Focuses on major institutions and cultural phenomena as seen through the study of ancient Greek literature, history, archaeology, and religion.

courses.title: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: Origins to Roman Republic
courses.desc: A survey of the development of Roman civilization from its eighth century BCE beginnings to the civil wars of the first century BCE. Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, architecture, and religion.

courses.title: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: Roman Empire
courses.desc: A survey of Roman civilization from Augustus’s consolidation of power following the civil wars of the first century BCE to the crisis of the third century CE. Includes social history, literature, art, architecture, and religion.

courses.title: The Formation of Ancient Roman Society: The Fall of Rome
courses.desc: A survey of Roman civilization from the crisis of the third century CE to the so-called “fall of Rome” in 476 CE.  Examines political and social history, as well as literature, art, architecture, and religion.

courses.title: Colonial America:  New Worlds
courses.prereqs: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Important themes in the social, economic, political, and cultural development in North America that transformed part of the geographical space into the U.S. Topics include Native Americans, European colonization, African enslavement, borderlands, gender, economic stratification, the American Revolution, the Constitution.

courses.title: Nineteenth-Century U
courses.prereqs: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Explores the transformation of American society, economy, and politics during the nineteenth century. Topics include industrial revolution, slavery, antislavery, women's rights, reform movements, Civil War and Reconstruction, immigration and ethnicity, and cultural and social transformation.

courses.title: Modern America:  Culture and Power
courses.prereqs: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Important themes in U.S. history in the twentieth and early twenty-first centuries. Topics include corporate capitalism, empire, immigration, race, gender, consumer society, World Wars, Progressiveness, New Deal, Great Society, civil rights, women's movements, Vietnam War, conservative politics, and economic stratification.

courses.title: Crises and Revolutions
courses.desc: Study of turning points in world history, illustrating themes and methods of historical analysis.

courses.title: The Making of Modern Science
courses.desc: Surveys the history of science and mathematics since the Scientific Revolution, examining central developments both chronologically and thematically, as well as investigating their significance for contemporary philosophical debates about the role and status of current scientific theories.

courses.title: Problems in History: Asia
courses.desc: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of Asia, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.

courses.title: Problems in History: Europe
courses.desc: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of Europe, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.

courses.title: Problems in History: United States
courses.desc: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of the United States, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.

courses.title: Problems in History: Latin America
courses.desc: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of Latin America, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.

courses.title: Problems in History: Middle East and Africa
courses.desc: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of the history of the Middle East and Africa, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.

courses.title: Problems in History: Transregional History
courses.desc: An introduction to the historical problems, the issues of interpretation, the primary sources, and the historical scholarship of transregional history, with an emphasis on developing skills in historical essay-writing.

courses.title: Writing About History
courses.prereqs: HISTORY 12 or HISTORY 15A or HISTORY 15C or HISTORY 15D or HISTORY 16A or HISTORY 16B or HISTORY 16C or HISTORY 18A or HISTORY 21A or HISTORY 21B or HISTORY 21C or HISTORY 40A or HISTORY 40B or HISTORY 40C or HISTORY 60 or HISTORY 70A or HISTORY 70B or HISTORY 70C or HISTORY 70D or HISTORY 70E or HISTORY 70F. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Specialized courses focusing on history writing and research skills. Each class reflects the instructor's intellectual interests and is conducted as a discussion group. Limited to 18 students. Several short writing assignments and one longer project meeting the upper-division writing requirement.

courses.title: Topics in Environmental History
courses.desc: Explores the many historical interfaces between climate change, modes of production, and culture. Topics include the environmental history of warfare, imperialism, and famine in the nineteenth century and the history of environmental thought.

courses.title: Europe in the Early Middle Ages
courses.desc: Survey of Europe between 300 A.D. and 900 A.D. Topics include the breakup of the Roman Empire, barbarian invasions, spread of Christianity, rise of Islam, the Carolingian Empire, and the Vikings.

courses.title: Topics in Medieval Europe
courses.desc: Studies of the topics in Medieval Europe.

courses.title: Topics in Early Modern Europe
courses.desc: Theme-based approach to the main social, political, and cultural developments in Europe between the fifteenth and eighteenth centuries.  Topics included Renaissance humanism, Reformation and Counter-Reformation, scientific revolution, court culture and nation building, interactions with non-European peoples, cities and commerce.

courses.title: Topics in Modern European History
courses.desc: Course content changes with instructor. Topics include the Inquisition; science and religion in modern Europe; sex and society in modern Europe; French revolutions; culture in interwar Europe; the Holocaust; the fall of communism in Eastern Europe.

courses.title: War and Empire: France and the World in the 20th Century
courses.desc: Examines French experience of World War I, the defeat and occupation by Germany in World War II, the violent struggles that came with the loss of the French empire in the 1950s and 1960s, immigration, French responses to globalization.

courses.title: Hitler and the Germans
courses.desc: Focuses on Hitler's rise to power and Nazi society. Examines Germany's defeat in World War I; the political and cultural experimentation of the 1920s; the causes of Hitler's success; and life in Germany under the Nazis.

courses.title: Topics in Spanish History
courses.desc: Topics include Spain in the nineteenth century, the Spanish Civil War, and dictatorship and democracy in modern Spain.

courses.title: Twentieth-Century Russia
courses.desc: Political and social developments in Twentieth-Century Russia.

courses.title: The Era of World War II: 1933-45
courses.desc: The era of World War II and its political, social and economic history.

courses.title: Topics in the History of Women in Europe
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of history of European women. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in the Jewish History
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Jewish history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Jews and Power
courses.desc: Examines the relationship between the Jewish people and political power over a 3500 year period. How have Jews preserved their communal interests and personal safety? How have they defined the proper relationship of the people to political authority.

courses.title: Ancient Persia
courses.desc: Survey of the history of Persia in antiquity.

courses.title: Medieval Persia
courses.desc: A survey of Persian history in the context of Late Antique and Medieval Islamic history.

courses.title: Modern Iran
courses.desc: The history of Iran from the end of the Safavid Empire in the eighteenth century to the present.

courses.title: The Emergence of the Modern Middle East
courses.desc: Offers a survey of the history of the Middle East from the 19th century to the present time. Formerly History 133A.

courses.title: Women and Gender in the Middle East
courses.desc: Focuses on women and gender in the Middle East from the pre-modern to the contemporary.

courses.title: Armenians and Armenia in Ancient to Early Modern World History
courses.desc: A history of Armenia and Armenians from ethnogenesis to the early modern period at the end of the 1700s within a regional and global context. Takes into account interactions and encounters with the empires, and peoples that encompassed their orbit.

courses.title: Armenians and Armenia in Modern World History
courses.desc: Covers the most important themes in the history of Armenians and Armenia in the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries within a regional (i.e., Middle East and Caucasus) and global context.

courses.title: Topics in Islamic History
courses.desc: The evolution of Islam as a religion within the social, political, and economic histories of various Muslim societies throughout its 14 centuries. Introduces major concepts, practices, and texts of Islam, and key historical events associated with them. Formerly History 131.

courses.title: Topics in Middle Eastern History
courses.desc: Topics include the cultural, political, intellectual, social, and/or economic histories of one or many regions of the Middle East.

courses.title: Africa: Societies and Cultures
courses.desc: Introduction to the variety of cultures, political organizations, social structures, and artistic expressions created by Africans over a broad time span. Indigenous development of African societies in distinct regions of the continent. Issues, themes, processes for understanding history of Africa.

courses.title: Topics in the History of Africa
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of African history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in South African History
courses.desc: Introduction to important historical events and processes in Southern Africa. Focuses on particular themes and explores how those themes change over time. Topics include: changing ideas about race, the development of class structures, identity formation, the role of gender.

courses.title: History of the African Diaspora
courses.desc: Examines the causes and consequences of the multiple diasporas of African peoples since the sixteenth century in the Atlantic world, especially the Americas and Europe.

courses.title: Crossing the World's Oceans: From Sail to Steam
courses.desc: Explores the basics of oceanography, the evolution of ships and sailing in the ancient Mediterranean world, the North Atlantic, Polynesia, the South China Sea, the Arab Indian Ocean, the global oceanic world, and the discovery of celestial and terrestrial navigation.

courses.title: Topics in the History of Science and Technology
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of science and technological history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Language Origins: Evolution, Genetics, and the Brain
courses.desc: Examines how human language(s) may have originated. Studies pertinent techniques (reconstruction) and addresses related questions, including is our language faculty inborn (i.e., genetically encoded)? Can brain imaging and population genetics research help to unlock this mystery of human evolution?.

courses.title: Topics in the History of Medicine and Health Care
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Medicine and Health Care history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Revolutionary America:  1740-1790
courses.desc: An exploration of why 13 continental colonies, whose commercial and cultural connections with Britain far exceed their interaction with one another, resisted imperial reform after 1763 to the point of war in 1775 and independence the following year.

courses.title: California Dreaming: Conquest, Conflict, and Globalization in the Golden State
courses.desc: California as a case study of national trends and as a unique setting: its specific problems and culture. Major themes include: colonization, immigration, race relations, agricultural development, industrialization, urbanization, working class movements, social conflict, and political reform.

courses.title: Topics in American Social and Economic History
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of American social and economic history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in American Cultural and Intellectual History
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of American cultural and intellectual history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Women and Gender Relations in the United States
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of women and gender relations in the United States. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Education and the American Dream: Historical Perspectives on Democracy and Education
courses.desc: Examines the relationship between public schooling and the promotion of democratic ideals in American society over the past two centuries.

courses.title: Topics in Multicultural U
courses.desc: Examines the variety of cultural expressions through which the people who came to inhabit the United States historically signify their collective identities.

courses.title: Topics in African American History
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of African American history.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Chicana/Chicano History: Pre-Colonial to 1900
courses.desc: Examines social history of the southwest region from antiquity to 1900. Discusses major questions, theory and research methods pertinent to Chicanas/Chicanos. Themes include: indigenous empires, conquest, colonialism, social stratification, ideology, marriage, sexuality, industrial capitalism, accommodation and resistance.

courses.title: Chicana/Chicano History: Twentieth Century
courses.desc: Examines social history of the Southwest with emphasis on Mexican-origin people. Discusses major questions, theory and research methods pertinent to Chicana/Chicano history. Themes explored include: immigration, xenophobia, class struggle, leadership, generational cohorts, unionization, education, barrioization, ethnicity, patriarchy, sexuality.

courses.title: Latinas in the Twentieth Century U
courses.desc: Latinas in the U.S. from 1900 to present, offering a diversity of their cultures, regional histories, sexualities, generations, and classes.

courses.title: Latina/Latino Pop:  Latina/Latino Popular Culture
courses.desc: With a focus on the politics of language and space/place, prepares students to critically analyze sites of Latina/Latino popular culture including: music, film, performance, sports, media, and varied subcultures.

courses.title: Topics in Asian-American History
courses.desc: Introduction to important themes in the history of people of Asian ancestry in the United States from the nineteenth century to the present.

courses.title: Asian American Labor
courses.desc: Explores history of Asian Americans and work from the nineteenth century to the present. Areas of study include migration, colonialism, family, social organization, and work culture.

courses.title: Asian American and African American Relations
courses.desc: Addresses relationships of Asian American and African American communities in the United States. Topics include race, class, gender, labor, economic systems, political mobilization, community, civil rights, activism, cultural expression.

courses.title: American Urban History
courses.desc: A study of urban communities in the United States, from colonial times to the present. Traces the impact of industrialization and urbanization on social and cultural life, and investigates the significance of urban life for U.S. democratic culture.

courses.title: Sex and Conquest in Latin America
courses.desc: Competing ideas of masculinity and femininity, sexual violence, sexual identities, and gendered hierarchies informed how the Spanish engaged in military and religious domination of Mexican and Andean communities, as well as the forms of native resistance throughout colonial Latin America.

courses.title: Topics in Brazilian History
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Brazilian history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: World of Coffee
courses.desc: History of consumption and production of coffee over the centuries, and coffee's cultural, economic, social, political consequences. Coffee's social life as a drug, symbol of hospitality, religious rite, sociability and bourgeois lifestyle, commodity, source of livelihoods, imperial revenues, corporate profits.

courses.title: Caribbean History: Colonization to Emancipation
courses.desc: Exploration of the history of the archipelago from pre-Columbian times to the end of slavery; examining the impact of European colonization, decimation of the indigenous populations, African slavery, resistance, and emancipation; the unity and diversity of experience in region.

courses.title: Caribbean History: Emancipation to Independence
courses.desc: Post-emancipation and anti-colonial struggles ending with political independence for most of the region. Examines social, political, economic, cultural dimensions of post-emancipation period, including large-scale migration to Central America, the U.S., and Britain; the region's global cultural and political contribution.

courses.title: Race and Empire in Colonial Latin America
courses.desc: Explores how native people of Latin America with enslaved and free African incorporated and defied Spanish and Portuguese colonization. Focuses on religious adaptions, resistance movements, legal systems, and the emergence of multicultural communities to explain how race shaped European empires.

courses.title: War and Revolution in Colonial Latin America
courses.desc: Comparison of how Andeans resurrected the leaders of the Inca, a defeated indigenous empire, to contest the Spanish empire with how enslaved Africans, with their descendants and others, defeated Spanish colonial rule in what would become the Cuban nation.

courses.title: U
courses.desc: Explores political, economic, social, and cultural ties that bind Latin America to the United States. Focuses on U.S. intervention and Latin American response from early nineteenth century to present day. Case studies include Mexico, Guatemala, Cuba, Chile, and Central America.

courses.title: Revolution and Reaction in Cold War Latin America
courses.desc: Explores Latin American experiences of revolutionary change and military dictatorship during the Cold War (1945-1990). Pays particular attention to the lives of women, peasants, workers, and the urban middle classes. Case studies include Guatemala, Cuba, Chile, Argentina, Nicaragua, and Mexico.

courses.title: Cuban Society and Revolution
courses.desc: Explores the causes, development, and legacy of the 1959 Revolution. Themes include economic dependency, democracy, race, gender, culture, and the always volatile relations between Cuba and the United States.

courses.title: Revolution in Latin America
courses.desc: Presents a comparative analysis of the causes, development, and consequences of selected revolutionary movements, focusing on outbreaks in Mexico, Bolivia, Cuba, Chile, Nicaragua, and Grenada.  Explores topics of state formation, economic nationalism, social justice, ethnicity, and role of international affairs.

courses.title: Topics in Latin American History
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Latin American history.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Ancient India
courses.desc: Examines the visual and religious history of the region defined as "India" today, but necessarily encompassing modern Bangladesh and Pakistan.  Culminates with the supposed Golden Age of the Gupta empire and its far-reaching legacies.

courses.title: Medieval India
courses.desc: Begins with the Gupta period's aesthetic legacies in South Asia's architecture, sculpture, and painting. Explores the dispersal of Islam throughout South Asia, including the Muslim communities of southern India.

courses.title: Topics in the History of Asia
courses.desc: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual, and religious history of Asia.

courses.title: Chinese History to 1800
courses.desc: A survey of the history of China to 1800.

courses.title: Chinese History: 1800-1949
courses.desc: An examination of Chinese society and thought from the late-eighteenth century to the 1949 revolution. Focuses on the role of intellectuals; popular culture; women in Chinese society; developments in commerce and urban life; rebellion; foreign imperialism.

courses.title: Topics in the History of China
courses.desc: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual, and religious history of China.

courses.title: Topics in the History of Japan
courses.desc: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual and religious history of Japan.

courses.title: Topics in the History of Korea
courses.desc: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual, and religious history of Korea.

courses.title: Topics in the History of South Asia
courses.desc: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual, and religious history of South Asia.

courses.title: Topics in the History of Southeast Asia
courses.desc: Topics include the cultural, political, economic, social, intellectual, and religious history of Southeast Asia.

courses.title: Special Studies in Social History
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of social history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Studies in Economic History
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of economic history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Studies in Intellectual-Cultural History
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of intellectual-cultural history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Studies in International History
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of international history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Studies in Comparative History
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of comparative history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Studies in Social Theory
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of social theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Colloquium
courses.desc: Specialized courses dealing primarily with close reading and analysis of primary and secondary works; required reports and papers. Each colloquium reflects the instructor's intellectual interests and is conducted as a discussion group. Limited to 18 students.

courses.title: Advanced Research Seminar I
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: The first course in a two-quarter advanced research sequence, this course allows upper-division history majors to undertake significant research and writing under close faculty supervision.

courses.title: Advanced Research Seminar II
courses.prereqs: HISTORY 193. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Second course in a two-quarter advanced research sequence. Allows upper division history majors to undertake significant research and writing under close faculty supervision.

courses.title: Internships in Public History
courses.desc: Students will sharpen their abilities to research, critically interpret, and present history by “doing history” beyond the formal classroom. Internships, which introduce students to the field of “public history,” include working as archivists, oral historians, project advisers, and exhibit curators.

courses.title: Directed Group Study
courses.desc: Special topics through directed reading. Paper required.

courses.title: Independent Reading
courses.desc: Investigation of special topics through directed reading. Paper required.

courses.title: History and Theory
courses.desc: Explores a variety of theoretical issues and methodological concerns that have sparked lively debate in the humanities and social sciences in past decades and which remain of urgent concern to 21st-century historical writing.

courses.title: First-Year Research Seminar
courses.desc: Introduction to historical methodologies and preparation for the first-year research paper. Required of all first-year doctoral students and M.A. students.

courses.title: First-Year Research Seminar
courses.desc: Research and writing of a paper demonstrating command of historical methods explored in HISTORY 202A. Required of all first-year Ph.D. students and M.A. students.

courses.title: Second-Year Research Seminar
courses.desc: Part one of a two-quarter sequence required of all Ph.D. students during the second year of the program; not required for M.A. students. Includes primary research and writing a research paper, often related to a future dissertation topic.

courses.title: Second-Year Research Seminar
courses.desc: Part two of a two-quarter sequence required of all Ph.D. students. Taken during the second year of the Ph.D. program; not required for M.A. students. Includes primary research and writing a research paper, often related to a future dissertation topic.

courses.title: Topics in European History
courses.desc: Studies in selected themes and time periods in European history. Topics and period vary.

courses.title: The Literature and Interpretations of Modern European History: Europe, 1789-1848
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Europe, 1789-1848. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: The Literature and Interpretations of Modern European History: Europe, 1850-1914
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Europe, 1850-1914. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: The Literature and Interpretations of Modern European History: Europe, 1914-1989
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Europe, 1914-1989. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in World History
courses.desc: Studies in selected themes and time periods in world history. Topics and period vary.

courses.title: The Literature and Interpretations of World History: Approaches to World History
courses.desc: Overview of major directions of inquiry in world history and their implications for teaching and research.  Topics will include cultural, sociological, economic, and political frameworks.

courses.title: The Literature and Interpretations of World History: Topics in World History
courses.desc: Selected historical issues and periods viewed from a global perspective.  Examples include: environmental history, media studies, political economy.  May be repeated two times for graduate credit other than fulfillment of field requirement.

courses.title: The Literature and Interpretations of World History: Advanced Research in World History
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of advanced research in world history. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Latin American History
courses.desc: Studies in selected themes and time periods in Latin American history. Topics and period vary.

courses.title: The Literature and Interpretations of Latin American History: Colonial Period
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of the Colonial Period. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: The Literature and Interpretations of Latin American History: Nineteenth Century
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of nineteenth century. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: The Literature and Interpretations of Latin American History:  Twentieth Century
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of twentieth century. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in American History
courses.desc: Studies in selected themes and time periods in U.S. history. Topics and period vary.

courses.title: The Literature and Interpretations of American History: Seventeenth & Eighteenth Centuries
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: The Literature and Interpretations of American History: Nineteenth Century
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of the nineteenth century. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: The Literature and Interpretations of American History: Twentieth Century
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of the twentieth century. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Seminar in Japanese History: 1600-Present
courses.desc: Studies in Japanese history since 1600. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Research Methods in Chinese History
courses.desc: Introduces major tools for research in Qing and twentieth-century Chinese history as well as an introduction to research tools for earlier periods.

courses.title: Seminar in Chinese History: 1100-1750
courses.desc: The development of Chinese society and culture from 1100-1750. May be used to fulfill the First-Year Research requirement.

courses.title: Seminar in Chinese History: 1600-1937
courses.desc: The development of Chinese society and culture from 1600-1937. May be used to fulfill the First-Year Research requirement.

courses.title: Seminar in Chinese History: 1850-Present
courses.desc: The development of Chinese society and culture from 1850 to the present.  May be used to fulfill the First-Year Research requirement.

courses.title: Topics in Asian History
courses.desc: Studies in selected themes and time periods in Asian history. Topics and period vary.

courses.title: China
courses.desc: Studies in literatures and interpretations of Chinese history.

courses.title: Korea
courses.desc: Studies in literatures and interpretations of Korean history.

courses.title: South Asia
courses.desc: Studies in literatures and interpretations of South Asian history.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.desc: Lectures, readings, and discussion on subjects more limited in scope than those included in the year-long colloquium series.

courses.title: Directed Reading
courses.desc: Reading courses focused on specialized topics.

courses.title: Special Methods
courses.desc: Development of particular research skills.

courses.title: Experimental Group Study
courses.desc: Open to four or more students.

courses.title: Dissertation Research
courses.desc: Specifically designed for students researching and writing their dissertations.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Humanities Core Lecture
courses.desc: Through a range of cultural traditions and an interdisciplinary approach to works of literature, history, philosophy, and contemporary media, students are introduced to the humanities.

courses.title: Humanities Core Writing: Entry Level Writing
courses.desc: A small writing course for Entry Level Writing students exploring the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.

courses.title: Humanities Core Writing
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1A
Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.
courses.desc: A small writing course in which students explore the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.

courses.title: Humanities Core Lecture
courses.desc: Through a range of cultural traditions and an interdisciplinary approach to works of literature, history, philosophy, and contemporary media, students are introduced to the humanities.

courses.title: Humanities Core Writing: Entry Level Writing
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1B
HUMAN 1AES. HUMAN 1AES with a grade of C- or better
courses.desc: A small writing course for Entry Level Writing students exploring the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.

courses.title: Humanities Core Writing
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1B
Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.
courses.desc: A small writing course in which students explore the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.

courses.title: Humanities Core Lecture
courses.desc: Through a range of cultural traditions and an interdisciplinary approach to works of literature, history, philosophy, and contemporary media, students are introduced to the humanities.

courses.title: Humanities Core Writing: Entry Level Writing
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1C
HUMAN 1BES with a grade of C- or lower.
courses.desc: A small writing course for Entry Level Writing students exploring the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.

courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1C
HUMAN 1AS or HUMAN H1AS or HUMAN 1AES or HUMAN 1BS or HUMAN H1BS or HUMAN 1BES. HUMAN 1AS with a grade of C or better. HUMAN H1AS with a grade of C or better. HUMAN 1AES with a grade of C or better. HUMAN 1BS with a grade of C or better. HUMAN H1BS with a grade of C or better. HUMAN 1BES with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: A small writing course in which students explore the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.

courses.title: Humanities Core Biological Sciences Lecture
courses.desc: Through a range of cultural traditions and an interdisciplinary approach to works of literature, history, philosophy, and contemporary media, students are introduced to the humanities.

courses.title: Humanities Core Writing: Honors
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1A
Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.
courses.desc: A small writing course for Campuswide Honors students exploring the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.

courses.title: Humanities Core Writing: Honors
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1B
Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.
courses.desc: A small writing course for Campuswide Honors students exploring the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.

courses.title: Humanities Core Writing: Honors
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: HUMAN 1C
HUMAN 1AS or HUMAN H1AS or HUMAN 1AES or HUMAN 1BS or HUMAN H1BS or HUMAN 1BES with a grade of C or better.
courses.desc: A small writing course for Campuswide Honors students exploring the ideas presented in the companion lecture course and illustrated in the literary, historical, philosophical, and media works assigned.

courses.title: Masterpieces of Literature
courses.desc: Students closely read major works of world literature that are significant (1) in their own right, (2) for a specific literary tradition, and (3) because of their reception in other cultural contexts. Literature written in English and English translation.

courses.title: Foundations of Bilingual Education and Bilingualism
courses.desc: Provides a comprehensive overview of current issues in bilingual education and bilingualism. Topics include dimensions of bilingualism, the effects of bilingualism on children's linguistic and cognitive development, bilingual education programs, literacy, special needs, and assessment.

courses.title: Exploring Memory
courses.desc: Questions about human memory are central to a wide range of disciplines. Students will explore how historians, sociologists, social psychologists, legal experts, and neuroscientists understand human memory and apply their findings to understand and shape their own societies.

courses.title: The Vietnam War
courses.desc: Examines the origins, evolution, opposition against, conclusion, and legacy of the United States in the Vietnam War.

courses.title: Sanctuary: Medieval and Modern
courses.desc: Principles and significance of the practice of legal sanctuary in medieval English history, literature, and religion. Development of modern use of churches and other safe spaces in the American Civil Rights movement, immigrant sanctuary movements, and international asylum.

courses.title: How Nations Remember
courses.desc: Just like people, nations select and organize what and how they want to remember. Compares how specific historical events (such as slavery and the Holocaust) are memorialized in various countries and represented in public art works, museums, literature, and film.

courses.title: Traveling East/West
courses.desc: Traveling East/West presents a wide range of travel writings by Chinese, Indian, and Euro-American authors in which they contemplate the complexities of cross-cultural encounters and how knowledge about others and knowledge of ourselves are closely intertwined.

courses.title: Latin America and the Caribbean
courses.desc: Introduces students to Latin America and the Caribbean by focusing on the social, cultural, economic, and/or political issues and processes that have widely affected the region during various time periods.

courses.title: Honors Proseminar
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary Honors courses organized each year around a single topic problem designed to compare and contrast modes of analysis in history, literary studies, and philosophy.

courses.title: Senior Honors Seminar
courses.desc: Directed by Humanities Honors Thesis Advisor and required of students in Humanities Honors program and Humanities majors in Campuswide Honors Program.  Designed to facilitate exchange of ideas and research strategies among students and begin process of writing senior honors thesis.

courses.title: Senior Honors Thesis
courses.desc: Directed independent research required of participants in the Humanities Honors Program and Humanities majors in the Campuswide Honors Program.

courses.title: Senior Honors Colloquium
courses.desc: Completion, presentation, and discussion of Senior Honors Theses.

courses.title: Arts of Contemporary Communication
courses.desc: A workshop seminar exploring the theory and practice of visual design, data visualization, and oral presentation. Designed to get students to think about, and hone their skills in, effective presentation of information in multiple media.

courses.title: Topics in Humanities and Science
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary topics exploring the relationship between the humanities and the physical and biological sciences.

courses.title: Humanities Out There (H
courses.desc: H.O.T. sponsors tutoring opportunities in local schools and after-school sites for UCI students. Requirements include weekly one-hour training sessions at UCI; at least eight off-site tutoring sessions; and short writing assignments.

courses.title: Individual Field Study
courses.desc: Individually arranged field study.

courses.title: Directed Group Study
courses.desc: Directed group study on special topics.

courses.title: Directed Research
courses.desc: Directed research for senior Humanities students.

courses.title: Studies in Literary Theory and Its History
courses.desc: Introduction to criticism and aesthetics for beginning graduate students. Readings from continental, English, and American theorists.

courses.title: Critical Theory Workshop
courses.desc: A year-long Critical Theory Workshop, conducted by a team of instructors, conceived as a reading group, and developed with the input of all participants, where significant texts are discussed and analyzed in class.

courses.title: Critical Theory Workshop
courses.desc: A year-long Critical Theory Workshop, conducted by a team of instructors, conceived as a reading group, and developed with the input of all participants, where significant texts are discussed and analyzed in class.

courses.title: Critical Theory Workshop
courses.desc: A year-long Critical Theory Workshop, conducted by a team of instructors, conceived as a reading group, and developed with the input of all participants, where significant texts are discussed and analyzed in class.

courses.title: Race and Justice Studies Writing Seminar
courses.desc: A required writing-intensive seminar conducted by an instructor affiliated with the Race and Justice Studies emphasis. Students with manuscripts on relevant topics will read and critique peer manuscripts, and revise manuscripts toward completion of articles, dissertation chapters, and other publications.

courses.title: Issues In Latin American Studies I
courses.desc: Students discuss significant texts on Latin America from a range of disciplines in the humanities, social sciences, and the arts. This course will meet 3-4 times per quarter throughout the academic year.

courses.title: Issues In Latin American Studies II
courses.desc: Students discuss significant texts on Latin America from a range of disciplines in the humanities, social sciences, and the arts. This course will meet 3-4 times per quarter throughout the academic year.

courses.title: Issues In Latin American Studies III
courses.desc: Students discuss significant texts on Latin America from a range of disciplines in the humanities, social sciences, and the arts. This course will meet 3-4 times per quarter throughout the academic year.

courses.title: Advanced Critical Theory
courses.prereqs: Students should have taken introductory courses before enrolling in these seminars.
courses.desc: Seminars on various topics in critical theory.

courses.title: Humanities Out There (H
courses.desc: Individual study with H.O.T. faculty supervisor.

courses.title: Foreign Language Teaching: Approaches and Methods
courses.desc: Introduces approaches and methods of foreign language learning and teaching, and the theoretical models of second-language acquisition and teaching. Focus areas include lesson planning, teaching vocabulary, grammar, speaking, reading, writing, listening, culture, task-based teaching, uses of digital media.

courses.title: Foreign Language Teaching: Approaches and Methods
courses.desc: Introduces approaches and methods of foreign language learning and teaching, and the theoretical models of second-language acquisition and teaching. Focus areas include lesson planning, teaching vocabulary, grammar, speaking, reading, writing, listening, culture, task-based teaching, uses of digital media.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Associates in Humanities Core course.

courses.title: Barter to Bitcoin: Society, Technology and the Future of Money
courses.desc: Digital money has captured the broad imagination of speculators, coders, regulators, criminals and the mass media. Course puts this change in context: how do we understand money as a social, political and technological phenomenon?.

courses.title: Introduction to Software Engineering
courses.desc: Concepts, methods, and current practice of software engineering. Large-scale software production, software life cycle models, principles and techniques for each stage of development.

courses.title: Ethics, Technology, and Design
courses.desc: Provides a critical framework for how and why biases of many kinds are built into everyday digital tools. Reflections on ethics, technology, and design through case studies drawn from machine learning, CS education, engineering, social media, and criminal justice.

courses.title: Concepts in Programming Languages I
courses.prereqs: (I&C SCI 51 or CSE 31 or EECS 31) and (I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46). I&C SCI 51 with a grade of C or better. CSE 31 with a grade of C or better. EECS 31 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: In-depth study of several contemporary programming languages stressing variety in data structures, operations, notation, and control. Examination of different programming paradigms, such as logic programming, functional programming and object-oriented programming; implementation strategies, programming environments, and programming style.

courses.title: Concepts of Programming Language II
courses.prereqs: IN4MATX 101 or COMPSCI 141 or CSE 141. CSE 141 with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: In-depth study of major programming paradigms: imperative, functional, declarative, object-oriented, and aspect-oriented. Understanding the role of programming languages in software development and the suitability of languages in context. Domain-specific languages. Designing new languages for better software development support.

courses.title: Requirements Analysis and Engineering
courses.prereqs: (I&C SCI 33 or CSE 43) and IN4MATX 43. I&C SCI 33 with a grade of C or better. CSE 43 with a grade of C or better. IN4MATX 43 with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Equips students to develop techniques of software-intensive systems through successful requirements analysis techniques and requirements engineering. Students learn systematic process of developing requirements through cooperative problem analysis, representation, and validation.

courses.title: Software Testing, Analysis, and Quality Assurance
courses.prereqs: (I&C SCI 45J or I&C SCI 45C or I&C SCI 46 or CSE 46) and IN4MATX 43. I&C SCI 45J with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 45C with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 46 with a grade of C or better. CSE 46 with a grade of C or better. IN4MATX 43 with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Preparation for developing high-quality software through successful veriﬁcation and validation techniques. Fundamental principles of software testing, implementing software testing practices, ensuring the thoroughness of testing to gain conﬁdence in the correctness of the software.

courses.title: Project in Software System Design
courses.desc: Specification, design, construction, testing, and documentation of a complete software system. Special emphasis on the need for and use of teamwork, careful planning, and other techniques for working with large systems.

courses.title: Software Design: Applications
courses.prereqs: I&C SCI 33 or CSE 43. I&C SCI 33 with a grade of C or better. CSE 43 with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Introduction to application design: designing the overall functionality of a software application. Topics include general design theory, software design theory, and software architecture. Includes practice in designing and case studies of existing designs.

courses.title: Software Design: Structure and Implementation
courses.prereqs: (I&C SCI 45J or I&C SCI 46 or IN4MATX 45) and (IN4MATX 101 or COMPSCI 141 or CSE 141)
courses.desc: Introduction to implementation design: designing the internals of a software application. Topics include design aesthetics, design implementation, design recovery, design patterns, and component reuse. Includes practice in designing and case studies of existing designs.

courses.title: Internet Applications Engineering
courses.desc: Concepts in Internet applications engineering with emphasis on the Web. Peer-to-Peer and Interoperability. Topics include HTTP and REST, Remote Procedure/Method Calls, Web Services, data representations, content distribution networks, identity management, relevant W3C/IETF standards, and relevant new large-scale computing styles.

courses.title: Computer Game Development
courses.prereqs: COMPSCI 112 or COMPSCI 171 or IN4MATX 121 or ART 106B or I&C SCI 163 or I&C SCI 166
courses.desc: Introduction to the principles of interactive 2D and 3D computer game development. Concepts in computer graphics, algorithms, software engineering, art and graphics, music and sound, story analysis, and artificial intelligence are presented and are the basis for student work.

courses.title: Human Computer Interaction
courses.prereqs: I&C SCI 10 or I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A or CSE 41 or ENGR 10 or ENGRMAE 10 or EECS 10. I&C SCI 10 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 32A with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better. ENGR 10 with a grade of C or better. ENGRMAE 10 with a grade of C or better. EECS 10 with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Basic principles of human-computer interaction (HCI). Introduces students to user interface design techniques, design guidelines, and usability testing. Students gain the ability to design and evaluate user interfaces and become familiar with some of the outstanding research problems in HCI.

courses.title: Project in Human-Computer Interaction Requirements and Evaluation
courses.desc: Students undertake significant projects in the elicitation and specification of HCI requirements and the thorough evaluation of user interfaces.

courses.title: User Interaction Software
courses.prereqs: I&C SCI 45J. I&C SCI 45J with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Introduction to human-computer interaction programming. Emphasis on current tools, standards, methodologies for implementing effective interaction designs. Widget toolkits, Web interface programming, geo-spatial and map interfaces, mobile phone interfaces.

courses.title: Project in User Interaction Software
courses.desc: Students complete an end-to-end user interface programming project based on an iterative design paradigm. Topics may include requirements brainstorming, paper prototyping, iterative development, cognitive walk-through, quantitative evaluation, and acceptance testing. Materials fee.

courses.title: Information Retrieval
courses.prereqs: (I&C SCI 45C or I&C SCI 45J) and (STATS 7 or STATS 67). I&C SCI 45C with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 45J with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: An introduction to information retrieval including indexing, retrieval, classifying, and clustering text and multimedia documents.

courses.title: Information Visualization
courses.prereqs: IN4MATX 131 or I&C SCI 52 or (IN4MATX 43 and I&C SCI 31 or CSE 41 or I&C SCI 21 or CSE 21 or IN4MATX 41). IN4MATX 131 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 52 with a grade of C or better. IN4MATX 43 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 21 with a grade of C or better. CSE 21 with a grade of C or better. IN4MATX 41 with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Introduction to interactive visual interfaces for large datasets, and to principles of human visual perception and human computer interaction that inform their design. Various applications for data analysis and monitoring are discussed.

courses.title: Project in Ubiquitous Computing
courses.prereqs: I&C SCI 10 or I&C SCI 21 or CSE 21 or I&C SCI 31 or CSE 41 or IN4MATX 41. I&C SCI 10 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 21 with a grade of C or better. CSE 21 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better. IN4MATX 41 with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Introduction to ubiquitous computing research methods, tools, and techniques. Prototyping, design, and evaluation of physical computing applications, smart environments, embedded systems, and future computing scenarios. Includes hands-on in-class laboratory exercises. Materials fee.

courses.title: Project Management
courses.prereqs: IN4MATX 43 or I&C SCI 52. I&C SCI 52 with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Introduces theoretical and practical aspects of project management. Topics include organizational theory, group behavior, project management skills, case studies, personal and group productivity tools, management of distributed work, stakeholders, consultants, and knowledge management. Students do a project exercise.

courses.title: Computer Supported Cooperative Work
courses.prereqs: (IN4MATX 161 or I&C SCI 52 or IN4MATX 43) and (I&C SCI 31 or CSE 41 or I&C SCI 21 or CSE 21 or IN4MATX 41). I&C SCI 52 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 21 with a grade of C or better. CSE 21 with a grade of C or better. IN4MATX 41 with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Introduces concepts and principles of collaborative systems. Topics may include shared workspaces, group interaction, workflow, architectures, interaction between social and technical features of group work, and examples of collaborative systems used in real-world settings. Students develop a simple collaborative application.

courses.title: Social Analysis of Computing
courses.prereqs: I&C SCI 10 or I&C SCI 31 or I&C SCI 32A or CSE 41 or ENGR 10 or EECS 10 or ENGRMAE 10. I&C SCI 10 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 31 with a grade of C or better. I&C SCI 32A with a grade of C or better. CSE 41 with a grade of C or better. ENGR 10 with a grade of C or better. EECS 10 with a grade of C or better. ENGRMAE 10 with a grade of C or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Introduction of computing as a social process. Examines the social opportunities and problems raised by new information technologies, and the consequences of different ways of organizing. Topics include computing and work life, privacy, virtual communities, productivity paradox, systems risks.

courses.title: Organizational Information Systems
courses.prereqs: IN4MATX 161. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Introduction to role of information systems in organizations, components and structure of organizational information systems, and techniques used in information systems analysis, design, and implementation.

courses.title: Project in the Social and Organizational Impacts of Computing
courses.desc: Students undertake projects intended to gather and analyze data from situations in which computers are used, organize and conduct experiments intended to test hypotheses about impacts, and explore the application of concepts learned in previous courses.

courses.title: Children's Learning and Media
courses.desc: Examines how popular media may impact how young people learn, develop, and communicate by looking at research related to the impacts of a wide range of popular media including television, video games, digital environments, mobile devices, and other multimedia.

courses.title: Introduction to Medical Informatics
courses.desc: Broad overview of medical informatics for students with varied backgrounds. Electronic medical records, online resources, mobile technologies, patient safety, and computational design. Legal, ethical, and public policy issues. Health systems management. Evaluation and fieldwork for health systems.

courses.title: Project in Health Informatics
courses.desc: Students undertake significant quarter-long projects related to health informatics. Topics may include field evaluations of health care technologies, prototypes, iterative design, and system implementations.

courses.title: Special Topics in Informatics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of informatics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Senior Design Project
courses.prereqs: IN4MATX 113 and IN4MATX 121 and IN4MATX 131 and IN4MATX 151 and IN4MATX 161
courses.desc: Group supervised project in which students analyze, specify, design, construct, evaluate, and adapt a significant information processing system. Topics include team management, professional ethics, and systems analysis.

courses.title: Senior Design Project
courses.prereqs: IN4MATX 191A. In Progress (IP) grade for IN4MATX 191A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Group supervised project in which students analyze, specify, design, construct, evaluate, and adapt a significant information processing system. Topics include team management, professional ethics, and systems analysis.

courses.title: Honors Research
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Directed independent research in Informatics for honors students.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.desc: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

courses.title: Research Methodology for Informatics
courses.desc: Introduction to strategies and idioms of research in Informatics. Includes examination of issues in scientific inquiry, qualitative and quantitative methods, and research design. Both classic texts and contemporary research literature are read and analyzed.

courses.title: Qualitative Research Methods in Information Systems
courses.desc: Introduction to qualitative research methods used to study computerization and information systems, such as open-ended interviewing, participant observation, and ethnography. Studies of the methods in practice through examination of research literature.

courses.title: Quantitative Research Methods in Information Systems
courses.prereqs: IN4MATX 251 or IN4MATX 261. Basic knowledge of elementary statistics is also required.
courses.desc: Quantitative research methods used to study computerization and information systems. Design of instruments, sampling, sample sizes, and data analysis. Validity and reliability. Longitudinal versus cross-sectional designs. Analysis of secondary data. Studies of the methods through examination of research literature.

courses.title: Doctoral Seminar on Research and Writing
courses.desc: Doctoral seminar centered on original research and writing. Provides a chance for doctoral students at all levels to present original work, brainstorm ongoing issues, and learn to provide and receive critical feedback from peers.

courses.title: Seminar in Informatics
courses.desc: Current research and research trends in informatics. Forum for presentation and criticism by students of research work in progress.

courses.title: User Interface Design and Evaluation
courses.desc: Introduction to the design and evaluation of user interfaces, with an emphasis on methodology. Cognitive principles, design life cycle, on-line and off-line prototyping techniques. Toolkits and architectures for interactive systems. Evaluation techniques, including heuristic and laboratory methods.

courses.title: Research in Human-Centered Computing
courses.desc: Introduction to contemporary topics in human-computer interaction, including methods, technologies, design, and evaluation. Emerging application domains and their challenges to traditional research methods. Advanced architectures and technologies. Critical issues.

courses.title: Intelligent User Interfaces
courses.desc: Explores example software systems and their underlying concepts that leverage computing to empower and augment human individuals in their activities. Topics span the fields of user interface design, human-computer interaction, software engineering, and cognitive computing.

courses.title: Advanced User Interface Architecture
courses.desc: Architectural concerns in advanced interactive systems. The design of current and emerging platforms for novel interactive systems. Paradigms such as constraint-based programming, multimodal interaction, and perceptual user interfaces for individual, distributed, and ubiquitous applications.

courses.title: Usable Security and Privacy
courses.desc: Introduces usability problems in security and privacy methods, tools, and software. Overviews prominent examples of both failures and successes in usable security and privacy. Surveys state-of- the-art techniques and evaluation methodologies.

courses.title: Introduction to Ubiquitous Computing
courses.desc: The "disappearing computer" paradigm. Differences to the desktop computing model: applications, interaction in augmented environments, security, alternate media, small operating systems, sensors, and embedded systems design. Evaluation by project work and class participation.

courses.title: Ubiquitous Computing and Interaction
courses.desc: Principles and design techniques for ubiquitous computing applications. Conceptual basis for tangible and embodied interaction. Interaction in virtual and augmented environments. Design methods and techniques. Design case studies. Examination by project work.

courses.title: Introduction to Embedded and Ubiquitous Systems
courses.prereqs: I&C SCI 51 and COMPSCI 152 and COMPSCI 161 and (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 3A or MATH 6G or I&C SCI 6D). B.S. degree in Computer Science is also accepted.
courses.desc: Embedded and ubiquitous system technologies including processors, DSP, memory, and software. System interfacing basics; communication strategies; sensors and actuators, mobile and wireless technology. Using pre-designed hardware and software components. Design case studies in wireless, multimedia, and/or networking domains.

courses.title: Computer-Supported Cooperative Work
courses.desc: The role of information systems in supporting work in groups and organizations. Examines various technologies designed to support communication, information sharing, and coordination. Focuses on behavioral and social aspects of designing and using group support technologies.

courses.title: Social Analysis of Computing
courses.desc: The social and economic impacts of computing and information technologies on groups, organizations, and society. Topics include computerization and changes in the character of work, social control and privacy, electronic communities, and risks of safety-critical systems to people.

courses.title: Computerization, Work, and Organizations
courses.desc: Selected topics in the influence of computerization and information systems in transforming work and organizations. Theories of organization and organizational change. Processes by which diverse information technologies influence changes in work and organizations over short and long time periods.

courses.title: Theories of Information Society
courses.desc: Social and economic conceptions of information technology. Macrosocial and economic conditions that foster changes in information technologies. Social construction of information and computer technology in professional worlds. Theories of information technology and large-scale social change.

courses.title: Digital Media and Society
courses.desc: Selected topics in the technological and social aspects of online interactions, and policy including online games, social media, electronic activism, e-commerce, and digital libraries. Media-theoretic approaches to digital technology. Architectures, infrastructure considerations, and their consequences.

courses.title: Information Technology in Global Sustainability
courses.desc: Explores the relationship between recent developments in information technology and the global transition to sustainability. Topics include the role of IT systems in the provision of human needs and wants (e.g., smart grids, food systems, and other IT-enabled infrastructure).

courses.title: Overview of Human-Computer Interaction and Design
courses.desc: Introduction to human-computer interaction and user-centered design. The material is focused on laying the groundwork for understanding the history, importance, and methods of human-computer interaction and design.

courses.title: User Needs Analysis
courses.desc: Understanding the user's context, needs, and preferences. Topics include interviews and observations, modeling the context, flow, culture, space and artifacts involved in an endeavor, ways of aggregating what is found, and presenting these findings to others.

courses.title: Design and Prototyping
