courses.desc: Fundamentals and principles of statistical experimental design and analysis. Emphasis addresses understanding and use of designed experiments, response surfaces, linear regression modeling, process optimization, and development of links between empirical and theoretical models.

courses.title: Master of Science Thesis Project
courses.desc: Tutorial in which masters-level students taking the comprehensive examination option undertake a masters-level research project.

courses.title: Special Topics in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courses.desc: Special topics by individual faculty in major fields of interest.

courses.title: Master of Science Thesis Research
courses.desc: Individual research or investigation conducted in the pursuit of preparing and completing the thesis required for the M.S. in Engineering.

courses.title: Doctor of Philosophy Dissertation Research
courses.desc: Individual research or investigation conducted in the pursuit of preparing and completing the dissertation required for the Ph.D. in Engineering.

courses.title: Seminars in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courses.desc: Presentation of advanced topics and reports of current research efforts in mechanical engineering. Required of all graduate students in mechanical engineering.

courses.title: Individual Research
courses.desc: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Pharmacology
courses.desc: Application of pharmacological principles in disease therapy.  Advanced pharmacological mechanisms and in-depth study of drug action.  Discussion of several major drug classes/therapeutic strategies:  molecular mechanisms of action, physiological consequences of administration, and clinical use.

courses.title: Experimental Pharmacology
courses.desc: Introduction to the concepts and techniques used in pharmacological science. Molecular biology, quantitative and biochemical pharmacology, fluorescent probes, behavior, genetics, animal handling, anatomical and receptor binding analysis, methods for ion channel study, the absorption, distribution, metabolism and elimination of drugs.

courses.title: Introduction to Pharmacology
courses.desc: Ligand-gated ion channels, G protein-coupled receptors, receptor tyrosine kinases, ligand-regulated transcription factors, their signaling mechanisms, trafficking, macromolecular complexes, and physiological responses.

courses.title: Neuropharmacology
courses.desc: Mechanisms underlying chemical signaling processes in the brain and periphery. Molecular biology, signal transduction, transmitter synthesis, and inactivation of major neurotransmitter systems. Drugs that act on these major neurotransmitters.

courses.title: Experimental Design for Pharmacologists
courses.desc: Population and sample statistics, hypothesis testing, analysis of variance, nonparametric statistics, experimental design, power, and the use of statistical computer software.

courses.title: Ethics in Research
courses.desc: Ethical conduct in research including data handling, authorship, conflict of interest, animal rights, handling of misconduct.

courses.title: Applied Pharmacology
courses.desc: One week (five days, 40 hours) in-residence course offered on the UCI campus. Introduction to pharmacological techniques and current research problems; includes laboratory demonstrations and research seminars.

courses.title: Principles of Pharmacology
courses.desc: Principles of pharmacology: pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, pharmacogenetics, drug interactions, and toxicity.

courses.title: Receptors and Drug Targets
courses.desc: Molecular basis of drug-receptor interaction. Receptor properties including gene and protein structure, signaling mechanisms, trafficking and physiological effects: G-protein linked receptors, ligand-gated ion channels, receptor tyrosine kinases, nuclear receptors, and ligand regulated transcription factors.

courses.title: Research Techniques in Pharmacology
courses.desc: Experimental techniques and model systems used in pharmacological research. Receptor analysis, bioassay, molecular biology, in vitro pharmacology, biochemical pharmacology, imaging, electrophysiology, in vivo pharmacology, disease models.

courses.title: Experimental Design and Data Analysis
courses.desc: Experimental design, data analysis and interpretation. Population and sample statistics, hypothesis testing, analysis of variance, nonparametric statistics, and power calculations.

courses.title: Ethics in Scientific Research
courses.desc: Ethical conduct in research including data handling, authorship, conflict of interest, animal rights, and handling of misconduct.

courses.title: Concepts in Drug Discovery
courses.desc: Critical steps involved in discovery and optimization of a new drug. Target selection, relationship of molecular structure to pharmacological activities, screening methods, strategies to identify lead compounds, and preclinical characterization necessary for development of the drug for clinical trials.

courses.title: Special Topics in Pharmacology
courses.desc: Topics of current interest in pharmacology; discussion of recent research publications.

courses.title: Master's Project in Pharmacology
courses.desc: Capstone research paper on topic of interest in pharmacology.

courses.title: Neuropharmacology
courses.desc: Autonomic and central nervous system pharmacology, including major drug classes and therapeutic uses. Mechanisms underlying chemical signaling processes in the brain and peripheral nervous system, including neurotransmitter synthesis, inactivation, and receptor action.

courses.title: Behavioral Pharmacology
courses.desc: Pharmacology of integrative function and behavior. Drug treatment of pain. Mechanisms of reward, addiction, and drugs of abuse.

courses.title: Cardiovascular Pharmacology
courses.desc: Basic understanding of drugs used in the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease. Mechanisms of action, clinical and adverse effects.

courses.title: Endocrine, Respiratory, and Gastrointestinal Pharmacology
courses.desc: Basic understanding of drugs used in endocrine, respiratory, and gastrointestinal conditions, including hormone replacement, contraceptives, and drugs for diabetes, asthma, obesity, ulcer, and gastric reflux. Mechanisms of drug action, clinical and adverse effects.

courses.title: Seminar
courses.desc: Presentation and discussion of current problems and methods in teaching and research in pharmacology, toxicology, and therapeutics.

courses.title: Research
courses.desc: Independent research with Pharmacology and Toxicology faculty.

courses.title: Research in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
courses.desc: Individual research supervised by a particular professor.

courses.title: Research in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
courses.desc: Individual research supervised by a particular professor.

courses.title: Research in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
courses.desc: Individual research supervised by a particular professor.

courses.title: Research in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics for First-Year Students
courses.desc: Independent research within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in the Department of Microbiology and Molecular Genetics for first-year Ph.D. students.

courses.title: Research topics in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
courses.desc: Seminars presented by graduate students and faculty of the Department which explore research topics in specialized areas of microbiology and molecular genetics. Opportunity for students to gain experience in the organization, critical evaluation, and oral presentation of current research developments.

courses.title: Research topics in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
courses.desc: Seminars presented by graduate students and faculty of the Department which explore research topics in specialized areas of microbiology and molecular genetics. Oppurtunity for students to gain experience in the organization, critical evaluation, and oral presentation of current research developments.

courses.title: Research topics in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
courses.desc: Seminars presented by graduate students and faculty of the Department which explore research topics in specialized areas of microbiology and molecular genetics. Oppurtunity for students to gain experience in the organization, critical evaluation, and oral presentation of current research developments.

courses.title: Advanced Studies in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
courses.desc: Organized within each laboratory group, one to four hours. Advanced study in areas related to faculty research interests. Involves small group study based on readings, discussions, and guest speakers. May be conducted as journal clubs.

courses.title: Advanced Studies in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
courses.desc: Organized within each laboratory group, one to four hours. Advanced study in areas related to faculty research interests. Involves small group study based on readings, discussions, and guest speakers. May be conducted as journal clubs.

courses.title: Advanced Studies in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
courses.desc: Organized within each laboratory group, one to four hours. Advanced study in areas related to faculty research interests. Involves small group study based on readings, discussions, and guest speakers. May be conducted as journal clubs.

courses.title: Basic Immunology Core Lectures
courses.desc: Basic concepts in human immunology including development of the immune system, innate immunity, immunoglobulin structure and genetics, antigen-antibody reactions, the major histocompatibility complex and antigen presentation, T cell and B cell development, initiation of the immune response, effector mechanisms.

courses.title: Basic Immunology Core Lectures
courses.desc: Basic concepts in human immunology incluing development of the immune system, innate immunity, immunoglobulin structure and genetics, antigen-antibody reactions, the major histocompatibility complex and antigen presentation, T cell and B cell development, initiation of the immune response, effector mechanisms.

courses.title: Basic Immunology Core Lectures
courses.desc: Basic concepts in human immunology including development of the immune system, innate immunity, immunoglobulin structure and genetics, antigen-antibody reactions, the major histocompatibility complex and antigen presentation, T cell and B cell development, initiation of the immune response, effector mechanisms.

courses.title: Regulation of Gene Expression
courses.desc: Aspects of gene expression including the organization of the eukaryotic nucleus in terms of protein-nucleic acid interaction (i.e., chromatin and chromosome structure); the enzymology and regulation of RNA transcription and pre-mRNA processing in eukaryotes; mechanisms of RNAi and translation.

courses.title: Medical Microbiology
courses.desc: Biology of microbial pathogens (viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites) as foundation for subsequent study of infectious diseases. Topics: molecular basis of microbial pathogenesis; clinical presentation and epidemiology; diagnostic testing; antimicrobial therapy; prevention strategies. Format: lectures, laboratory, clinical cases, liveclasstech interactive questions.

courses.title: Medical Immunology
courses.desc: Cellular and molecular basis of immune response and roles of the immune system in both maintaining health and contributing to disease.

courses.title: Integrative Immunology
courses.desc: Lectures and student presentations of primary literature. The main goal is to achieve a basic understanding of the cellular and molecular basis of innate and adaptive immunity, and how immune function is coordinated at a systems level.

courses.title: Pathogenic Microbiology
courses.desc: Biochemical and genetic properties of infectious agents; identification and behavior of pathogens; activities of toxins; the chemotherapy, biochemistry, and genetics of drug resistance; and epidemiology of infectious diseases.

courses.title: Medical Virology
courses.desc: Animal viruses as disease causing agents, including mechanisms of infection at both the cellular and organismic levels. Topics include comparative studies of different groups of viruses, viral transformation, and mechanisms of viral gene expression.

courses.title: Immunopathogenic Mechanisms of Disease
courses.desc: Examination of the mechanisms underlying disease states mediated by immune dysregulation. Topics include mechanisms of immune evasion by cancer, diseases mediated by cytokine dysregulation, role of the microbiome of the GI tract and other disease sites, and adoptive T-cell therapy.

courses.title: Molecular Pathogenesis of Microbial Infections
courses.desc: Features lectures by faculty on the molecular aspects of microbial pathogenesis, highlighting both microbe and cellular functions. In addition to lectures, students review papers and discuss them. There will be two written exams, one on viruses and one on microbes.

courses.title: Molecular Mechanisms of Human Disease
courses.desc: Provides an overview of the molecular mechanisms of human diseases, including neurologic, hematologic, neoplastic, and infectious diseases. Students gain an understanding of these mechanisms, as well as models of human diseases.

courses.title: Immunology Journal Club
courses.desc: Advanced topics in immunology as related to an understanding of human disease.

courses.title: Topics in Stem Cells
courses.desc: One-hour seminar presentation by participating faculty or guest lecturer and open to the science community, followed by one-hour discussion of the lecture topic or related topic. Students are responsible for presentations and readings.

courses.title: M
courses.desc: Explores a variety of topics that impact careers of medical scientists (M.D./Ph.D students). Topics range from scientific, such as recent advances in particular research areas, to ethical problems brought on by increased technology and intervention in the disease process.

courses.title: Responsible Conduct of Research
courses.desc: Each session includes a formal presentation by faculty/invited speaker followed by a discussion of case studies related to the topic under consideration.

courses.title: Career Development
courses.desc: Topics include preparation of papers, grants and fellowships, scientific presentations, and curriculum vitae, and career opportunities.

courses.title: Tutorial in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
courses.desc: Tutorial in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics. Presented by the department chair; relates current laboratory research to the literature.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Provided for MSTP students to synthesize the basic science information learned during the basic science years of medical school and learn how to apply that knowledge toward graduate research directed at understanding the basis of human disease.

courses.title: Dissertation—Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
courses.desc: Course provided for Ph.D. students to prepare and complete the dissertation required for a Ph.D. degree.

courses.title: Research in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
courses.desc: Individual research with Molecular Biology and Biochemistry faculty.

courses.title: Research in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
courses.desc: Individual research with Molecular Biology and Biochemistry faculty.

courses.title: Research in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
courses.desc: Individual research with Molecular Biology and Biochemistry faculty.

courses.title: Research in Developmental & Cell Biology for First-year Students
courses.desc: Independent research within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in the Department of Molecular Biology and Biochemistry for first-year Ph.D. students.

courses.title: Seminars in Molecular Biology & Biochemistry
courses.desc: Presentation of research from department laboratories or, when pertinent, of other recent developments.

courses.title: Seminars in Molecular Biology & Biochemistry
courses.desc: Presentation of research from department laboratories or, when pertinent, of other recent developments.

courses.title: Seminars in Molecular Biology & Biochemistry
courses.desc: Presentation of research from department laboratories or, when pertinent, of other recent developments.

courses.title: Tutorial in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
courses.desc: Tutorials in the area of research of a particular professor which relate current research to the literature. May be conducted as journal clubs.

courses.title: Tutorial in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
courses.desc: Tutorials in the area of research of a particular professor which relate current research to the literature.  May be conducted as journal clubs.

courses.title: Tutorial in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
courses.desc: Tutorials in the area of research of a particular professor which relate current research to the literature. May be conducted as journal clubs.

courses.title: Nucleic Acid Structure and Function
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 98 and BIO SCI 99 and CHEM 51A and CHEM 51B and CHEM 51C
courses.desc: Structure and chemistry of nucleic acids. Relationship between these properties and the mechanisms of fundamental processes such as replication and repair, RNA-mediated catalysis, formation and regulation of higher order chromatin structure and recombination.

courses.title: Protein Structure and Function
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 98 and BIO SCI 99 and CHEM 51C
courses.desc: The structure and properties of proteins, enzymes, and their kinetic properties.

courses.title: Molecular Virology
courses.desc: Primary research data on the major DNA and RNA viruses emphasizing strategies of regulation of gene expression. Utilization of viruses as molecular biological tools. Graduate-level knowledge of the biochemistry and molecular biology of macromolecules is required.

courses.title: High-Resolution Structures: NMR and X-ray
courses.desc: Basic principles of magnetic resonance and x-ray crystallography toward the determination of high-resolution biomolecular structures.

courses.title: Literature in Nucleic Acid Structure and Function
courses.desc: Exploration and critical analysis of recent primary scientific literature in structure, properties, and biological mechanisms involving nucleic acids.

courses.title: Literature in Protein Structure and Function
courses.desc: Exploration and critical analysis of recent primary scientific literature in structure and properties of proteins, enzymes, and their kinetic properties.

courses.title: Integrative Immunology
courses.desc: Lectures and student presentations of primary literature. The main goal is to achieve a basic understanding of the cellular and molecular basis of innate and adaptive immunity, and how immune function is coordinated at a systems level.

courses.title: Principles of Cancer Biology I
courses.desc: Oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes are studied from molecular viewpoints. Also studies their role in cancer; viral carcinogenesis. Designed for graduate students interested in cancer research. Format includes lectures and student-led discussions.

courses.title: Principles of Cancer Biology II
courses.desc: Topics include cancer cell growth and metastasis, chemical carcinogenesis, and cancer genetics and epidemiology. Designed for graduate students interested in cancer research. Format includes lectures and student-led discussions.

courses.title: Clinical Cancer
courses.desc: Designed to acquaint students in basic life science with clinical cancer.

courses.title: Structure & Synthesis of Biological Macromolecules Journal Club
courses.desc: Advanced topics in macromolecular struture and synthesis as related to biological problems.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Immunology
courses.desc: Literature-based, interactive discussions focused on review of seminal historic and recent immunology literature. Student responsibilities include reading, critical evaluation, and discussion of manuscripts.

courses.title: Advanced Immunology Laboratory
courses.desc: An advanced course in immunology for graduate students enrolled in the Biotechnology master's program. Emphasis is placed on learning modern techniques in immunology such as ELISAs, western blotting, immunofluorescent staining assays.

courses.title: Introduction to Computational Biology
courses.desc: The use of theories and methods based on computer science, mathematics, and physics in molecular biology and biochemistry. Basics in biomolecular modeling. Analysis of sequence and structural data of biomolecules. Analysis of biomolecular functions.

courses.title: Immunlology Journal Club
courses.desc: Advanced topics in immunology as related to an understanding of human disease.

courses.title: Virology and Immunology Laboratory
courses.desc: Introductory laboratory course in virology and immunology designed for Biological Sciences graduate students. Curriculum includes plasmid preparation, plasmid characterization, microscopy, cell culture, transfection and infection of cells, cell counting, plaque assays, ELISA, Western blot, mixed lymphocyte reactions.

courses.title: Research-in-Progress Seminars
courses.desc: Two half-hour presentations by graduate students and postdoctorals to the department on their current research projects.

courses.title: Literature in Chemical and Structural Biology
courses.desc: Exploration and critical analysis of recent primary scientific literature in chemical and structural biology.

courses.title: Principles of Genomics
courses.desc: A survey course of the principal subfields of genomics and their applications to biological and health sciences that will cover genome assembly and annotation, genome structure, comparative genomics, population genomics, functional genomics, and medical genomics.

courses.title: Metallobiochemistry
courses.desc: A review of the biochemistry of metallic elements emphasizing: methods for studying metals in biological systems; the chemical basis for nature's exploitation of specific elements; structures of active sites; mechanisms; solid-state structures and devices; metals in medicine.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Biotechnology - Nucleic Acids
courses.desc: Supplements laboratory curriculum with scientific background behind experimental methods. Format consists of lectures and the presentation and analysis of relevant papers from the scientific literature.

courses.title: Biotechnology Laboratory - Nucleic Acids
courses.desc: Nucleic acid techniques and recombinant DNA technology. Extraction and purification of nucleic acids, cloning and subcloning, PCR, site-directed mutagenesis, nucleic acid hybridization, additional associated procedures. Students must demonstrate accurate documentation of data (laboratory notebook) detailing experience and results.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Biotechnology - Protein Purification and Characterization
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: MOL BIO 251L
MOL BIO 250L and MOL BIO 250
courses.desc: Supplements laboratory curriculum with scientific background behind experimental methods. Format consists of lectures and the presentation and analysis of relevant papers from the scientific literature.

courses.title: Biotechnology Laboratory - Protein Purification and Characterization
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: MOL BIO 251
MOL BIO 250L and MOL BIO 250
courses.desc: Major techniques of handling proteins and antibodies. Protein engineering, expression and large-scale purification of recombinant proteins from bacteria, HPLC, antibody purification, western blotting, additional associated procedures. Students must demonstrate accurate documentation of data (laboratory notebook) detailing experience and results.

courses.title: Biotechnology Management Laboratory
courses.desc: Overview of current methods in biotechnology, designed specifically for biotechnology graduate students. Organized into four distinct sections (nucleic acids, proteins, virology, and immunology). Students must demonstrate accurate documentation of data (laboratory notebooks) detailing experience and results.

courses.title: Biotech Management
courses.desc: Taught jointly by Bio Sci and Merage School faculty, the course addresses fundamental aspects within, and associated with, the biotechnology industry. Curriculum is focused largely on management issues, including finance, product development, pharmaceuticals, project management, regulatory affairs, and ethics.

courses.title: Stem Cell Laboratory
courses.desc: Designed to prepare M.S. Biotechnology program students for a career in stem cell research. Laboratory training utilizes tissue culture, mouse and human embryonic stem cells, and is enhanced with didactic material and discussion.

courses.title: Seminar in Systems Microbiology Research
courses.desc: A research and journal club seminar that covers topics on bacteria and phage using approaches and principles from biology, engineering, and physics.

courses.title: Science Communication Skills
courses.desc: Development of effective communication skills, oral and written presentations. Topics range from the art of creating keynote slides to strategically crafting a personal story, culminating in a live presentation to an invited audience.

courses.title: Graduate School Fundamentals
courses.desc: Lectures and discussions providing basic skills needed for success in Ph.D. graduate studies. Topics include formulating a hypothesis, experimental design, literature review, grant writing, oral communication, biostatistics, time management, and professional development.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Cancer Biology Journal Club
courses.desc: Focuses on molecular mechanisms that underlie the development and progression of cancers. Covers a variety of cancer-related research areas, such as cell cycle control, apoptosis, DNA repair, metastasis, angiogenesis, and others.

courses.title: Cancer Biology Journal Club
courses.desc: Focuses on molecular mechanisms that underlie the development and progression of cancers. Covers a variety of cancer-related research areas, such as cell cycle control, apoptosis, DNA repair, metastasis, angiogenesis, and others.

courses.title: Cancer Biology Journal Club
courses.desc: Focuses on molecular mechanisms that underlie the development and progression of cancers. Covers a variety of cancer-related research areas, such as cell cycle control, apoptosis, DNA repair, metastasis, angiogenesis, and others.

courses.title: Biomedical Research Methods
courses.desc: Lectures and interactive discussions of research methods in modern biomedical science. Each week will focus on a different class of techniques, including molecular, biochemical, immunological, genomic, bioinformatics, microscopy, cancer biology, genome editing. One hour per week, grading based on attendance.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Introduction to Music
courses.desc: Introduction to musical concepts and active listening skills. Students develop musical understanding through critical readings, selected repertoire, fundamental concepts related to rhythm, pitch, and genre.  Students apply those concepts to music from a wide range of historical and cultural origins.

courses.title: Introduction to Opera
courses.desc: Introduces students with no musical background to the dramatic and performance conventions of opera, and suggests ways of developing a critical stance vis-a-vis the social, political, gender-related and moral conflicts that are presented by composers and librettists.

courses.title: Popular Music in the United States
courses.desc: Examines the cultural, social, political, and economic dimensions of popular music in the United States over the last century and a half, with an emphasis on matters related to class, race, ethnicity, and gender.

courses.title: The Beatles and the Sixties
courses.desc: Through a study of the music of the Beatles, students are introduced to selected broader historical and cultural themes (e.g., race and music, gender and music, music and the counterculture) while developing an understanding of the basic elements of music.

courses.title: Rock: The Early Years
courses.desc: Surveys the social and cultural fabric of the post-World War II United States (from the late 1940s through the early 1970s) as seen through the prism of music - rock and roll music.

courses.title: Piano for Majors
courses.desc: For Music majors with little or no piano experience. Provides the necessary background for realizing keyboard exercises required in the theory and harmony courses, and develops skills to play and sight-read simple music from different periods.

courses.title: Musicianship I
courses.desc: Interval and chord quality identification, melodic and harmonic dictation, tonal and chromatic sight-singing, and rhythmic reading and dictation.

courses.title: Musicianship II
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: MUSIC 16B
MUSIC 15A and MUSIC 16A. MUSIC 15A with a grade of C- or better. MUSIC 16A with a grade of C- or better
courses.desc: Interval and chord quality identification, melodic and harmonic dictation, tonal and chromatic sight-singing, and rhythmic reading and dictation.

courses.title: Musicianship III
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: MUSIC 16C
MUSIC 15B and MUSIC 16B. MUSIC 15B with a grade of C- or better. MUSIC 16B with a grade of C- or better
courses.desc: Interval and chord quality identification, melodic and harmonic dictation, tonal and chromatic sight-singing, and rhythmic reading and dictation.

courses.title: Music Theory
courses.desc: Review of music fundamentals.  Triad and seventh chords, musical texture, chord spacing, embellishing tones, and introduction to diatonic harmony.  Part-writing and model composition with tonic, dominant seventh, and subdominant harmonies.

courses.title: Music Theory
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: MUSIC 15B
MUSIC 15A and MUSIC 16A. MUSIC 15A with a grade of C- or better. MUSIC 16A with a grade of C- or better
courses.desc: Introduction to phrase structure.  Part-writing and harmonization with predominants, linear dominants, 6/4 embellishing chords, leading-tone and other diatonic seventh chords.  Advanced meters and rhythmic-metric dissonance. Diatonic sequence.  Introduction to tonicization and modulation through motion to V and III.

courses.title: Music Theory
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: MUSIC 15C
MUSIC 15B and MUSIC 16B. MUSIC 15B with a grade of C- or better. MUSIC 16B with a grade of C- or better
courses.desc: Tonicization and modulation to closely related keys.  Simple binary and ternary forms.  Voice-leading reductions and simple forms.  Diatonic sequence with seventh chords.  Introduction to chromatic harmony I: modal exchange and mixture chords, the Neapolitan and augmented sixth chords.

courses.title: Theory/Musicianship
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 15C and MUSIC 16C. MUSIC 15C with a grade of C- or better. MUSIC 16C with a grade of C- or better
courses.desc: Extended homophonic and contrapuntal formal designs (continuous variations, rondo form, sonata form, invention, fugue). Embellishing chromatic chords, dominant prolongation, modulations to foreign keys, extended harmonies, chromatic sequence, chromatic voice-leading and symmetrical divisions of the octave.

courses.title: Keyboard Skills
courses.desc: Designed to develop the foundational skills of sight-reading, harmonization, transposition, improvisation, figured bass realization, and score reading.

courses.title: Keyboard Skills
courses.desc: Designed to develop the foundational skills of sight-reading, harmonization, transposition, improvisation, figured bass realization, and score reading.

courses.title: Keyboard Skills
courses.desc: Designed to develop the foundational skills of sight-reading, harmonization, transposition, improvisation, figured bass realization, and score reading.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Music
courses.desc: Gain comprehensive insight into the fundamental concepts of music theory, including notation, harmony, and score analysis. Designed for students of all levels to improve their understanding of how music is composed, performed, and heard. Formerly MUSIC 25A.

courses.title: History of European Music: From the Renaissance through the Baroque
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 16C. MUSIC 16C with a grade of C- or better
courses.desc: An introduction to the analysis of musical styles and forms, to the sources for constructing music history and reconstructing historical music, and to J.S. Bach.

courses.title: History of European Music: Hasse to Mahler
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 40B. MUSIC 40B with a grade of D or better. Recommended: MUSIC 16D
courses.desc: An introduction to the analysis of musical styles and forms, and to the sources for constructing music history and reconstructing historical music, to Richard Wagner.

courses.title: 20th Century Music
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 16C. MUSIC 16C with a grade of C- or better
courses.desc: Survey of principal composers, movements, and compositional techniques of Western art music of the modern era.

courses.title: Major Composer
courses.desc: Study of the works of an important composer with emphasis on their significance in historical and social contexts. Composers selected represent a wide variety of historical periods, nationalities, and stylistic orientations.

courses.title: Music and Gender
courses.desc: Explores various intersections between music and gender. Examines ways in which gender and sexuality have played a vital role in the creation, dissemination, and consumption of music ranging from medieval Christian mysticism to contemporary hip-hop artists.

courses.title: Classical Music in Society
courses.desc: Examines some ways in which classical music has played an integral role in aspects of society. Studies pieces from different cultural, political, and historical contexts in order to understand how musical meaning is created and interpreted.

courses.title: History of Film Music
courses.desc: Course provides an overview of film music history. Special emphasis will be placed on developing an analytic vocabulary for musical elements and cultivating an understanding of how music can function within a film.

courses.title: Music in Multimedia
courses.desc: Students explore intersections between music and other media forms through creating multimedia projects, readings, lectures, and discussion. Students produce music, edit video, increase media literacy, and study theories behind how music communicates meaning.

courses.title: Introductory Topics in Music Technology
courses.desc: Introductory topics in electronic music, digital audio, and other aspects of music technology.

courses.title: Introductory Topics in Music and Culture
courses.desc: Examines music and musical practices in different historical periods, societies, and cultural settings.

courses.title: Music Technology and Computers
courses.desc: A study of the influence of technology on the musical culture and aesthetics from the 20th century to the present, with particular emphasis on the role of the computer. Work includes lectures, readings, listenings, discussions, demonstrations, writing, and experimentation.

courses.title: Piano for Music Majors
courses.desc: Private weekly lessons. Materials fee.

courses.title: Strings for Music Majors
courses.desc: Private weekly lessons. Materials fee.

courses.title: Winds for Music Majors
courses.desc: Private weekly lessons. Materials fee.

courses.title: Voice for Music Majors
courses.desc: Private weekly lessons. Materials fee.

courses.title: Percussion for Music Majors
courses.desc: Private weekly lessons. Materials fee.

courses.title: Guitar, Lute, and Other Plucked Instruments for Music Majors
courses.desc: Private weekly lessons. Materials fee.

courses.title: History of Jazz
courses.desc: Development of jazz from African and African American folk origins through blues, early jazz, swing, bebop, "cool" jazz, fusion, free jazz, and contemporary trends.

courses.title: Experiments in Music
courses.desc: Scientists explain the cognition of music using experimental methodology; artists expand the domain of music by trying previously unknown ways of making it. These two types of experiment deepen our understanding of music, from both scientific and artistic vantage points.

courses.title: MAHUR-Pish Radif: Introduction to Classical Persian Music
courses.desc: Survey of art music in Iran and basic structures of classical Persian music, with emphasis on MAHUR modal system and different instruments of classical Persian music. No musical experience required, but interest in vocal music is strongly recommended.

courses.title: HOMAYUN-Pish Radif: Introduction to Classical Persian Music
courses.desc: Survey of art music in Iran and basic structures of classical Persian music, with emphasis on HOMAYUN modal system and famous musicians and performers of classical Persian music. No musical experience required, but interest in vocal music is strongly recommended.

courses.title: SHUR-Pish Radif: Introduction to Classical Persian Music
courses.desc: Survey of art music in Iran and basic structures of classical Persian music, with emphasis on the SHUR modal system and different poetic rhythms in classical Persian music. No musical experience required, but interest in vocal music is strongly recommended.

courses.title: Piano Literature
courses.desc: Survey of stringed keyboard literature from the English Virginalists through twentieth-century composers.  Historical, formal, and stylistic considerations of music presented. Performances by class participants and occasional outside guests.

courses.title: Piano Literature
courses.desc: Survey of stringed keyboard literature from the English Virginalists through twentieth-century composers.  Historical, formal, and stylistic considerations of music presented. Performances by class participants and occasional outside guests.

courses.title: Piano Literature
courses.desc: Survey of stringed keyboard literature from the English Virginalists through twentieth-century composers.  Historical, formal, and stylistic considerations of music presented. Performances by class participants and occasional outside guests.

courses.title: Piano Pedagogy
courses.desc: The materials and methods of piano instruction are examined and evaluated.

courses.title: Post-Tonal Theory
courses.desc: Significant harmonic, rhythmic, and structural practices since 1900. Analysis and written work exploring free atonality and serialism; neo-tonal practices such as use of extended tertian harmonies, modalism, pandiatonicism, and non-tertian harmonies; structural principles such as aleatory, metric modulation and minimalism.

courses.title: Jazz Theory
courses.desc: Study of jazz harmony and melody construction in improvisation.  Covered topics include terminology, chord symbols, notation, voicings, and scales as commonly used in jazz and popular  music.  Issues regarding tonality and ramifications of the blue scale are also examined.

courses.title: Instrumentation
courses.desc: Ranges and capabilities of modern orchestral instruments. Exercise in writing for various combinations of wind, string, and percussion instruments and for full orchestra.

courses.title: Topics in Medieval Music
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 40B. MUSIC 40B with a grade of D or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Topics in medieval music.

courses.title: Topics in Renaissance Music
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 40B. MUSIC 40B with a grade of D or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Topics in renaissance music.

courses.title: Topics in Baroque Music
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 40B. MUSIC 40B with a grade of D or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Topics in Baroque music.

courses.title: Topics in Baroque Music
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 40B. MUSIC 40B with a grade of D or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Topics in Baroque music.

courses.title: Topics in Classical Music
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 40C. MUSIC 40C with a grade of D or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Topics in Classical music.

courses.title: Topics in Classical Music
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 40C. MUSIC 40C with a grade of D or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Topics in Classical music.

courses.title: Topics in Romantic Music
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 40C. MUSIC 40C with a grade of D or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Topics in Romantic music.

courses.title: Topics in Romantic Music
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 40C. MUSIC 40C with a grade of D or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Topics in Romantic music.

courses.title: Topics in 20th Century Music
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 40D. MUSIC 40D with a grade of D or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Topics in 20th century music.

courses.title: Topics in 20th Century Music
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 40D. MUSIC 40D with a grade of D or better. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Topics in 20th century music.

courses.title: Studies in Jazz Music
courses.desc: Topics in Jazz Music.

courses.title: Studies in Music Technology
courses.desc: Specialized topics in electronic music, computer-aided music, and other aspects of music technology.

courses.title: Studies in Ethnomusicology
courses.desc: Topics in Ethnomusicology.

courses.title: Studies in Music History
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 40B and MUSIC 40C and MUSIC 40D. Satisfactory completion of the lower-division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Specialized topics in musical genres; culture and social issues; performance practices; and interrelated arts.

courses.title: Composition
courses.desc: Exercises and projects for diverse instrumental-vocal combinations; contemporary techniques and problems. Participation in the improvisation ensemble and working with electronic media.

courses.title: Computer Music Composition
courses.desc: Exercises in the composition of music uniquely possible by computer, including digital signal processing, computer control of synthesizers and processors, and algorithmic composition. Demonstrations and musical analyses in class; considerable studio work outside class.

courses.title: Interactive Arts Programming
courses.desc: Study of artistic issues and programming techniques involved in the development of interactive computer art and music. Theoretical background, basic tenets of programming, and practical exercises in programming interactive computer multimedia art.

courses.title: Counterpoint
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 16B. MUSIC 16B with a grade of C- or better
courses.desc: Studies in contrapuntal practices of various style periods such as the 16th, 18th, and 20th centuries.

courses.title: Analysis
courses.desc: Methods of formal analysis applicable to all Western musical styles: additive, continuous, transformational, and hierarchic forms; rhythm, texture, and sonority as form and process.

courses.title: Song Literature
courses.desc: A survey of song literature.  Designed as an overview of the song repertoire, German Lieder.

courses.title: Song Literature
courses.desc: A survey of song literature.  Designed as an overview of the song repertoire, French mélodie.

courses.title: Advanced Study in Composition
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 150. MUSIC 150 with a grade of C- or better
courses.desc: Individual weekly lessons in composition.

courses.title: Diction
courses.desc: In-depth study of the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA), including its transcription and pronunciation, and its application for singers.  Introduction to IPA and Italian Diction.

courses.title: Diction
courses.desc: In-depth study of the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA), including its transcription and pronunciation, and its application for singers. German Diction.

courses.title: Diction
courses.desc: In-depth study of the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA), including its transcription and pronunciation, and its application for singers. French Diction.

courses.title: Vocal Pedagogy
courses.desc: Survey about the physical structure of the singing mechanism, science, and philosophy of studio instruction.

courses.title: University Orchestra
courses.desc: Study and performance of standard orchestral repertory and works by contemporary composers.  Membership is open to all qualified students by audition only.

courses.title: Wind Ensemble
courses.desc: Study and performance of works written for varying combinations of wind and percussion instruments.  Membership is open to all qualified students by audition only.

courses.title: University Chorus
courses.desc: Make-up of the ensembles varies and may include University Chorus, Chamber Choir, Madrigal Singers, Women's Chorus, and Reading Choir. Membership is open to all qualified students by audition only.

courses.title: University Chorus: Accompanying
courses.desc: Keyboard accompanying for one of the UCI choral organizations, with individual coaching in sight reading, score reading, and other accompanying skills.

courses.title: Opera Workshop
courses.desc: Preparation and performance of operatic repertoire, including arias, scenes, and fully staged operas, and/or stage training and role analysis.

courses.title: Opera Workshop: Accompanying
courses.desc: Training in techniques and operatic repertory for keyboard players.

courses.title: Piano for Music Performance Majors
courses.desc: Private weekly lessons. Materials fee.

courses.title: Strings for Music Performance Majors
courses.desc: Private weekly lessons. Materials fee.

courses.title: String Accompaniment
courses.desc: Chamber ensemble experience with the solo string repertory for keyboard, participation in the weekly string master class, performance in public recitals.

courses.title: Winds for Music Performance Majors
courses.desc: Private weekly lessons. Materials fee.

courses.title: Voice for Music Performance Majors
courses.desc: Private weekly lessons. Materials fee.

courses.title: Percussion for Music Performance Majors
courses.desc: Private weekly lessons. Materials fee.

courses.title: Guitar, Lute, and Other Plucked Instruments for Music Performance Majors
courses.desc: Private weekly lessons and a weekly master class/workshop for the discussion of solo repertory and performance practice, including special topics such as historical notational systems, traditional American guitar styles, and demonstrations of period plucked instruments. Materials fee.

courses.title: Chamber Singers
courses.desc: A select ensemble specializing in vocal chamber music from all periods.  Frequent performances on and off campus.  Membership is open to all singers by audition.

courses.title: Chamber Ensembles
courses.desc: Make-up of the ensembles varies and may include various Classical ensembles, Latin Jazz Ensemble, Small Jazz Combos, Percussion Ensemble, and Guitar Ensemble.  Membership is open to all qualified students by audition only.

courses.title: Jazz Orchestra
courses.desc: Rehearsal and performance of literature written for large jazz ensemble with emphasis on methods and materials.  Laboratory setting for new arrangers and/or composers of modern jazz pieces.

courses.title: Music Criticism
courses.desc: Topics in Music Criticism.

courses.title: Music Criticism
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Topics in Music Criticism.

courses.title: Improvisation
courses.desc: Improvisation has been central to all music traditions. Course explores real-time music-making in a variety of non-notated contexts. Different improvisational styles are presented, including jazz, Asian improvisation, and experimental modern music. Emphasis on actual classroom performance.

courses.title: Advanced Jazz Combo
courses.desc: Small-group jazz ensemble and improvisational workshop.  Range of music covered encompasses the full traditional jazz from improvised ragtime up through the most current avant-garde musical techniques.

courses.title: Jazz Composition I
courses.desc: Performance and lecture course for writing and performing original jazz compositions.  Emphasis is placed on composing as a way to create new improvisational frameworks. Cyclical forms, modal compositions, blues-oriented compositions, and ballad writing.

courses.title: Jazz Composition II
courses.desc: Performance and lecture course for writing and performing original jazz compositions.  Emphasis is placed on composing as a way to create new improvisational frameworks. Non-functional harmony, contemporary forms, free-bop, and current trends.

courses.title: Jazz Composition III
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 78 and MUSIC 132 and MUSIC 183A and MUSIC 183B
courses.desc: Performance and lecture course for writing and performing original jazz compositions.  Emphasis is placed on composing as a way to create new improvisational frameworks. Study of modern tonal-center compositions, intervallic compositions, and alternate rhythms.

courses.title: Accompanying for Plucked Strings: Continuo and Changes
courses.desc: Students apply theory to their instruments as they learn the basics of pre-1800 continuo playing and post-1900 jazz charts. Includes discussions of appropriate repertory, treatment of harmonic progressions, and finer points of style and technique.

courses.title: Tutorial in Music
courses.desc: Supplemental instruction related to student's area of study. Taken only when the materials studied lie outside regular departmental offerings, and when the student has no formal chance to pursue the subject.

courses.title: Conducting
courses.desc: Introduces students to the basic techniques employed in the practice of conducting and includes score study and development of leadership skills.

courses.title: Senior Thesis
courses.prereqs: Senior standing in the Honors Program in Music and Culture.
courses.desc: With consultation in regularly scheduled meetings, students identify and study relevant texts and materials and prepare a prospectus for an original thesis.

courses.title: Senior Thesis
courses.desc: Students submit an outline and preliminary drafts of section of their thesis to the instructor, on a schedule supervised by the instructor. The final version will address the instructor's comments and criticisms.

courses.title: Word and Music
courses.desc: Performance class for advanced singers and pianists with emphasis on collaborative approach to vocal literature.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.prereqs: Undergraduate or graduate advisor approval required.
courses.desc: Student-devised research/composition project, with faculty guidance, resulting in a formal paper/project. Taken only when materials studied lie outside regular departmental offerings or when students have no formal chance to pursue the subject.

courses.title: Bibliography and Research
courses.desc: Required of all entering students.  A systematic introduction to the bibliographical tools both in the general field of music and in the student's areas of specialization.

courses.title: Topics in Analysis
courses.desc: Seminar focusing on different analytical methods, modal, tonal, and post-tonal, and their applications to repertories drawn from various historical periods through to the present day.

courses.title: Proseminar in Musicology
courses.desc: Introduces significant issues and recent developments in musicology and music criticism, including exposure to the controversies that have brought change and reflection to the discipline.

courses.title: Music Thesis
courses.prereqs: MUSIC 200. MUSIC 200 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Intensive work dedicated to researching and writing a Master's thesis under the supervision of a faculty advisor.

courses.title: Seminar in Creative Practices
courses.desc: Core first-year seminar required for graduate students in the Integrated Composition, Improvisation, and Technology emphasis of the M.A. and Ph.D. programs. Composition and presentation of original student works, lecture, and discussion.

courses.title: Choral Conducting
courses.desc: Intensive private instruction and study of the various choral literatures.

courses.title: Performance
courses.desc: Contents vary according to the student's major instrument. Intensive private instruction and study of the various literatures.

courses.title: Composition
courses.desc: Intensive work in composition geared to each student's level of competence.

courses.title: Orchestral Conducting
courses.desc: Intensive private instruction in instrumental conducting.

courses.title: Graduate Recital
courses.desc: Performance of public recital.

courses.title: Computer Music Composition and Production
courses.desc: Study of the composition and production of music made uniquely possible by the computer, including usage of prevalent digital music technology, techniques of digital signal processing, and computer control of synthesizers and audio processors.

courses.title: Computer Music Programming
courses.desc: Study of the artistic issues and programming techniques involved in the development of original applications for computer music composition and interactive performance.

courses.title: Seminar in Music History
courses.desc: Topics in music history.

courses.title: Seminar in Musicology
courses.desc: Focuses on current scholarship in musicology and related fields with a strong critical content. Addresses topics relative to their historical and stylistic periods. Recent topics have included Stravinsky, Holy Women, Mahler, Historiography, Issues in Performance Practice, and Brahms’s Chamber Music.

courses.title: Seminar in Music Theory and Analysis
courses.desc: Typical topics include Schenkerian theory and analysis, contemporary form theory, and advanced techniques in the analysis of late 19th-century and contemporary music (e.g., transformational theory, Neo-Riemannian and scale network theory).

courses.title: Seminar in Contemporary Music
courses.desc: Special seminar projects dealing with contemporary music with emphasis on analytical techniques and style criticism.

courses.title: Improvisation
courses.desc: Introduces the practice and history of improvisation in diverse fields of Western music since 1950. Performance projects and group critiques, weekly reading and listening assignments, participation in a class concert, and a research paper.

courses.title: Critical Studies in Music
courses.desc: A critical examination of Western music traditions, institutions, and aesthetics, employing new scholarship in music and new critical studies in other disciplines.

courses.title: Theoretical ICIT Seminar
courses.desc: Seminar studying new genres and topics that integrate composition, improvisation, new technologies, and non-classical cultures.

courses.title: Practical ICIT Seminar
courses.desc: Study of new practices and techniques that integrate composition, improvisation, new technologies, and non-classical cultures.

courses.title: Thesis Colloquium
courses.desc: ICIT students present their thesis work-in-progress for discussion and criticism. Faculty and visiting artists/scholars also present their current work.

courses.title: Graduate Projects
courses.desc: Substantial projects in performance, conducting, or composition (other than those specifically required for the degree), accompanied by a summary paper.

courses.title: Directed Research
courses.desc: Preparation for qualifying exams and dissertation, or an individual research project resulting in a substantial paper or comparable documentation of the research results.

courses.title: Contemporary Ensemble
courses.desc: Chamber ensemble for the performance of contemporary music, including newly composed and improvised forms.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Student-devised research/composition project, with faculty guidance, resulting in a formal paper/project. Taken only when materials studied lie outside regular departmental offerings or when students have no formal chance to pursue the subject.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Computer and Communication Networks
courses.desc: Network architecture of the Internet, telephone networks, cable networks, and cell phone networks. Network performance models. Network performance models. Advanced concepts and implementations of flow and congestion control, addressing, internetworking, forwarding, routing, multiple access, streaming, and quality-of-service.

courses.title: Networking Laboratory
courses.desc: A laboratory-based introduction to basic networking concepts such as addressing, sub-netting, bridging, ARP, and routing. Network simulation and design. Structured around weekly readings and laboratory assignments.

courses.title: Advanced Networks
courses.prereqs: NET SYS 201 or COMPSCI 232 or EECS 248A
courses.desc: Design principles of networked systems, advanced routing and congestion control algorithms, network algorithms, network measurement, management, security, Internet economics, and emerging networks.

courses.title: Wireless and Mobile Networking
courses.desc: Introduction to wireless networking. The focus is on layers 2 and 3 of the OSI reference model, design, performance analysis, and protocols. Topics covered include: an introduction to wireless networking, digital cellular, next generation cellular, wireless LANs, and mobile IP.

courses.title: Network and Distributed Systems Security
courses.desc: Modern computer and networks security: attacks and countermeasures, authentication, identification, data secrecy, data integrity, authorization, access control, computer viruses, network security. Group communication and multicast security techniques. Covers secure e-commerce and applications of public key methods, digital certificates, and credentials.

courses.title: Middleware for Networked and Distributed Systems
courses.prereqs: An undergraduate-level course in operating systems and networks.
courses.desc: Discusses concepts, techniques, and issues in developing distributed systems middleware that provides high performance and Quality of Service for emerging applications. Also covers existing standards (e.g., CORBA, DCOM, Jini, Espeak) and their relative advantages and shortcomings.

courses.title: Topics in Networked Systems
courses.desc: Study of Networked concepts.

courses.title: Networked Systems Seminar
courses.desc: Current research in networked systems. Includes talks by UCI faculty, visiting researchers, and Networked Systems graduate students.

courses.title: Research in Neurobiology and Behavior
courses.desc: Individual research with Neurobiology and Behavior faculty.

courses.title: Research in Neurobiology and Behavior
courses.desc: Individual research with Neurobiology and Behavior faculty.

courses.title: Research in Neurobiology and Behavior
courses.desc: Individual research with Neurobiology and Behavior faculty.

courses.title: Research in Neurobiology and Behavior
courses.desc: Individual research with Neurobiology and Behavior faculty.

courses.title: Research in Neurobiology and Behavior
courses.desc: Individual research with Neurobiology and Behavior faculty.

courses.title: Research in Neurobiology and Behavior
courses.desc: Individual research with Neurobiology and Behavior faculty.

courses.title: Foundations of Neuroscience
courses.desc: Intended to expose students to critical reading and analysis of the primary neuroscience literature. Instructors from departments associated with the Interdepartmental Neuroscience Program participate and discuss topics of current interest.

courses.title: Foundations of Neuroscience
courses.desc: Intended to expose students to critical reading and analysis of the primary neuroscience literature. Instructors from departments associated with the Interdepartmental Neuroscience Program participate and discuss topics of current interest.

courses.title: Molecular Neuroscience
courses.desc: Surveys molecular and cellular mechanisms involved in neuronal function, including control of gene expression, post-transcriptional and post-translational processing, RNA and protein targeting, cell death mechanisms, and molecular genetic basis of neurological disorders. Overview of the molecular aspects of developmental neurobiology.

courses.title: Cellular Neuroscience
courses.desc: Neurophysiological and neurochemical mechanisms of electrical and chemical signaling in neurons. Topics include generation of resting- and action-potentials, voltage- and ligand-gated ion channels, second messenger systems, and synaptic transmission and integration.

courses.title: Cellular Neuroscience Laboratory
courses.desc: Intensive hands-on laboratory experience of contemporary techniques for studying ion channels and synaptic function. Experiments include microelectrode recording, patch clamp, quantal analysis of synaptic transmission, heterologous expression of genes for channels and receptors, brain slice, and fluorescence calcium imaging.

courses.title: Systems Neuroscience
courses.desc: Study of the mammalian nervous system at the systems level. Anatomy and physiology of sensory, motor, and integrative functions.

courses.title: Behavioral Neuroscience
courses.desc: Overview of fundamental conceptual and experimental issues in the neurobiology of learning and memory. The approach is a cross-level integration of research in molecular-genetic, cellular, circuit, systems, and behavioral analyses.

courses.title: Neural Coding, Computation, and Dynamics
courses.prereqs: At least one upper-division course in the field of Neuroscience or one upper-division course in Cognitive Science or Machine Learning.
courses.desc: Theoretical principles and biological mechanisms underlying how brains acquire, assimilate, store, and retrieve information, compute adaptive responses to external inputs, and how knowledge is extracted from experience to generate an internal model of the world.

courses.title: Scientific Presentation Skills
courses.desc: A tutorial seminar on developing skills for presenting research to scientific audiences.

courses.title: Rigor, Reproducibility, and Research Methods
courses.desc: Understanding key concepts in experimental design, execution, and analysis that enhance or detract from scientific rigor.

courses.title: Epigenetics in Health and Disease
courses.prereqs: MOL BIO 203 or MOL BIO 204 or NEURBIO 206
courses.desc: Focuses on the role of chromatin/nuclear structure organization (histone and DNA modification, chromatin remodeling, higher order chromatin structure and nuclear organization) on gene regulation, DNA replication and repair, relevant to development, metabolism, learning and memory, and human disease.

courses.title: Clinical and Epidemiological Aspects of Neurodegenerative Diseases
courses.desc: Clinical and epidemiological aspects of neurodegenerative disorders causing dementia will be reviewed, including AD, PD, FTD, HD and cerebrovascular disease. Seminar format will include student presentations and group discussion.

courses.title: Regenerative Neurobiology
courses.desc: Surveys the latest research on regenerative neurobiology. Both basic stem cell discoveries and their potential clinical application to brain disorders will be examined.

courses.title: Neurobiology of Drug Addiction
courses.desc: Provides a comprehensive overview of topics in the addiction field, including drug pharmacology, models/approaches to investigate addiction, brain circuits, genetics, epigenetics, and the cellular and molecular biology of drug addiction.

courses.title: Cortex: Structure, Function, and Plasticity
courses.desc: Structured to include lectures and presentation of papers about cortex with emphasis on sensory-motor cortex. Both historical and current perspectives on cortical structure-function relationship will be critically evaluated.

courses.title: Neurobiology of Brain Aging
courses.desc: Outlines some of the significant changes that occur in the aging brain, with a special emphasis on risk factors and protective strategies that promote successful brain aging. Topics include changes in synaptic plasticity, neurotrophic factors, and molecular mechanisms in aging.

courses.title: Functional Imaging of the Nervous System
courses.desc: Overview of technical and applied aspects of imaging techniques available for studying the nervous system. The areas emphasized are cellular and subcellular imaging of neural function, systems-level imaging of brain function, and imaging of the human brain.

courses.title: Advanced Analysis of Learning and Memory
courses.desc: Advanced analysis of contemporary research concerning the nature and neurobiological bases of learning and memory. Special emphasis is given to time-dependent processes involved in memory storage.

courses.title: Programming for Neuroscience Research
courses.desc: A neuroscience-specific introduction to programming and data analysis using either MATLAB or Scientific PYTHON. Students will learn general programming skills and effective use of programming for data management, statistical analysis, and image analysis.

courses.title: Topics in Neurobiology and Behavior
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Neurobiology and Behavior. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Electronics for Biologists
courses.desc: Basic principles of electricity; properties and use of discrete components and integrated circuits; circuit analysis and design. Intended for advanced students in the life sciences.

courses.title: Molecular Neurobiology
courses.desc: The application of genetic and recombinant DNA technology to neurobiology.  Topics include the study of neuronal proteins which play important roles in the formation of synapses and synaptic transmission.

courses.title: History of Neuroscience
courses.desc: An overview of the conceptual and technical foundations of contemporary neuroscience from ancient times to the present. The subjects include synapses, neurons, brain organization, sensory, motor and regulatory systems, learning and memory, human brain function and dysfunction.

courses.title: Statistics for Neurobiologists
courses.desc: Introduction to common methods for statistical analysis used in neurobiology. Topics covered include t-tests, ANOVAs, correlations and regressions, general linear model, power analysis, and non-parametric tests.

courses.title: Auditory Neuroscience
courses.desc: Multidisciplinary overview of brain mechanisms of hearing. Emphasizes breadth of auditory function and research: single neurons to psychoacoustics, the chochlea to the cortex, and basic science to clinic.

courses.title: Colloquium in Neurobiology and Behavior
courses.desc: Presentation of contemporary research problems in neurobiology and behavior and related areas by invited speakers.

courses.title: Scientific Proposals for Neuroscience Trainees
courses.desc: Students learn how to effectively communicate scientific ideas and results. Activities include learning how to effectively write a scientific proposal, how to perform a coherent, persuasive slide presentation, and how to give meaningful, constructive review critiques.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Compassion in Health Care
courses.desc: An overview of the importance of compassion in health care, providing examples from a variety of health care professions through lectures and discussion.

courses.title: Frameworks for Professional Nursing Practice
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 112LA and NUR SCI 114A and NUR SCI 118A
BIO SCI D170 and BIO SCI E109. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Conceptual frameworks for professional practice. Scope of professional nursing, jurisprudence and ethics, professional interpersonal relationships, and health care delivery systems in the context of the social, political, and economic environments. Socialization of the student for professional roles in nursing.

courses.title: Foundations of Professional Practice
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 110W and NUR SCI 114A and NUR SCI 118A
BIO SCI E109 and BIO SCI D170
courses.desc: Development of skills in communication, interviewing, functional and physical health assessment across the life span, the art and science of human care, and clinical judgment.

courses.title: Foundations of Professional Practice
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 114B and NUR SCI 118B and NUR SCI 125 and NUR SCI 135
NUR SCI 112LA and NUR SCI 110W and NUR SCI 114A and NUR SCI 118A
courses.desc: Development of skills in communication, interviewing, functional and physical health assessment across the life span, the art and science of human care, and clinical judgment.

courses.title: Applied Pharmacology I
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 110W and NUR SCI 118A and NUR SCI 112LA
BIO SCI E109 and BIO SCI D170
courses.desc: Presents principles of pharmacology applied to interventions in pathophysiologic states across the life span. Discussion of the major drug groups with implications for monitoring, drug administration, toxicity, and patient education are included.

courses.title: Applied Pharmacology II
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 118B and NUR SCI 112LB and NUR SCI 125 and NUR SCI 135
NUR SCI 114A and NUR SCI 118A and NUR SCI 110W and NUR SCI 112LA
courses.desc: Presents principles of pharmacology applied to interventions in pathophysiologic states across the life span. Discussion of the major drug groups with implications for monitoring, drug administration, toxicity, and patient education are included.

courses.title: Human Growth and Development through the Lifespan
courses.prereqs: PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9. PSYCH 7A with a grade of C or better. PSY BEH 9 with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Examines theories and concepts of typical human development throughout the life cycle, from the time of conception through adulthood, and familiarizes students with the many forces that shape individual development, including family, society, and culture.

courses.title: Human Health and Disease I
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 114A and NUR SCI 112LA and NUR SCI 110W
BIO SCI E109 and BIO SCI D170
courses.desc: Presents content on pathologic alterations in physiologic processes in cells, tissues, organs, and systems across the life span. Emphasis on critical thinking, application of concepts to clinical practice, and related research.

courses.title: Human Health and Disease II
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 114B and NUR SCI 112LB and NUR SCI 125 and NUR SCI 135
NUR SCI 112LA and NUR SCI 114A and NUR SCI 118A and NUR SCI 110W
courses.desc: Presents content on pathologic alterations in physiologic processes in cells, tissues, organs, and systems across the life span. Emphasis on critical thinking, application of concepts to clinical practice, and related research.

courses.title: Adult Health Care
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 140
NUR SCI 112LB and NUR SCI 114B and NUR SCI 118B and NUR SCI 125 and NUR SCI 135
courses.desc: Restorative, perioperative, supportive care of adults with acute/chronic alterations in oxygenation, regulation, immune response, elimination, metabolism, mobility, cognition, and substance abuse. Concurrent practicum occurs in inpatient medical-surgical units, perioperative units and outpatient clinics utilizing critical thinking and research skills.

courses.title: Research Methods and Applications in Health Care
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 112LB and NUR SCI 114B and NUR SCI 118B and NUR SCI 135
NUR SCI 110W and NUR SCI 112LA and NUR SCI 114A and NUR SCI 118A. And a basic statistics course.
courses.desc: Foundational concepts of research in health care. Emphasizes critical evaluation and interpretation of research for application in practice.

courses.title: Maternity and Women’s Health Care
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 132
NUR SCI 120 and NUR SCI 140 and PSYCH 120D
courses.desc: Provides didactic and clinical experiences in nursing management of women’s wellness across the lifespan, the childbirth process, and newborn care. Incorporates concepts of family-centered care, teamwork and collaboration, patient safety, quality improvement and informatics, utilizing an evidence-based practice approach.

courses.title: Pediatrics: Care of Children and Families
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 130
NUR SCI 120 and NUR SCI 140 and PSYCH 120D
courses.desc: Provides didactic and clinical experiences in nursing management of infants, children, and adolescents with acute, chronic and/or life-threatening conditions. Incorporates concepts of family-centered care, teamwork and collaboration, patient safety, quality improvement and informatics, utilizing an evidence-based practice approach.

courses.title: Older Adult Health Care
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 112LB and NUR SCI 114B and NUR SCI 118B and NUR SCI 125
NUR SCI 112LA and NUR SCI 114A and NUR SCI 118A and NUR SCI 110W
courses.desc: Theories of aging and application of principles of gerontology in health maintenance of older adults. Concepts and principles of rehabilitation and palliative care.

courses.title: Human Behavior and Mental Health Care
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 120
NUR SCI 112LB and NUR SCI 114B and NUR SCI 118B and NUR SCI 125 and NUR SCI 135
courses.desc: Biopsychosocial and cultural influences on promotion and restoration of mental health in adults and adolescents. Assessment, classification, and care of clients with mental health problems and/or substance abuse. Concurrent practicum in adult/adolescent inpatient psychiatric units and outpatient mental health clinics.

courses.title: Critical and Specialty Health Care
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 160 and NUR SCI 179A
NUR SCI 130 and NUR SCI 132
courses.desc: Delivery of patient-centered care for individuals with life-threatening alterations in health status utilizing technology and pharmacology for life support. Concurrent practicum in critical care units emphasizes collaboration, team work, and quality improvement in safe care delivery.

courses.title: Leadership and Management in Health Care
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 150 and NUR SCI 179A
NUR SCI 130 and NUR SCI 132
courses.desc: Principles, concepts, and theories related to organizations, management, leadership, decision-making, and group process applied to the delivery of health care. The professional nurse using evidenced-based practice, collaboration, and informatics is incorporated in concurrent practicum emphasizing safe patient care delivery.

courses.title: Community-Based Health Care
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 175L and NUR SCI 179BW
NUR SCI 150 and NUR SCI 160 and NUR SCI 179A
courses.desc: Epidemiology, primary health care promotion, and disease prevention applied to nursing care of individuals, families, groups, and communities. Includes sociocultural, political, economic, and environmental influences. Concepts and methods of assessing populations and communities incorporated in concurrent practicum.

courses.title: Clinical Preceptorship
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 170 and NUR SCI 179BW
NUR SCI 150 and NUR SCI 160 and NUR SCI 179A
courses.desc: Independent study course focusing on critical thinking skills for nursing practice in selected clinical areas of interest to the student. The clinical experience focuses on core competencies: patient-centered care, evidence-based practice, quality improvement, safety, and informatics.

courses.title: Scholarly Concentration I
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 150 and NUR SCI 160
NUR SCI 130 and NUR SCI 132
courses.desc: Focuses on analysis and use of evidence to improve nursing practice. Emphasis is to develop critical analysis skills synthesizing a body of research evidence for clinical issues on a formal, collaborative written paper.

courses.title: Scholarly Concentration II
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: NUR SCI 170 and NUR SCI 175L
NUR SCI 179A
courses.desc: Continuation of evidence-based research and application for nursing practice. Emphasis is to develop a collaborative quality improvement project with clinical nurses applying the evidence to improve nursing practice.

courses.title: Independent Study in Nursing Science
courses.desc: Original research with Nursing Science faculty.

courses.title: Research Methods and Evaluation for Evidence-Based Practice
courses.prereqs: Undergraduate statistics course; undergraduate nursing research course.
courses.desc: Clinical research methods and evaluation procedures relevant to evidence-based advanced nursing practice.

courses.title: Advanced Pathophysiology
courses.desc: Principles of normal body functioning and pathophysiologic changes that occur as a result of compensatory mechanisms and disease. Physical and psychological aspects of altered health are explored from the cellular to the level of the total body system.

courses.title: Philosophy of Science for Nursing Scholarship
courses.desc: Development of philosophy of science in relation to nursing science, scholarship, and practice; emphasis on inquiry, scientific reasoning, and contemporary philosophical thought; historical and contemporary influences on nursing science theory development; evaluation/analysis of interdisciplinary theory and application to nursing research.

courses.title: Health Promotion/Disease Prevention
courses.desc: Covers the evidence-based national clinical preventive services guidelines for health promotion and disease prevention. Emphasizes counseling about personal health behaviors, screening tests for the early dtection of risk factors and disease, immunizations and chemo-prophylaxis.

courses.title: The Ecology of Healthy Communities
courses.desc: Nursing science research contributions and opportunities as they pertain to the ecology of health in local, national, and global communities. Emphasis on methodological and ethical issues, research gaps, and clinical translational opportunities.

courses.title: Seminar in Clinical Translational Science
courses.prereqs: Consent of the instructor is required.
courses.desc: Discussion of clinical translational science methods in the context of nursing science research. Emphasis placed on interdisciplinary and community participatory research approaches.
