courses.title: Seminar in Clinical Translational Science
courses.desc: Discussion of clinical translational science methods in the context of nursing science research. Emphasis placed on interdisciplinary and community participatory research approaches.  Course may be offered online.

courses.title: Biostatistics for Health Sciences I
courses.desc: Helps students to develop skills necessary for applying statistical principles and practices in health research. This is achieved through in-depth review of existing research articles and hands-on statistical programming exercises.

courses.title: Biostatistics for Health Sciences II
courses.desc: Introduces advanced methods of statistical analysis and research design used in health research. These include linear, logistic, Poisson regression, and a brief introduction to regression models for correlated data.

courses.title: Advanced Pharmacology I
courses.desc: Principles of pharmacology that serve as a foundation for the pharmacotherapeutic management of patients evaluated and treated by advanced practice nurses.  Emphasis includes the application of pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic principles.

courses.title: Advanced Pharmacology II
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 225A. NUR SCI 225A with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Principles of pharmacology that serve as a foundation for the pharmacotherapeutic management of patients evaluated and treated by advanced practice nurses.  Emphasis includes the application of pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic principles.

courses.title: Theoretical and Conceptual Frameworks
courses.desc: Explores the history, roles, and uses of theory in nursing and health scholarship. Students examine, analyze, and utilize the components of theory, theory construction, concept analysis, and theory evaluation.

courses.title: Grant Writing I
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 212 and NUR SCI 233 and NUR SCI 226 and NUR SCI 246 and NUR SCI 247
courses.desc: Introduction to the principles and methods of proposal writing used in preparing grant proposals. Provides content on the process for good proposal development, key elements and sections of proposal, necessary information to include in grant proposal and development of budget.

courses.title: Grant Writing II
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 227A. NUR SCI 227A with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Provides a continuation of skill building in preparing a grant proposal, with emphasis on developing the educational training plan, budget and budget justification, the IRB and ethics component, and letters of support for a career-development grant.

courses.title: Advanced Health and Physical Assessment
courses.desc: Application of theoretical concepts related to comprehensive health assessment of patients across the lifespan. Analysis, synthesis, and application of comprehensive health assessment data.

courses.title: Advanced Health and Physical Assessment Laboratory
courses.desc: Clinical laboratory course for the application of concepts related to comprehensive health assessment of patients across the lifespan.

courses.title: DNP Prologue
courses.desc: An onsite 2 ½ day immersive experience that provides an introduction to DNP scholarship and foundations essential for academic success in a doctoral program. Preparatory activities and onsite individual and group assignments are completed.

courses.title: Clinical Reasoning Competency Assessment
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 230 and NUR SCI 230L. NUR SCI 230 with a grade of B or better. NUR SCI 230L with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Hybrid lab course that focuses on comprehensive clinical application of advanced practice registered nursing physical assessment skills. Emphasis is placed on critical decision-making skills in synthesizing and analyzing assessment data at the APRN level.

courses.title: Leadership and Professional Collaboration in Healthcare
courses.desc: Explore and debate the relationship between various leadership and collaboration models, theories health care practice, and outcomes. Prepares DNP graduates to assume leadership roles across the healthcare spectrum.

courses.title: Appraisal and Translation of Evidence for Practice
courses.prereqs: Consent of the instructor is required.
courses.desc: Provides advanced concepts on research methods and measurement strategies that are applicable to support the advanced practice nurse to access, evaluate, and utilize data from various sources including research, quality improvement initiatives, and information technology origins to achieve improvements.

courses.title: Health Politics and Policy
courses.desc: Participants will analyze, apply, and evaluate current health policy-related literature, engage in the process of health policy development within professional, regulatory, or administrative environments, and develop an evidence-based health policy proposal across the spectrum of health care systems.

courses.title: DNP Scholarly Project I: Conceptualization and Planning
courses.desc: Students gain the knowledge, skills, and abilities necessary to develop an evidence-based project plan and proposal. Structured didactic content and application of the Student's DNP Scholarly Project. First of four DNP Scholarly Project courses.

courses.title: Social Determinants of Health and Health Equity
courses.desc: The four components of the Clinical Prevention and Population Health Framework: evidence-based practice, clinical preventive service and health promotion, health systems and policy, and population health and community aspects of practice with emphasis on ethical care delivery.

courses.title: DNP Intersession
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 235. NUR SCI 235 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Provides DNP students an opportunity to present and receive faculty and peer feedback on their DNP project plan. Recommendations related to practical data collection and information gathering approaches and data analysis are also emphasized.

courses.title: Foundations of Health Systems and Health Economics
courses.desc: Foundational understanding of how healthcare is financed in the U.S. Explores economic theories and policies, various types of healthcare organizations, and healthcare delivery systems. Healthcare finance is discussed at national and practice levels.

courses.title: The Science of Change, Quality Improvement, and Program Evaluation
courses.desc: Intro to science of quality improvement and program evaluation. Focus on info system technology and its application in quality improvement. Focus placed on the role of the advanced practice nurse leader in developing and leading clinical quality and safety initiatives.

courses.title: DNP Scholarly Project II: Proposal
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 237. NUR SCI 237 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Developing a full proposal that reflects synthesis of the student's knowledge from prior coursework and work in an area of interest or expertise under the direction of a faculty mentor. Second of four DNP Scholarly Project course sequence.

courses.title: DNP Scholarly Project III: Implementation and Evaluation
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 240. NUR SCI 240 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Continued development of knowledge, skills, and abilities to implement the chosen DNP proposal. Students receive direction from a faculty mentor and peer feedback as they become engaged in the microsystem where they are implementing their DNP Scholarly Project.

courses.title: DNP Scholarly Project IV: Implications
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 241. NUR SCI 241 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Selection and implementation of evidence-based interventions supported through informatics and technological advances and measurement of outcomes in a selected practicum site as applicable. Includes reflection and mapping of the DNP Scholarly Project with DNP Essentials as published.

courses.title: DNP Epilogue
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 242. NUR SCI 242 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: DNP students develop DNP competency through the presentation of their project and development of a professional manuscript. Individual direction from the DNP Project Team and peer feedback are provided throughout the course.

courses.title: Primary Care Adult/Gerontology Acute Common Conditions
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 210 and NUR SCI 230. NUR SCI 210 with a grade of B or better. NUR SCI 230 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Assessment and management of acute or episodic problems affecting patients and families across the lifespan. Diagnostics, pharmacology, pathophysiology, and therapeutics are integrated. Concepts of quality health care, resource management, and shared-decision making are emphasized.

courses.title: Qualitative Research Designs in Nursing Science
courses.desc: Seminar in qualitative research philosophies, methods, and analysis in nursing science clinical research. Consideration of population access and sampling, ethics, data management, analytical approaches, and translational potential.

courses.title: Quantitative Research Designs in Nursing Science
courses.desc: Seminar in experimental and survey research designs, methods, and analysis in nursing science clinical research. Consideration of measurement issues, mixed methods models, population access and sampling, data management, analytical approaches, and translational potential.

courses.title: Curricular Design for the Health Professions
courses.desc: Introduces students to the theoretical foundations, essential components, and accreditation standards for curriculum development at the program level. Outcome competencies are addressed as they apply to the development and evaluation of an educational program to meet society’s diverse healthcare needs.

courses.title: Transformational Leadership in Education for the Health Professions
courses.desc: Students are introduced to the role of the nurse educator as change agent, leader, and scholar and provided experience in planning learner-centered learning activities that are engaging and effective in achieving desired student performance.

courses.title: Primary Care Women's Health
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 210 and NUR SCI 230. NUR SCI 210 with a grade of B or better. NUR SCI 230 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Primary health care needs of women including adolescent, adult, and aging adults.  Emphasizes assessment, diagnosis, prevention, management, and education of common gynecologic and family planning health care needs.

courses.title: Primary Care Obstetrics
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 210 NUR SCI 230. NUR SCI 210 with a grade of B or better. NUR SCI 230 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Assessment and management of women during pregnancy. Diagnostics, pharmacology, pathophysiology and therapeutics are integrated. Includes assessment, differential diagnosis, management, patient/family education, and counseling related to normal pregnancy care.

courses.title: Primary Care Adult/Gerontology Chronic Conditions
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 245. NUR SCI 245 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Assessment and management of acute or episodic problems affecting adult and geriatric patients and their families. Diagnostics, pharmacology, pathophysiology, and therapeutic are integrated.

courses.title: Foundations of Professional Nursing Practice
courses.desc: Focuses on the development of skills in therapeutic communication, interviewing, functional assessment across the lifespan, the art and science of human care, and clinical judgment. Faculty-facilitated, participatory peer group, and self-learning laboratory activities are included.

courses.title: Frameworks for Professional Nursing Practice
courses.desc: A theory-intensive course focused on conceptual frameworks for professional nursing practice. Topics address the professional, political, and economic contexts of nursing practice, with an emphasis on jurisprudence and ethics, professional interpersonal relationships, and nursing’s role in the care delivery system.

courses.title: Applied Pharmacology I
courses.desc: Principles of pharmacology applied to intervention in pathophysiologic states across the life span. Discussion of the major drug groups with implications for monitoring, drug administration, toxicity, and patient education included. Physical, psychological, social, and cultural factors affecting drug administration.

courses.title: Applied Pharmacology II
courses.desc: Principles of pharmacology applied to intervention in pathophysiologic states across the life span. Discussion of the major drug groups with implications for monitoring, drug administration, toxicity, and patient education included. Physical, psychological, social, and cultural factors affecting drug administration.

courses.title: Older Adult Health Care
courses.desc: Analyzes the interaction of physical, pathophysiological, psychological, social, cultural, and health care policy factors influencing the health and health care of older adults. Topics include health risk factors, health assessment, acute illness and chronic conditions, and ethical issues.

courses.title: Adult Health Care
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 200 and NUR SCI 262 and NUR SCI 264A and NUR SCI 264B and NUR SCI 268A and NUR SCI 268B and NUR SCI 265 and NUR SCI 281
courses.desc: Focuses on the restorative, peri-operative, and supportive nursing management of adults with acute or chronic alterations in oxygenation, regulation, immune response, elimination, metabolism, mobility, cognition, and substance abuse. Diagnostics, pharmacology, pathophysiology, and therapeutics will be integrated.

courses.title: Human Behavior and Mental Health Nursing
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 200 and NUR SCI 262 and NUR SCI 264A and NUR SCI 264B and NUR SCI 268A and NUR SCI 268B and NUR SCI 265 and NUR SCI 281
courses.desc: Focuses on nursing management of individuals across the lifespan with alterations in mental health. Mental health promotion and crisis intervention, chemical dependency, acute and chronic care for psychiatric conditions, rehabilitation, and recovery will be addressed.

courses.title: Pathophysiology I
courses.desc: Focuses on pathologic alterations in physiologic processes in cells, tissues, organs, and systems across the life span. Content includes disease processes, linkage of relevant physiology to disease states, and factors that influence epidemiology and pathophysiology.

courses.title: Pathophysiology II
courses.desc: Focuses on pathologic alterations in physiologic processes in cells, tissues, organs, and systems across the life span. Content includes disease processes, linkage of relevant physiology to disease states, and factors that influence epidemiology and pathophysiology.

courses.title: Primary Care Pediatrics
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 210 and NUR SCI 230. NUR SCI 210 with a grade of B or better. NUR SCI 230 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Assessment and management of acute or episodic problems affecting pediatric patients and their families. Diagnostics, pharmacology, pathophysiology, and therapeutics are integrated.

courses.title: Community-Based Health Care
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 215 and NUR SCI 274 and NUR SCI 276
courses.desc: Epidemiology, primary health care promotion, and disease prevention applied to nursing care of individuals, families, groups, and communities. Includes sociocultural, political, economic, and environmental influences. Concepts and methods of assessing populations and communities incorporated in concurrent practicum.

courses.title: Pediatrics: Care of Children and Families
courses.desc: Provides didactic and clinical experiences in nursing management of infants, children, and adolescents with acute, chronic, and/or life-threatening conditions. Incorporates concepts of family-centered care, teamwork and collaboration, patient safety, quality improvement and informatics, utilizing an evidence-based practice approach.

courses.title: Maternity and Women’s Health Care
courses.desc: Provides didactic and clinical experiences in nursing management of women’s wellness across the lifespan, the childbirth process, and newborn care. Incorporates concepts of family-centered care, teamwork and collaboration, patient safety, quality improvement and informatics, utilizing an evidence-based practice approach.

courses.title: Critical and Specialty Health Care
courses.desc: Focuses on the restorative, supportive care of individuals with life-threatening alterations in health status utilizing technology and pharmacology for life support. The course includes pathophysiology, diagnostics, monitoring, pharmacology, therapeutics, and evidence-based management interventions will be integrated.

courses.title: Clinical Preceptorship
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 215 and NUR SCI 274 and NUR SCI 276
courses.desc: Independent study course focusing on in-depth clinical nursing practice in a selected clinical area of interest to the graduate student. Students are mentored by a preceptor who is an expert clinician in the area.

courses.title: Leadership and Management in Health Care
courses.desc: Explores the professional nurse as leader and manager of a health care team. Principles and theories related to organizations, leadership, decision-making, and group process are applied to the delivery of health care at the individual and population levels.

courses.title: Frameworks for the Advanced Practice Registered Nursing Role: Nurse Practitioner
courses.desc: Orientation to the scope and standards of advanced practice registered nursing pertinent to the APRN role. Principles of jurisprudence, ethics, and advocacy will be introduced along with conceptual frameworks for advanced nursing practice.

courses.title: Professional Issues in Nursing
courses.desc: Provides an orientation to the scope and standards of professional nursing practice for master's students. The social, political, and economic environments affecting health care delivery systems and the ethics of professional nursing practice are analyzed.

courses.title: Compassionate Care with Underserved Populations
courses.desc: Addresses theory/research on health risk factors (e.g., psychiatric illness, sociocultural and economic characteristics) that impact patient health and well-being across the lifespan. Emphasis is on cultural awareness, lifestyle modification, community resources, and communication/coping strategies to promote well-being.

courses.title: Primary Care Procedures
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 245. NUR SCI 245 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Introduces the theoretical basis for common procedures performed in primary care clinical practice. Focus includes EKG interpretation, x-ray interpretation, minor surgery, and orthopaedic procedures.

courses.title: Scholarly Concentration
courses.desc: Independent study focusing on critique, analysis, and synthesis of research evidence as a basis for graduate practice nursing in an area of interest to the student.

courses.title: DNP APRN Practicum I
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 210 and NUR SCI 230 and (NUR SCI 230L or NUR SCI 231L). NUR SCI 210 with a grade of B or better. NUR SCI 230 with a grade of B or better. NUR SCI 230L with a grade of B or better. NUR SCI 231L with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Clinical application of theory and research related to the advanced assessment and health promotion of patients across the lifespan.

courses.title: DNP APRN Practicum II
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 285. NUR SCI 285 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Clinical field study applying theory, research, and developing clinical skills related to the provision of care to patients and their families in increasingly complex clinical situations.

courses.title: DNP APRN Practicum III
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 286. NUR SCI 286 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Clinical application of theory and research through clinical experiences in selected primary care settings designed to provide students with competencies in the assessment, diagnosis, management, and education/counseling in selected populations.

courses.title: DNP APRN Practicum IV
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 287. NUR SCI 287 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Continued clinical application of theory and research through clinical experiences in selected primary care settings designed to provide students with competencies in the assessment, diagnosis, management, and education/counseling in selected populations.

courses.title: DNP APRN Practicum V
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 288. NUR SCI 288 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Culminating clinical experience serves as a transition from the student role to that of the advanced practice nurse.

courses.title: DNP APRN Practicum VI
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 289. NUR SCI 289 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Through continued clinical experience, students demonstrate increased responsibility and accountability for performance as an advanced practice nurse and clinical scholar, synthesizing knowledge of pathophysiology and disease management, evidence-based guidelines, anticipatory guidance, models of provider-patient communication, and provision of educational resources.

courses.title: DNP Practicum I
courses.desc: Implementation and evaluation of an evidence-based, DNP project in an area of advanced practice in partnership with a selected agency or organization that solves a practice problem or improves population health, educational, or performance outcomes.

courses.title: DNP Practicum II
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 291. NUR SCI 291 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Implementation and evaluation of an evidence-based, DNP project in an area of advanced practice in partnership with a selected agency or organization that solves a practice problem or improves population health, educational, or performance outcomes.

courses.title: DNP Practicum III
courses.prereqs: NUR SCI 292. NUR SCI 292 with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Implementation and evaluation of an evidence-based, DNP project in an area of advanced practice in partnership with a selected agency or organization that solves a practice problem or improves population health, educational, or performance outcomes.

courses.title: Directed Study in Vulnerable Populations
courses.desc: Independent study that focuses on individually designed clinical learning experiences and goals within a selected vulnerable population, such as the homeless, veterans, minority groups, etc. Students work in a clinical setting addressing health care needs of the vulnerable population(s).

courses.title: Doctoral Dissertation Reading and Writing
courses.desc: Dissertation research with Nursing Sciences faculty.

courses.title: Directed Studies in Nursing Science
courses.desc: Directed study with Nursing Science faculty.

courses.title: Independent Study in Nursing Science
courses.desc: Independent research with Nursing Science faculty.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Research in Experimental Pathology
courses.desc: Independent research for the Ph.D. program within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in Experimental Pathology.

courses.title: Research in Experimental Pathology
courses.desc: Independent research for the Ph.D. program within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in Experimental Pathology.

courses.title: Research in Experimental Pathology
courses.desc: Independent research for the Ph.D. program within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in Experimental Pathology.

courses.title: Research in Experimental Pathology for First-Year Students
courses.desc: Independent research within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in Experimental Pathology for first-year Ph.D. students.

courses.title: Advanced Studies in Experimental Pathology
courses.desc: A tutorial course for Ph.D. students in Experimental Pathology entailing attendance at Departmental seminars and critical reading of the scientific literature.

courses.title: Advanced Studies in Experimental Pathology
courses.desc: A tutorial course for Ph.D. students in Experimental Pathology entailing attendance at Departmental seminars and critical reading of the scientific literature.

courses.title: Advanced Studies in Experimental Pathology
courses.desc: A tutorial course for Ph.D. students in Experimental Pathology entailing attendance at Departmental seminars and critical reading of the scientific literature.

courses.title: Experimental Pathology Research Seminar
courses.desc: Seminar series for graduate students in Experimental Pathology. Students attend seminars and, beginning in their third year of graduate study, present one formal seminar on their graduate research.

courses.title: Experimental Pathology Research Seminar
courses.desc: Seminar series for graduate students in Experimental Pathology. Students attend seminars and, beginning in their third year of graduate study, present one formal seminar on their graduate research.

courses.title: Experimental Pathology Research Seminar
courses.desc: Seminar series for graduate students in Experimental Pathology. Students attend seminars and, beginning in their third year of graduate study, present one formal seminar on their graduate research.

courses.title: Immunopathogenic Mechanisms of Disease
courses.desc: Examination of the mechanisms underlying disease states mediated by immune dysregulation. Topics include mechanisms of immune evasion by cancer, diseases mediated by cytokine dysregulation, role of the microbiome of the GI tract and other disease sites, and adoptive T-cell therapy.

courses.title: Molecular Mechanisms of Human Disease
courses.desc: Provides an overview of the molecular mechanisms of human diseases, including neurologic, hematologic, neoplastic, and infectious diseases. Students gain an understanding of these mechanisms, as well as models of human diseases.

courses.title: Topics in Experimental Pathology
courses.desc: Select topics related to principles of experimental pathology including normal host responses to disease are presented. Animal models of human disease are emphasized. Material includes both lectures and critical review of the primary literature.

courses.title: Experimental Pathology Journal Club
courses.desc: Graduate-level course, which is open to all years, will involve the reading and discussion of papers, preferably written by the invited seminar speaker. Discussions will cover advanced topics in experimental pathology as related to an understanding of human disease.

courses.title: Principles of Experimental Pathology
courses.desc: Introduces graduate students to the general pathologic processes that mediate disease. Topics include cell injury and repair, inflammation, immunopathology, neoplasia, and genetic diseases. Combines lecture, small group discussion, and oral presentations.

courses.title: Pathology of Cardiovascular Diseases
courses.desc: For graduate students interested in human cardiovascular disease. Students receive training in physiology, anatomy, and pathologic processes of the heart and blood vessels. Experimental approaches to study such processes are emphasized.

courses.title: Pathology of Pulmonary Diseases
courses.desc: For graduate students interested in pulmonary disease. Students receive training in physiology, anatomy, and pathologic processes of the lungs and airways. Experimental approaches to study such processes are emphasized.

courses.title: Pathology of Renal Diseases
courses.desc: For graduate students interested in renal disease. Students receive training in physiology, anatomy, and pathologic processes of the kidneys. Experimental approaches to study such processes are emphasized.

courses.title: Pathology of Gastrointestinal Diseases
courses.desc: For graduate students interested in grastrointestinal disease. Students receive training in physiology, anatomy, and pathologic processes of the gastrointestinal tract. Experimental approaches to study such processes are emphasized.

courses.title: Pathology of Gastrointestinal Diseases
courses.desc: For graduate students interested in grastrointestinal disease. Students receive training in physiology, anatomy, and pathologic processes of the gastrointestinal tract. Experimental approaches to study such processes are emphasized.

courses.title: Pathology of Genitourinary Tract Disease
courses.desc: For graduate students interested in genitourinary tract or breast disease. Students receive training in physiology, anatomy, and pathologic processes of the breast and genitourinary tract. Experimental approaches to study such processes are emphasized.

courses.title: Pathology of Genitourinary Tract Disease
courses.desc: For graduate students interested in genitourinary tract or breast disease. Students receive training in physiology, anatomy, and pathologic processes of the breast and genitourinary tract. Experimental approaches to study such processes are emphasized.

courses.title: Graduate Neuropathology
courses.desc: For graduate students interested in diseases of the nervous system. Students receive training in physiology, anatomy, and pathologic processes of the central and peripheral nervous system. Experimental approaches to study such processes are emphasized.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Dissertation in Experimental Pathology
courses.desc: Provided for the preparation and completion of the dissertation required for the Ph.D. degree.

courses.title: Introduction to Medical Genetics and Cytogenetics
courses.desc: Covers current concepts regarding mitosis, meiosis, the cell cycle, and chromosome ultrastructure and function. Clinical disorders caused by chromosomal aneuploidy, duplication, and deletion, and principles of Mendelian, chromosomal, and multifactorial and nontraditional inheritance are presented and illustrated.

courses.title: Genetic Screening, Prenatal Development, and Human Teratology
courses.desc: Principles and techniques of prenatal, neonatal, and carrier screening. Infertility, pregnancy, and delivery. Normal and abnormal prenatal growth and development. Reproductive and fetal effects of drugs, radiation, infections, and other environmental factors.

courses.title: Human Genetic Disorders
courses.desc: Inheritance, diagnosis, natural history, management, and counseling considerations for commonly encountered genetic diseases, birth defects, and dysmorphic syndromes.

courses.title: Disorders due to Inborn Errors of Metabolism
courses.desc: Aspects of biochemistry and metabolism are reviewed with special emphasis on genetic abnormalities which lead to inborn errors of metabolism. Diagnostic procedures, heterozygote detection, treatment, counseling issues, and prenatal diagnosis are reviewed.

courses.title: Molecular Genetics, Gene Mapping, and Genetic Linkage
courses.desc: Derivation of different types of DNA probes and DNA libraries, restriction endonuclease polymorphisms, assignment of genes to chromosomes, and genetic linkage.  Emphasis on the use of recombinant DNA technologies and genetic analysis for diagnosis of human genetic disease.

courses.title: Quantitative Genetics
courses.desc: Quantitative aspects of human genetics, including population studies, segregation analysis, linkage, mapping, and genetic risk determination.

courses.title: Hereditary Cancer Counseling
courses.desc: Issues in genetic counseling for cancer. Cancer biology; genetic mechanisms and environmental influences in carcinogenesis; tumor pathology; cancer gene mapping; epidemiology. Features natural history, diagnosis, prevention, surveillance, and management of heredity cancers. Psychosocial, ethical, legal aspects of cancer risk assessment.

courses.title: Genetic Counselin Research Design
courses.desc: Quantitative and qualitative methods for genetic counseling research. Reference management; statistics: sample size, power, and data analysis; reliability and validity; surveys, questionnaires, interviews, focus groups; quality of life and genetic epidemiology research; designing a research protocol; IRB issues; grant writing.

courses.title: Cytogenetics Laboratory
courses.desc: Practicum introducing methods of specimen collection, short-term lymphocyte and bone marrow culture, long-term fibroblast and amniocyte culture, harvesting and slide preparation, chromosome staining, microphotography, and darkroom techniques. Microscopic chromosome analysis, photographic karyotyping, and appropriate use of cytogenetic nomenclature are emphasized.

courses.title: Introduction to Genetic Counseling
courses.desc: Through directed readings, observing patient evaluations, role-playing, and conducting intake interviews, students are introduced to the process of diagnosis, management, and counseling for genetic disease. Psychosocial issues, interviewing techniques, pedigree construction, clinical photography, and various other skills are addressed.

courses.title: Clinical Rotation I
courses.desc: Provides extensive supervised experience in history taking, interviewing, and psychosocial assessment in the clinical genetics setting. Students independently perform telephone, office, and home-visit intake interviews, participate in counseling, and present cases at patient management conferences.

courses.title: Clinical Rotation II
courses.desc: Provides further supervised experience in genetic counseling, case management, clinic administration and organization, and the use of community resources. Emphasis is on sharpening counseling skills and on developing a professional identity and code of ethics.

courses.title: Prenatal Diagnosis Counseling
courses.prereqs: PED GEN 200A and PED GEN 200B and PED GEN 200C
courses.desc: A practicum with extensive supervised experience in prenatal diagnosis counseling which provides the student with the opportunity to conduct genetic counseling sessions semi-independently and to further develop clinical skills.

courses.title: Counseling in Human Genetics: Theory and Methods
courses.desc: Theoretical approaches, counseling models and methods, and bio-psychosocial assessment strategies are examined in the context of genetic counseling. Contract-setting, working alliance, the use of self and evaluation methods. Beginning counseling and peer supervision skills are practiced in class.

courses.title: Community Resources
courses.desc: Lectures, guest speakers, and community visits acquaint genetic counselors with public and private health care and funding agencies, parent support and advocacy groups, and other resources to assist individuals and families confronted with genetic disorders, developmental disabilities, and birth defects.

courses.title: Ethical Issues in Human Genetics
courses.desc: Explores major social, legal, and ethical issues in genetic counseling including those arising in genetic screening, prenatal diagnosis, informed consent, privacy and confidentiality, rights of the disabled, new genetic and reproductive technologies, treatment, and access to services.

courses.title: Counseling in Human Genetics: Putting Thought to Practice
courses.desc: Builds upon the skills learned in previous courses emphasizing advanced counseling methods such as listening, empathy, and collaboration. The counselor's own self-awareness, ethical behaviors, and limits are explored. Individual, team, and group exercises are performed.

courses.title: Professional Skills Development
courses.desc: Hones and augments existing competencies in genetic counseling through ongoing clinical experiences. Develops skills using computers for genetics applications, provision of community and professional education, and clinic administration. Further experience in genetics laboratories or specialty clinics may be elected.

courses.title: Professional Skills Development
courses.desc: Hones and augments existing competencies in genetic counseling through ongoing clinical experiences. Develops skills using computers for genetics applications, provision of community and professional education, and clinic administration. Further experience in genetics laboratories or specialty clinics may be elected.

courses.title: Professional Skills Development
courses.desc: Hones and augments existing competencies in genetic counseling through ongoing clinical experiences. Develops skills using computers for genetics applications, provision of community and professional education, and clinic administration. Further experience in genetics laboratories or specialty clinics may be elected.

courses.title: Master's Thesis and Research Writing
courses.desc: Under the supervision of one or more faculty members, the student designs and conducts a research project or completes a case report. A problem in the cytogenetics, biochemical, clinical, psychosocial, or behavioral areas of medical genetics may be investigated.

courses.title: Fundamentals in Persian
courses.desc: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Persian. Students learn the modern writing system and grammar of Persian. Facilitates basic reading, writing, and speaking skills and fosters college-level literacy in Persian culture.

courses.title: Fundamentals in Persian
courses.prereqs: PERSIAN 1A. PERSIAN 1A with a grade of C or better. Placement into PERSIAN 1B is also accepted.
courses.desc: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Persian. Students learn the modern writing system and grammar of Persian. Facilitates basic reading, writing, and speaking skills and fosters college-level literacy in Persian culture.

courses.title: Fundamentals in Persian
courses.prereqs: PERSIAN 1B or PERSIAN S1AB. PERSIAN 1B with a grade of C or better. PERSIAN S1AB with a grade of C or better. Placement into PERSIAN 1C is also accepted.
courses.desc: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Persian. Students learn the modern writing system and grammar of Persian. Facilitates basic reading, writing, and speaking skills and fosters college-level literacy in Persian culture.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Persian
courses.desc: First half of first-year Persian. Designed for students with little or no exposure to Persian. Students learn the modern writing system and grammar of Persian. Facilitates basic reading, writing, and speaking skills. Fosters college-level literacy in Persian culture.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Persian
courses.prereqs: PERSIAN S1AB or PERSIAN 1B. PERSIAN S1AB with a grade of C or better. PERSIAN 1B with a grade of C or better. Placement into PERSIAN S1BC is also accepted.
courses.desc: Second half of first-year Persian. Continuation of S1AB, or for students with limited exposure to Persian. Students learn the modern writing system and grammar of Persian. Facilitates basic reading, writing, and speaking skills. Fosters college-level literacy in Persian culture.

courses.title: Intermediate Persian
courses.prereqs: PERSIAN 1C or PERSIAN S1BC. PERSIAN 1C with a grade of C or better. PERSIAN S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into PERSIAN 2A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Designed for students to advance their Persian language skills from introductory to intermediate level. Student will advance their understanding of grammar and syntax. Facilitates intermediate-level reading, writing, and speaking skills. Fosters college-level cultural literacy.

courses.title: Intermediate Persian
courses.prereqs: PERSIAN 2A. PERSIAN 2A with a grade of C or better. Placement into PERSIAN 2B is also accepted.
courses.desc: Designed for students to advance their Persian language skills from introductory to intermediate level. Students will advance their understanding of grammar and syntax. Facilitates intermediate-level reading, writing, and speaking skills. Fosters college-level cultural literacy.

courses.title: Intermediate Persian
courses.prereqs: PERSIAN 2B. PERSIAN 2B with a grade of C or better. Placement into PERSIAN 2C is also accepted.
courses.desc: Designed for students to advance their Persian language skills from introductory to intermediate level. Students will advance their understanding of grammar and syntax. Facilitates intermediate-level reading, writing, and speaking skills. Fosters college-level cultural literacy.

courses.title: Persian Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program
courses.desc: Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program in which student mentors work with student mentees to increase the language skills of both participants. One hour weekly meetings. PERSIAN 10A is for language mentors.

courses.title: Persian Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program
courses.desc: Peer-to-Peer Language Mentor Program in which student mentors work with student mentees to increase the language skills of both participants. One hour weekly meetings. PERSIAN 10B is for language mentees.

courses.title: Persian Culture
courses.desc: Study of varied topics in Persian culture, area studies, and society, both in the present and in historical perspective. Topics are not normally repeated for a two-year period.

courses.title: Topics in Advanced Persian Culture
courses.desc: In-depth examination of major works in premodern and modern Persian literature and/or the arts, with specific emphasis upon historical and cultural context and relevant societal issues and trends. Course is conducted in English.

courses.title: Modern Iran: Cinema and the City
courses.desc: Exploring modern Iran through film, literature, photography, travel writing, and philosophy and social science texts that introduce students to important concepts in post-colonial studies, social thought, war culture, religion, and media as experienced through the paradigm of a non-Western modernity.

courses.title: New Student Seminar
courses.desc: Weekly meetings consisting of presentations by faculty, professional staff, and Peer Academic Advisors provide information about the Pharmaceutical Sciences major, campus resources, learning skills, and special programs and opportunities.

courses.title: Professional Development and Careers in the Pharmaceutical Sciences
courses.desc: Designed to help Pharmaceutical Science majors select a career track and prepare for graduate program applications and careers in industry.

courses.title: Life 101
courses.desc: Covers the latest scientific work on the impact of nutrition, exercise, and lifestyle choices on mental and physical health. The course will motivate students to make positive changes by fostering personal growth.

courses.title: Ethical Conduct of Research
courses.desc: Covers the ethical responsibilities of biomedical scientists. Topics include, as discussions and case studies, the high standards of science, the responsible conduct of research, animal experimentation, and clinical trials as they relate to the pharmaceutical sciences.

courses.title: Drugs and Society
courses.prereqs: Recommended: High school chemistry and biology.
courses.desc: Where drugs come from, how drugs work, how and why people abuse drugs, the costs of drug abuse on society, which drugs are commonly abused, and how drug abuse can be prevented and treated. Course intended for non-science majors.

courses.title: Speaking about Science
courses.desc: Students learn to effectively prepare and present public speeches and slide presentations. Included are storytelling, informative, commemorative, and persuasive speeches, and scientific presentation. Evaluating speeches and strategies to reduce speaker apprehension is also covered.

courses.title: Human Physiology
courses.desc: Covers the function of the human body. All major organ systems are discussed. Designed to prepare students for healthcare careers, such as medicine, pharmacy, dentistry, and for research careers which require basic knowledge of how the human body functions.

courses.title: Human Physiology Lab
courses.desc: Designed to complement PHRMSCI 120. Computer-based lab simulations will be used to study the function of the human body. Class will physically meet for review sessions and exams.

courses.title: Neuropsychopharmacology
courses.prereqs: PHRMSCI 170A. PHRMSCI 170A with a grade of C- or better
courses.desc: Mechanisms underlying chemical signaling processes in the nervous system. Fundamental knowledge for understanding the cellular and molecular actions of drugs and their mechanisms of action on synaptic transmission. Applied neuropsychopharmacology including major drug classes and therapeutic uses.

courses.title: Pharmacogenomics and Epigenetics
courses.desc: Survey of the genetic and epigenetic basis of inter-subject variability in response to drugs. Covers drug efficacy, safety, and need for their optimization in pharmacotherapy. Emphasizes genetic mechanisms of polymorphisms in the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of representative therapeutic drugs.

courses.title: Molecular Pharmacology I
courses.desc: Molecular basis of drug-receptor action at the molecular and cellular levels. Structure-function of drug targets emphasizing enzymes, ion channels, and membrane transport proteins. Understanding how the drugs' mechanisms of action contribute to the development of more efficacious and safer drugs.

courses.title: Molecular Pharmacology II
courses.desc: Introductory survey covering the molecular mechanisms of drugs that target the nervous system, such as anxiolytics, antidepressants, antipsychotics, hypnotics, muscle relaxants, and recreational drugs; drugs related to the immune system, including antibiotics, antihistamines, and immunosuppressants; drugs used to treat cancer.

courses.title: Physical Biochemistry
courses.prereqs: MATH 2B and PHYSICS 3C and (CHEM 1C or CHEM H2C) and BIO SCI 99
courses.desc: Thermodynamics and kinetic fundamentals as applied to problems relevant to pharmaceutical sciences such as receptor/enzyme-ligand interactions. Fundamentals of biophysical methods used in the pharmaceutical sciences including structure determination and biomolecular spectroscopy.

courses.title: Topics in Pharmaceutical Sciences
courses.desc: Presents information about various fields of research, study, careers, and graduate school opportunities in pharmaceutical sciences. Taught by guest lecturers from various disciplines including 199 research course faculty. Helps Pharmaceutical Sciences students select electives appropriate to their future goals.

courses.title: Pharmacotherapy
courses.desc: An exploration of the clinical application of medications to selected disease states. Focus is on an understanding of underlying principles of pharmacology and how this knowledge can be applied to treatment of diseases.

courses.title: Biopharmaceutics and Nanomedicine
courses.desc: Introduces theories and tools of new drug formulations. Particularly new novel therapeutics based on biological materials, pathological characteristics utilized to achieve the maximum efficacy and specificity, and drug delivery systems based on emerging nanotechnology are extensively discussed.

courses.title: Biopharmaceutics and Nanomedicine Lab
courses.desc: Introduction to cancer drug screening using cellular models, and confirmation of comprehensive therapeutic efficacy using a live animal model. Includes basic cell culture, cytotoxicity assays, cell analysis, drug circulation test, and tumor eradication and imaging experiments. Materials fee.

courses.title: Drug Discovery Computing Techniques
courses.prereqs: CSE 41 or I&C SCI 31. CSE 42 or I&C SCI 32 is recommended.
courses.desc: Techniques used in computer-aided drug discovery, including theory behind these techniques and practical applications. Topics include scientific computing; python; classical force fields and simulations; visualization and movie-making; quantum mechanics in drug discovery; molecular dynamics; solvation models; and several others.

courses.title: Medicinal Chemistry
courses.prereqs: CHEM 51A and CHEM 51B and CHEM 51C and (BIO SCI 98 or CHEM 128)
courses.desc: An introduction of the basics of drug activity and mechanisms. Strategies used to identify lead compounds such as natural product chemistry, combinatorial chemistry, molecular modeling, and high-through put screening.  Relationship of molecular structure to pharmacological activity.

courses.title: Medicinal Chemistry Laboratory
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: PHRMSCI 177 or CHEM 177.
CHEM 51A and CHEM 51B and CHEM 51C and BIO SCI 100 and (BIO SCI 98 or CHEM 128)
courses.desc: An introduction of the basics of drug activity and mechanisms. Strategies used to identify lead compounds such as natural product chemistry, combinatorial chemistry, molecular modeling, and high-through put screening.  Relationship of molecular structure to pharmacological activity. Materials fee.

courses.title: Stem Cell Therapy
courses.desc: Introduces new paradigms in regenerative medicine involving stem cells, and emerging molecular, nano- and micro-engineered tools for in vivo imaging that is critical for studying and monitoring regeneration. Selected topics include stem cell biology and in vivo imaging modalities.

courses.title: Emerging Technologies in Pharmaceutical Sciences and Medicine
courses.desc: Introduces emerging, ground-breaking technologies in pharmaceutical sciences and medicine, including pharmacogenomics, genome editing, and stem cell and engineered T cell therapies. Explores these novel technologies with both their underlying theories and forward-thinking applications.

courses.title: Tutoring in Pharmaceutical Sciences
courses.desc: Tutoring program with Pharmaceutical Sciences student peers.

courses.title: Professional Internship
courses.desc: Provides students with opportunity to develop leadership and professional skills necessary for competitive placement in their chosen industry. Students gain new and field-specific skills outside the classroom environment while participating in a supervised internship for a total of 100 hours.

courses.title: Independent Study in Pharmaceutical Sciences
courses.desc: Students interested in independent study should arrange with a faculty member to sponsor and supervise such work. A time commitment of three hours per week per unit is expected. A written report is required at the end of each quarter.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.desc: Original research in the laboratory of Pharmaceutical Sciences faculty. Attendance at regular research group meetings is also generally expected, and a quarterly written report is required. Strongly recommended for students considering research careers and/or graduate degree programs.

courses.title: Honors Research in Pharmaceutical Sciences
courses.desc: Undergraduate honors research in Pharmaceutical Sciences. A student time commitment of 10-15 hours per week is required.

courses.title: Biological Macromolecules
courses.desc: Introduction to nucleic acid and protein structure, dynamics, and function. Topics include analytical methods, molecular evolution, folding, and catalysis.

courses.title: Current Topics in Pharmaceutical Sciences
courses.desc: Intended to expose students to the primary literature and current research in the field of Pharmaceutical Sciences. Students analyze and present information for discussion. Guest speakers from academia and industry may participate throughout the quarter.

courses.title: Current Topics in Pharmaceutical Sciences
courses.desc: Intended to expose students to the primary literature and current research in the field of Pharmaceutical Sciences. Students analyze and present information for discussion. Guest speakers from academia and industry may participate throughout the quarter.

courses.title: Current Topics in Pharmaceutical Sciences
courses.desc: Intended to expose students to the primary literature and current research in the field of Pharmaceutical Sciences. Students analyze and present information for discussion. Guest speakers from academia and industry may participate throughout the quarter.

courses.title: Pharmacogenomics and Epigenetics
courses.desc: Survey of the genetic and epigenetic basis of inter-subject variability in response to drugs. Covers drug efficacy, safety, and the need for their optimization in pharmacotherapy.Emphasizes genetic mechanisms of polymorphisms in the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of representative therapeutic drugs.

courses.title: The RNA World: From Discovery to Mechanism
courses.desc: Provides a comprehensive understanding of RNA in biology. Use of knowledge gained in organic chemistry, biochemistry, genomics, and molecular biology to understand how RNA is integrated into contemporary biology.

courses.title: New Frontiers in Chemical and Synthetic Biology
courses.desc: Explores new developments in chemical and synthetic biology that span the areas of chemistry, molecular biology, genetics, bioengineering, systems biology, and computational genomics.

courses.title: Advanced Pharmacology
courses.desc: Provides a mechanism-based overview of pharmacology with strong emphasis on clinical application of pharmacology. Students learn the most recent advances in pharmacology as they relate to drug discovery, development, and clinical application.

courses.title: Special Topics in Pharmaceutical Sciences
courses.desc: Reserved for current topics of particular interest in areas of pharmaceutical sciences that are not covered by other courses. The subject will vary from year to year, highlighting, for example, significant emerging fields or highly specialized but vital research areas.

courses.title: Nanomedicine
courses.desc: Students will learn the current challenges in administering drugs to treat highly challenging diseases, the background theories of drug and gene delivery systems, and apply their knowledge in designing innovative forms of therapeutics formulations.

courses.title: Drug Discovery Computing Techniques
courses.desc: Techniques used in computer-aided drug discovery, including theory behind these techniques and practical applications. Topics include scientific computing; python; classical force fields and simulations; visualization and movie-making; quantum mechanics in drug discovery; molecular dynamics; solvation models; and several others.

courses.title: Medicinal Chemistry
courses.desc: Fundamentals of medicinal chemistry covering diverse aspects of drug design, discovery, synthesis, and development. Molecular basis of drug action with an emphasis on the structure-to-function continuum.

courses.title: Stem Cell Therapy
courses.desc: Introduces new paradigms in regenerative medicine particularly those that involve stem cells, and emerging molecular, nano- and micro-engineered tools for in vivo imaging that is critical for studying and monitoring regeneration.

courses.title: Emerging Technologies in Pharmaceutical Sciences and Medicine
courses.desc: Introduces emerging, ground-breaking technologies in pharmaceutical sciences and medicine, including pharmacogenomics, genome editing, and stem cell and engineered T cell therapies. Explores these novel technologies with both their underlying theories and forward-thinking applications.

courses.title: Research Seminar
courses.desc: Presentation and discussion of current problems and methods in teaching and research in pharmaceutical sciences.

courses.title: Graduate Research
courses.desc: Supervised original research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Introduction to Philosophy
courses.desc: A selection of philosophical problems, concepts, and methods, e.g., free will, cause and substance, personal identity, the nature of philosophy itself. Materials fee.

courses.title: Puzzles and Paradoxes
courses.desc: Introduction to the formal tools needed to comprehend and evaluate philosophical arguments and theoretical reasoning in general.

courses.title: Technology and Society
courses.desc: A study of the nature of technology, its relation to human values, the philosophical assumptions in its development, and the philosophical implications of technology.

courses.title: Introduction to Ethics
courses.desc: Selected topics from the history of ethics, e.g., the nature of the good life and the moral justification of conduct.

courses.title: Contemporary Moral Problems
courses.desc: Selected moral issues of current interest, e.g., abortion, sexual morality, euthanasia, capital punishment, reverse discrimination, civil disobedience, or violence.

courses.title: Introduction to Existentialism
courses.desc: An analysis of themes in phenomenology and existentialism and their philosophical origins, e.g., consciousness, self and other, freedom and individuality.

courses.title: History of Ancient Philosophy
courses.desc: Examination of the central philosophical themes developed by the pre-Socratics, Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, the Stoics, the Epicureans, and the Skeptics.

courses.title: History of Medieval Philosophy
courses.desc: A study of some of the major theological and philosophical texts from the Medieval period.

courses.title: History of Modern Philosophy
courses.desc: A study of major developments in western philosophy from Descartes to Kant with readings from Descartes, Leibniz, Locke, Berkeley, Hume, and Kant.

courses.title: History of Contemporary Philosophy
courses.desc: A study of recent philosophical developments in Anglo-American and Continental philosophy with readings from such figures as Russell, Moore, Wittgenstein, Quine, Heidegger, and Sartre.

courses.title: Introduction to Philosophy and Religion
courses.desc: What is religion?  What is its relation to philosophy?  Must one be religious in order to be a moral or good person?  In examining these issues, we will attend to both Eastern and Western traditions and perspectives.

courses.title: Introduction to Law and Society
courses.desc: What constitutes a legal system? What does it mean for a society to have a system as a part of the social fabric. Examines the social status of law and its use as a tool for fashioning society.

courses.title: Critical Reasoning
courses.desc: Introduction to analysis and reasoning. The concepts of argument, premise, and conclusion, validity and invalidity, consistency and inconsistency. Identifying and assessing premises and inferences. Deductive versus inductive reasoning, and introduction to the probability calculus. Evaluating definitions. Informal fallacies.

courses.title: Introduction to Symbolic Logic
courses.desc: An introduction to the symbolism and methods of the logic of statements, including evaluation of arguments by truth tables, the techniques of natural deduction, and semantic tableaux.

courses.title: Introduction to Inductive Logic
courses.desc: Philosophical questions concerning the foundations of scientific inference, e.g., the traditional problem of induction, the Goodman paradox, the concept of cause, Mill's method of inductive reasoning, probability calculus, different interpretations of probability, and their interaction in inductive reasoning.

courses.title: Special Topics in Philosophy
courses.desc: Lectures on selected topics at the lower-division level.

courses.title: The Philosophy of Sex
courses.desc: Discusses the origins of biological sex, dynamics of sexual selection, sex differences in humans, and the construction of gender in human societies. Seeks to understand the role social values play in the creation of science.

courses.title: Writing Philosophy
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Discussion of those aspects of writing of special importance in philosophy, e.g., philosophical terminology, techniques for evaluating arguments, philosophical definitions and theories. At least 4,000 words of assigned composition based on philosophical readings.

courses.title: Introduction to Metaphysics
courses.desc: A study of one or more of the problems of "first philosophy," e.g., substance, free will, causation, abstract entities, identity.

courses.title: Introduction to the Theory of Knowledge
courses.desc: A study of one or more of the basic issues in epistemology, e.g., the role of perception in the acquisition of knowledge, the nature of evidence, the distinction between belief and knowledge, and the nature of truth and certainty.

courses.title: Introduction to the Theory of Knowledge
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: A study of one or more of the basic issues in epistemology, e.g., the role of perception in the acquisition of knowledge, the nature of evidence, the distinction between belief and knowledge, and the nature of truth and certainty.

courses.title: Introduction to Moral Philosophy
courses.desc: A study of one or more of the problems of contemporary moral philosophy, e.g., the nature of justice, liberalism versus conservatism, happiness and its relation to virtue and right conduct, the objectivity of moral standards.

courses.title: Introduction to Logic
courses.desc: Introduction to sentence logic, including truth tables and natural deduction; and to predicate logic, including semantics and natural deduction.

courses.title: Elementary Set Theory
courses.desc: An introduction to the basic working vocabulary of mathematical reasoning. Topics include sets, Boolean operations, ordered n-tuples, relations, functions, ordinal and cardinal numbers.

courses.title: Metalogic
courses.desc: Introduction to formal syntax (proof theory) and semantics (model theory) for first-order logic, including the deduction, completeness, compactness, and Löewenheim-Skolem theorems.

courses.title: Undecidability and Incompleteness
courses.desc: Introduction to the formal theory of effective processes, including recursive functions, Turing machines, Church's thesis, and proofs of Göedel's incompleteness theorem for arithmetic, and Church's undecidability theorem for first-order logic.

courses.title: Topics in Logic
courses.desc: Selected topics in mathematical or philosophical logic.

courses.title: Topics in Induction, Probability, and Decision Theory
courses.desc: Selected topics in induction, probability, and decision theory.

courses.title: Topics in Ancient Philosophy
courses.desc: Selected topics from the writings of Plato and Aristotle, e.g., Aristotle's criticisms of Plato's metaphysics, ethics, or politics.

courses.title: Topics in Medieval Philosophy
courses.desc: Studies of some of the major issues of concern to Medieval philosophers, e.g., universals, the nature and existence of God, faith, and reason.

courses.title: Topics in Modern Philosophy
courses.desc: Focuses on the works of central philosophical figures of modern Philosophy (e.g., Descartes, Leibniz, Hobbes, Locke, Hume, Kant) or on the treatment of one or more central philosophical problems by a number of these figures.

courses.title: Topics in Nineteenth-Century Philosophy
courses.desc: Studies of some of the major figures after Kant (e.g., Hegel, Nietzsche, Marx, Kierkegaard), especially in German idealism and social thought.

courses.title: Topics in History of Analytic Philosophy
courses.desc: Review of central theories or figures in the history of analytic philosophy. Emphasis on writings of Frege, Russell, Schlick, Carnap, and Quine. Topics include the nature of meaning and truth, the synthetic/analytic distinction, and scientific knowledge.

courses.title: Topics in Continental Philosophy
courses.desc: Studies of some of the major figures (e.g., Husserl), movements (e.g., phenomenology, existentialism) in early twentieth-century continental European thought.

courses.title: Topics in East Asian Philosophy
courses.desc: Selected topics in the philosophies of Asia, e.g. Jainism, Buddhism, Yoga, Vedanta, Confucianism, Taoism, and Shinto.

courses.title: Topics in Metaphysics
courses.desc: Examines central philosophical questions concerning our own fundamental nature and that of the world around us (e.g., causation and necessity, determination, free will, personal identity, the mind-body problem).

courses.title: Topics in the Theory of Knowledge
courses.desc: One or more topics in the theory of knowledge, e.g., the nature of rational justification, of perceptual knowledge, of a priori knowledge.

courses.title: Medical Epistemology
courses.desc: Analysis of epistemological issues concerning medical research and health care. Topics may include medical evidence, transmission of medical knowledge, medical expertise, the epistemology of medical disagreement, classification of illnesses, well-being, philosophy of pain, and medical decision making.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Mind
courses.desc: Selected topics involving the concept of mind, e.g., the relation between mind and body, the self, personal identity, consciousness, the unconscious.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Religion
courses.desc: Critical examination of concepts involved in the theological literature, e.g., the nature and existence of God, miracles, the problem of evil, divine command theories in ethics.

courses.title: Topics in Moral Philosophy
courses.desc: Selected topics in ethics.

courses.title: Applied Ethics
courses.desc: Topics may include capital punishment, world hunger, obligations to future generations, environmental ethics, animal rights, economic justice, sexual morality, affirmative action, racism and sexism, or legalization of drugs.

courses.title: Medical Ethics
courses.desc: Analysis of moral issues concerning health care. Topics may include just allocation of scarce medical resources, the doctor/patient relationship, genetic engineering, surrogate motherhood, abortion, euthanasia, or social policy concerning AIDS.

courses.title: Topics in Political and Social Philosophy
courses.desc: Selected topics in social and political philosophy, e.g., the functions of government, the justification of political authority, the nature of democracy, the varieties of liberty, and social justice. Readings from classical and contemporary sources.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Law
courses.desc: Selected topics concerning legal systems and the concept of law, e.g., the nature and purpose of law, the nature of authority, the relationship between law and morality, law and political-economic systems.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Science
courses.desc: Selected topics in contemporary philosophy of science, e.g., the status of theoretical entities, the confirmation of theories, the nature of scientific explanation.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Physics
courses.desc: Selected topics in the philosophy of physics, e.g., the interpretation of quantum mechanics, the nature of spacetime, the problem of quantum field theories.

courses.title: Geometry and Spacetime
courses.desc: An examination of the foundations of the special theory of relativity, with emphasis on the geometry of Minkowski spacetime, and its relation to both Euclidean and non-Euclidean (hyperbolic) plane geometries.

courses.title: Philosophy of Quantum Mechanics
courses.desc: An examination of the standard von Neumann-Dirac formulation of quantum mechanics. The quantum measurement problem is discussed along with several proposed solutions, including GRW, many-worlds, man-minds, and Bohm's theory.

courses.title: Probability and Determinism
courses.desc: An examination of a cluster of interrelated issues concerning probability, determinism, logic, and the foundations of quantum mechanics.

courses.title: Writing/Philosophy of Biology
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Philosophy of biology, e.g., scientific method in biology, the structure of evolutionary theory, teleology, ethics, and evolution. Course work includes one 4,000-word and four 1,000-word papers.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Psychology
courses.desc: Selected topics in the philosophy of psychology, e.g., the nature of psychological explanation, reductionism, issues in cognitive, behavioral, and neuroscience.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Social Science
courses.desc: Selected topics in the philosophy of the social sciences, e.g., Is their goal to understand behavior or to predict and control it?; Are they normative and the natural sciences not?; Do they incorporate philosophical doctrines about language and mind?.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Language
courses.desc: Selected topics in the philosophy of language, e.g., the nature of meaning, mechanisms of reference, speech acts.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Logic
courses.desc: Selected topics in the philosophy of logic, e.g., the nature of logical truth and our knowledge of it, the status of propositions, definite descriptions, and existential presuppositions.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Mathematics
courses.desc: Selected historical and contemporary topics in the philosophy of mathematics, e.g., mathematical truth and ontology, mathematical knowledge, the nature and role of proof, the workings of mathematics in application.

courses.title: Phenomenology
courses.desc: A study of the foundations of phenomenology in Husserl and its background in Bolzano, Frege, Brentano, Meinong, Kant, and Descartes.

courses.title: Existentialism
courses.desc: A study of such central existentialist thinkers as Heidegger and Sartre.

courses.title: Social Ontology
courses.desc: Examines how things in one’s social environment exist. Such things are compared and contrasted to others in what might be regarded as the given, natural environment. Topics discussed include natural kinds; artifacts; essentialism; constructivism; intentionality; agency.

courses.title: Social Epistemology
courses.desc: Social epistemology is specifically concerned with questions concerning knowledge and justification that arise in a social context. Topics discussed include testimony, experts, disagreement, group knowledge, feminist epistemology, legal epistemology, and epistemology of education.

courses.title: Well-Being
courses.desc: Examines what it is that makes a life good (or bad) for the person who lives it. Topics include hedonism, desire-satisfaction theories of well-being (as well as other such theories), the notion of harm, the possibility of posthumous harm.

courses.title: Philosophy of Action
courses.desc: Philosophy of action is specifically concerned with questions concerning the nature of acting, and related phenomena such as intending, willing, trying, and trusting. It deals both with individual and group action and their moral and epistemological  underpinnings.

courses.title: Special Topics in Philosophy
courses.desc: Lectures on selected topics to be given by regular faculty and visiting faculty.

courses.title: Directed Special Studies
courses.desc: Independent study on a research topic supervised by a faculty member.

courses.title: Special Topics in Philosophy
courses.desc: Seminars on selected topics to be given by regular faculty and visiting faculty.

courses.title: First-Year Seminar
courses.desc: An examination of some standard works in the history of philosophy, value theory, metaphysics, or epistemology; required of all first-year Philosophy graduate students in the School of Humanities.

courses.title: Set Theory
courses.desc: The basic working vocabulary of mathematical reasoning. Topics include: sets, Boolean operations, ordered n-tuples, relations, functions, ordinal and cardinal numbers.

courses.title: Metalogic
courses.desc: Formal syntax (proof theory) and semantics (model theory) for first-order logic, including the deduction, completeness, compactness, and Loewenheim-Skolem theorems.

courses.title: Undecidability and Incompleteness
courses.desc: Formal theory of effective processes, including recursive function, Turing machines, Church's thesis, proofs of Goedel's incompleteness theorem for arithmetics, and Church's undecidability for first-order logic.

courses.title: Topics in Logic
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of logic. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Ancient Philosophy
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of ancient philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Medieval Philosophy
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of medieval philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Renaissance Philosophy
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of renaissance philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Modern Philosophy
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of modern philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Nineteenth-Century Philosophy
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of nineteenth-century philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Analytic Philosophy
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of analytic philosophy.  Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Continental Philosophy
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of continental philosophy. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Contemporary Philosophy
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of contemporary philosophy. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Metaphysics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of metaphysics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Epistemology
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of epistemology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Medical Epistemology
courses.desc: Analysis of epistemological issues concerning medical research and healthcare. Topics may include medical evidence, transmission of medical knowledge in the doctor-patient interaction, medical expertise, epistemology of medical disagreement, classification of illness, well-being, philosophy of pain, or medical decision making.

courses.title: Topics in Mind and Action
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of mind and action. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Ethics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of ethics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Political and Social Philosophy
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of political and social philosophy. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Aesthetics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of aesthetics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Science
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Physics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of physics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Biology
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of biology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Psychology
courses.desc: Selected topics in the philosophy of psychology, e.g., the nature of psychological explanation, reductionism, issues in cognitive, behavioral, and neuroscience.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Social Science
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of philosophy and social science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Language
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of language. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Logic
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of logic. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Mathematics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of philosophy of mathematics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Topics in Existentialism and Phenomenology
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of existentialism and phenomenology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Independent research with Philosophy faculty.

courses.title: Directed Research
courses.desc: Directed research with Philosophy faculty.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: California Teach 1: Introduction to Science and Mathematics Teaching
courses.desc: First in a series for students interested in becoming middle or high school teachers of mathematics or science. Students gain an understanding of effective, research-based teaching strategies. Includes supervised field experience in a K-12 classroom.

courses.title: Skills Development
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Undergraduates identify, cultivate, and practice relevant soft skills applicable to careers in mathematics and science. The focus is on career readiness, how to market oneself to future employers, and what to expect from the professional world.

courses.title: California Teach 2: Middle School Science and Mathematics Teaching
courses.desc: Second in a series for students interested in becoming middle or high school teachers of mathematics or science. Students gain an understanding of effective, research-based teaching strategies for grades 6-8. Includes supervised field experience in a middle school classroom.

courses.title: Technical Writing and Communication Skills
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Workshop in writing technical reports, journal articles, proposals. Oral presentations. Communicating with the public. May not be used in satisfaction of any School or departmental requirement.

courses.title: Science Communication Skills
courses.desc: Development of effective communication skills, oral and written presentations. Topics range from the art of creating keynote slides to strategically crafting a personal story, culminating in a live presentation to an invited audience.

courses.title: Introduction to Mathematical Methods for Physics
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: MATH 2A or MATH 5A, or a score of 4 or higher on the AP Calculus AB exam, or a score of 3 or higher on the AP Calculus BC exam. 
Passing score on the UCI Physics Placement Exam.
courses.desc: Provides the applied mathematics and problem solving/presentation skills necessary for success in an introductory physics sequence. Focuses on practical exercises in problem solving. Covers kinematics in one and two dimensions in detail. Additional topics include vectors, differentiation, and integration.

courses.title: Basic Physics I
courses.desc: Vectors; motion, force, and energy.

courses.title: Basic Physics II
courses.prereqs: PHYSICS 3A or AP Physics C: Mechanics. AP Physics C: Mechanics with a minimum score of 5
courses.desc: Fluids; heat; electricity and magnetism.

courses.title: Basic Physics III
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: MATH 2B or MATH 5B, or a score of 4 or higher on the AP Calculus BC exam. 
PHYSICS 3A or AP Physics C: Mechanics. AP Physics C: Mechanics with a minimum score of 5
courses.desc: Waves and sound; optics; quantum ideas; atomic and nuclear physics; relativity.

courses.title: Basic Physics Laboratory
courses.desc: Practical applications of electronics and classical physics to biology. Goals include skill to use oscilloscope and other basic instrumentation. Materials fee.

courses.title: Basic Physics Laboratory
