courses.desc: Practical applications of physics to medical imaging.  Topics include optics, radioactivity, and acoustics. Materials fee.

courses.title: Classical Physics
courses.desc: Topics include force, energy, momentum, rotation, and gravity.

courses.title: Classical Physics
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: PHYSICS 7LD and MATH 2D
PHYSICS 7C and (MATH 2B or AP Calculus BC). AP Calculus BC with a minimum score of 4
courses.desc: Electricity and magnetism.

courses.title: Classical Physics
courses.desc: Fluids; oscillations; waves; and optics.

courses.title: Classical Physics Laboratory
courses.desc: Experiments related to lecture topics in Physics 7C. Materials fee.

courses.title: Classical Physics Laboratory
courses.desc: Electricity and magnetism.

courses.title: Science Fiction and Science Fact
courses.desc: An introduction to fundamental physics principles, the scientific process, and the mathematical language of science, used to analyze topics drawn from superheroes, science fiction works, and current science news to distinguish science fiction and science fact.

courses.title: Energy and the Environment
courses.desc: The physics of society’s energy production and consumption, and of their influences on the environment. Topics include fossil and renewable energy resources; nuclear power; prospects for a hydrogen economy; efficient and environmentally benign transportation; efficient home and commercial energy usage.

courses.title: Physics of Music
courses.desc: Introduces basic physical principles underlying generation and properties of music, including basic properties of sound waves, musical scales and temperament, musical instruments, and acoustics of music halls.  No mathematics background required, but high school algebra is recommended.

courses.title: Physics of Athletics
courses.desc: Introduces basic physical principles behind motion. Examples are drawn from a range of athletic endeavors (such as ice skating, baseball, diving, and dance). No mathematics background required, but high school algebra is recommended.

courses.title: How Things Work
courses.desc: Survey of the physical basis of modern technology, with an emphasis on electronics and materials. Topics include power generation and distribution, communication (radio, TV, telephone, computers, tape recorders, CD players), imaging (optics, x-rays, MRI), and modern materials (alloys, semiconductors, superconductors).

courses.title: Great Ideas of Physics
courses.desc: Introduces non-science majors to physics, examining important breakthroughs and controversies. Potential topics: Einstein's Relativity; Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle; black holes; extra-dimensions; antimatter. Case studies illustrate the essential nature of scientific review and independent confirmation of results. No mathematics background required.

courses.title: Introduction to Astronomy
courses.desc: History of astronomy. Underlying physics. Objects in the solar system and how they are studied. Properties of stars: their formation, structure, and evolution. Pulsars and black holes. Galaxies and quasars.

courses.title: Cosmology: Humanity's Place in the Universe
courses.desc: An overview of the origin, evolution, and ultimate fate of the Universe. Galaxies and dark matter. The Big Bang and dark energy.  Ancient world models.

courses.title: Space Science
courses.desc: Space exploration. Human missions to the moon, Mars, and beyond. Space stations, observatories, and deep-space probes. Robots and drones on distant worlds. Propulsion mechanisms, rockets, space flight, and the dangers of solar radiation.

courses.title: Life in the Universe
courses.desc: An overview of the scientific quest to discover life elsewhere in the universe. Topics include the origin of life on Earth, Mars, extra-solar planets, interstellar travel, and extra-terrestrial intelligence.

courses.title: Special Topics in Physics
courses.desc: Topics addressed vary each quarter. Past topics have included physics and music, Newton, planetary science. Lectures on areas of special interest in physics used to introduce students to scientific method, fundamental laws of science, qualitative and quantitative analysis of data.

courses.title: Introductory Mathematical Physics
courses.desc: Introduction to math methods for upper-division physics. Taylor and Fourier series; complex algebra; ordinary differential equations; matrices, tensors and vector spaces; eigensystems; orthogonal coordinates; vector calculus and fields. Symbolic computation with Mathematica is incorporated through-out.

courses.title: Modern Physics
courses.desc: Wave-particle duality; quantum mechanics; special relativity; statistical mechanics.

courses.title: Modern Physics
courses.desc: Atoms; molecules; solids; nuclei; elementary particles.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Experimental Physics
courses.desc: Optics: lenses, mirrors, polarization, lasers, optical fibers, interference, spectra. Materials fee.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Experimental Physics
courses.desc: Circuits: oscilloscope, meters, DC and AC circuits. Materials fee.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Experimental Physics
courses.desc: Data analysis: random and systematic errors, curve fitting; nuclear counting; quantum experiments. Error analysis: random and systematic errors, curve fitting, nuclear counting, and quantum experiments. Materials fee.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming and Numerical Analysis
courses.desc: Introduction to structured programming; in-depth training in python. Elementary numerical methods applied to physics problems.

courses.title: Thermal Physics
courses.desc: Introduction to thermodynamics and systems of many particles. Topics include first and second laws of thermodynamics, ideal gas laws, kinetic theory, heat engines and refrigerators, thermodynamic potentials, phase transitions, dilute solutions, chemical equilibrium, and basic statistical distributions.

courses.title: Modern Physics for Majors
courses.desc: Wave-particle duality; Schrödinger equation; angular momentum.

courses.title: Modern Physics for Majors
courses.desc: Atomic transitions; molecules; solids; nuclei; elementary particles; cosmological models.

courses.title: Introduction to Astrophysics
courses.desc: Introduction to fundamental topics in astrophysics, including stellar structure and evolution; stellar remnants; detection and characterization of exoplanets; physics of interstellar gas and star-forming regions.

courses.title: Impact of World War I on Science
courses.desc: Introduction to science in 1914 and WWI. Participants in groups of two or three will pick a preferred science; find out what happened to it during and after the war; write reports and present what they learned.

courses.title: The Idiom and Practice of Science
courses.desc: A series of fundamental and applied scientific problems of social relevance. Possible topics include Newton's Law, calculus, earthquake physics, and radiation.

courses.title: Current Topics in Physics
courses.desc: Designed to introduce undergraduate students to current topics in physics. Focus is discussion of selected readings on current research issues.

courses.title: Computational Methods
courses.desc: Mathematical and numerical analysis using Mathematica and C programming, as applied to problems in physical science.

courses.title: Laboratory Skills and Scientific Writing
courses.desc: Introduces practical laboratory techniques, including lock-in, boxcar, coincidence counting, noise-filtering, properties of common transducers, computer interfacing to instruments, basic mechanical design, shop skills. Students design their own experiments, take measurements, analyze data, and write up results in scientific manuscript style.

courses.title: Classical Mechanics
courses.desc: One-dimensional motion and oscillations; three-dimensional motion, non-inertial coordinates, conservation laws, and Lagrangian and Hamiltonian dynamics; rigid body motion and relativity.

courses.title: Classical Mechanics
courses.desc: One-dimensional motion and oscillations; three-dimensional motion, non-inertial coordinates, conservation laws, and Lagrangian and Hamiltonian dynamics; rigid body motion and relativity.

courses.title: Electromagnetic Theory
courses.desc: Electric, magnetic, and gravitational fields and potentials; electrodynamics; mechanical and electromagnetic waves and radiation.

courses.title: Electromagnetic Theory
courses.desc: Electric, magnetic, and gravitational fields and potentials; electrodynamics; mechanical and electromagnetic waves and radiation.

courses.title: Quantum Physics
courses.desc: Inadequacy of classical physics; time independent and time dependent Schrodinger equation; systems in one, two, and three dimensions; matrices; Hermitian operators; symmetries; angular momentum; perturbation theory; scattering theory; applications to atomic structure; emphasis on phenomenology.

courses.title: Quantum Physics
courses.desc: Inadequacy of classical physics; time independent and time dependent Schrodinger equation; systems in one, two, and three dimensions; matrices; Hermitian operators; symmetries; angular momentum; perturbation theory; scattering theory; applications to atomic structure; emphasis on phenomenology.

courses.title: Quantum Physics
courses.desc: Inadequacy of classical physics; time independent and time dependent Schrodinger equation; systems in one, two, and three dimensions; matrices; Hermitian operators; symmetries; angular momentum; perturbation theory; scattering theory; applications to atomic structure; emphasis on phenomenology.

courses.title: Statistical Physics
courses.prereqs: PHYSICS 50 and (PHYSICS 60 or CHEM 1C or ENGRMAE 91)
courses.desc: Microscopic theory of temperature, heat, and entropy; kinetic theory; multicomponent systems; quantum statistics.

courses.title: Relativity and Black Holes
courses.desc: Introduces students to both special and general relativity; includes the formalism of four-vectors, equivalence principle, curved space-time, and modern issues with black holes.

courses.title: Electronics for Scientists
courses.desc: Applications of modern semiconductor devices to physical instrumentation. Characteristics of semiconductor devices, integrated circuits, analog and digital circuits. Materials fee.

courses.title: Advanced Laboratory
courses.prereqs: (PHYSICS 51B or PHYSICS 61B or PHYSICS 61C) and (PHYSICS 52C or PHYSICS 193) and (PHYSICS 194 or EDUC 143BW)
courses.desc: Experiments in atomic, condensed matter, nuclear, particle, and plasma physics. Introduction to instrumentation and a first experience in the research laboratory.

courses.title: Mathematical Physics
courses.desc: Complex variables; Legendre and Bessel functions; complete sets of orthogonal functions; partial differential equations; integral equations; calculus of variations; coordinate transformations; special functions and series.

courses.title: Mathematical Physics
courses.desc: Complex variables; Legendre and Bessel functions; complete sets of orthogonal functions; partial differential equations; integral equations; calculus of variations; coordinate transformations; special functions and series.

courses.title: Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics
courses.desc: Phenomena of solids and their interpretation in terms of quantum theory.

courses.title: Physical and Geometrical Optics
courses.desc: Focuses on the practical aspects of optics and optical engineering, starting at the fundamentals. Topics include geometrical optics, ray tracing, polarization optics, interferometers, and diffractive optics.

courses.title: Plasma Physics
courses.desc: Basic concepts, orbits, kinetic and fluid equations, Coulomb collisions, fluctuations, scattering, radiation.

courses.title: Introduction to Particle Physics
courses.desc: Experimental techniques and theoretical concepts of high-energy phenomena: accelerators and detectors; classification of particles and interactions; particle properties; symmetries and mass multiplets; production and decay mechanisms.

courses.title: Introduction to Cosmology
courses.desc: Solution of the differential equations governing the expansion of the Universe. Observational determinations of the parameters governing the expansion. Big Bang inflation, primordial nucleosynthesis, and cosmic microwave background. Dark matter, dark energy, and large-scale structure of the Universe.

courses.title: Extragalactic Astrophysics
courses.desc: Introduction to the solar neighborhood, Milky Way, and other galaxies. Interstellar medium. Star formation.  Stellar populations. Evolution of spiral, elliptical, and irregular galaxies. Supermassive black holes, quasars, and active galaxies. Galaxies as probes of the expansion rate of the Universe.

courses.title: Observational Astrophysics
courses.prereqs: PHYSICS 52A and PHYSICS 52B and PHYSICS 52C and PHYSICS 53
courses.desc: Telescopes and astronomical observations, imaging with CCD detectors and image processing techniques. Photometry and spectroscopy of stars, galaxies, and quasars. Advanced imaging techniques such as deconvolution, adaptive optics, and interferometry.

courses.title: Stellar Astrophysics
courses.prereqs: (PHYSICS 51A or PHYSICS 61A) and PHYSICS 111A and PHYSICS 112A
courses.desc: Stars: their structure and evolution; physical state of the interior; the Hertzprung- Russell diagram, stellar classification, and physical principles responsible for the classification; star formation; nuclear burning; giant and dwarf stars; neutron stars and black holes.

courses.title: High-Energy Astrophysics
courses.prereqs: (PHYSICS 51A or PHYSICS 61A) and PHYSICS 111A and PHYSICS 112A
courses.desc: Production of radiation by high-energy particles, white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Evolution of galactic nuclei, radio galaxies, quasars, and pulsars.  Cosmic rays and the cosmic background radiation.

courses.title: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines
courses.desc: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.

courses.title: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines
courses.desc: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.

courses.title: Techniques in Medical Imaging I: X-ray, Nuclear, and NMR Imaging
courses.desc: Ionizing radiation, planar and tomographic radiographic and nuclear imaging, magnetism, NMR, MRI imaging.

courses.title: Techniques in Medical Imaging II: Ultrasound, Electrophysiological, Optical
courses.desc: Sound and ultrasound, ultrasonic imaging, physiological electromagnetism, EEG, MEG, ECG, MCG, optical properties of tissues, fluorescence and bioluminescence, MR impedance imaging, MR spectroscopy, electron spin resonance and ESR imaging.

courses.title: Special Topics in Physics and Astronomy
courses.desc: Current topics in physics.  Includes topics from nano-science, biological sciences, astrophysics, and the common use of estimation across subdisciplines within physics.

courses.title: Field Experience in Physics Education
courses.desc: Students develop and perform physics assemblies at neighboring public schools.

courses.title: Tutoring in Physics
courses.desc: Formalizes the already existing free tutoring for the lower-division physics courses that is provided by the Society of Physics Students (SPS). Includes instructions on tutoring techniques.

courses.title: Research Methods
courses.desc: Explores tools of inquiry for developing and implementing science research projects.  Students undertake independent projects requiring data collection, analysis, and modeling, and the organization and presentation of results.  Additional topics include ethical issues and role of scientific literature.

courses.title: Research Communication for Physics Majors
courses.prereqs: PHYSICS 61A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Students learn the fundamentals of communicating about research. Topics include preparing abstracts, proposals, and literature reviews. Provides preparation for presentation of independent research projects in PHYSICS 121 and PHYSICS 196.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.desc: Independent research under the guidance of a Physics faculty member.

courses.title: Thesis in Physics I
courses.desc: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.

courses.title: Thesis in Physics II
courses.desc: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.

courses.title: Thesis in Physics III
courses.desc: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.

courses.title: Honors Thesis in Physics I
courses.desc: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.

courses.title: Honors Thesis in Physics II
courses.desc: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.

courses.title: Honors Thesis in Physics III
courses.desc: Independent research for seniors conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Students’ research results are discussed in oral presentations, and a written proposal, progress report, and thesis are submitted.

courses.title: Readings on Special Topics
courses.desc: Readings in selected areas of Physics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Laboratory Skills
courses.desc: Introduces students to a variety of practical laboratory techniques, including lock-in, boxcar, coincidence counting, noise filtering, PID control, properties of common transducers, computer interfacing to instruments, vacuum technology, laboratory safety, basic mechanical design, and shop skills. Materials fee.

courses.title: Chemistry for Physicists
courses.desc: Introduction to fundamental concepts in molecular structure and reactivity: theory of bonding, valence and molecular orbitals; structure and reactivity in inorganic chemistry; elements in molecular group theory; nomenclature in organic chemistry; and survey of macromolecules.

courses.title: Mathematics for Chemists
courses.desc: Applications of mathematics to physical and chemical problems. Calculus of special functions, complex variables and vectors; linear vector spaces and eigenvalue problems. Differential equations.

courses.title: Classical Mechanics
courses.desc: Variational principles, Lagrange's equations; applications to two body problems, small oscillation theory, and other phenomena. Hamilton's equations. Hamilton-Jacobi theory. Canonical transformations.

courses.title: Mathematical Physics
courses.desc: Complex variables and integration; ordinary and partial differential equations; the eigenvalue problem.

courses.title: Electromagnetic Theory
courses.desc: Electrostatics; magnetostatics; relativity; classical electron theory; fields in vacuum and matter; retardation; radiation and absorption; dispersion; propagation of light; diffraction; geometric optics; theories of the electric and magnetic properties of materials; scattering.

courses.title: Electromagnetic Theory
courses.desc: Electrostatics; magnetostatics; relativity; classical electron theory; fields in vacuum and matter; retardation; radiation and absorption; dispersion; propagation of light; diffraction; geometric optics; theories of the electric and magnetic properties of materials; scattering.

courses.title: Statistical Physics
courses.desc: Maxwell-Boltzmann, Bose-Einstein, Fermi-Dirac statistics; ideal and imperfect gases; thermodynamic properties of solids; transport theory.

courses.title: Statistical Physics
courses.desc: Phase transitions; critical phenomena; cooperative phenomena; fluctuations.

courses.title: Many Body Theory
courses.desc: Application of field theory methods, perturbative and non-perturbative, to many particle systems; second quantization, Feynman diagrams, linear response theory, and functional integral methods applied to the ground state and at finite temperature.

courses.title: Quantum Mechanics
courses.desc: Foundations; Dirac notation; basic operators and their eigenstates; perturbation theory; spin.

courses.title: Quantum Mechanics
courses.desc: Atomic physics; scattering theory, formal collision theory; semi-classical radiation theory; many body systems.

courses.title: Electronics for Scientists
courses.desc: Applications of modern semiconductor devices to physical instrumentation. Characteristics of semiconductor devices, integrated circuits, analog and digital circuits.

courses.title: Continuum Mechanics
courses.desc: Introduction to the continuum limit and stress and strain tensors. Hydrodynamics of perfect fluids; two-dimensional problems, motion of incompressible viscous fluids, Navier Stokes equations. Basic elasticity theory. Description of viscoelastic materials. Introduction to nonlinear behavior instabilities.

courses.title: Electromagnetism
courses.desc: Maxwell’s equations, electrodynamics, electromagnetic waves and radiation, wave propagation in media, interference and quantum optics, coherent and incoherent radiation, with practical applications in interferometry, lasers, waveguides, and optical instrumentation.

courses.title: Computational Methods
courses.desc: Mathematical and numerical analysis using Mathematica and C programming, as applied to problems in physical science.

courses.title: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines
courses.desc: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.

courses.title: Biophysics of Molecules and Molecular Machines
courses.desc: Physical concepts and experimental and computational techniques used to study the structure and function of biological molecules and molecular machines with examples from enzyme action, protein folding, molecular motors, photobiology, chemotaxis, and vision.

courses.title: Principles of Imaging
courses.desc: Linear systems, probability and random processes, image processing, projecting imaging, tomographic imaging.

courses.title: Techniques in Medical Imaging I: X-ray, Nuclear, and NMR Imaging
courses.desc: Ionizing radiation, planar and tomographic radiographic and nuclear imaging, magnetism, NMR, MRI imaging.

courses.title: Techniques in Medical Imaging II: Ultrasound, Electrophysiological, Optical
courses.desc: Sound and ultrasound, ultrasonic imaging, physiological electromagnetism, EEG, MEG, ECG, MCG, optical properties of tissues, fluorescence and bioluminescence, MR impedance imaging, MR spectroscopy, electron spin resonance and ESR imaging.

courses.title: Elementary Particle Physics
courses.desc: Overview of Standard Model theory and phenomenology. Electromagnetic, strong and weak forces, quark model, interactions with matter, particle detectors and accelerators.

courses.title: Advanced Elementary Particle Physics
courses.desc: SU(3)xSU(2)xU(1) model of strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions. K-meson system and CP violation, neutrino masses and mixing, grand-unified theories, supersymmetry, introduction to cosmology and its connection to particle physics.

courses.title: Advanced Elementary Particle Physics
courses.desc: SU(3)xSU(2)xU(1) model of strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions. K-meson system and CP violation, neutrino masses and mixing, grand-unified theories, supersymmetry, introduction to cosmology and its connection to particle physics.

courses.title: Quantum Field Theory
courses.desc: Canonical quantization, scalar field theory, Feynman diagrams, tree-level quantum electrodynamics.

courses.title: Advanced Quantum Field Theory
courses.desc: Pathintegral techniques, loop diagrams, regularization and renormalization, anomalies.

courses.title: Condensed Matter Physics
courses.prereqs: PHYSICS 133 and (PHYSICS 214A or CHEM 232A) and (PHYSICS 215B or CHEM 231B)
courses.desc: Bonding in solids; crystal symmetry and group theory, elastic properties of crystals; lattice vibrations, interaction of radiation with matter; cohesion of solids; the electron gas; electron energy bands in solids; ferromagnetism; transport theory; semiconductors and superconductors; many-body perturbation theory.

courses.title: Condensed Matter Physics
courses.desc: Bonding in solids; crystal symmetry and group theory, elastic properties of crystals; lattice vibrations, interaction of radiation with matter; cohesion of solids; the electron gas; electron energy bands in solids; ferromagnetism; transport theory; semiconductors and superconductors; many-body perturbation theory.

courses.title: Condensed Matter Physics
courses.desc: Bonding in solids; crystal symmetry and group theory, elastic properties of crystals; lattice vibrations, interaction of radiation with matter; cohesion of solids; the electron gas; electron energy bands in solids; ferromagnetism; transport theory; semiconductors and superconductors; many-body perturbation theory.

courses.title: Plasma Physics
courses.desc: Basic concepts, orbits, kinetic and fluid equations, Coulomb collisions, fluctuations, scattering, radiation.

courses.title: Plasma Physics
courses.desc: Magnetic confinement, MHD equilibrium and stability, collisional transport.

courses.title: Plasma Physics
courses.desc: Linear waves and instabilities, uniform un-magnetized and magnetized plasmas, non-uniform plasmas.

courses.title: Galactic Astrophysics
courses.desc: The morphology, kinematics, and evolution of our Milky Way and other galaxies.  Topics include stellar formation and stellar evolution, end states of stars (supernovae, neutron stars), the distribution of stars, interstellar gas and mass in galaxies. The Local Group.

courses.title: Cosmology
courses.desc: An introduction to modern cosmology set within the context of general relativity.  Topics include the expansion history of the Universe, inflation, the cosmic microwave background, density fluctuations, structure formation, dark matter, dark energy, and gravitational lensing.

courses.title: Radiative Processes in Astrophysics
courses.desc: Exploration of radiation mechanisms (electron scattering, synchrotron emission, collisional excitation, and more) and radiative transfer through matter including absorption and emission. Includes such observational astrophysics topics as spectroscopic study of atoms and nuclei, X-rays, and cosmic rays.

courses.title: Stellar Astrophysics
courses.desc: Physics of stellar interiors and equations of stellar structure. Stellar atmospheres and absorption processes. Introduction to stellar winds. Thermonuclear reactions, nucleosynthesis, and solar neutrinos. Binary stars and mass accretion. White dwarfs, supernovae, neutron stars, and black holes.

courses.title: Extragalactic Astrophysics
courses.desc: The physics and phenomenology of galaxies; star formation, interstellar medium, and intergalactic medium.  Galaxy structure and dynamics.  Galaxy evolution, stellar populations, and scaling relations; the relationship between galaxy properties and environment.  Galaxy clusters and active galactic nuclei.

courses.title: Early Universe Physics
courses.desc: Includes a thorough quantum treatment of the generation of perturbations during inflation and various topics related to kinetic theory in an expanding Universe.  Other topics include the astrophysics and cosmology of weakly interacting particles.

courses.title: Special Topics in Astrophysics
courses.desc: Outlines and emphasizes a subarea of astrophysics that is undergoing rapid development.

courses.title: Special Topics in Particle Physics
courses.desc: Current topics in particle non-accelerator-based research fields.

courses.title: Special Topics in Condensed Matter Physics
courses.desc: Outlines and emphasizes a subarea of condensed matter physics that is undergoing rapid development.

courses.title: Special Topics in Plasma Physics
courses.desc: Outlines and emphasizes a subarea of plasma physics that is undergoing rapid development.

courses.title: General Relativity
courses.desc: An introduction to Einstein’s theory of gravitation. Tensor analysis, Einstein’s field equations, astronomical tests of Einstein’s theory, gravitational waves.

courses.title: Seminar in Condensed Matter Physics
courses.desc: Seminar designed to acquaint students with recent advances in solid state physics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy (both faculty and graduate students), other UCI departments, and other institutions.

courses.title: Seminar in Condensed Matter Physics
courses.desc: Seminar designed to acquaint students with recent advances in solid state physics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy (both faculty and graduate students), other UCI departments, and other institutions.

courses.title: Seminar in Condensed Matter Physics
courses.desc: Seminar designed to acquaint students with recent advances in solid state physics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy (both faculty and graduate students), other UCI departments, and other institutions.

courses.title: Seminar in Plasma Physics
courses.desc: Advanced topics in plasma physics:  wave propagation, nonlinear effects, kinetic theory and turbulence, stability problems, transport coefficients, containment, and diagnostics. Applications to controlled fusion and astrophysics.

courses.title: Seminar in Plasma Physics
courses.desc: Advanced topics in plasma physics:  wave propagation, nonlinear effects, kinetic theory and turbulence, stability problems, transport coefficients, containment, and diagnostics. Applications to controlled fusion and astrophysics.

courses.title: Seminar in Plasma Physics
courses.desc: Advanced topics in plasma physics:  wave propagation, nonlinear effects, kinetic theory and turbulence, stability problems, transport coefficients, containment, and diagnostics. Applications to controlled fusion and astrophysics.

courses.title: Seminar in Particle Physics
courses.desc: Discussion of advanced topics and reports of current research results in theoretical and experimental particle physics and cosmic rays.

courses.title: Seminar in Particle Physics
courses.desc: Discussion of advanced topics and reports of current research results in theoretical and experimental particle physics and cosmic rays.

courses.title: Seminar in Particle Physics
courses.desc: Discussion of advanced topics and reports of current research results in theoretical and experimental particle physics and cosmic rays.

courses.title: Seminar in Astrophysics
courses.desc: Acquaints students with current research in astrophysics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy and from other institutions.

courses.title: Seminar in Astrophysics
courses.desc: Acquaints students with current research in astrophysics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy and from other institutions.

courses.title: Seminar in Astrophysics
courses.desc: Acquaints students with current research in astrophysics. Lecturers from the Department of Physics and Astronomy and from other institutions.

courses.title: Current Topics in Chemical and Materials Physics
courses.desc: The subjects covered vary from year to year.  Connection between fundamental principles and implementations in practice in science, industry, and technology.

courses.title: Current Problems in Particle Physics
courses.desc: Presentation and discussion of current research and theory in particle physics.  Lectures given by staff and students.

courses.title: Current Problems in Particle Physics
courses.desc: Presentation and discussion of current research and theory in particle physics.  Lectures given by staff and students.

courses.title: Current Problems in Particle Physics
courses.desc: Presentation and discussion of current research and theory in particle physics.  Lectures given by staff and students.

courses.title: Seminar in Systems Microbiology Research
courses.desc: A research and journal club seminar that covers topics on bacteria and phage using approaches and principles from biology, engineering, and physics.

courses.title: Seminar in Teaching Physics
courses.desc: Techniques for effective teaching.  Covers active listening and student engagement, problem-solving skills, peer instruction and collaborative learning, and evaluation.  Required of all new Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Technical Communication Skills
courses.desc: Development of effective communication skills, oral and written presentations, through examples and practice.

courses.title: Research Seminar
courses.desc: Detailed discussion of research problems of current interest in the Department.  Format, content, and frequency of the course are variable.

courses.title: Experimental Research
courses.desc: With the approval of a faculty member, a student may pursue a research program in experimental physics.  Typical areas include astrophysics, condensed matter physics, elementary particle physics, and plasma physics.

courses.title: Theoretical Research
courses.desc: With approval of a faculty member, a student may pursue a research program in theoretical physics. Typical areas include astrophysics, condensed matter physics, elementary particle physics, and plasma physics.

courses.title: Physics Colloquium
courses.desc: Seminar held each week, in which a current research topic is explored. Frequently, off-campus researchers are invited to present the seminar, and on occasion a faculty member or researcher from the Department will speak.

courses.title: Reading of Special Topic
courses.desc: With special consent from a faculty member who will agree to supervise the program, a student may receive course credit for individual study of some area of physics.

courses.title: Laboratory Teaching
courses.desc: Required of and limited to teaching assistants of undergraduate laboratory courses. Designed to teach the  necessary skills required of teaching assistants for these courses.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Required of and limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Research in Physiology and Biophysics
courses.desc: Individual research directed toward doctoral dissertation and supervised by a particular professor.

courses.title: Research in Physiology and Biophysics for First-Year Students
courses.desc: Independent research within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in the Department of Physiology and Biophysics for first-year Ph.D. students.

courses.title: Introduction to Physiology Research
courses.desc: Introduction to research in physiology and related sciences. Concentrates on techniques emphasized in the various laboratories of the Department of Physiology and Biophysics.

courses.title: Concepts of Biophysics
courses.desc: Principles of crystallography; introduction to time-resolved absorption and fluorescence spectroscopy; the concepts of kinetic order and kinetic rate theory.

courses.title: Electronics for Biologists
courses.desc: Basic principles of electricity; properties and use of discrete components and integrated circuits; circuit analysis and design. Intended for advanced students in the life sciences.

courses.title: Introduction to Medical Physiology
courses.desc: Vertebrate physiology with emphasis on humans and on the relationship between the function of normal tissues and the processes of disease. Fundamental principles of physiology and the interrelationships which control organ function.

courses.title: Introduction to Medical Physiology
courses.desc: Vertebrate physiology with emphasis on humans and on the relationship between the function of normal tissues and the processes of disease. Fundamental principles of physiology and the interrelationships which control organ function.

courses.title: The Physiology of Ion Channels
courses.desc: Discusses how ion channels work (molecular/structural biophysics level) and what ion channels do in diverse cell types (cell physiology level).

courses.title: Introduction to Proteomics
courses.desc: Introduces students to concepts and methods of proteomics including protein identification, expression proteomics, and protein-protein interactions.

courses.title: Eye: Health and Disease
courses.desc: Introduces the anatomic and physiological basis of vertebrate vision and disease states in which the structure and function of the eye is disrupted with emphasis on current and developing research areas.

courses.title: Topics in Physiology
courses.desc: Contemporary research problems in physiology. Students review papers in the current literature and present ideas contained therein to other students.  Students present results of their own research and attend presentations given by other students and departmental researchers.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.desc: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.

courses.title: Dissertation in Physiology and Biophysics
courses.desc: Preparation and completion of the dissertation required for the Ph.D. or Master of Science degree.

courses.title: Public Policy
courses.desc: Explores different approaches to public policy analysis, the diverse conceptions of the goals and objectives that should be served by policy, and the appropriate role of the policy analyst. Policy consequences are traced to indirect and subtle incentives and disincentives.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics in Political Science I
courses.desc: Introduction to the variety of statistical applications in the social sciences.  Descriptive statistics.  Measures of central tendency and dispersion.  Percentile ranks.  Standardization and normal approximation.  Basic probability theory focuses on application to statistical inference and binomial distribution.  Laboratory required.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics in Political Science II
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical inference, sampling distribution, standard error.  Hypothesis tests for proportions and means. Inferential techniques for nominal variables including chi-square, study measures of strengths, significance of relationships between variables, assumptions, data requirements, and types of error in significance tests.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics in Political Science III
courses.desc: Focus on correlation, regression, and control for effects of variables.  One-way and two-way factorial analysis of variance.  A priori and a posteriori comparisons.  Introduction to repeated measures design and non-parametric statistics. Discusses use of statistics in newspapers and popular magazines.

courses.title: Introduction to Political Science: Political Analysis
courses.desc: Presents various modes of understanding politics. Emphasis on basic approaches to political analysis, their uses in constructing theories, and their application to particular national political systems.

courses.title: Introduction to Political Science: Macropolitics
courses.desc: An overview of macro-political inquiry, emphasizing the various determinants of political life in a political community. Explores the origins and challenges of democratic governance focusing on the tension between liberty and equality in a democratizing nation.

courses.title: Introduction to Political Science: Micropolitics
courses.desc: Introduction to political behavior of individuals and groups within national systems. Three questions addressed: How do individuals come to understand the political world? How do individuals behave within this world? How do groups and individuals engage in the political process.

courses.title: Introduction to American Government
courses.desc: Introduction to American political processes and institutions. Topics include elections, political participation, parties, interest groups, the Presidency, Congress, the bureaucracy, and the judiciary.

courses.title: Special Topics in American Politics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of American politics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Introduction to Political Theory
courses.desc: Types of questions:  What is politics?  What are the theoretical and philosophical bases for different types of political arrangements?  How do these perspectives get translated into reality?  Among others, the works of Rousseau, Locke, Mill, and Marx are read.

courses.title: Dilemmas of Diversity
courses.desc: Focuses on racial, ethnic, and gender diversity, multiculturalism, and their impact on our social and political ideals. Traces the sources of ideas about difference, equality, and toleration, and examines tensions that occur when forms of identity conflict with one another.

courses.title: Lower-Division Special Topics in Political Theory
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of political theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Introduction to International Relations
courses.desc: Analysis of political relations between and among nations with emphasis on explanations of conflict and cooperation. The role of ideologies and their relation to international problems are also examined.

courses.title: Global Political Ideologies
courses.desc: An overview of the major political ideologies shaping the current world order and global conflict. Topics include liberalism, democracy, nationalism, capitalism, communism, socialism, fascism, neoliberalism, clash of civilizations, sectarian violence, populist nationalism, and de-globalization.

courses.title: Human Rights and Global Governance
courses.desc: Historical development of civil, political rights and the rise of human rights in international law. Explores role, and limitations, of the UN, ICJ, and ICC in global governance. Reconceptualizing democracy and political representation in a postnational 21st century.

courses.title: Lower-Division Special Topics in International Relations
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of international relations. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Introduction to Politics Around the World
courses.desc: Introduces comparative politics. Compares political systems in a variety of countries. Includes elections, parties, parliaments, presidents, protest movements, and other aspects of national politics. Addresses how to make meaningful comparisons across countries.

courses.title: Introduction to Race and Ethnicity in Political Science
courses.desc: Examines major theories that attempt to explain the roles of race and ethnicity in U.S. politics.

courses.title: Lower Division Special Topics in Minority Politics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of minority politics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Introduction to Law
courses.desc: An introduction to the study of judicial politics.  Questions include:  what is law?; what is a court?; who are the judges? Analysis of a wide range of judicial decisions illustrates the political importance of courts in the U.S. and elsewhere.

courses.title: Lower-Division Special Topics in Law
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of law. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Globalization and Human Security
courses.desc: Emerging issues of human security in the globalized world, including personal human security, physical integrity, human trafficking, global climate change, food. Challenges of these complex human security problems for a multi-scalar system (international, national, local).

courses.title: Public Opinion
courses.desc: Theories concerning sources of public opinion, processes by which it is altered, organization of citizens’ belief systems, and role of public opinion in government policy. Students analyze survey data as a research project.

courses.title: The American Presidency
courses.desc: Presents a comprehensive survey of the American presidency and considers the question of political power.

courses.title: U
courses.desc: Examines how voters evaluate political parties, candidates, and issues in electoral campaigns to reach their decisions. Numerous controversies concerning the degree of issue voting, sophistication of candidate evaluations, and the decline of political parties are discussed.

courses.title: Public Policy Analysis
courses.desc: Examines different approaches to the analysis of public policy, what constitutes good policy, the role of government, and citizen participation in policy-making. Suggests a policy-design perspective which builds upon other frameworks but concentrates on goals, implementation structures, tools, and rationales.

courses.title: Presidents Since World War II
courses.desc: Reviews the actions and character of presidents from Harry Truman through Bill Clinton.  Each week a different president is examined from a variety of perspectives.  Students are expected to write a substantial original research paper.

courses.title: American Public Policy
courses.desc: Focuses on the development and implementation of public policy in the United States. Lectures cover theoretical models of the policy process as well as significant problems facing contemporary American decision-makers.

courses.title: American Metropolitan Politics
courses.desc: Explores the politics of urban and suburban America, including the policy making process; the exercise of political power; local politics, federalism and the problems of metropolitanism; and major policy problems facing urban areas.

courses.title: California Politics
courses.desc: Examines the structure and function of California government, traces historical development of political power, with constantly changing casts of power-brokers and seekers. Explores California exceptionalism and the roles played by the electorate, legislature, executive, and organized interests in policy making.

courses.title: California Politics
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Examines the structure and function of California government, traces historical development of political power, with constantly changing casts of power-brokers and seekers. Explores California exceptionalism and the roles played by the electorate, legislature, executive, and organized interests in policy making.

courses.title: Representation
courses.prereqs: SOC SCI 3A or SOC SCI 10A or SOC SCI 10B
courses.desc: Deals with classical theories of representation: issues of racial and political representation in U.S. legislatures and city councils; proportional representation models; and comparative election systems.

courses.title: The Politics of Protest
courses.desc: Examines the Civil Rights, Black Power, and women’s movements in relationship to the Asian American movement. Uses social movement theories to illuminate the cases, and the cases to critique and revise the theories.

courses.title: Latinos in U
courses.desc: Comparing the political issues facing Latino groups by examining their migration histories, voting behavior, nonelectoral participation, and policy issues.  Latino issues are examined on the national, state, and local levels, including formal representation, immigration, affirmative action, and language policy.

courses.title: Comparative Minority Politics
courses.desc: Examines the political experiences of Blacks, Latinos, and Asian Americans in the United States from roughly 1950 to the present. Focuses on how each group has pursued political empowerment via both conventional political channels and social movements.

courses.title: African American Politics
courses.desc: Examines politics of African Americans in order to gain a broader perspective of the American political process. Major developments in African American politics (including the civil rights movement, Black presidential bids), continuing problem of racism, responsiveness of key governing institutions.

courses.title: The United States Congress
courses.desc: Does the Congress do a good job of representing the American citizenry? Is it the most appropriate mechanism for the creation, resolution, and implementation of public policy.

courses.title: The United States Congress
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Does the Congress do a good job of representing the American citizenry? Is it the most appropriate mechanism for the creation, resolution, and implementation of public policy.

courses.title: Constitutional Convention
courses.prereqs: POL SCI 21A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Analyzes the Constitution, its amendments, and periods of Constitutional reform as a foundation for a critical evaluation of the Constitution with an eye both to necessary reforms and to elements of the Constitution that should be maintained.

courses.title: U
courses.desc: Examines selected immigration policy debates since the nineteenth century, rationale and consequences of immigration law since 1965, problems of administration, implementation and enforcement, impact of immigration policy on foreign relations, and contemporary debate regarding the future of U.S. policy.

courses.title: Urban Politics and Policy
courses.desc: Examines economic limits of cities and welfare policy. Addresses such issues as why are the poor concentrated in the central cities? Which anti-poverty programs will work best in cities? Which level of government can best combat poverty in the U.S.

courses.title: Politics of Animal Rights
courses.desc: Examines animal rights/welfare movement’s efforts to transform moral, practical, and legal standing of nonhuman animals in contemporary U.S. Explores intersection of racism, sexism, and speciesism informed by theories of race and ethnicity, including Asian American Studies.

courses.title: Political Ideologies: The Way We View Our World
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Politics has become divisive and ideological. But ideologies are poorly understood and have become mere labels for identifying friends and enemies. Course analyzes the nature of ideology, focusing on liberalism, conservatism, fascism, socialism, and contemporary "liberation" ideologies.

courses.title: Political Psychology
courses.desc: Examination of how psychological theory and research may be used to better understand political thought and behavior. Drawing on theories of learning, cognition, and personality, discusses such topics as the formation of political attitudes, and the process of political decision-making.

courses.title: Special Topics in American Politics and Society
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of American politics and society. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Game Theory and Politics I
courses.desc: Introduction to game theory and a survey of its political applications. Examples of topics covered include voting in small committees, legislatures, and mass elections; interest group activities and environmental issues; institutional design, and the evolution of cooperative behavior.

courses.title: Game Theory and Politics II
courses.desc: More advanced game theory and its political applications, beginning where Game Theory and Politics I ends.  Examples of topics covered include revolutions; arms race; spatial models of party competition; political manipulation; political coalitions and their power.

courses.title: Modern Political Theory
courses.desc: Examines major thinkers and intellectual movements in the political thought of the 17th and 18th centuries.

courses.title: Twentieth Century Political Theory
courses.desc: Examines major thinkers and intellectual movements in the political thought of the 20th Century.

courses.title: Social and Political Theory
courses.desc: Focus is on recent major work in social and political theory. An in-depth analysis of a relatively small body of writing. Authors discussed include Jurgen Habermas, Anthony Giddens, and Richard Rorty.

courses.title: Origins of Liberalism
courses.desc: Examines the ideals, social forces, and historical events that gave rise to liberal political theory. Topics include patriarchal authority, the divine right of kings, religious toleration, slavery, colonialism, political economy, the evolution of law, and tensions between liberty and equality.

courses.title: Just War Revisited
courses.desc: Examines the evolution of the doctrine of the just war across the history of Western political thought, the importance of changes in the doctrine and whether it applies today; examines international relations case studies to determine today's relevancy.

courses.title: Cannibals and Conquistadores: The Philosophy of the Other
courses.desc: Examines critically the notion of the "other" by looking at the philosophical challenges difference poses in the context of the European discovery of the New World. Seeks to understand the naissance of the concept of human rights and tolerance.

courses.title: Cannibals and Conquistadores: The Philosophy of the Other
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Examines critically the notion of the "other" by looking at the philosophical challenges difference poses in the context of the European discovery of the New World. Seeks to understand the naissance of the concept of human rights and tolerance.

courses.title: Types of Political Representation
courses.desc: Political representation plays an important role in democratic systems, but is elusive once examined closely.  Students delve into the concept and relate different views to political life. Half of the course is spent on writing instruction.

courses.title: Types of Political Representation
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Political representation plays an important role in democratic systems, but is elusive once examined closely.  Students delve into the concept and relate different views to political life. Half of the course is spent on writing instruction.

courses.title: The Moral of the Story: Introductory Seminar in Ethics
courses.desc: Introduces major theories and classic texts in ethics, from Plato and Aristotelian virtue ethics to utilitarianism and Kant and contemporary moral psychology.

courses.title: Moral of the Story: Introduction to Ethics
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Focuses on how we learn about ethics from stories, in the form of fables, bedtime stories, religious stories, soap operas, television, and movies as adults. Students bring in stories that informed their own ethical development.

courses.title: Ethics of Difference
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Examines differences traditionally judged politically salient—race, ethnicity, religion, gender. Personal interviews with an elderly person encourage students to understand the social construction of difference and to reexamine their own attitudes by putting themselves in the place of another.

courses.title: The Moral Life During War
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Can people keep their humanity during war? What does the term humanity signify when simply surviving requires faith, courage, and desperation? When facing wartime brutality, must we abrogate morality? What does it mean to compose a moral life during war?.

courses.title: Special Topics in Political Theory and Methods
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of political theory and methods. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: International Political Economy
courses.desc: Examination of problems in global political-economic relations through competing conceptual lenses or grand theories: mercantilism, liberalism, and Marxism. Surveys North-North and North-South issues relating power and wealth.

courses.title: International Political Economy of East Asia
courses.desc: Integration of theoretical perspectives in international political economy with the study of economic development in East Asia, with special emphasis on regional integration.

courses.title: U
courses.desc: U.S. policy toward the countries of East Asia: bilateral and regional security relationships, U.S. economic relations with the major Asian countries, the development of regional institutions, and human rights.

courses.title: The International Relations of East Asia
courses.desc: Surveys various aspects of relations between the nations of East Asia. Topics include the historical development of the region; current political and security relations, including the impact of the American military presence.

courses.title: U
courses.desc: Looks at changing international perspectives, policy responses, and military strategies of presidential administrations from Truman to Reagan. In assessing the motives and objectives of U.S. foreign policy leaders during the “Cold War” era, the concept of “national interest” is examined.

courses.title: U
courses.desc: Examines the theory of compellence and the U.S. practice of coercive diplomacy--the power to change behavior of other governments. Specific case examples: the Cuban missile crisis, bombing of North Vietnam, the Nicaraguan Contras, Desert Shield/Desert Storm, and Libya.

courses.title: U
courses.desc: Explores political, economic, social, and cultural ties that bind Latin America to the United States. Focuses on U.S. intervention and Latin American response from early nineteenth century to present day. Case studies include Mexico, Guatemala, Cuba, Chile, and Central America.

courses.title: Homeland Security
courses.desc: Examines the 9/11 origins of the concept of homeland security; assess the evolution, structure, and operations of the Department of Homeland Security; critically examines the evolution of threat assessment to the U.S. and the utilization of risk management methodologies.

courses.title: Approaches to International Relations
courses.desc: Reviews theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of international relations using contending perspectives to analyze power and influence, capabilities, interdependence, reciprocity, international regimes, anarchy, cooperation, imperialism, and hegemony.

courses.title: Ethics in an Age of Terror and Genocide
courses.desc: Original sources document personal impact of wars on genocides, from World War II to the Bosnian and Rwandan genocides and current wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. Students train for and conduct personal interviews with someone who lived through a war.

courses.title: Religion and World Politics
courses.prereqs: POL SCI 41A or INTL ST 11 or INTL ST 12 or REL STD 5A or REL STD 5B or REL STD 5C
courses.desc: Examines the relationship between religion and world politics historically and today, focusing on connections with peace/war, democracy, human rights, secularism(s), and globalization. Covers major debates, scholarship, concepts, and theories through class exercises, exams, and essays.

courses.title: International Humanitarianism
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Examines, analyzes, and evaluates the humanitarian phenomenon, the actors involved in it (including states, international organizations (IOs), and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs)), the rise of a body of international humanitarian law, and the problems and debates associated with international humanitarianism today.

courses.title: International Organizations
courses.desc: Active learning course that examines origins, decision-making processes, activities, and evolution of leading international organizations (e.g. U.N., NATO, EU, AU, WTO, World Bank, IMF). Activities include drafting reforms, applying theory, assessing dysfunctions, and participating in U.N. negotiation simulations.

courses.title: Special Topics in International Relations
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of international relations. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: East Asian Politics
courses.desc: Explores the recent history and political systems of China, Japan, and Korea, comparing the three countries with each other and with occasional reference to the United States, British, and French systems.

courses.title: Introduction to Chinese Politics
courses.desc: Background to the Chinese revolution, rise of the communist party; and institutions, ideology, and structure of Communist party rule from 1949-present.

courses.title: Chinese Politics: Policy, Leadership, and Change
courses.desc: Examines major policies from 1949 to the present, and considers the changing role of the Communist Party and its shifting treatment of various social groups; the era of Mao Zedong, reforms under Deng, and post-Deng politics.

courses.title: Voting and Political Manipulation
courses.desc: Introduction to social choice and cooperative games. Topics include majority rule, types of voting methods, apportionment and proportional representation, agenda manipulation, coalition formation, voting power, political consequences of electoral laws.

courses.title: West European Politics
courses.desc: Explores four main themes: (1) thinking scientifically about politics; (2) understanding the linkages between different political structures and spheres of activity; (3) evaluating some theories about politics; (4) learning about three countries: Britain, France, and Germany.

courses.title: Immigration Politics in Western Europe
courses.desc: Examines immigration politics in Western Europe, analyzing trends and policy from the postwar period through to today. Topics include citizenship, immigrant integration, asylum, the far-right, and a rotating focus on contemporary issues, e.g., terrorism, Islamophobia.

courses.title: Canadian Politics
courses.desc: Addresses the basic structures and processes of contemporary Canadian government and politics. Additional topics may include regionalism, federalism, western alienation and oil, Canadian solutions to social welfare policy questions, developments in Quebec, and other issues associated with French-English relations.

courses.title: Human Rights
courses.desc: Examines the causes and consequences of human rights violations with a focus on Latin America. What are human rights? When and where are they violated? What political mechanisms are available to deal with human rights problems? How effective are they.

courses.title: Cuban Society and Revolution
courses.desc: Explores the causes, development, and legacy of the 1959 Revolution. Themes include economic dependency, democracy, race, gender, culture, and the always volatile relations between Cuba and the United States.

courses.title: Comparative Politics:  Four Nations, Three Continents
courses.desc: Studies four countries in a comparative fashion: their respective political histories and cultural traditions; actual differences among their superficially similar party, parliamentary, and executive institutions; contemporary economic policy. The countries represent three continents and varying levels of economic development.

courses.title: Peoples and Cultures of Post-Soviet Eurasia
courses.desc: Examines the cultures and political conflicts of the more than 130 indigenous ethnic groups in the European and Asian territories of the former U.S.S.R. Emphasis is on the theoretical issues of ethnicity, nationalism, and conflict management.

courses.title: Conflict Resolution in Cross-Cultural Perspective
courses.desc: Examines theories of conflict management. Analyzes how conflict is mitigated in diverse cultures: at the interpersonal level, between groups, and on the international scale. Students discuss readings, hear from conflict management practitioners, and simulate negotiations.

courses.title: Jews and Power
courses.desc: Examines the relationship between the Jewish people and political power over a 3500 year period. How have Jews preserved their communal interests and personal safety? How have they defined the proper relationship of the people to political authority.

courses.title: US Government in Comparative Perspective
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Introduction to the United States in comparative perspective, covering general features of the United States and other countries, such as institutional design and policy choices. Addresses the debates about American exceptionalism and American decline.

courses.title: Organizations
courses.desc: How bureaucracies, formal organizations, and voluntary associations work, how/why they grow, and where they are going. History and structure of organizational rationality; dynamics of organized groups; behavior in organizations; limits of bureaucratization and attempts to overcome these limits through decentralization.

courses.title: Political Participation
courses.desc: The ways in which people in various political systems take part in politics, especially in activities directed toward affecting outcomes.  Who is active, what they do, why they do it, and what difference it makes.

courses.title: Protests, Movements, and Revolutions
courses.prereqs: SOCIOL 1 or POL SCI 6A or ECON 1
courses.desc: A survey of models of collective action drawn from sociology, economics, psychology, and political science. Focus on areas such as social movements, strikes, crowd psychology, cults, fads, fashions, public opinion, and symbolic and mythical elements in collective culture.

courses.title: International Divided Cities
courses.desc: Investigates urban divisions in international cities where deep-seated nationalistic ethnic differences create pressures for intergroup conflicts, autonomy, or territorial separation, and can incite violence. Urban political polarization as it is manifest in the urban setting.

courses.title: Introduction to Contemporary Middle East Politics
courses.desc: An overview of basic issues that shape the politics of the Middle East and North Africa. Themes include implication of the colonization era, nation-state formation, inter-Arab relations, nationalism, Arab-Israel conflict, Islamic resurgence, and more.

courses.title: Special Topics in Comparative Politics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of comparative politics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Undocumented Immigrant Experiences
courses.desc: Examines the experiences of undocumented immigrants and the policies that structure their educational, economic, social, and political participation.

courses.title: Special Topics in Race and Ethnicity Politics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of race and ethnicity. Topics vary each quarter.

courses.title: Law and Society
courses.desc: Law and its various roles in society. The nature and meaning of law; legality and power in the American system; law as a mechanism for social change; the role of law in dispute processing, social control, compliance with judicial decisions.

courses.title: Law and Society
courses.prereqs: POL SCI 71A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Law and its various roles in society. The nature and meaning of law; legality and power in the American system; law as a mechanism for social change; the role of law in dispute processing, social control, compliance with judicial decisions.

courses.title: Comparative Constitutional Politics
courses.prereqs: POL SCI 71A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Examines the impact of constitutional courts on politics and policy-making in Canada, France, Germany, and the United States. Cases may focus on the constitutional politics of free speech, abortion, rights to property, and the conduct of foreign relations.

courses.title: American Constitutional Law
courses.desc: American constitutional interpretation of cases involving separation of powers, federal-state relations, rights of property, free expression, privacy, criminal due process, political participation, and equality. Includes legal research methods, development of judicial review, legal reasoning, and impact of Supreme Court decisions.

courses.title: Law in the Twenty-First Century
courses.desc: Examines the complex relationship between law, the social sciences, and modern society.  Lectures explore such issues as the interplay between technology and constitutional rights, the impact of science on law, and the evolving roles of attorneys and judges.

courses.title: Legal Implications of the Drug Trade
courses.desc: Examines United States policy to combat domestic and international narcotics trafficking. Analyzes the national drug policy and program implementation by federal and state agencies. Considers the effects of these policies on our individual constitutional rights and the criminal justice system.

courses.title: International Law
courses.desc: Examination of the origin, changing structure, application of international law, and the role of legal norms in regulating the behavior of states and maintaining international order.

courses.title: Civil Liberties
courses.desc: Political analysis of selected Supreme Court cases involving claims under the Bill of Rights and the Fourteenth Amendment. Topics include:  race, sex, and other forms of discrimination; criminal justice; privacy; freedom of speech and related claims.

courses.title: U
courses.desc: Overview and analysis of the role played by the U.S. Supreme Court in the American political system. Judicial review, appointment of justices, judicial activism and judicial restraint, process of case selection, court deliberation, land decision-making, impact of Supreme Court decisions.

courses.title: U
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Overview and analysis of the role played by the U.S. Supreme Court in the American political system. Judicial review, appointment of justices, judicial activism and judicial restraint, process of case selection, court deliberation, land decision-making, impact of Supreme Court decisions.

courses.title: The Bill of Rights in Film
courses.desc: Focuses on ways American cinema has portrayed, represented, and analyzed U.S. Bills of Rights. Juxtaposes cinematic presentations on specific Bill of Rights clauses, treating films as cultural texts, with pertinent judicial decisions and more scholarly appraisals of those same provisions.

courses.title: Special Topics in Public Law
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of public law. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Honors Seminar in Political Science
courses.prereqs: Only open to students in the Political Science Honors Program.
courses.desc: Course for students enrolled in the Honors Program in Political Science.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Workshop
courses.desc: A weekly seminar/workshop to facilitate the exchange of ideas and research strategies among students and to review their progress in writing the thesis.

courses.title: Senior Thesis
courses.desc: Thesis research with Political Science faculty.

courses.title: Senior Thesis
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Thesis research with Political Science faculty.

courses.title: Field Study
courses.desc: Field study with Political Science faculty.

courses.title: Directed Group Study
courses.desc: Directed group study with Political Science faculty.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Independent study or research with a Political Science faculty member.

courses.title: Study of Democracy Colloquium
courses.desc: Skills critical to professional success. Students learn and practice professional presentation skills, develop substantive knowledge in the field by attending talks and panels, and interact with scholars and professionals in the field.

courses.title: Study of Democracy Colloquium
courses.desc: This colloquium teaches students skills critical to professional success. Students learn and practice professional presentation skills and develop substantive knowledge in the field by attending talks and panels and interacting with scholars and professionals in the field.

courses.title: Study of Democracy Colloquium
courses.desc: This colloquium teaches students skills critical to professional success. Students learn and practice professional presentation skills and develop substantive knowledge in the field by attending talks and panels and interacting with scholars and professionals in the field.

courses.title: Colloquium
courses.desc: Doctoral training requires more than learning substantive debates and research methods; it also requires students learn professional practices, routines, and expectations.  This year-long workshop offers students a mix of professional development, outside speakers, and casual conversations with departmental faculty.

courses.title: Colloquium
courses.desc: Doctoral training requires more than learning substantive debates and research methods; it also requires students learn professional practices, routines, and expectations.  This year-long workshop offers students a mix of professional development, outside speakers, and casual conversations with departmental faculty.

courses.title: Colloquium
courses.desc: Doctoral training requires more than learning substantive debates and research methods; it also requires students learn professional practices, routines, and expectations.  This year-long workshop offers students a mix of professional development, outside speakers, and casual conversations with departmental faculty.

courses.title: Public Opinion
courses.desc: Introduction to the study of U.S. public opinion. Provides an overview of the theories regarding opinion formation, the methodologies employed, and the role of public opinion in democratic governments.

courses.title: Ethics Workshop
courses.desc: Students find an important question in ethics, search literature to assess topic's importance, post question to be researched, propose method of analysis and type of data, analyze data, and note how their works contribute to knowledge in the field.

courses.title: Special Topics in Politics and Society
courses.desc: Current research in politics and society.

courses.title: Public Policy
courses.desc: Explores different approaches to public policy analysis, the diverse conceptions of the goals and objectives that should be served by policy, and the appropriate role of the policy analyst.  Policy consequences are traced to indirect and subtle incentives and disincentives.

courses.title: Theories of Power and Empowerment
courses.desc: Studies different ways of thinking about power and its uses. Explores theories of power that inform various notions of empowerment, including resistance, participatory democracy, and workplace empowerment.

courses.title: Special Topics in American Politics
courses.desc: Current research in American Politics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Political Epistemology
courses.desc: Focuses on fundamental issues of knowledge in the study of politics, especially interconnections and tensions between politics and knowledge.  Counts as the Field Seminar in Political Theory.

courses.title: Theories of Textual Interpretation
courses.desc: Examination of different theories of textual interpretation, including Straussian, hermeneutical, poststructuralist, feminist, postcolonial, and critical race theories. Key questions include: How does one go about the task of interpreting texts? What makes one interpretation better or more insightful than another.

courses.title: Introduction to Voting Theory
courses.desc: Introduction to voting modules. Substantive topics include majority rule, voting methods and their properties, apportionment and proportional representation, agenda manipulation, coalition formation, voting power, political consequences of electoral laws.

courses.title: Research Logic and Design in Political Science
courses.desc: An introduction to standard research techniques in political science. Issues of epistemology, research design, and approaches to empirical analysis.

courses.title: The Moral Life During War
courses.desc: Can people keep their humanity during war? What does the term humanity signify when simply surviving requires faith, courage, and desperation? When facing wartime brutality must we abrogate morality? What does it mean to compose a moral life during war?.

courses.title: Special Topics in Political Theory
courses.desc: Current research in political theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Seminar in International Relations Theory
courses.desc: Overview of the major theories guiding research and scholarship in international relations.  Focus on major conceptual approaches (realism, neoliberalism, marxism) and levels of analysis (systemic, state, and subnational), as well as on methodological/epistemological debates engulfing the field.

courses.title: Research Design in International Relations
courses.desc: Surveys research design primarily through substantive readings in international relations. The purpose is to familiarize students with choices/dilemmas relevant to IR-specific research. Students at various stages in the graduate program and with different methodological orientations are welcome.

courses.title: Special Topics in International Relations
courses.desc: Current research in international relations. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Theories and Practice of Migration and Citizenship
courses.desc: Examines theories of migration and citizenship. In examining these themes, the course includes discussion of theory development, multi-method testing, and case study comparison with a focus on Western Europe and other advanced democratic receiving states.

courses.title: Introduction to Game Theory
courses.desc: Introduction to non-cooperative games.  The prisoner's dilemma, Nash equilibrium, sequential games, subgame perfection. Applications include collective action, agenda-setter models, spatial competition of political parties, models of revolution and arms race.

courses.title: Special Topics in Comparative Politics
courses.desc: Current research in comparative politics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.
