courses.title: Political Participation
courses.desc: Examines theoretical approaches to the explanation of the pattern of participation and consideration of the results of empirical studies of such activity by mass publics (mainly in Europe and North America).  Addresses issues in both comparative politics and political behavior.

courses.title: Political Economy I
courses.desc: Political Economy lies at the intersection of economics and political science. Course studies effects of politics on the economy and uses tools derived from economics to understand the behavior of governments and of citizens when they deal with politics.

courses.title: Political Economy II
courses.desc: Political Economy lies at the intersection of economics and political science. Course studies effects of politics on the economy and uses tools derived from economics to understand the behavior of governments and of citizens when they deal with politics.

courses.title: Political Economy III
courses.desc: Political Economy lies at the intersection of economics and political science. Course studies effects of politics on the economy and uses tools derived from economics to understand the behavior of governments and of citizens when they deal with politics.

courses.title: Advanced Qualitative Methods: Analyzing Qualitative Data
courses.desc: Introduction to the theory and practice of analyzing qualitative data. Students must have already learned about data collection and research design for qualitative research and must have qualitative data they can analyze.

courses.title: Predictive Models in Social Sciences
courses.desc: Basic numeracy (logarithms, fixed-exponent and exponential formats, graphing). Models based on ignorance and logical constraints. Logical quantitative models (how things should be) to complement and guide statistical analysis (how things are).

courses.title: Introduction to Political Psychology I
courses.desc: Reviews theoretical questions regarding the relationship between the analytical and normative and the polity. Considers relationships between the analytical and normative concerns of psychology and political science, addressing empirical literatures on political socialization, ideology and public opinion, identity and nationality.

courses.title: Dissertation Research
courses.desc: Dissertation research with Political Science faculty.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Independent research with Political Science faculty.

courses.title: Topics in Luso-Brazilian Literature
courses.desc: In English. Contextualized study of a major author, current, or genre in Brazilian, Portuguese, and/or Lusophone African literature. Examples: Gender, Race, and Sexualities in Postcolonial Lusophone Literatures; Women and Writing in Brazil and Portugal; The Short Story.

courses.title: Studies in Luso-Brazilian Literature and Culture
courses.desc: Critical analysis of selected literary works from Portugal and/or Brazil. Contextualizes the works within their historical and literary specificity, and discusses pertinent theoretical issues raised by them. Taught in Portuguese.

courses.title: Introduction to Psychology
courses.desc: Introduction to field of psychology, addressing the application of scientific methods to the study of human development, learning, memory, problem solving, perception, biological mechanisms, emotions and motivation, personality, psychopathology, and effects of diverse social and cultural contexts on human behavior.

courses.title: Psychology Fundamentals
courses.desc: Designed to provide freshman with an in-depth survey of general psychology. Topics include biological bases of behavior, sensation, perception, cognition, development, personality, psychopathology, and social psychology.

courses.title: Psychology Fundamentals
courses.desc: Designed to provide freshmen with an in-depth survey of general psychology. Topics include biological bases of behavior, sensation, perception, cognition, development, personality, psychopathology, and social psychology.

courses.title: Psychology Fundamentals
courses.desc: Designed to provide freshman with an in-depth survey of general psychology. Topics include biological bases of behavior, sensation, perception, cognition, development, personality, psychopathology, and social psychology.

courses.title: Special Topics in Social Behavior
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Course content varies with interest of instructor.

courses.title: Life Span Developmental Psychology
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9B
courses.desc: Addresses the major issues, concepts, and methods of life span developmental psychology. The fundamental theories, distinctive methods, and the physical, perceptual, cognitive, social, motivational, and emotional development for each developmental phase of the life course are considered.

courses.title: Abnormal Psychology
courses.prereqs: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C) and SOCECOL 10
courses.desc: Survey of disorders organized by the diagnostic categories of the American Psychiatric Association. Interdisciplinary orientation combines environmental, psychological, and organic perspectives on etiology and treatment.

courses.title: Health Psychology
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Theory and research are considered as they contribute to an understanding of the role of psychological processes in health and illness. The distinction between prevention and treatment of illness is established, and a variety of psychosocial interventions are elaborated.

courses.title: Social Animal: An Introduction to Social Psychology
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Theories and research exploring social behavior and social influences on behavior. Topics include methods of social research, attitude formation and change, social perception, the social self, stereotypes and prejudice, conformity, obedience, altruism, aggression, interpersonal relationships and love, and group behavior.

courses.title: Infant Development
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9B
courses.desc: Study of human development from conception through the first two years of life, covering processes and events in the domains of physical, social, and cognitive development.

courses.title: Child Development
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9B
courses.desc: Examines social, emotional, and intellectual growth and development between the ages of 2 and 12 years.

courses.title: Adolescent Development
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9B
courses.desc: Examines current research on the biological, social, and cultural contexts of adolescent development. Topics include the impacts of puberty, adolescents' decision-making competencies, changes in family and peer relationships, identity development, and psychosocial problems such as depression and problem behavior.

courses.title: Adult Development
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9B
courses.desc: Examines why and how we change (with attention to gains as well as losses) from ages 18-65 and the nature and sources of continuity over time. Topics include physical and intellectual functioning, personality, coping strategies, and social roles and relationships.

courses.title: Gerontology
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9B
courses.desc: Examines stereotypes and myths associated with aging; physiological and psychological changes that accompany old age; distinguishes behavior changes due to aging per se from those due to historical and socioeconomic factors; political, social aspects of old age in contemporary society.

courses.title: Cognitive Development
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9B
courses.desc: Examines theories on nature of cognitive development. Discusses behaviorist theories on role of the environment including those of Vygotsky and Piaget, and recent evidence from cognitive psychologists stressing the importance of knowledge and skills within specific domains.

courses.title: Human Development and Cross-Cultural Perspectives
courses.prereqs: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9B) and SOCECOL 10
courses.desc: Human development in diverse cultures (e.g., Asian, American, and African). Special emphasis on East-West contrasts and when East meets West (i.e., Asian-American experiences). Topics include parenting, family relations, language and cognition, schooling and academic achievement, and morality.

courses.title: The Psychology of Gender
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSYCH 9B or PSCI 11B or PSYCH 7A
courses.desc: Discussion of gender identity development and examination of gender differences and similarities across the life span. Consideration of the biology and psychology of gender in relation to physical, behavioral, personality, and intellectual capabilities.

courses.title: Human Sexuality
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9B
courses.desc: A broad survey of human sexuality encompassing genetic factors, physiological and anatomical development, customary and atypical forms of behavior, reproductive processes, and cultural determinants.

courses.title: Child Development, the Law, and Social Policy
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C. Recommended: PSCI 111D or PSCI 112D.
courses.desc: Examines the rights of children and adolescents in the U.S. and internationally; law and policy with regard to the family, government services, health care, education, juvenile justice and the labor market; and the connection between child development, law and policy.

courses.title: Work and Family
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Effects of employment and unemployment on mental health and marital quality; effects of work on parenting and child development; corporate and social policies for "families that work"; young adults' decision-making about work and family.

courses.title: Attachment Relationships
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSYCH 7A or PSCI 11A or PSYCH 9A or PSCI 11B or PSYCH 9B
courses.desc: Students learn about the development of attachment-related needs throughout development, as well as the links between attachment and emotion, psychopathology and treatment. Lectures emphasize classic as well as cutting-edge research and are supplemented by primary source readings.

courses.title: Behavioral Medicine
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Examines biobehavioral aspects of health and illness, focusing on how stress contributes to or exacerbates disease processes. Background information on psychosomatic medicine and stress models and detailed examination of specific organ systems emphasizing the reactivity of these systems to stress.

courses.title: Human Stress
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Stress as a multidisciplinary topic. Biological, psychological, and sociological approaches to adaptation-related disorders. Effects of acute and chronic stress on emotions, physiology, and behavior. Methods of stress assessment, stress reduction, and intervention.

courses.title: Child Health Psychology
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 9C or PSYCH 7A. Recommended: SOCECOL 10.
courses.desc: Exploration of psychological antecedents, concomitants, and consequences of medical illnesses in children. Children's beliefs about health, illness, and medication; the role of stress; coronary-prone behavior; therapeutic adherence and physician-patient interaction; coping with chronic illness; effects of child's illness on family.

courses.title: Clinical Sport Psychology
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to clinical sport psychology, that includes, among other things, an introduction to psychopathology in sport; plus the use of psychological skills training, including anxiety reduction techniques, visualization, self-efficacy, coping skills, concentration, and goal-setting in sports.

courses.title: The Hardiness Approach to Stress Management
courses.desc: New development within psychology involving a combination of motivations and skills that extensive research has shown enhances performance, conduct, morale, stamina, and health. Combines study of hardiness research with strategies for improvement of personal hardiness through a series of exercises.

courses.title: Clinical Health Psychology
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Behavioral role in etiology, treatment, and prevention of certain diseases. Behavioral intervention including biofeedback, stress-, pain-management, health habit counseling, and other skills to assist patients make cognitive, emotional, and behavioral changes needed to cope with disease or achieve better health.

courses.title: Clinical Psychology
courses.prereqs: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C) and PSCI 102C
courses.desc: Overview of theories, assessment techniques, research methodologies, and intervention approaches in clinical psychology. Psychodynamic, behavioral, humanistic, and cognitive perspectives are examined along with ethical and professional issues.

courses.title: Psychological Testing and Assessment
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C and (PSCI 102C and PSCI 150C). Recommended: SOCECOL 10.
courses.desc: Laboratory-seminar exploration of diverse methods of assessing, analyzing, and recording behavior. Includes methods of direct behavioral observation, structured (analog) assessments, rating scales, interviewing, and self-monitoring. Development of assessment skills and their application in intervention and research programs.

courses.title: Clinical Child Psychology
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Examines research and theory concerning childhood psychopathology behavior disorders. Diagnosis and assessment, early identification of high-risk children, fears and phobias, antisocial behavior, childhood psychoses, autism, depression, attention deficit/hyperactivity disorders, and ethical and policy implications of identifying children who are different.

courses.title: Developmental Psychopathology
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C. Recommended: SOCECOL 10.
courses.desc: Research and theory of origins, course, and outcomes of disordered behavior. Continuity and change in patterns of behavior; environmental challenges and buffers; stress/competence in children; vulnerable/invincible children; children of mentally ill parents; families at risk; childhood antecedents of adult disorders.

courses.title: Cognitive Behavior Therapy
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or (PSCI 11A and PSCI 11C) or PSYCH 7A or (PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9C)
courses.desc: Presentation of principles and procedures of therapeutic interventions based on cognitive-behavior methods. Cognitive factors in learning, emotional arousal, psychological disorder, and psychotherapy reviewed. Introduces the application of cognitive behavioral methods to problems of depression, anxiety, anger, pain, and impulsivity.

courses.title: Child Therapies
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Examines research methodologies, empirical data, and implications of diverse intervention strategies. Primary topics include psychotherapy process and outcome, family therapies, behavioral intervention, cognitive behavior modification, pediatric psychopharmacology, and ethical and social policy implications of intervening in other people's lives.

courses.title: Forensic Psychology: Advanced Seminar
courses.prereqs: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C) and PSCI 102C and (PSCI 178S or CRM/LAW C149)
courses.desc: Focuses on the psychology of criminal offending, particularly violent behavior. Examines violence, sexual offending, and mental disorder related to crime with regard to clinical assessment and treatment; mental health services within forensic institutions.

courses.title: Clinical Neuroscience
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSYCH 7A or PSCI 11A or PSYCH 9A or BIO SCI 99
courses.desc: An introduction to the neuroclinical bases of human behavior, including neuropsychological approaches to mental disorders. Also includes case formulations, research articles, therapeutic approaches, and other discussions related to select psychopathology and other neurobehavioral topics.

courses.title: Forensic Psychology
courses.desc: Forensic psychology is the interface between clinical psychology and the law. Emphasizes clinically relevant legal topics (insanity defense; competency to stand trial) and includes critical thinking about issues that arise when psychologists are involved in legal proceedings.

courses.title: Psychodynamic Studies
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Introduction to contemporary psychodynamic studies. Emphasis on clinical concepts associated with psychodynamic psychotherapy, including unconscious determinants of behavior, typical defenses, life experiences, and techniques. Exploration of links between psychodynamic-oriented psychotherapy and other disciplines (e.g., psychology, music, medicine, neuroscience, film).

courses.title: Human  Neuropsychology
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI N110 or PSYCH 9A or PSCI 11A
courses.desc: A survey of human brain disorders using a clinical case study approach to illustrate fundamental issues in studying brain and behavior. Topics include sensory deficits, attentional neglect, amnesia, cortical organization, clinical psychopathology, and more.

courses.title: Addiction
courses.prereqs: PSCI 11A and PSCI 11B and PSCI 11C and PSCI 102C
courses.desc: Designed for those with an interest in the nature and treatment of addiction. Focuses on the etiology and treatment of addiction, but does not prepare students to treat substance abuse disorders.

courses.title: Adult Psychopathology
courses.prereqs: PSCI 102C. Equivalent to PSCI 102C is also accepted.
courses.desc: Advanced course in abnormal psychology, focusing on adult psychopathology. Covers historical and fundamental issues about psychiatric disorders, clinical research on disorders of anxiety, PTSD, mood, psychoses, personality, and dementia, and their biopsychosocial features, and attends to assessment and treatment.

courses.title: Personality
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Comparison of the major theories of personality. Provides a frame of reference for understanding lifestyles, development, maturity, and psychopathology. Emerging research themes are used to identify promising lines of personality theorizing.

courses.title: Environmental Psychology
courses.desc: Impact of the physical environment on individual and group behavior. Three basic concerns examined: (a) environmental determinants of behavior at the individual and interpersonal level; (b) social planning and urban design; (c) methodological approaches to the study of environmental issues.

courses.title: Social Relationships
courses.prereqs: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C) and SOCECOL 10
courses.desc: Examines major issues, concepts, and methods in the scientific study of social relationships. Topics include relationship formation and dissolution, friendships and love relationships, loneliness, bereavement, societal influences on close relationships, significance of close relationships for health and well-being.

courses.title: Error and Bias in Social Judgement
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Examines how people encode, reason about, and remember social information and explores how biases and shortcomings in social perception, judgment, and memory are central to understanding both effective social functioning and many forms of maladaptive behavior and social conflict.

courses.title: Motivation
courses.prereqs: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C) and PSCI 101D and (PSCI 104S or UPPP 151)
courses.desc: History, major theories, methods, and applications of motivational psychology, with emphasis on European approaches. Origins of the field in personality, learning, cognition, and activation research. Recent innovations in motivational and volitional self-recognition. Current approaches, major debates, empirical research programs.

courses.title: Violence in Society
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Current theory and research on aggression; anger and violence as problems in individual and social functioning. Process and functions of anger examined with regard to normal behavior and psychopathology. The determinants, prevalence, and implications of violence in society are analyzed.

courses.title: Cultural Psychology
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11B or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9B or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: An examination of culture's influence on human minds. Topics include culture's impact on perception, cognition, motivation, emotion, moral reasoning, communication, and health. Addresses cultural psychology's methods, history, and place within psychology and related fields.

courses.title: Social Epidemiology
courses.prereqs: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C) and SOCECOL 10 and SOCECOL 13
courses.desc: Overviews evidence linking environmental factors to mental and physical disorders including such variables as socioeconomic status, income inequality, work stress, job loss, social capital, location, and other demographic characteristics. Measurement and research design issues of both individual and aggregate levels.

courses.title: Positive Psychology
courses.desc: The field of positive psychology focuses on what is right and positive about people and institutions. Introduces findings associated with human strengths and positive emotions, and provides clinical and personal applications and implications.

courses.title: Industrial-Organizational Psychology
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11A or PSCI 11B or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9A or PSYCH 9B or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Examines the application of social psychology to organizational settings. Topics include motivation of workers, group decision-making, leadership styles, career management, and organizational development.

courses.title: Psychology of Inequality
courses.desc: Focuses on the psychological dimensions of poverty, wealth, and economic inequality.

courses.title: Evolutionary Psychology
courses.desc: Understanding our evolutionary origins is critical to truly understanding the complexities of human psychology. Explores how Darwinian principles, applied to both genes and culture, can help us understand not just how the mind works, but why.

courses.title: The Science and Practice of Compassion
courses.desc: Explores the latest scientific research on compassion and its correlates, and considers practical strategies for increasing compassion in everyday life. Students discover how cutting-edge research is yielding insights into kindness, empathy, altruism, and compassion.

courses.title: Chicano/Latino Social Psychology
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Examines theories, research, and major issues of relevance to understanding social psychological processes in Chicano/Latino populations. Topics include social development, cultural orientations, gender and sexuality, close relationships, happiness and well-being, stereotyping, prejudice and discrimination, and mental and physical health.

courses.title: Cognition and Learning in Educational Settings
courses.desc: Foundational concepts in cognition and development as applied to student learning. Primary topics include historical behaviorism, basic cognitive structure and processes, complex cognition, cognitive development, and motivation.

courses.title: Psychology of Learning, Abilities, and Intelligence
courses.prereqs: PSYCH 7A or PSCI 9 or PSCI 11A or PSCI 11B or PSCI 11C
courses.desc: Overview of classic positions on the mind, human abilities, and intelligence, especially as related to academic achievement. Contrasting views: psychometric versus information processing; experimental versus correlational research.

courses.title: Language and Literacy
courses.desc: Addresses the linguistic principles and processes that underlie oral and written language proficiency. Emphasis is on how to use phonology, morphology, orthography, semantics, syntax, and pragmatics to support literacy and oral language development for K-12 students.

courses.title: Juvenile Delinquency
courses.desc: Patterns of delinquent behavior, theories that explain behavior, current research aimed at enhancing exploratory power. Attempts to prevent and control delinquency are put in historical perspective. Development of the current juvenile justice system and evolution of modern juvenile law.

courses.title: Social Control of Delinquency
courses.desc: Assumes familiarity with theories of delinquency, the juvenile justice system, and elements of juvenile law. Explores socio-historical origins and evolution of juvenile justice, current research and policy on delinquency prevention and treatment, and future directions of law, policy, and practice.

courses.title: Psychology and the Law
courses.desc: Psychological assumptions of the American legal system and mental health aspects of provision of criminal justice services. Civil commitment, insanity defense, competence to stand trial, jury selection, eyewitness identification. Use of police, courts, correctional institutions in prevention of behavior disorder.

courses.title: Family Law
courses.desc: Examines legal issues surrounding marriage, cohabitation, divorce, child custody and support, adoption, and the rights of parents and children in the family context. The findings of social science research are used to illuminate the legal issues.

courses.title: Eyewitness Testimony
courses.desc: Faulty eyewitness testimony is a major cause of wrongful convictions. Covers the fast-growing topic of eyewitness testimony and memory for real-world events, both how psychologists study eyewitness capacity, and how the legal system has dealt with eyewitness issues.

courses.title: Research Seminar in Psychological Science
courses.desc: Special topics research seminar. Content varies with interest of instructor. Capstone seminar for students who have conducted research with, or have a background in, the research topics of the PSCI faculty member offering this seminar in a given quarter.

courses.title: Introduction to Legal and Forensic Psychology
courses.desc: Familiarizes students with the interrelated fields of psychology, law, and forensic studies. Emphasizes clinically relevant legal topics (insanity defense; competency to stand trial) and includes critical thinking about issues that arise when psychologists are involved in legal proceedings.

courses.title: Research Methods in Psychology
courses.desc: In-depth examination of the conceptualization of research problems and linkages between theory and the design of appropriate strategies for empirical research in psychological science. Topics include experimental and quasi-experimental designs, reliability and validity of measurement and non-experimental procedures.

courses.title: Data Analysis and Statistics
courses.desc: Statistical techniques to facilitate inferences in psychological research, including fundamentals of statistical inference and methods for analyzing data.

courses.title: Adolescence
courses.desc: Considers pubertal and cognitive changes and their social consequences; the family, peer group, school, and cultural contexts in which adolescence is embedded; and selected psychosocial issues including autonomy, identity, health, and well-being.

courses.title: Research Methods
courses.desc: In-depth examination of issues relevant to designing and evaluating research in psychological science. Topics address casual inference, ethical issues surrounding the responsible conduct of research, experimental and quasi-experimental designs, reliability and validity of measurement, and non-experimental procedures.

courses.title: Applied Psychological Research
courses.desc: Focuses on scientific and professional issues in the field of psychology. Topics include communication skills; intervention approaches; collaboration, consultation, and referral; and ethical issues associated with at-risk populations research.

courses.title: Social Cognition
courses.desc: Explores historical and current developments in cognitive social psychology. Topics include judgment and decision making, automatic versus controlled processing, affective forecasting, motivated reasoning, and the effects of emotion on memory and judgment.

courses.title: Seminar in Social Psychology
courses.desc: Presents an overview of selected theoretical and empirical topics in social psychology including social influence and conformity, altruism and aggression, persuasion and attitude change, self and social perception, and social cognition.

courses.title: Psychology and Law
courses.desc: An interdisciplinary approach to research in psychology, law, and/or criminology. Examines how psychology is applied to the civil and criminal justice systems, how case law shapes this application, and how legal decisions affect the direction of psychological research.

courses.title: Life-Span Development
courses.desc: Introduces the major concepts of life-span development and discusses those with regard to some key topics of developmental psychology. For example, change and continuity, evolutionary and inherited nature, culture, society, and family-based nurture, and their dynamic interaction.

courses.title: Infancy
courses.desc: Covers development from conception through the second year. Focus is on research and theory concerning infants' physical, social, cognitive, perceptual, emotional, and language development. Also covers transition to parenthood and family context of infant development.

courses.title: Developmental Psychology: Theories and History
courses.desc: Examines key concepts, theories, and the historical and philosophical roots of research in human life span development. Focuses on biological and environmental causation, universalism and cultural relativism, continuity and change.

courses.title: Forensic Assessment
courses.desc: Explores the various ways in which clinical psychology is relevant to the law, and how forensic psychologists can meaningfully contribute to the adjudicatory process. Examines legal, scientific, and ethical issues that arise when psychologists are involved in legal proceedings.

courses.title: Cross-Cultural Developmental Psychology
courses.desc: Examines human development in diverse cultures (e.g., Asian, American, and African). Cultural diversity within the U.S. and acculturation of various ethnic groups is also discussed. Topics include parenting, family relations, language, and cognition, schooling and academic achievement, and morality.

courses.title: Children and the Law
courses.desc: Examines how psychology research and practice can inform several areas of law and social policy affecting children, adolescents, and families. Topics include education, mental health, reproductive rights, and delinquency.

courses.title: Emotion in Psychology
courses.desc: Covers original and recent theories of emotions and how they guide current research.  Specific topics include neuroantomical structure of emotion, life-span emotional development, and health and emotion.

courses.title: Professional Issues in Psychology
courses.desc: Examines a variety of issues related to the professional socialization and development of graduate students in psychology. Topics include the publication process, sources of research funding, alternative employment options, competitiveness on the job market, and the academic career route.

courses.title: Personality
courses.desc: Provides a frame of reference for understanding personality and its role in life-span development, the relationship of the individual to society, and both mental and physical illness.

courses.title: Childhood
courses.desc: Provides graduate students with an overview of traditional and emerging theories, models, and research designed to understand children's development in the domains of cognitive, social, and emotional functioning.

courses.title: Child Psychopathology
courses.desc: Examination of etiology, classification, and developmental pathways of disorders, as well as risk and resilience factors, during the childhood/adolescent years. Discussion of genetic influences and contextual risk factors as well as internalizing and externalizing disorders.

courses.title: Legal Reasoning and Jurisprudence
courses.desc: Overview of the law and legal process as well as the history and assumptions underlying modern legal reasoning. Issues related to procedure and evidence as well as key jurisprudential perspectives are discussed.

courses.title: Affective Neuroscience
courses.desc: Provides an overview of the emerging field of affective neuroscience. Emphasis is placed on mapping affective experience and behavior to brain function, including cross-level integration of anatomical, chemical, fMRI, and electrical data.

courses.title: EEG Methods
courses.desc: Provides an in-depth training of the electroencephalogram (EEG) methodology with a specific focus on the event-related potential technique. Emphasis is on learning how to use this methodology and how to analyze data, with a focus on emotional stimuli.

courses.title: Advanced Social Psychology
courses.desc: Conveys an appreciation of the flavors of contemporary social psychology, an understanding of empirical approaches to problems in this area, and a sense of the array of theoretical orientations in the field.

courses.title: Emotion, Reasoning, and Memory
courses.desc: Examines research and theory on emotion from the perspective of cognitive psychology. Topics include the effects of emotions on attention, memory, and problem solving; the relations between emotional and cognitive development; flash-bulb memories of intense emotional experiences; eyewitness testimony.

courses.title: Clinical Interviewing and Treatment in a Forensic Setting
courses.desc: Students receive an introduction to clinical interviewing, learn details of strategic, solution-focused therapy, and think critically about issues that come at the interaction of psychology and the law. Students are not "license-eligible" at end of this course.

courses.title: Law and Behavior: Compliance and Enforcement
courses.desc: Provides sophisticated insight into the different ways through which law shapes behavior. Addresses both the economic amoral rational choice theories, as well as ideas from social psychology, criminology, and sociology about the moral, social, and and unconscious dimensions of compliance.

courses.title: Master of Legal and Forensic Psychology Capstone
courses.desc: Focuses on macro-level writing topics such as developing a meaningful research question, conducting a thorough review of relevant literature, and presenting a clear and convincing research-based argument.

courses.title: Mental Health and the Law
courses.desc: Explores the history of criminalization of persons with mental illness. Topics include challenges and needs of persons with mental illness; civil and outpatient commitment; law enforcement responses to persons with mental illness; and mentally ill offenders in jails and prisons.

courses.title: Violence, Anger, and Psychopathology
courses.desc: Overviews the prevalence of violence as a criminal and public health problem. Topics include violence within families and intimate partner relationships, traumatic origins of violence, the development of a violence-prone personality, the association of anger and violence with psychopathology.

courses.title: Family and the Law
courses.desc: Examines sociological and legal perspectives on the relationship between family life and law, with a focus on three distinct but sometimes interconnected domains: the child welfare system, the criminal justice system, and the immigration system.

courses.title: Health Psychology
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary exploration of emerging fields of health psychology and behavioral medicine. Topics: role of stress in development/treatment of medical problems; sociocognitive determinants of health and illness; interpersonal health transactions; behavioral approaches to medical problems such as diabetes, obesity, hypertension.

courses.title: Technology and Health
courses.desc: Explores the growing intersection of health and technology, including electronic Health (“eHealth”), mobile health (“mHealth”), and digital health and medicine. Specifically, it focuses on the implications and uses of technologies for behavioral and emotional health, and behavioral change.

courses.title: Intensive Longitudinal Data Analysis
courses.desc: Fundamentals of Intensive Longitudinal Study designs, gain first-hand experience collecting ILD using web and/or mobile-based platforms, and learn.

courses.title: Interpersonal Processes and Health
courses.desc: Examines traditions of research linking interpersonal processes to emotional or physical health. Topics include: role of social support in ameliorating stress, effects of social control on health-compromising behaviors, adverse effects of social relationships on health, causes of deficient social relationships.

courses.title: Eyewitness Testimony
courses.desc: Examines the evidence that shows that faulty eyewitness memory is the major cause of wrongful convictions. Explores what the legal system thinks of eyewitness testimony and how the legal system has dealt with eyewitness issues.

courses.title: Memory and the Law
courses.desc: Examines the controversial topic of repressed memory, or perception and memory of real-world events.

courses.title: Psychology and the Law
courses.desc: Overview of how psychology is applied to the civil and criminal justice systems, how case law shapes this application, and how legal decisions affect the direction of psychological research. Interdisciplinary approach to research in psychology, law, and/or  criminology.

courses.title: Coping with Stressful Life Events
courses.desc: Explores how individuals cope with serious life crises (e.g., illness, bereavement), life transitions, and daily stressors. Considers how such events impact on people's cognitions, emotions, and health, and the role of others in the coping process.

courses.title: Human Evolution and Behavior
courses.desc: Covers theories and empirical research concerning the evolutionary origins of human behaviors and their variations. An interdisciplinary course emphasizing both evolutionary psychology (e.g., mating strategies, kinship, and parenting) and molecular evolution (i.e., evolution of genes for various behaviors).

courses.title: Biobehavioral Aspects of Health and Illness
courses.desc: Examines the behavior-physiology interactions of some major bodily systems: the nervous, cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, and endocrine systems. Analysis of normal and abnormal states of these systems as they relate to tissue injury, disease, and rehabilitation.

courses.title: Special Topics in Psychological Science
courses.desc: Topics covered vary with interests of instructor.

courses.title: Meta Analysis
courses.desc: The process of synthesizing results from a number of studies that address a common research question is often referred to as meta-analysis. Explores the meta-analysis process from the coding of retrieved studies to the final research synthesis.

courses.title: Prosocial Behavior
courses.desc: Focuses on detailed discussions of selected topics in contemporary psychology to hone in on a set of core processes that enable prosocial action, cooperation, and helping.

courses.title: Interdisciplinary Salivary Bioscience
courses.desc: Theory and research on the integration of salivary analytes into developmental, social, behavioral, and health sciences. Topics include oral fluid as biological specimens; practical aspects of sample handing, collection, and study design; basics of laboratory methods used for assaying saliva.

courses.title: Interdisciplinary Salivary Bioscience Lab
courses.desc: Laboratory sequel to the P280A seminar. Provides laboratory-based hands-on experience integrating salivary analytes into developmental, social, behavioral, and health sciences that also includes supervised training on sample processing.

courses.title: Race and the Law
courses.desc: Explores how race and other markers of social identity shape outcomes within the criminal justice system. Students examine how race, ethnicity, and national origin intersect with rules governing the policing, trials, and punishment.

courses.title: Salivary Bioscience Data Analysis
courses.desc: A salivary bioscience statistical research working group. Students conduct guided data analyses with salivary biomarker data. Special topics related to salivary bioscience analytic strategies and the interpretation and dissemination of research findings are discussed.

courses.title: Psychoneuroimmunology
courses.desc: Introduces students to the field of psychoneuroimmunology and helps them develop the conceptual and methodological skills necessary for designing and interpreting research on the bidirectional relationship between the immune system and psychological processes.

courses.title: Health and Emotion
courses.desc: Overview of research focused on understanding how emotional processes influence physical health. Provides students with a deeper understanding of how emotions play into the health of others as well.

courses.title: Anger: A Turbulent Emotion
courses.desc: Provides an enriched perspective on anger beginning with its understanding in classical antiquity. Topics include developmental processes and trauma, anger physiology and neuroscience, anger-related physical health impairments, and the involvement of anger in psychopathology and violence.

courses.title: The Teaching of Psychology
courses.desc: Provides students with the theory and skills needed to teach undergraduate psychology courses. Covers research on theories and methods of teaching, curriculum design, and evaluation. Students also gain practical experience preparing and presenting material.

courses.title: Research in Developmental Psychology
courses.desc: Introduces graduate students to research conducted by individual faculty members in the area of developmental psychology. This is accomplished by having students involve themselves in the conceptualization, strategy, and implementation of the faculty member's research.

courses.title: Research in Health Psychology
courses.desc: Introduces graduate students to research conducted by individual faculty members in the area of health psychology. This is accomplished by having students involve themselves in the conceptualization, strategy, and implementation of the faculty member's research.

courses.title: Research in Psychopathology and Behavior Disorder
courses.desc: Introduces graduate students to research conducted by individual faculty members in the area of psychopathology and behavior disorder. This is accomplished by having students involve themselves in the conceptualization, strategy, and implementation of the faculty member's research.

courses.title: Research in Social and Personality Psychology
courses.desc: Introduces graduate students to research conducted by individual faculty members in the area of social and personality psychology. This is accomplished by having students involve themselves in the conceptualization, strategy, and implementation of the faculty member's research.

courses.title: Research Directions in Psychological Science I
courses.desc: Introduces students to the current research of faculty, graduate students, and visitors to the Department of Psychological Science. Includes examination of contemporary research issues and controversies, as well as issues related to students' development as professionals.

courses.title: Research Directions in Psychological Science II
courses.desc: Introduces students to the current research of faculty, graduate students, and visitors to the Department of Psychological Science. Includes examination of contemporary research issues and controversies, as well as issues related to students' development as professionals.

courses.title: Research Directions in Psychological Science III
courses.desc: Introduces students to the current research of faculty, graduate students, and visitors to the Department of Psychological Science. Includes examination of contemporary research issues and controversies, as well as issues related to students' development as professionals.

courses.title: Research in Psychology and Law
courses.desc: Introduces graduate students to research conducted by individual faculty members in the area of psychology and law. This is accomplished by having students involve themselves in the conceptualization, strategy, and implementation of the faculty member's research.

courses.title: Doctoral Dissertation Research and Writing
courses.desc: Dissertation research with Psychological Science faculty.

courses.title: Directed Studies in Psychological Science
courses.desc: Directed study with Psychological Science faculty.

courses.title: Independent Studies in Psychological Science
courses.desc: Independent research with Psychological Science faculty.

courses.title: Introduction to Psychology
courses.desc: Introduction to field of psychology, addressing the application of scientific methods to the study of human development, learning, memory, problem solving, perception, biological mechanisms, emotions and motivation, personality, psychopathology, and effects of diverse social and cultural contexts on human behavior.

courses.title: Psychology Fundamentals
courses.desc: Designed to provide freshman with an in-depth survey of general psychology. Topics include biological bases of behavior, sensation, perception, cognition, development, personality, psychopathology, and social psychology.

courses.title: Psychology Fundamentals
courses.desc: Designed to provide freshmen with an in-depth survey of general psychology. Topics include biological bases of behavior, sensation, perception, cognition, development, personality, psychopathology, and social psychology.

courses.title: Psychology Fundamentals
courses.desc: Designed to provide freshman with an in-depth survey of general psychology. Topics include biological bases of behavior, sensation, perception, cognition, development, personality, psychopathology, and social psychology.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics in Psychology I
courses.desc: An introduction to probability and statistics. Emphasis on thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Examples drawn primarily from psychology.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics in Psychology II
courses.desc: An introduction to probability and statistics. Emphasis on thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Examples drawn primarily from psychology.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics in Psychology III
courses.desc: An introduction to probability and statistics. Emphasis on thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Examples drawn primarily from psychology.

courses.title: Adolescent Psychology
courses.desc: Focuses on psychosocial dynamics of today's adolescents in America emphasizing the quest for identity, independence, values, and sexual orientation. The influence of society, family, school, and peers is analyzed. Strategies for helping troubled adolescents are discussed.

courses.title: Introduction to Human Memory
courses.desc: Covers the core concepts of modern research and theorizing about human memory, including structural subdivisions (e.g., perceptual memory, short-term memory, long-term memory), different measures of memory (e.g., recall, reorganization), and some practical applications of memory research (e.g., mnemonics).

courses.title: Acquisition of Language
courses.desc: What children say, what they mean, and what they understand. Theories about the learning of language by one-, two-, and three-year-olds. Comparison of kinds of data on which these theories are based.

courses.title: Self-Identity and Society
courses.desc: Studies sociological contributions to theory and research in social psychology, with focus on the social influences on personality, attitudes, beliefs, and behavior; socialization, human groups, and social interaction.

courses.title: Special Topics in Lower-Division Psychology
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of psychology at the lower-division level. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Honors Seminar in Psychology I
courses.desc: Focuses on the research activities and honors thesis research projects of each student and the research of various Cognitive Sciences faculty. Students discuss their research interests in the early and later stages of their projects. Research projects and write-ups required.

courses.title: Honors Seminar in Psychology II
courses.desc: Focuses on the research activities and honors thesis research projects of each student and the research of various Cognitive Sciences faculty. Students discuss their research interests in the early and later stages of their projects. Research projects and write-ups required.

courses.title: Honors Seminar in Psychology III
courses.desc: Focuses on the research activities and honors thesis research projects of each student and the research of various Cognitive Sciences faculty. Students discuss their research interests in the early and later stages of their projects. Research projects and write-ups required.

courses.title: Honors Advanced Experimental Psychology
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: PSYCH H111B
PSYCH H111A and (PSYC H11A or PSYCH 112A). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Design and analysis of multivalent, factorial, and correlational studies. Students prepare proposals for independent research.

courses.title: Honors Experimental Psychology
courses.prereqs: ((PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C) or (PSY BEH 11A and PSY BEH 11B and PSY BEH 11C)) and ((PSYCH 10A and 10B and 10C) or (MATH 2A and MATH 2B and (MATH 7 or STATS 7))).
courses.desc: Emphasis on design of experiments and analysis of results. Experiments are conducted in laboratory sections.

courses.title: Honors Advanced Experimental Psychology Laboratory
courses.desc: Design and analysis of multivalent, factorial, and correlational studies. Students prepare proposals for independent research.

courses.title: Honors Research in Experimental Psychology
courses.desc: Each student conducts a research project in experimental psychology. The projects are discussed in a seminar format. Written reports on each project are submitted at the end of the quarter.

courses.title: Experimental Psychology
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: PSYCH 112LA
((PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C) or (PSY BEH 11A and PSY BEH 11B and PSY BEH 11C)) and ((PSYCH 10A and PSYCH 10B and PSYCH 10C) or (MATH 2A and MATH 2B and (MATH 7 or STATS 7)) )
courses.desc: Emphasis on design of experiments and analysis of results. Experiments are conducted in laboratory sections.

courses.title: Advanced Experimental Psychology
courses.prereqs: PSYCH 112A and PSYCH 112LA. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Design and analysis of multivalent, factorial, and correlational studies. Students prepare proposals for independent research.

courses.title: Research in Experimental Psychology
courses.desc: Each student conducts a research project in experimental psychology. The projects are discussed in a seminar format. Written reports on each project are submitted at the end of the quarter.

courses.title: Effective Graphical Presentation of Data
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: PSYCH 112LD
(PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C) or (PSY BEH 11A and PSY BEH 11B and PSY BEH 11C) and (PSYCH 10C or SOC SCI 10C or ANTHRO 10C or POL SCI 10C or SOCIOL 10C) or (MATH 2B and STATS 7)
courses.desc: Learn to use MATLAB to produce graphical displays of data based on psychological principles for effective design. Approach is problem-oriented, with emphasis on case-studies using data from psychological experiments and real-world corpora. Assessment via independent individual projects.

courses.title: Experimental Psychology Laboratory
courses.desc: Required laboratory section and co-requisite for Psych 112A.

courses.title: Advanced Experimental Psychology Laboratory
courses.desc: Required laboratory section for PSYCH 112B and PSYCH 112BW.

courses.title: Research in Experimental Psychology
courses.desc: Required laboratory section and co-requisite for PSYCH 112C.

courses.title: Effective Graphical Presentation of Data Lab
courses.desc: Lab to learn to use MATLAB to produce graphical displays of data based on psychological principles for effective design. Approach is problem-oriented, with emphasis on case-studies using data from psychological experiments and real-world corpora. Assessment via independent individual projects.

courses.title: Research Methods in Psychology Laboratory
courses.desc: Required laboratory section and co-requisite for PSYCH 112M.

courses.title: Cognitive Robotics Laboratory
courses.desc: Required laboratory section and corequisite for PSYCH 112R.

courses.title: Research Methods in Psychology
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: PSYCH 112LM
(PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C) or (PSY BEH 11A and PSY BEH 11B and PSY BEH 11C) and (PSYCH 10C or SOC SCI 10C or ANTHRO 10C or POL SCI 10C or SOCIOL 10C) or (MATH 2B and STATS 7)
courses.desc: Research methods in psychology for majors who wish to fulfill this requirement separately from upper-division writing. Covers both experimental and descriptive research methods, analysis of results, and reading the psychological literature. Research experience is provided in laboratory sections.

courses.title: Cognitive Robotics
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: PSYCH 112LR
(PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C) or (PSY BEH 11A and PSY BEH 11B and PSY BEH 11C) and (PSYCH 10C or SOC SCI 10C or ANTHRO 10C or POL SCI 10C or SOCIOL 10C) or (MATH 2B and STATS 7)
courses.desc: Introduces concepts on experimental design, embodiment, robot construction, and computer programming. Concepts of embodied intelligence and case studies of cognitive robotics are covered in lecture. Simple robots are constructed and programmed to carry out different behavioral experiments in lab.

courses.title: MATLAB Programming
courses.desc: MATLAB is a mathematical software package for solving quantitative problems often encountered in experimental psychology. Topics include rudiments of programming, statistical analysis of data, matrix algebra, signal processing, graphic visualization, and simulated models of cognitive and perceptual processes.

courses.title: Special Topics in Research Methodologies
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of research methodologies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Abnormal Psychology
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9C or PSY BEH 11C)
courses.desc: Introduction to psychopathology and behavioral deviations, and the concepts of theories regarding these conditions.

courses.title: Developmental Psychology
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A)
courses.desc: A general introduction to the study of the physical, intellectual, social, and emotional development of the child from birth to adulthood.

courses.title: History of Psychology
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9C or PSY BEH 11C)
courses.desc: A history of the development of various schools and systems of psychological thought.

courses.title: Personality Theories
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9C or PSY BEH 11C)
courses.desc: A survey of the evolution of personality theory during this century. An overview of major perspectives in the field, with special attention to Freud, Jung, and Adler.

courses.title: Theories of Motivation
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) and (PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C) or (PSY BEH 11A and PSY BEH 11B and PSY BEH 11C)
courses.desc: Factors affecting the behavioral performance of organisms. A survey of theoretical and empirical approaches to the physiological, psychological, and social factors which generate behavior.

courses.title: Positive Psychology
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C) or (PSY BEH 11A and PSY BEH 11B and PSY BEH 11C)
courses.desc: Positive psychology, at the subjective level, is about valued subjective experiences; at the individual level, it is about positive individual traits; and at the group level, it is about the civic virtues and institutions that move individuals toward better citizenship.

courses.title: Psychology of Sleep and Consciousness
courses.desc: Covers the physiology, neurochemistry, and neuroanatomy associated with sleep, contemporary sleep theory, REM and NREM, phenomenology, sleep disorders, examination of differences between conscious and unconscious cognitive function, the history of sleep and dream theories from ancient time to present day.

courses.title: Clinical Psychology
courses.desc: Provides overview of the clinical psychology field including theories and techniques used in counseling and testing.

courses.title: Organizational/Industrial Psychology
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A) or (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B) or (PSYCH 9C or PSY BEH 11C)
courses.desc: Introduction to applied psychology in organizations, including personnel testing, selection, training and evaluation, job and classification analysis, job satisfaction and motivation, organizational development, leadership, market research, and consumer psychology. Potential ethical problems are discussed.

courses.title: Clinical Psychophysiology
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI N110 or PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A
courses.desc: Psychophysiology investigates the relationships between physiological processes and psychological phenomena. Technologies examined include reaction times, heart rate variability, EEGs, ERPs, magnetoencephalography, and eye tracking. Applications include diagnosis, the longitudinal assessment, and the identification of individuals at risk of disease onset.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Psychology
courses.desc: Selected topics in the philosophy of psychology, e.g., the nature of psychological explanation, reductionism, issues in cognitive, behavioral, and neuroscience.

courses.title: Sports Psychology
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9C or PSY BEH 11C)
courses.desc: Discusses the field of sports psychology with an emphasis on clinical practice including motivation, goal setting, performance skills, and mental skills. Discusses and utilizes a wide range of techniques designed to enhance performance and manage problems among athletes.

courses.title: Psychology of Violence
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9C or PSY BEH 11C)
courses.desc: Discusses the psychology of violence and aggression with an emphasis on understanding the psychological, social, and physiological roots of violent and aggressive behavior. Psychological treatment techniques and strategies for prevention of aggressive and violent behavior are also discussed.

courses.title: Special Topics in General Psychology
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of general psychology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Perception and Sensory Processes
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A)
courses.desc: A general introduction to the scientific study of sensory processes and perceptual phonomena, with special emphasis in the visual systems.

courses.title: Vision
courses.desc: Visual perception and the anatomy and physiology of the visual system. Topics include the retina and the visual pathway; visual sensitivity; color vision; spatial vision; motion perception; and the development of the visual system.

courses.title: Hearing
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A) and (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B)
courses.desc: Auditory perception, the anatomy and physiology of the auditory system, and the physics of sound. Topics include neural transduction of sound, sensitivity, sound localization, complex sound perception, and hearing loss.

courses.title: The Mind/Body Problem
courses.desc: What is consciousness and what is matter and how are the two related? How can brains have minds? This multidisciplinary course draws on information from the fields of computer vision, artificial intelligence, cognition, neurophysiology, philosophy, and psychophysics.

courses.title: Special Topics in Perception and Sensory Processes
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of perception and sensory processes. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Cognitive Science
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) and (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A) and (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B)
courses.desc: Introduction to the investigations of the structure and function of the mind, from viewpoints of computation, neuroscience, philosophy, and cognitive psychology. Topics include perception, attention, knowledge representations, learning and memory, action, reasoning, and language.

courses.title: Principles of Learning Theory
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A)
courses.desc: Investigation of the learning and memory processes of human and animals.  Basic experimental approaches to learning and memory, empirical results, and theoretical interpretations of the evidence are discussed.

courses.title: Human Memory
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B)
courses.desc: Developments in the area of memory; history of memory research; theories of the nature of memory. Visual memory, recognition memory, high-speed scanning, free recall, short-term memory, mnemonics, retrieval, relationship of memory to thinking. Selected theoretical formulations for memory.

courses.title: Jumpstart I: Early Language, Literacy, and Social Development
courses.desc: An experiential course integrated with lecture material in the field of child development and education. Students are expected to attend lectures, complete assignments, and commit eight hours per week as mentors of disadvantaged preschool children.

courses.title: Jumpstart I: Early Language, Literacy, and Social Development
courses.desc: An experiential course integrated with lecture material in the field of child development and education. Students are expected to attend lectures, complete assignments, and commit eight hours per week as mentors of disadvantaged preschool children.

courses.title: Jumpstart I: Early Language, Literacy, and Social Development
courses.desc: An experiential course integrated with lecture material in the field of child development and education. Students are expected to attend lectures, complete assignments, and commit eight hours per week as mentors of disadvantaged preschool children.

courses.title: Jumpstart II: Early Language, Literacy, and Social Development
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 141J and PSYCH 141K and PSYCH 141L) or (EDUC 141A and EDUC 141B and EDUC 141C)
courses.desc: An experiential course integrated with lecture material in the field of child development and education. Students are expected to attend lectures, complete assignments, and commit eight hours per week as mentors of disadvantaged preschool children.

courses.title: Jumpstart II: Early Language, Literacy, and Social Development
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 141J and PSYCH 141K and PSYCH 141L) or (EDUC 141A and EDUC 141B and EDUC 141C)
courses.desc: An experiential course integrated with lecture material in the field of child development and education. Students are expected to attend lectures, complete assignments, and commit eight hours per week as mentors of disadvantaged preschool children.

courses.title: Jumpstart II: Early Language, Literacy, and Social Development
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 141J and PSYCH 141K and PSYCH 141L) or (EDUC 141A and EDUC 141B and EDUC 141C)
courses.desc: An experiential course integrated with lecture material in the field of child development and education. Students are expected to attend lectures, complete assignments, and commit eight hours per week as mentors of disadvantaged preschool children.

courses.title: Jumpstart III: Early Language, Literacy, and Social Development
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 141M and PSYCH 141N and PSYCH 141O) or (EDUC 141D and EDUC 141E and EDUC 141F)
courses.desc: An experiential course integrated with lecture material in the field of child development and education. Students are expected to attend lectures, complete assignments, and commit eight hours per week as mentors of disadvantaged preschool children.

courses.title: Jumpstart III: Early Language, Literacy, and Social Development
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 141M and PSYCH 141N and PSYCH 141O) or (EDUC 141D and EDUC 141E and EDUC 141F)
courses.desc: An experiential course integrated with lecture material in the field of child development and education. Students are expected to attend lectures, complete assignments, and commit eight hours per week as mentors of disadvantaged preschool children.

courses.title: Jumpstart III: Early Language, Literacy, and Social Development
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 141M and PSYCH 141N and PSYCH 141O) or (EDUC 141D and EDUC 141E and EDUC 141F)
courses.desc: An experiential course integrated with lecture material in the field of child development and education. Students are expected to attend lectures, complete assignments, and commit eight hours per week as mentors of disadvantaged preschool children.

courses.title: Human Problem Solving
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B)
courses.desc: Modern developments in the psychology of human problem solving. Topics include concept identification, arithmetic, sets, logic puzzles, story problems, group problem solving, and theorem proving.

courses.title: Writing about Memory
courses.prereqs: PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 9 or PSY BEH 11B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Covers a broad range of texts, literary, philosophical, and scientific, each probing the nature of memory and its meaning in human life. Readings are drawn from across many disciplines and many perspectives.

courses.title: Cognitive Development Research
courses.desc: Provides experience in cognitive development research, centered around the child's acquisition of number words and concepts. Students conduct research and review and discuss each other's projects in weekly lab meetings with instructor and graduate students.

courses.title: Cognitive Development Research
courses.desc: Provides experience in cognitive development research, centered around the child's acquisition of number words and concepts. Students conduct research and review and discuss each other's projects in weekly lab meetings with instructor and graduate students.

courses.title: Cognitive Development Research
courses.desc: Provides experience in cognitive development research, centered around the child's acquisition of number words and concepts. Students conduct research and review and discuss each other's projects in weekly lab meetings with instructor and graduate students.

courses.title: Special Topics in Cognition and Learning
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of cognition and learning. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Psychology of Language
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) or (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B)
courses.desc: Examines language using the tools of experimental psychology. From sounds to words to spoken and written sentences, explores how language is used in real time, and how its use reveals how it is represented in the mind.

courses.title: Acquisition of Language II
courses.desc: Focuses on native language learning, exploring the way in which infants and very young children unconsciously uncover the rich systematic knowledge of their native language. Examines both experimental and computational studies that quantitatively investigate the "how" of language acquisition.

courses.title: Computational Methods for Language Research
courses.prereqs: PSYCH 150 or LSCI 155 or PSYCH 156A or LSCI 151
courses.desc: Focuses on computational methods useful for language research. Students become familiar with software and programming languages used for extracting information from electronic datasets and for creating basic simulations of linguistic cognition. No prior programming experience assumed.

courses.title: Special Topics in Language
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of language sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) and (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A) and (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B)
courses.desc: Introduction to the neural basis of human perceptual, motor, and cognitive abilities. Topics include sensory perception, motor control, memory, language, attention, emotion, frontal lobe function, functional brain imaging, and neuropsychological disorders.

courses.title: Brain Disorders and Behavior
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9) and (PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A) and (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B) or BIO SCI 35 or BIO SCI N110
courses.desc: Examines the localization of human brain functions and the effects of neurological disorders on psychological functions such as perception, motor control, language, memory, and decision-making.

courses.title: History of Cognitive Neuroscience
courses.prereqs: PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A or PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9
courses.desc: Studies of the human mind from ancient cultures to the innovation of modern methods of brain imaging. Logic of valid and invalid brain hypothesis are examined. Recurring theme is the competition between holistic and localized views of brain function.

courses.title: Language and the Brain
courses.prereqs: (PSYCH 7A or PSY BEH 9 or PSYCH 9A or PSY BEH 11A) and (PSYCH 9B or PSY BEH 11B or BIO SCI 35 or BIO SCI N110)
courses.desc: Research analysis on biological bases of human linguistic capacity. Development, focusing on hemispheric specialization, plasticity; localization of specific linguistic functions in adults, with emphasis on study of aphasias; relation of linguistic capacity to general cognitive capacity, considering research on retardation.

courses.title: Hearing and the Brain
courses.desc: An overview of brain mechanisms of hearing, including perception of simple sounds, speech, and music. Begins with sound itself, and looks at processing by the ear, auditory pathways, auditory cortex, and beyond. Also auditory development, learning, and clinical issues.

courses.title: Human  Neuropsychology
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI N110 or PSYCH 9A or PSCI 11A
courses.desc: A survey of human brain disorders using a clinical case study approach to illustrate fundamental issues in studying brain and behavior. Topics include sensory deficits, attentional neglect, amnesia, cortical organization, clinical psychopathology, and more.

courses.title: Visual Neuroscience Research
courses.desc: Covers a range of cognitive neuroscience research topics with emphasis on cortical organization of visual circuits, object recognition, motion perception, visual attention, and decision making.

courses.title: Visual Neuroscience Research
courses.desc: Covers a range of cognitive neuroscience research topics with emphasis on cortical organization of visual circuits, object recognition, motion perception, visual attention, and decision making.

courses.title: Visual Neuroscience Research
courses.desc: Covers a range of cognitive neuroscience research topics with emphasis on cortical organization of visual circuits, object recognition, motion perception, visual attention, and decision making.

courses.title: Special Topics in Cognitive Neuroscience
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of cognitive neuroscience. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Psychological Anthropology
courses.prereqs: ANTHRO 2A or PSYCH 7A or (PSYCH 9A and PSYCH 9B and PSYCH 9C) or (PSY BEH 11A and PSY BEH 11B and PSY BEH 11C)
courses.desc: Cultural differences and similarities in personality and behavior.  Child-rearing practices and consequent adult personality characteristics, biocultural aspects of child development and attachment, culture and behavior evolutionary models, politically linked personality, cognitive anthropology, psychology of narrative forms, comparative national character studies.

courses.title: African American Psychology
courses.desc: Historical overview of the development of black psychology and the African American frame of reference. Topics include personality development, psychological assessment, issues in education, black mental health, and the role of the African American psychologist in the community.

courses.title: Chicano/Latino Families
courses.desc: Introduction to the research, literature, and issues surrounding the topic of Chicano/Latino families including cultural history, contemporary issues, organization of family, traditions, lifestyles, values, beliefs, generational differences, gender issues, ethnic identity, evolution of demographic patterns, current economic and political standings.

courses.title: Political Psychology
courses.desc: Examination of how psychological theory and research may be used to better understand political thought and behavior. Drawing on theories of learning, cognition, and personality, discusses such topics as the formation of political attitudes, and the process of political decision-making.

courses.title: Deviance
courses.desc: Perspectives on deviance and criminality in behavior, institution, community, and myth. The suitability of contemporary theories of deviant behavior.

courses.title: Forensic Psychology: Advanced Seminar
courses.prereqs: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C) and PSCI 102C and (PSCI 178S or CRM/LAW C149)
courses.desc: Focuses on the psychology of criminal offending, particularly violent behavior. Examines violence, sexual offending, and mental disorder related to crime with regard to clinical assessment and treatment; mental health services within forensic institutions.

courses.title: Social Psychology of Networks
courses.desc: Review of network methods used in small group and organizational research. Discussion of social psychological literature relevant to the network of study of cognitive social structure, exchange/communication, identity negotiation, and social control. Case study of network datasets exemplifies research issues.

courses.title: Special Topics in Interdisciplinary Studies
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of interdisciplinary studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Directed Group Study
courses.desc: Directed study with Cognitive Sciences faculty.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Independent research with Cognitive Sciences faculty.

courses.title: Cognitive Sciences Research Seminar
courses.desc: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors.

courses.title: Cognitive Sciences Research Seminar
courses.desc: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors.

courses.title: Cognitive Sciences Research Seminar
courses.desc: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors.

courses.title: Proseminar in the Cognitive Sciences
courses.desc: Introduction to the conceptual foundations and basic research results in the cognitive sciences for first-year graduate students.

courses.title: Discrete Mathematics and Probability
courses.desc: Logic and set theory are covered during the first three weeks, using an interactive computer system. The remaining seven weeks are devoted to probability theory and cover elementary concepts from samples spaces to Chebychev's Inequality and the moment generating function.

courses.title: Algorithmic Statistics
courses.desc: Discussion of the fundamentals of statistical inference and computational implementations of common statistical models.

courses.title: Applied Mathematics for Cognitive Sciences Research
courses.desc: Covers the basics of linear systems analysis, focusing on linear algebra, Fourier analysis, differential equations, and elementary signal processing. Applications in Cognitive Science and Cognitive Neuroscience research will be developed.

courses.title: Computational and Research Methods with MATLAB
courses.desc: Introduces rudiments of programming, statistical analysis and probability theory, graphic visualization, GUI design, spectral analysis, and simulation models using MATLAB, a software package for solving quantitative problems often encountered in experimental psychology.

courses.title: Running Experiments Using MATLAB
courses.desc: Provides an in-depth introduction to writing MATLAB programs to run auditory and visual experiments. Topics covered include program structure, stimulus generation, presentation, and data collection.

courses.title: Computational Statistics
courses.desc: Introduction to a number of computational statistics approaches including exploratory data analysis and modeling using a probabilistic framework with Bayesian graphical models. Emphasis will be on in-class programming using MATLAB.

courses.title: Introduction to Cognitive and Brain Sciences I: Perception
courses.desc: Discusses models of cognition and evidence linking cognition and the brain. Focus is on visual, auditory, and somatic perception and bottom-up mechanisms of attention.

courses.title: Introduction to Cognitive and Brain Sciences II: Cognition
courses.desc: Discusses models of cognition and evidence linking cognition and the brain. Focus is on emotion, top-down attention, goal-directed behavior, categorization, judgment, and decision-making.

courses.title: Introduction to Cognitive and Brain Sciences III: Learning and Development
courses.desc: Discusses experimental data, formal models of learning, and evidence linking learning and development to its neural substrates. Topics include Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning, language acquisition, causal reasoning, perceptual learning, category formation, and structure learning.

courses.title: The Mind/Body Problem
courses.desc: Course is multidisciplinary, drawing on information from the fields of quantum physics, computer vision, artificial intelligence, cognition, neurophysiology, philosophy, and psychophysics.

courses.title: Bayesian Cognitive Modeling
courses.desc: Considers a range of statistical methods of data analysis and simple cognitive models using the Bayesian graphical modeling framework.

courses.title: Hearing
courses.desc: Examines auditory sensation and perception using psychophysical and neuroscientific perspectives. Covers physical aspects of sound; subcortical auditory processing; aspects of sensation and perception such as sensitivity, sound localization, and complex-sound recognition; neuroscientific studies of cortical function; and abnormal auditory processing.

courses.title: Cognitive Development Research
