courses.desc: Provides experience in cognitive development research, centered around the child's acquisition of number words and concepts. Students conduct research and review and discuss each other's projects in weekly lab meetings with instructor and graduate students.

courses.title: Cognitive Development Research
courses.desc: Provides experience in cognitive development research, centered around the child's acquisition of number words and concepts. Students conduct research and review and discuss each other's projects in weekly lab meetings with instructor and graduate students.

courses.title: Cognitive Development Research
courses.desc: Provides experience in cognitive development research, centered around the child's acquisition of number words and concepts. Students conduct research and review and discuss each other's projects in weekly lab meetings with instructor and graduate students.

courses.title: Special Topics in Human Cognition
courses.desc: Current research in brain/ behavior relationships, human memory, and learning theory is presented.

courses.title: Topics in Philosophy of Psychology
courses.desc: Selected topics in the philosophy of psychology, e.g., the nature of psychological explanation, reductionism, issues in cognitive, behavioral, and neuroscience.

courses.title: Mathematical Models of Cognitive Processes I
courses.desc: Mathematical models of various cognitive processes developed since 1960, including learning, memory, perception, psycholinguistics, and problem solving. Models are formulated in different mathematical languages: calculus, algebra, logic, probability, and computer. Difficulties in testing and validating models discussed.

courses.title: Advanced Bayesian Cognitive Modeling
courses.desc: Considers a range of advanced cognitive process models including models of signal detection, memory retention, category learning, stimulus representation, and reasoning using the Bayesian graphical modeling framework.

courses.title: Special Topics in Methodology and Models
courses.desc: Current research in cognitive sciences methodologies, concepts, and models is presented.

courses.title: Computational Models of Language Learning
courses.desc: Focuses on computational models of native language learning, exploring how probabilistic learning and inference fare on difficult case studies within language acquisition. In all cases, grounds the learning models in available empirical data and considers their psychological plausibility.

courses.title: Special Topics in Language Science
courses.desc: Foundations and current research in theoretical, experimental, and computational linguistics.

courses.title: Human Information Processing
courses.desc: Detailed introduction to speed-accuracy tradeoff experimental procedures; speed-accuracy tradeoff issues; quantitative modeling of temporal aspects of human information processing.

courses.title: Special Topics in Human Performance
courses.desc: Current research in the human issues involved with sensation, perception, and cognition.

courses.title: Cortical Neuroscience
courses.desc: Physiology of the cerebral cortex, theoretical neuroscience, and the neural basis of perception.

courses.title: Functional Neuroanatomy
courses.desc: It is impossible to truly understand human behavior without some understanding of the physical structure that enables behavior. Examines recent findings in functional neuroantomy through lectures and papers discussing links between particular behaviors and specific brain structures.

courses.title: Visual Neuroscience Research
courses.desc: Covers a range of cognitive neuroscience research topics with emphasis on cortical organization of visual circuits, object recognition, motion perception, visual attention, and decision making.

courses.title: Visual Neuroscience Research
courses.desc: Covers a range of cognitive neuroscience research topics with emphasis on cortical organization of visual circuits, object recognition, motion perception, visual attention, and decision making.

courses.title: Visual Neuroscience Research
courses.desc: Covers a range of cognitive neuroscience research topics with emphasis on cortical organization of visual circuits, object recognition, motion perception, visual attention, and decision making.

courses.title: Introduction to Functional MRI
courses.desc: Describes the fundamentals of imaging the human brain function using functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI). Topics include basic fMRI physics, experimental design, and data acquisition and analysis.

courses.title: Cognitive Neuroscience of Music
courses.desc: Introduction to cortical mechanisms involved in music perception and production.

courses.title: Computational Neuroscience
courses.prereqs: PSYCH 205A and (PSYCH 210A or PSYCH 210B or PSYCH 210C)
courses.desc: Introduction to computational neuroscience. Mathematical models of single neurons, neural circuits, thalamocortical systems, and cortical mass action can stimulate single-unit, local field potential, and EEG dynamics. These models are used to investigate mechanisms of sensation, motor control, attention, and consciousness.

courses.title: Cognitive Robotics
courses.desc: Introduces concepts for studying cognitive function by embedding brain models on robotic platforms. Topics include robot construction, computer programming, and the notion of embodiment. Students construct simple robots and program these robots to perform different behaviors.

courses.title: Special Topics in Cognitive Neuroscience
courses.desc: Current research in cognitive neuroscience.

courses.title: Special Topics in Sensation and Perception
courses.desc: Current research in the reception and processing of visual and auditory stimuli presented.

courses.title: Dissertation Research
courses.desc: Dissertation research with Cognitive Science faculty.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.desc: Individual research with Cognitive Science faculty.

courses.title: Principles of Public Health
courses.desc: Introduces the major concepts and principles of public health and the determinants of health status in communities. Emphasizes the ecological model that focuses on the linkages and relationships among multiple natural and social determinants affecting health.

courses.title: Case Studies in Public Health Practice
courses.desc: Presents case studies in various themes of public health practice to demonstrate how the principles of public health were established and continue to evolve.

courses.title: Public Health Statistics I
courses.desc: Introduces the development and application of statistical reasoning and methods in addressing, analyzing, and solving problems in public health, health care, and biomedical, clinical, and population-based research and practice.

courses.title: Public Health Statistics II
courses.desc: Introduces the development and application of statistical reasoning and methods in addressing, analyzing, and solving problems in public health, health care, and biomedical, clinical, and population-based research and practice.

courses.title: Special Topics in Public Health
courses.desc: Introduction to emerging topics in public health. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Introduction to Urban Environmental Health
courses.desc: Study of natural and physical components of earth's environmental problems due to human activities. Topics include global air, water, soil, biodiversity, rainforests, energy, demographics, agriculture, and urbanization. Theme is sustainability. Integrated into the science are social, legal, and economic considerations.

courses.title: Environmental Quality and Health
courses.desc: Overviews how pollution in the environment affects human health. Topics are toxicology, epidemiology, risk assessment, water, food, air, radiation, pesticides, solid and hazardous waste. Included are interdisciplinary elements of environmental regulations, education, and consumer protection.

courses.title: AIDS Fundamentals
courses.desc: Considers the biological and sociological bases of the AIDS epidemic. Topics include the history of AIDS, current medical knowledge, transmission, risk reduction, and how the community can respond.

courses.title: Natural Disasters
courses.desc: Natural disasters are natural Earth processes that adversely affect humans. Topics include tectonics, earthquakes, tsunami, volcanoes, landslides, severe weather, flooding, coastal processes, wildfire, related topics, and use of GIS for hazard and risk assessment.

courses.title: Disparities in Health Care
courses.desc: Student participatory course practicing initiation, planning, and coordination of various speakers on the subject of Disparities in Health Care.

courses.title: Special Topics in Public Health
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of public health. Topics addressed vary each quarter. Course may be offered online when topic is Public Health in the Corporate World.

courses.title: Introduction to Epidemiology
courses.desc: The distribution of disease and injury across time, space, and populations. Covers basic concepts and methods of descriptive epidemiology including the natural history of disease, data, and indices of health.

courses.title: Social Epidemiology
courses.prereqs: (PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C) and SOCECOL 10 and SOCECOL 13
courses.desc: Overviews evidence linking environmental factors to mental and physical disorders including such variables as socioeconomic status, income inequality, work stress, job loss, social capital, location, and other demographic characteristics. Measurement and research design issues of both individual and aggregate levels.

courses.title: Introduction to Medical Informatics
courses.desc: Broad overview of medical informatics for students with varied backgrounds. Electronic medical records, online resources, mobile technologies, patient safety, and computational design. Legal, ethical, and public policy issues. Health systems management. Evaluation and fieldwork for health systems.

courses.title: Project in Health Informatics
courses.desc: Students undertake significant quarter-long projects related to health informatics. Topics may include field evaluations of health care technologies, prototypes, iterative design, and system implementations.

courses.title: Epidemiology of Drug Use and Misuse
courses.desc: Applies epidemiologic concepts to the use and misuse of licit/illicit substances. Emphasizes descriptive aspects of drug use and determinants of progressing from experimental use to misuse. Assesses subgroups of abusers, risk factors, trends, and surveillance techniques for estimating drug prevalence.

courses.title: Community, Social Justice, and Health Equity Research for Action
courses.prereqs: PUBHLTH 1 or PUBHLTH 2 or CHC/LAT 61 or CHC/LAT 62 or CHC/LAT 63
courses.desc: Focuses on community as a unit of identity, community, well-being, and social justice perspectives and initiatives to promote community health. Addresses community change and improvements in community well-being, with a focus on health equity research for action.

courses.title: Special Topics in Epidemiology and Genetics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of epidemiology and genetics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Nutrition and Global Health
courses.desc: Global issues related to nutrition and public health. Evaluation of nutritional risk factors associated with the development of chronic diseases and the role of nutritional medicine in prevention. Topics include food safety, communicable diseases, supplements, and regulatory issues.

courses.title: Introduction to Complementary and Alternative Medicine
courses.desc: Examines health and disease in contemporary American culture/society with definitions, models, and practices of what has come to be known as "orthodox" or "conventional" medicine. Selected "alternative" or "complementary" modes of promoting health and well-being including homeopathy, herbology, and chiropractic.

courses.title: Health Policy
courses.desc: Considers social and economic aspects of health and disease in the United States.  What are the proper roles of the individual, community, and government in improving health and health care?  International comparisons will be made wherever possible.

courses.title: Foundations of Community Health
courses.desc: A social ecological framework for understanding community health is presented. Measures of individual and community health are compared, and the influence of personal and environmental factors on individual, group, and population health is examined. Community health promotion strategies are discussed.

courses.title: Public Health Law: Fundamentals in Action
courses.desc: Addresses the relationship of U.S. public health law to health systems at the individual and population levels. Examines legislative and judicial concepts and how they are applied to disease prevention strategies, health services, management, and policy.

courses.title: Public Health Programs for the Corporate World
courses.desc: International perspective on workplace health promotion. Strategies for developing programs to improve employee health and to decrease risks of chronic degenerative diseases. Case studies include assessment of employee health, program design, implementation, and evaluation. Emphasis on disease prevention.

courses.title: Public Health Administration
courses.desc: Examines historical aspects of public health administration including policies, procedures, trends, and development of organizations. Addresses information and skills necessary to succeed in public health leadership roles. Discusses strategic planning, collaborations, and ethical considerations for successful management in public health.

courses.title: American Public Policy
courses.desc: Focuses on the development and implementation of public policy in the United States. Lectures cover theoretical models of the policy process as well as significant problems facing contemporary American decision-makers.

courses.title: Medical Sociology
courses.desc: Current problems in U.S. health-care system and proposals for reform. Examines  financial barriers to access; problem of patient dumping; underinsurance; prenatal and perinatal care; child services; preventative care and needs of the elderly; minorities; low-income people; undocumented.

courses.title: Tobacco Control Policy
courses.desc: Examines the challenges that governments encounter in regulating the marketing, sales and acquisition, and use of tobacco products. Students assess the supply and demand for tobacco from the perspectives of the industry and consumer.

courses.title: Special Topics in Health Policy and Administration
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of health policy and administration. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Clinical Health Psychology
courses.prereqs: PSCI 9 or PSCI 11C or PSYCH 7A or PSYCH 9C
courses.desc: Behavioral role in etiology, treatment, and prevention of certain diseases. Behavioral intervention including biofeedback, stress-, pain-management, health habit counseling, and other skills to assist patients make cognitive, emotional, and behavioral changes needed to cope with disease or achieve better health.

courses.title: Health Behavior Theory
courses.desc: Introduces theoretical perspectives from the social sciences to understand health behavior from the vantage point of individuals, their interpersonal contacts, communities, and ecological contexts. Application of theory to public health problems is a central focus.

courses.title: Health Promotion Programs
courses.desc: Examines ecological perspectives of health promotion programs and risk factors related to mortality/morbidity.  Analyzes effectiveness of health promotion strategies and issues in the existing healthcare systems in light of sociocultural beliefs and economical/political conditions.

courses.title: Drug Abuse and Its Prevention
courses.desc: Theoretical and practical underpinnings of drug abuse and its prevention at the individual and population levels. Students practice developing drug abuse prevention schemes for specific populations. Recent developments in pharmacological and biobehavioral theories of drug dependence are explored.

courses.title: Public Health Communication
courses.desc: Theoretical underpinnings and practical applications of communication sciences in public health practice. Techniques of effective communication, including fear appeal and deterrence; social marketing; public-private partnerships; health service delivery; and outreach in rural and urban settings, and for international health strategies.

courses.title: Public Health and Wellness
courses.desc: Presents information about wellness from both science and policy perspectives in order to demonstrate the role of wellness in public health. Emphasizes the conditions that create wellness in the individual, the community, the nation, and the world.

courses.title: Environmental Psychology
courses.desc: Impact of the physical environment on individual and group behaviour. Three basic concerns examined: (a) environmental determinants of behaviour at the individual and interpersonal level; (b) social planning and urban design; (c) methodological approaches to the study of environmental issues.

courses.title: Special Topics in Social and Behavioral Health Science
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of social and behavioral health sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Environmental Geology
courses.desc: Introduction to geologic principles and applications to environmental problems. Topics include: tectonic processes, earth materials, soils, river processes, groundwater, the coastal environment, slope failures, seismic hazards, mineral resources, and land-use evaluation based on geologic conditions. Examples from case studies.

courses.title: Introduction to Environmental Health Science
courses.desc: Focuses on processes of exposure to environmental toxins/agents and their impact to human health and the environment. Media transport, exposure assessment, susceptibility, behavior, and health effect of several toxins are discussed.

courses.title: Air Pollution, Climate, and Health
courses.desc: Introduction to how air pollutants are emitted into the atmosphere, how people are most exposed to air pollutants in developed and developing areas, physical and meteorological processes that affect transport, and the influence of air pollutants on global warming.

courses.title: Nuclear Environments
courses.desc: Understanding the impact of the nuclear age on the environment and human health through interrelated developments of nuclear power and nuclear weapons. The early years of weapon development, catastrophic environmental pollution, perils of nuclear power in the U.S. and Russia.

courses.title: Introduction to Global Health
courses.desc: Provides a foundational interdisciplinary understanding of global health issues and their importance to various societal goals, including poverty reduction, economic productivity, and peace promotion. Covers major communicable and non-communicable diseases and demographic patterns of disease burden.

courses.title: Human Exposure to Environmental Contaminants
courses.desc: Introduces origins of human's realization that chemicals in the environment may adversely affect health. Introduces the theory and principles of exposure assessment. Covers estimation of exposure, variability of measures, the way exposure assessment is incorporated into the risk-assessment paradigm.

courses.title: Climate Change and Disaster Management
courses.desc: Examines the social, economic, environmental, and health impacts of anthropogenic climate change through engaged learning that integrates practice and theory.

courses.title: Health and Global Environmental Change
courses.prereqs: One upper-division course in environmental science, public health, environmental policy, and/or environmental management.
courses.desc: Overview of scientific underpinnings of global environmental change and human health consequences. Provides  an understanding of the fundamental dependency of human health on global environmental integrity. Encourages disciplinary cross-fertilization through interaction of students in environmental, health, and policy sciences.

courses.title: Global Health Ethics
courses.desc: Provides a foundation for understanding and application of key issues.

courses.title: War and Public Health
courses.desc: Explores how war impacts public health both globally and domestically in the United States. Focus on the link between war and the burden that it ultimately places on physical, mental, environmental, and societal health as well as on health systems.

courses.title: Special Topics in Environmental and Global Health Science
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of environmental and global health sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Epidemiology of Infectious Disease
courses.desc: Examines the distribution of infectious disease and the health and disease risk among human populations. Introduces basic methods for infectious disease epidemiology. Case studies of important diseases, including HIV and malaria, are conducted.

courses.title: Special Topics in Infectious Diseases
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of infectious diseases. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Geographic Information Systems for Public Health
courses.desc: Provides a broad introduction to the use of Geographic Information Systems software to carry out projects for visualizing and analyzing spatial data to address significant issues of health care and policy-planning.

courses.title: Seminar: Advances and Challenges in Public Health
courses.desc: Forum for exploring recent advances and challenges in all disciplines of public health research and practice. Features case studies exemplifying the integration of core competencies with cross-cutting interdisciplinary themes of public health.

courses.title: Seminar: Advances and Challenges in Public Health
courses.desc: Forum for exploring recent advances and challenges in all disciplines of public health research and practice. Features case studies exemplifying the integration of core competencies with cross-cutting interdisciplinary themes of public health.

courses.title: Seminar: Advances and Challenges in Public Health
courses.desc: Forum for exploring recent advances and challenges in all disciplines of public health research and practice. Features case studies exemplifying the integration of core competencies with cross-cutting interdisciplinary themes of public health.

courses.title: Public Health Honors Seminar and Thesis I
courses.desc: Provides an opportunity for selected students to pursue advanced work in research and earn Public Health Honors. Students will conduct their honors research project with faculty through lectures, guest speakers, creating timelines and assignments.

courses.title: Public Health Honors Seminar and Thesis II
courses.desc: Students initiate and complete data collection for the honors thesis. In addition, students begin data analysis and summarize results at a class symposium at the end of the quarter. A faculty mentor provides supervision and feedback on thesis chapters.

courses.title: Public Health Honors Seminar and Thesis III
courses.desc: Students write their honors research project (PUBHLTH H192A-PUBHLTH H192B) and prepare an oral report to be presented at a class symposium at the end of the quarter. A faculty mentor provides supervision and feedback on thesis chapters.

courses.title: Ethics and Responsible Conduct of Research in Public Health
courses.desc: Issues of scientific integrity and satisfies the requirements for training in public health ethics. Includes guidelines for responsible conduct of research, federal and international codes, administrative review and approval, conflict of interest, and privacy and safety of research participants.  Course may be offered online.

courses.title: Clinical and Translational Research Preparatory I
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 99 and BIO SCI 194S and CHEM 1C and CHEM 1LC and CHEM 1LD. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Provides training for students with an interest in clinical and translational research in the health care setting. Cultivates skills for study design, research literature review, ethics, responsible conduct of research, and cultural competence while emphasizing professionalism and personal responsibility.

courses.title: Clinical and Translational Research Preparatory II
courses.prereqs: PUBHLTH 194A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Provides opportunities for students to participate in clinical and translational research through rotations in at least two health care settings. Builds on preparation through the first course (194A) in the sequence to support exploration of various research topics.

courses.title: Clinical and Translational Research Preparatory III
courses.prereqs: PUBHLTH 194B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Provides opportunities for students to work closely in a particular clinical and translational research setting. Builds on preparation through the didactic instruction presented in first course of the sequence (194A) to support deeper engagement on a particular research topic.

courses.title: Clinical and Translational Research Preparatory IV
courses.desc: Provides opportunities for students to participate in clinical and translational research through placement in a research laboratory. This course is a continuation of 194C in which students have the opportunity to participate in a permanent research rotation.

courses.title: Public Health Practicum and Culminating Experience
courses.prereqs: PUBHLTH 1 and PUBHLTH 2. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Provides direct opportunities for Public Health majors to observe and participate in public health activities and/or research; and to cultivate skills for verbal and written communication of contemporary public health topics for an integrative culminating experience.

courses.title: Clinical and Translational Research Preparatory I - Community-Based Research and Evaluation
courses.desc: Provides training for students with an interest in clinical and translational research in a community-based setting. Cultivates skills for study design, research literature review, ethics, responsible conduct of research, and cultural competence while emphasizing professionalism and personal responsibility.

courses.title: Clinical and Translational Research Preparatory II - Community-Based Research and Evaluation
courses.desc: Provides the unique opportunity for students to participate in research in two or more community-based settings. Builds on preparation through PUBHLTH 196A to support exploration of various research topics.

courses.title: Clinical and Translational Research Preparatory III - Community-Based Research and Evaluation III
courses.desc: Final course in the 196 series where students have the unique opportunity to participate in permanent research rotation. Instructs students how to design, perform, interpret, and discuss independent research in a collaborative atmosphere.

courses.title: Field Studies in Public Health
courses.desc: For students who may either accompany faculty members on field trips or engage in post-practicum work at a field agency.

courses.title: Directed Studies
courses.desc: Student participation in a series of research-related activities performed in an individual or small-group setting under the guidance of a faculty advisor.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.desc: Original research with Public Health faculty. Attendance at regular research group meetings is also generally expected, and a quarterly written report is required. Strongly recommended for students considering research careers and/or graduate degree programs.

courses.title: Foundations of Public Health
courses.desc: Presents the overarching framework, principles, and core responsibilities of public health research and practice from a multidisciplinary perspective. Provides necessary foundation for further studies toward advanced cross-cutting approaches essential for public health practice.

courses.title: Biostatistics I: Introduction to Statistical Methods
courses.desc: Designed to help students develop an appreciation for statistician's view of the research process, emphasizing biomedical research. Instills an understanding of how statistical models are used to yield insights about data that form evidence-based understanding of the world around us.

courses.title: Principles of Epidemiology
courses.desc: Fundamental principles of epidemiology, biostatistics, and epidemiological research. Topics include research methods of measuring health problems in populations, disease control and prevention in populations, how epidemiology contributes to knowledge of disease etiology, and biostatistical analysis and interpretation of epidemiologic data.

courses.title: Intermediate Epidemiology
courses.prereqs: PUBHLTH 206A. PUBHLTH 206A with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Learn to design and conduct epidemiologic studies using common designs. Determine why bias and measurement error arise in observational studies, and how they influence effect estimates. Perform and interpret epidemiologic data analyses using statistical software.

courses.title: Advanced Epidemiologic Methods
courses.prereqs: EPIDEM 200A and EPIDEM 200B. EPIDEM 200A with a grade of B or better. EPIDEM 200B with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Advanced topics in the design and statistical analysis of epidemiologic studies. Topics include simulation methods, counter-matching and multiphase study designs, missing data, and Bayesian analysis. Published simulation studies are discussed and replicated using the R software package.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics in Public Health
courses.prereqs: PUBHLTH 206A. PUBHLTH 206A with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: An introduction to probability and statistical methods, using examples in public health. Topics include descriptive statistics, laws of probability, discrete and continuous probability distributions, estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, and power calculations for one- and two-sample comparisons.

courses.title: Analysis of Public Health Data Using Statistical Software
courses.prereqs: PUBHLTH 207A. PUBHLTH 207A with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Overview of common statistical methods in public health and how to implement them in R. Topics include linear regression, ANOVA, the Kruskal-Wallis test, logistic regression, missing data and censoring, Kaplan-Meier survival curves, log-rank tests, and Cox regression.

courses.title: Advances in Social Epidemiology
courses.desc: Advances understanding of social distribution and social determinants of disease through multiple risk factor models and mechanisms that emphasize developmental and socio-environmental risk factors on mental and physical health across the life span.

courses.title: Methods of Demographic Analysis
courses.desc: Introduces basic demographic methods used in social science and public health research. Topics include sources and limitations of demographic data; components of population growth; measures of nuptiality, fertility, mortality, and population mobility projection methods; and demographic models.

courses.title: Epidemiology in Global Health
courses.desc: Examines major topics in epidemiology and global health. Research topics within these two disciplines are focused on resource-poor communities, with an application to the global world.

courses.title: Surveillance Systems
courses.desc: Surveillance as a fundamental element of the practice of public health is examined in terms of the application and evaluation of monitoring systems. Topics include surveillance of infectious and chronic diseases, environmental constituents, and other indicators of population health.

courses.title: Special Topics in Biostatistics, Epidemiology, and Health Informatics
courses.desc: Current research in biostatistics, epidemiology, and health informatics. Topics vary from quarter to quarter.

courses.title: Health Policy and Management
courses.desc: Multidisciplinary inquiry into theory and practice concerned with delivery, quantity, costs of health care for individuals and populations. Explores managerial and policy concerns regarding structure, process, outcomes of health services including the costs, financing, organization, outcomes, and accessibility of care.

courses.title: Risk Communication
courses.desc: Examines theory and research related to the communication of scientific information in risk communication contexts, risk perceptions, and behavior as related to decision-making under risk.

courses.title: Special Topics in Health Policy and Management
courses.desc: Current research in health policy and management. Topics vary from quarter to quarter.

courses.title: Environmental Policy and Global Sustainability
courses.desc: Organized around four transcendent questions: does the world value sustainability, what challenges must be met to move toward it, what are the roots of inequality, and is capitalism compatible with sustainability.

courses.title: Theories of Health Communication
courses.desc: Explores the concepts, constructs, and theories of communication in health and risk contexts. Examines interpersonal, family, organizational, and mediated communicative processes about health care and conditions from a global perspective.

courses.title: Health Behavior Theory
courses.desc: Introduces the field of Health Behavior and segues into major theoretical perspectives. Focus on health behavior change from the vantage point of individual health behavior and theoretical abstraction. Explores how to relate theory to behavior-change intervention programs.

courses.title: Health Promotion Planning
courses.desc: Introduces strategic planning integral to intervention planning in public health practice and research, emphasizing the fundamental domains of social and behavioral health science and practices. Students develop an intervention plan for a specific health problem, health behavior, and target population.

courses.title: Social Research Methods
courses.desc: An interactive graduate seminar covering topics related to the research process and study design. Begins with conceptualizing research questions, hypotheses, and then turns to topics in measurement and concludes with experimental, quasi-experimental, and observational study designs.

courses.title: Program Evaluation
courses.desc: Introduces methods, tools, and procedures for systematic investigation of the effectiveness of programs in health and social services for disease intervention, prevention, and health promotion. Includes development of program evaluation plans, logic models, contextual frameworks, study designs, and data analyses.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Maternal and Child Health - Programs, Problems, and Policy
courses.desc: Overview of issues facing women, children, and families from a public health perspective.  Discusses role of socio-economic, political, biological, environmental factors on population health. Studies historical foundations and current factors impacting Maternal Child Health programs and legislation in the US.

courses.title: Health Status and Care Disparities
courses.desc: Expert health care providers present viewpoints and interdisciplinary strategies for addressing sociocultural, economic, gender, age, and other disparities in population health status and care provision.

courses.title: Special Topics in Social and Behavioral Health Sciences
courses.desc: Current research in Social and Behavioral Health Sciences. Topics vary from quarter to quarter.

courses.title: Human Exposure Modeling
courses.desc: Explores the basic principles and methods in estimating human exposure to environmental pollutants. Topics include source emissions, spatial/temporal aspects of human exposures, air pollution exposure modeling, time-activity patterns, micro-environmental exposure assessment, the uncertainty/variability analysis.

courses.title: Introduction to Environmental Health Science
courses.desc: Convergence of agents (chemical, physical, biological, or psychosocial) in environment can emerge as diseases influenced by social, political, and economic factors, allowing them to become rooted in society. How these agents from various spheres come together and impact human health.

courses.title: Advanced Environmental Health Science
courses.desc: Explores the complex relationships among exposure processes and adverse health effects of environmental toxins focusing on specific chemicals, sources, transport media, exposure pathways, and human behaviors. Techniques of environmental sampling for exposure assessment are discussed.

courses.title: Air Pollution, Climate, and Health
courses.desc: Emission of air pollutants into the atmosphere, physical and meteorological processes that affect transport, and influence on global warming. Concepts of how and where people are most exposed, and how exposures and health effects differ in developed and developing regions.

courses.title: Human Exposure to Environmental Contaminants
courses.desc: Introduces founders of conceptual thought that environmental contaminants can impact health. Theory and principles of exposure assessment, the continuum from emissions of a contaminant into the environment to evidence of health effects in a population.

courses.title: Environmental Modeling and Risk Management
courses.desc: Surveys the general principles, basic mathematical methods, and practices of environmental modeling and human health risk assessment. Topics include advection-dispersion models, risk management, and risk perception. Students conduct an original risk assessment as a final group project.

courses.title: Target Organ Toxicology I
courses.desc: Mechanistic analysis of responses occurring in various organ systems of experimental animals and humans exposed to environmental and occupational chemicals and radiation. Review distinctive cellular and tissue structure and physiological function of the various organ systems.

courses.title: Target Organ Toxicology II
courses.desc: Mechanistic analysis of responses occurring in various organ systems of experimental animals and humans exposed to environmental and occupational chemicals and radiation. Review of distinctive cellular and tissue structure and physiological function of the various organ systems.

courses.title: Industrial Toxicology
courses.desc: Analysis of responsibilities toxicologists have in industry, including product safety, generating material safety, data sheets, animal testing, ecotoxicological testing, risk/hazard communication, and assisting industrial hygienists and occupational physicians; emphasis on interdisciplinary nature of industrial toxicology and communication skills.

courses.title: Special Topics in Environmental & Occupational Health
courses.desc: Current research in environmental and occupational health. Topics vary from quarter to quarter.

courses.title: Global Burden of Disease
courses.desc: Introduces composite measures of disease burden, including Disability Adjusted Life Years and their use in prioritizing disease burden at local, regional, and global levels. Focuses on WHO's landmark assessments and introduces DISMOD software for specific analyses.

courses.title: Infectious Disease Epidemiology
courses.desc: Geographical distribution of infectious diseases and the health and disease risk in diverse human populations. Introduces basic methods for infectious disease epidemiology and case studies of important diseases. Includes surveillance, outbreak investigation, emerging pathogens, traditional and molecular epidemiology.

courses.title: Geographic Information Systems for Public Health
courses.desc: Provides a broad introduction to the use of Geographic Information Systems software to carry out projects for visualizing and analyzing spatial data to address significant issues of health care and policy-planning.

courses.title: Graduate Field Studies
courses.desc: Field studies with Public Health faculty.

courses.title: Advanced Geographic Information Systems and Spatial Epidemiology
courses.desc: Students expand their current knowledge of the ArcGIS software to develop advanced geographic-related research questions, learn how to apply spatial epidemiologic methods to public health data, and integrate their skills in a GIS project of their design.

courses.title: Qualitative Research Methods in Public Health
courses.desc: General introduction to qualitative research methods for investigating public health questions at various scales from community level to global populations. Emphasizes systematic approaches to the collection, analysis, interpretation of qualitative data.

courses.title: Research Proposal Writing in Global Health
courses.desc: Overview of financial support for research in global health and disease prevention. Collaborative agreements, guidelines for proposal writing, team building, budgeting, peer-review process, and transitioning from proposal to research project implementation.

courses.title: Special Topics in Global Health and Disease Prevention
courses.desc: Current research in global health and disease prevention. Topics vary from quarter to quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Public Health
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of public health. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Seminar: Advances and Challenges in Public Health
courses.desc: Forum for exploring recent advances and challenges in all disciplines of public health research and practice.  Features case studies exemplifying the integration of core competencies with cross-cutting interdisciplinary themes of public health.

courses.title: Seminar: Advances and Challenges in Public Health
courses.desc: Forum for exploring recent advances and challenges in all disciplines of public health research and practice.  Features case studies exemplifying the integration of core competencies with cross-cutting interdisciplinary themes of public health.

courses.title: Seminar: Advances and Challenges in Public Health
courses.desc: Forum for exploring recent advances and challenges in all disciplines of public health research and practice.  Features case studies exemplifying the integration of core competencies with cross-cutting interdisciplinary themes of public health.

courses.title: Ethics and Responsible Conduct of Research in Public Health
courses.desc: Issues of scientific integrity and satisfies the requirements for training in public health ethics. Includes guidelines for responsible conduct of research, federal and international codes, administrative review and approval, conflict of interest, and privacy and safety of research participants.

courses.title: Foundations of Clinical and Translational Science
courses.desc: Introduces rationale and imperative for clinical translational science and various approaches being developed to speed-up discoveries and their transformation into health care practices. Compares and contrasts current impediments to clinical research with the potential and transformative power of translational science.

courses.title: Research Communication in Public Health
courses.desc: Strategies for effective writing and oral presentation of research characteristics and results to various audiences. Includes exercises in writing for the public, for scholarly journals, and at conferences.

courses.title: Graduate Practicum and Culminating Experience in Public Health
courses.prereqs: PUBHLTH 200 and PUBHLTH 244 and PUBHLTH 222 and PUBHLTH 264 and PUBHLTH 207A. PUBHLTH 200 with a grade of B or better. PUBHLTH 244 with a grade of B or better. PUBHLTH 222 with a grade of B or better. PUBHLTH 264 with a grade of B or better. PUBHLTH 207A with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Provides opportunities for hands-on experience for graduate students at agencies or organizations engaged in public health practice. Students are matched with placement sites based on academic preparation and students' career goals. The practicum report is integrated into the culminating experience.

courses.title: Doctoral Dissertation Research and Writing
courses.desc: Dissertation research with Public Health faculty.

courses.title: Research Design and Proposal Writing
courses.desc: Evaluate strengths of research findings based on methods used by researchers to develop research proposals. Components such as collaborative agreements, guidelines for proposal writing, budgeting, peer-review process, and transitioning from proposal to research project implementation are addressed.

courses.title: Directed Studies in Public Health
courses.desc: Directed study with Public Health faculty.

courses.title: Independent Study in Public Health
courses.desc: Independent research with Public Health faculty.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to teaching assistants.

courses.title: Statistics and Methods for Public Policy
courses.desc: Introductory course with focus on gaining a sound understanding of what constitutes credible evidence in support of policy arguments and  management decisions.

courses.title: Information and Public Policy
courses.desc: Evaluates strengths and weaknesses of qualitative and quantitative methods and the data used in making public policy claims. Looks at the bases of certain widely accepted measures of poverty, growth, environmental quality, and the like.

courses.title: Public Policy
courses.desc: Explores different approaches to public policy analysis, the diverse conceptions of the goals and objectives that should be served by policy, and the appropriate role of the policy analyst. Policy consequences are traced to indirect and subtle incentives and disincentives.

courses.title: Qualitative Methods
courses.desc: Fieldwork, data collections techniques, and related issues for anti-positivistic research. Data collection techniques include observation, physical traces, participation, in-depth interview. Data checks include veracity, detail, completeness, rigor.

courses.title: Economics of Government
courses.desc: Prepares students to analyze public policy questions with tools from economics. By the end, students should be able to identify important economic issues in public policy debates and consume and critique economic research on these topics.

courses.title: Microeconomics and Public Policy
courses.desc: Introduces the fundamental principles of microeconomics that are required for applied policy analysis. Provides students with an intuitive understanding of the microeconomic approach, and familiarizes them with concepts used in applied public policy analysis.

courses.title: Policy and Ethics
courses.desc: Examines the challenge of identifying ethical principles that can guide us in formulating and assessing public policy, the public policy process from an ethical perspective, and the ethics of the individual engaged in the public policy arena.

courses.title: Collaborative Governance and Public Management
courses.desc: Introduction to inclusive management. To make effective use of public resources, public managers are inventing ways of managing that alter relationships within organizations, between organizations, between sectors, and with the public. Requires rethinking fundamentals such as leadership and motivation.

courses.title: World Religions I
courses.desc: An introduction to the history, doctrine, culture, and writing of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

courses.title: World Religions II
courses.desc: An introduction to various religious traditions in selected areas of the world—including India and South Asia, East Asia, Africa, and the Americas.

courses.title: Religious Dialogue
courses.desc: Lectures and discussion on controversial topics in religion: sexual morality; religious violence; science; treatment of women and girls; religious truth, American Constitutional matters; secularization; the future of religion, and other topics.

courses.title: An Economic Approach to Religion
courses.desc: Introduction to how basic economic concepts such as demand, supply, consumption, production, competition, free-riding, innovation, regulation, and rent-seeking can be applied to understand observed religious behavior.

courses.title: Philosophy and Religion
courses.desc: Examines the intersection of religion and philosophy from a standpoint that does not presuppose previous academic study of either.  Both Western and Eastern traditions and perspectives may be explored.

courses.title: Society and Religion
courses.desc: A critical and personal examination of the varieties of religious and spiritual experience human beings are undergoing in contemporary society.  The role of conscious understanding and unconscious conditioning regarding religion and spirituality.

courses.title: Gender and Religion
courses.desc: A presentation in selected issues in the study of gender and religion.

courses.title: Aspects of Religion
courses.desc: A presentation of selected issues in the study of religion.

courses.title: Topics in Aspects of Asian Religions
courses.desc: A survey course of a specific Asian religious tradition such as Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Daoism, Confucianism, or Shinto in its manifestation in Asia or in its transmission to the Americas.

courses.title: Topics in the Study of Religion
courses.desc: The intersection of religious belief and practices with selected subjects of continuing interest.

courses.title: Topics in the Philosophy of Religion
courses.desc: Critical examination of philosophical concepts in religious scripture and theology, e.g., the nature and existence of God, miracles, the problem of evil, and divine command theories in ethics. May include any religious tradition.

courses.title: Topics in Gender and Religion
courses.desc: Critical examination of how religious beliefs and practices have shaped (and been shaped by) attitudes toward gender and sexuality in modern and/or premodern society.

courses.title: Thinking about Religion: Theories and Methodologies
courses.prereqs: (REL STD 5A or HISTORY 16A) and (REL STD 5B or HISTORY 16B) and (REL STD 5C or HISTORY 16C)
courses.desc: A survey and investigation of the major thinkers, theories, and methodologies in the study of religions. Designed to develop the student's ability to analyze and articulate theoretical arguments; includes a paper on relevant Religious Studies topics.

courses.title: Thinking about Religion: Theories and Methodologies
courses.prereqs: (REL STD 5A or HISTORY 16A) and (REL STD 5B or HISTORY 16B) and (REL STD 5C or HISTORY 16C). Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: A survey and investigation of the major thinkers, theories, and methodologies in the study of religions. Designed to develop the student's ability to analyze and articulate theoretical arguments in writing; includes a paper on relevant Religious Studies topics.

courses.title: Religion and World Politics
courses.prereqs: POL SCI 41A or INTL ST 11 or INTL ST 12 or REL STD 5A or REL STD 5B or REL STD 5C
courses.desc: Examines the relationship between religion and world politics historically and today, focusing on connections with peace/war, democracy, human rights, secularism(s), and globalization. Covers major debates, scholarship, concepts, and theories through class exercises, exams, and essays.

courses.title: Topics in Asian Religious Traditions
courses.desc: Studies involving (but not limited to) Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Jainism, Sikhism, Daoism, Shinto or Shamanism, including both elite and doctrinal aspects and forms of more popular religiosity.

courses.title: Ancient India
courses.desc: Examines the visual and religious history of the region defined as "India" today, but necessarily encompassing modern Bangladesh and Pakistan.  Culminates with the supposed Golden Age of the Gupta empire and its far-reaching legacies.

courses.title: Medieval India
courses.desc: Begins with the Gupta period's aesthetic legacies in South Asia's architecture, sculpture, and painting. Explores the dispersal of Islam throughout South Asia, including the Muslim communities of southern India.

courses.title: Topics in Modern Indian Religion
courses.desc: Topics in religions of the Indian subcontinent including, but not confined to, Hinduism, Jainism, Sikhism, Islam, and Buddhism from the founding of the Mughal Empire in 1526 to the creation of the several modern states of the Indian subcontinent.

courses.title: Jewish, Islamic, and Middle Eastern Religious Traditions
courses.desc: Character and evolution of Egyptian, Jewish, Zoroastrian, Muslim, and other religious communities of the region from their formative periods to the present era.

courses.title: Jews and Power
courses.desc: Examines the relationship between the Jewish people and political power over a 3500 year period. How have Jews preserved their communal interests and personal safety? How have they defined the proper relationship of the people to political authority.

courses.title: Early Western Religious Traditions
courses.desc: Religious perspectives of the Mediterranean and European regions from the earliest times to approximately 1500 C.E.

courses.title: Recent Western Religious Traditions
courses.desc: Studies related to Catholic, Protestant, and Orthodox Christianity as well as alternative belief systems in Europe of the early modern and modern eras.

courses.title: Religion in the Americas
courses.desc: Religious belief and social context in North and South America from the earliest human societies to the present.

courses.title: Diaspora Religions
courses.desc: Examination of what happens to belief and practice as religious communities are scattered geographically.

courses.title: Topics in Comparative Studies in Religion
courses.desc: Literary, historical, or philosophical comparison of selected religious and quasi-religious traditions, their beliefs and practices.

courses.title: Senior Colloquium
courses.desc: Reading and group discussion of selected texts under the direction of an instructor.  Paper required.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Directed reading and research in consultation with a faculty member.  Substantial written work required.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to teaching assistants.

courses.title: Military Science-Basic Leadership Laboratory
courses.desc: Provides hands-on and practical military science material covered in the corresponding military science courses.

courses.title: Military Science-Personal Development
courses.desc: Focuses on life skills such as physical fitness, nutrition, and time management while providing an introduction to military knowledge, customs, and skills.

courses.title: Military Science-Leadership I
courses.desc: Focuses on the fundamentals of leadership, Army leadership values, ethics, and counseling techniques.

courses.title: Military Science-Tactical Leadership I
courses.desc: Focuses on leadership at the tactical level and includes instruction in fundamental military skills such as map reading, land navigation, squad and platoon operations, and resource planning techniques.

courses.title: Military Science-Team Leadership I
courses.desc: Explores the dimensions of creative and innovative tactical leadership strategies and styles by examining team dynamics and two historical leadership theories that form the basis of the Army leadership requirements model.

courses.title: Military Science-Team Leadership II
courses.desc: Explores team dynamics and two historical leadership theories that form the basis of the Army leadership requirements model.

courses.title: Military Science-Tactical Leadership II
courses.desc: Examines the challenges of leading tactical teams in the OE. Highlights dimensions of terrain analysis, patrolling, and operation orders.

courses.title: Military Science-Advanced Leadership Laboratory
courses.desc: Provides hands-on and practical exercises for the military science material covered in the corresponding military science courses as well as leader training through practical application of the Leadership Development Program.

courses.title: Military Science-Leadership II
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: ROTC 100L
ROTC 11 and ROTC 12 and ROTC 13 and ROTC 21 and ROTC 22 and ROTC 23
courses.desc: Challenges cadets to study, practice, and evaluate adaptive leadership skills as they are presented with challenging scenarios related to squad tactical operations. Cadets receive systematic and specified feedback on their leadership attributes and core leader competencies.

courses.title: Military Science-Team Leadership III
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: ROTC 100L
ROTC 11 and ROTC 12 and ROTC 13 and ROTC 21 and ROTC 22 and ROTC 23
courses.desc: Provides cadets systematic and specific feedback on their leadership attributes and core leader competencies. Based on such feedback, as well as their own self-evaluations, cadets continue to develop their leadership and critical thinking abilities.

courses.title: Military Science-Tactical Leadership III
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: ROTC 100L
ROTC 11 and ROTC 12 and ROTC 13 and ROTC 21 and ROTC 22 and ROTC 23
courses.desc: Uses increasingly intense situational leadership challenges to build cadet awareness and skills in leading small units. Skills in decision-making, persuading, and motivating team members when "under fire" are explored, evaluated, and developed.

courses.title: Military Science-Leadership III
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: ROTC 100L
ROTC 131 and ROTC 132 and ROTC 133
courses.desc: Transitions the focus of student learning from being trained, mentored, and evaluated as a cadet to learning how to train, mentor, and evaluate cadets. Cadets begin to learn the duties and responsibilities of an Army staff officer.

courses.title: Military Science-Leadership IV
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: ROTC 100L
ROTC 131 and ROTC 132 and ROTC 133 and ROTC 141
courses.desc: Requires students to continue to train, mentor, and evaluate underclass cadets. Cadets learn to safely conduct training by understanding and employing the Composite Risk Management Process and the Comprehensive Soldier Fitness (CSF) program.

courses.title: Military Science-Officership
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: ROTC 100L
ROTC 131 and ROTC 132 and ROTC 133 and ROTC 141 and ROTC 142
courses.desc: Explores the dynamics of leading in the complex situations of current military operations in the OE. Cadets examine differences in customs and courtesies, military law, principles of war, and rules of engagement in the face of international terrorism.

courses.title: United States Military History-1607 to 1865
courses.desc: Examines the creation of the American military establishment and traces its evolution in the context of the changing nature of warfare, the progression of military professionalism, and social, political, economic, and technological developments through the Civil War.

courses.title: United States Military History-1865 to 1945
courses.desc: Examines the evolution of the American military establishment and the progression of military professionalism in terms of social, political, economic, military, and technological developments from the end of the Civil War through World War II.

courses.title: United States Military History-1945 to 2001
courses.desc: Examines the evolution of the American military establishment and the progression of military professionalism in terms of social, political, economic, military, and technological developments from the Cold War to the War on Terrorism.

courses.title: Military Science Independent Studies
courses.desc: Provides intensive, individual study with scheduled meetings to be arranged between Cadre and student. Assigned reading and tangible evidence of mastery of subject matter required.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Russian
courses.desc: Focuses on reading, comprehension, basic composition, and conversation skills, and gives the student an initial exposure to the Russian cultural scene.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Russian
courses.prereqs: RUSSIAN 1A. RUSSIAN 1A with a grade of C or better. Placement into RUSSIAN 1B is also accepted.
courses.desc: Focuses on reading, comprehension, basic composition, and conversation skills, and gives the student an initial exposure to the Russian cultural scene.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Russian
courses.prereqs: RUSSIAN 1AB or RUSSIAN 1B. RUSSIAN 1AB with a grade of C or better. RUSSIAN 1B with a grade of C or better. Placement into RUSSIAN 1C is also accepted.
courses.desc: Focuses on reading, comprehension, basic composition, and conversation skills, and gives the student an initial exposure to the Russian cultural scene.

courses.title: Intermediate Russian
courses.prereqs: RUSSIAN 1BC or RUSSIAN 1C. RUSSIAN 1BC with a grade of C or better. RUSSIAN 1C with a grade of C or better. Placement into RUSSIAN 2A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Students read simple passages from contemporary Russian literary texts and newspapers. Development of oral skills and exposure to Russian culture continue.

courses.title: Intermediate Russian
courses.prereqs: RUSSIAN 2A. RUSSIAN 2A with a grade of C or better. Placement into RUSSIAN 2B is also accepted.
courses.desc: Students read simple passages from contemporary Russian literary texts and newspapers. Development of oral skills and exposure to Russian culture continue.

courses.title: Intermediate Russian
courses.prereqs: RUSSIAN 2B. RUSSIAN 2B with a grade of C or better. Placement into RUSSIAN 2C is also accepted.
courses.desc: Students read simple passages from contemporary Russian literary texts and newspapers. Development of oral skills and exposure to Russian culture continue.

courses.title: Russian Culture
courses.desc: Study of varied topics in Russian culture, area studies, and society, both in the present and in historical perspective.

courses.title: Special Studies Russian
courses.desc: Special studies under faculty supervision.

courses.title: Topics in Russian Literature
courses.desc: Examines major themes in Russian literature, film, and other media from the eighteenth to twenty-first centuries. Taught in English.

courses.title: Topics in Russian Language Through Film
courses.desc: Uses Russian films of the late 20th century to enhance students' language skills and deepen their cultural knowledge. Work involves intensive conversation, reading and listening comprehension, and the acquisition of written skills and grammatical accuracy. Conducted primarily in Russian.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Independent study under direct faculty supervision.

courses.title: Introduction to Environmental Analysis and Design
courses.desc: Overview of general concepts, theoretical principles, and analytical techniques for investigating environmental systems. Integrates tools from natural and social sciences to analyze contemporary environmental challenges such as pollution, resource acquisition, facility and ecosystem design, impact assessments, formulation of environmental policy.

courses.title: Research Design
courses.desc: An introduction to the logic behind and methods of designing and conducting research studies in Social Ecology. Topics include how to measure variables of interest, identifying causal relationships, sampling, survey research methods, experiments, quasi-experimental designs, and ethics in research.

courses.title: Statistical Analysis in Social Ecology
courses.desc: Introduction to the techniques of statistical analysis in Social Ecology. Topics include probability, statistical inference, significance testing, univariate descriptive statistics, and multivariate analysis from an interdisciplinary perspective.

courses.title: Honors: Critical Issues on the Social Sciences
courses.desc: Major themes, methods, and works in the social sciences from an interdisciplinary perspective. Each quarter focuses on a different topic. Weekly seminars emphasizing development of critical thinking skills and quantitative analysis through written work are integral to the course.

courses.title: Honors: Critical Issues on the Social Sciences
courses.prereqs: SOC SCI H1E or SOCECOL H20A
courses.desc: Major themes, methods, and works in the social sciences from an interdisciplinary perspective. Each quarter focuses on a different topic. Weekly seminars emphasizing development of critical thinking skills and quantitative analysis through written work are integral to the course.

courses.title: Honors: Critical Issues on the Social Sciences
courses.prereqs: SOC SCI H1F or SOCECOL H20B
courses.desc: Major themes, methods, and works in the social sciences from an interdisciplinary perspective. Each quarter focuses on a different topic. Weekly seminars emphasizing development of critical thinking skills and quantitative analysis through written work are integral to the course.

courses.title: Moral Development and Just Communities
courses.desc: A three-quarter sequence exploring interpersonal, personal, and social issues based on principles of fairness and justice. Both the living environment of a University residence hall and selected institutions of society are analyzed in terms of moral development theory.

courses.title: Moral Development and Just Communities
courses.desc: A three-quarter sequence exploring interpersonal, personal, and social issues based on principles of fairness and justice. Both the living environment of a University residence hall and selected institutions of society are analyzed in terms of moral development theory.

courses.title: Moral Development and Just Communities
courses.desc: A three-quarter sequence exploring interpersonal, personal, and social issues based on principles of fairness and justice. Both the living environment of a University residence hall and selected institutions of society are analyzed in terms of moral development theory.

courses.title: Special Topics in Social Ecology
courses.desc: Special topics courses are offered from time to time. In general they will focus on a topic from interdisciplinary perspectives. Course content varies with the interest of the instructor.

courses.title: Advanced Research Methods
courses.prereqs: SOCECOL 10 and SOCECOL 13. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: For students planning to conduct senior research projects or apply to graduate school in social research fields. Topics include reviewing literature, preparing a research proposal, protecting human subjects, citing scholarly work, building measures, estimating sample size, interview and presentation skills.

courses.title: Domestic Violence
courses.desc: General perspectives about domestic violence and theoretical accounts about what causes such behavior.

courses.title: Violence in Intimate Relationships
courses.desc: Responses to various forms of domestic violence, such as intimate partner violence and child abuse. Covers barriers to reporting to the police, and prosecutors and courts. Human services, such as safety planning for victims, treatment programs, and restorative justice approaches.

courses.title: Nuclear Environments
courses.desc: Understanding the impact of the nuclear age on the environment and human health through interrelated developments of nuclear power and nuclear weapons. The early years of weapon development, catastrophic environmental pollution, perils of nuclear power in the U.S. and Russia.

courses.title: Global and International Studies Forum
courses.desc: A faculty-student forum featuring lectures from a variety of institutions with discussion issues related to Global and International Studies.

courses.title: Seminar in Mediation
courses.desc: Student develop mediation skills and refine knowledge in the practice and theory of conflict resolution. Students who complete this course may serve as mediators in the Campus Mediation Program. Course is a prerequisite to completing Indep Study as an intern.

courses.title: Seminar in Conflict Resolution
courses.desc: Designed for students pursuing the minor in Conflict Resolution and/or International Studies majors. Provides a forum in which students will refine skills and theory in the study of cooperation and conflict, from local to global arenas. Students write research paper.

courses.title: Seminar Conflict Resolution
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Designed for seniors who are pursuing the minor in Conflict Resolution and/or International Studies major. Provides a forum in which students will refine skills and theory in the study of cooperation and conflict, from local to global arenas.

courses.title: Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability I
courses.desc: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability. Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum is also required. Seminar utilized to analyze forum presentations.  Prepare bibliography.

courses.title: Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability II
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 191A or SOCECOL 186A or EARTHSS 190A
courses.desc: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability. Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum is also required. Seminar utilized to analyze forum presentations.  Prepare research proposal.

courses.title: Writing/Senior Seminar on Global Sustainability III
courses.prereqs: BIO SCI 191B or EARTHSS 190B or SOCECOL 186B. BIO SCI 191B or EARTHSS 190B or SOCECOL 186B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Students attend weekly seminar to discuss current issues in global sustainability.  Weekly attendance at Global Sustainability Forum also is required.  Seminar utilized to analyze Forum presentations and to prepare senior research paper.  Prepare/write research paper under direction of faculty member.

courses.title: Global Service Scholars Advanced Seminar
courses.desc: For students who are accepted into the Global Service Scholars Program. Provides advanced training in empathy and compassion, and prepares students for their summer international field experience.

courses.title: Applied Statistics in Social and Behavioral Research
courses.desc: Covers statistical techniques used to describe and make generalizations about phenomena represented by data. Hands-on experience in data analysis and interpretation using statistical software (SPSS, STATA) is emphasized. Topics include data visualization, ANOVA, multiple regression, and categorical data analyses.

courses.title: Honors Research
courses.desc: Independent work on an individual research project in addition to participation in a mini proseminar in which faculty discuss their ongoing research.  Students prepare a written proposal for a research project.

courses.title: Honors Research
courses.desc: Independent work on an individual research project in a addition to participation in a mini proseminar in which faculty discuss their ongoing research. Students prepare a  written proposal for a research project.

courses.title: Honors Research
courses.desc: Students write up their honors research project (H190A-B) and prepare an oral report which is presented at the honors seminar.

courses.title: Naturalistic Field Research
courses.prereqs: SOCECOL 10. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Introduction to alternative models of experiential learning and to various methods of observation, assessment, and evaluation. Introduction to the nature of organizations and ethical issues that emerge from research and intervention in natural settings.

courses.title: Field Study
courses.desc: Community engagement to facilitate civic education through field research experience, social intervention, and professionalization. Small group instruction, discussion, writing, and presentations synthesizing students’ experiences in the field with theory, paradigms, and ideas learned about in their course work.

courses.title: Advanced Field Study
courses.prereqs: SOCECOL 10 and SOCECOL 13. Acceptance to Advanced Field Study required.
courses.desc: While completing 10 hours of field work per week, students become acquainted with the goals and activities of their placement and will work closely with the placement supervisor and AFS instructor to identify the scope of a research project.

courses.title: Advanced Field Study
courses.prereqs: SOCECOL 195A. Acceptance to Advanced Field Study required.
courses.desc: While completing 10 hours of field work per week, students implement their research project through data collection and observations which allow them to reflect on, apply, and synthesize their academic training through observations and experiences at the placement.

courses.title: Advanced Field Study
courses.prereqs: SOCECOL 195B. Acceptance to Advanced Field Study required. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: While completing 10 hours per week of field work, students write and finalize their AFS Client Project in consultation with the placement and the FS instructor, and make a final written and oral presentation to the placement and invited guests.

courses.title: Field Study Writing Seminar
courses.prereqs: SOCECOL 10. Cumulative UC GPA of 2.0. Authorization is required. Successful completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Community engagement to promote civic education through field research experience, and the opportunity to study social issues and the environments where they occur. Develop discipline-specific writing and communication skills, methodology, and integrate information from multiple sources.   Course may be offered online.

courses.title: Directed Study
courses.desc: Directed study with Social Ecology faculty.

courses.title: Special Studies
courses.desc: Special Studies with Social Ecology faculty.

courses.title: Seminar in Social Ecology
courses.desc: Students are introduced to the classic and contemporary literature of human and social ecology and are expected to use the ecological paradigm to analyze social phenomena of interest to the differing subprograms.

courses.title: Strategies of Theory Development
courses.desc: Examines key issues and controversies facing the development of social ecological theory, and encourages students to develop their own abilities as theorists. Strategies for enhancing creative hypothesis formation are emphasized.

courses.title: Data Analysis
courses.desc: Provides an appreciation and understanding of statistics necessary to conduct applied research. Topics include approaches to and presentation of data, robust statistics, standardization techniques, multivariate regression, and analysis of variance.

courses.title: Data Analysis
courses.desc: Provides an appreciation and understanding of statistics necessary to conduct applied research. Topics include approaches to and presentation of data, robust statistics, standardization techniques, multivariate regression, and analysis of variance.

courses.title: Analysis of Survival Data
courses.desc: Provides an introduction to survival analysis methods for the analysis of change in discrete dependent variables. Focuses on data collection strategies for obtaining longitudinal data and continuous-time hazards models. Communicates the variety and power of multivariate hazard models.

courses.title: Structural Equation Modeling I
courses.desc: The general structural equation model is developed including path models, recursive and nonrecursive structural models, multiple indicator models, and confirmatory factor models. Use of LISREL and other software for estimating model parameters is covered.

courses.title: Structural Equation Modeling II: Longitudinal and Advanced Topics
courses.desc: Provides hands-on experience with longitudinal and advanced structural equation models and is of interest to students from a range of disciplines. Topics covered include confirmatory factor, latent growth curve, general growth mixture, and multi-level modeling.

courses.title: Special Topics in Social Ecology
courses.desc: Topics covered vary with interests of the instructor.

courses.title: Program Evaluation
courses.desc: Students are introduced to the use of research techniques and statistical methods in assessing the effectiveness of social programs. Different evaluative models are discussed using examples of actual program evaluations.

courses.title: Masters Thesis Research & Writing
courses.desc: Independent research with Social Ecology faculty.

courses.title: Doctoral Dissertation Research & Writing
courses.desc: Dissertation research with Social Ecology faculty.

courses.title: Field Study
courses.desc: Field studies in Social Ecology.

courses.title: Directed Studies
courses.desc: Directed study with Social Ecology faculty.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Independent study with Social Ecology faculty.

courses.title: University Supervised Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Social Policy and Public Service
courses.desc: An introduction to the basic theories and principles of public policy. Students examine various influences on the development of public policy and the principle actors in the process, and learn to identify tools and techniques employed in policy making.

courses.title: Race and Ethnicity
courses.desc: Focuses on racial and ethnic relations in the United States and compares them with those found in other societies. Analyzes the conditions that favor either cooperation and integration or rivalry, tension, and conflict. Appraises strategies for reducing and resolving conflicts.

courses.title: Immigration, Nation, and Media
courses.desc: Examines media shapes and reflects public opinion on immigration and its representation of immigrants, citizens, and ideas about the nation, and who belongs and who is a potential threat; as well as the relationship between scholars and journalists.

courses.title: Honors Research Workshop
courses.desc: Student develops a 10–15-page prospectus of research for the honors thesis which includes: the research question, literature review, methods of investigation, and bibliography. Student selects a faculty mentor who will supervise thesis research and writing in winter and spring.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Research
courses.prereqs: SOC SCI H190A or SPPS H190A
courses.desc: The student initiates and completes data collection for the honors thesis. A faculty mentor provides supervision and feedback on thesis chapters.

courses.title: Honors Thesis
courses.prereqs: SOC SCI H190B or SPPS H190B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: The student completes, with the approval of the faculty mentor, an honors thesis containing: statement of the problem, literature review, research hypotheses, methods of investigation, results, discussion, and bibliography.

courses.title: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
courses.prereqs: SOC SCI 70C or SOCIOL 63. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service.
