Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and underserved communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.

courses.title: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
courses.desc: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and underserved communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.

courses.title: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
courses.desc: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and underserved communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.

courses.title: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
courses.desc: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and under-served communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.

courses.title: Principles in the Social Sciences
courses.desc: Introduction to various disciplines within the social sciences. Provides an interdisciplinary perspective on understanding human behavior and social institutions, including interpersonal, economic, and cultural activities.

courses.title: Honors: Critical Issues on the Social Sciences
courses.desc: Major themes, methods, and works in the social sciences from an interdisciplinary perspective. Each quarter focuses on a different topic. Weekly seminars emphasizing development of critical thinking skills and quantitative analysis through written work are integral to the course.

courses.title: Honors: Critical Issues on the Social Sciences
courses.prereqs: SOC SCI H1E or SOCECOL H20A
courses.desc: Major themes, methods, and works in the social sciences from an interdisciplinary perspective. Each quarter focuses on a different topic. Weekly seminars emphasizing development of critical thinking skills and quantitative analysis through written work are integral to the course.

courses.title: Honors: Critical Issues on the Social Sciences
courses.prereqs: SOC SCI H1F or SOCECOL H20B
courses.desc: Major themes, methods, and works in the social sciences from an interdisciplinary perspective. Each quarter focuses on a different topic. Weekly seminars emphasizing development of critical thinking skills and quantitative analysis through written work are integral to the course.

courses.title: Introduction to Social Science Analysis
courses.desc: Introduction to social science research and analytical models. Theory construction and use of research methods in an interdisciplinary context.  Discussion of the application of social science research to public policy.  Computer laboratories develop creative thinking, graphing, and data presentation skills.

courses.title: Computer-Based Research in the Social Sciences
courses.desc: Focuses on the data manipulation, data visualization, and information searching techniques. Hands-on experience in hypothesis testing, mapping, graphics, and data arrays.

courses.title: Introduction to Global Studies
courses.desc: Ongoing historical processes that increase global integration, the social, economic, and political interdependence of different regions, cultures, and peoples. Topics include ancient empires, colonialism, nationalism, industrialization, modern imperialism and warfare, decolonization, global social movements, conflict, inequality, and global governance.

courses.title: Introduction to Human Geography
courses.desc: Human behavior in a geographical context. Spatial patterns and organization of the cultural, social, and economic activities of man as imposed on and influenced by the earth's physical setting.

courses.title: Introduction to Physical Geography
courses.desc: An introduction to the physical world we live in. Distribution and dynamics of the earth's air, water, and solid crust. Concepts and principles from climatology and geology. Selected examples from North America and beyond.

courses.title: US & World Geography
courses.desc: Survey of general geographical principles and facts on a world scale, as well as introduction to the broad regional and resource geography of the U.S., emphasizing in particular the interactions of physical and cultural factors.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics in Social Sciences I
courses.desc: Introduction to the variety of statistical applications in the social sciences. Descriptive statistics. Measures of central tendency and dispersion. Percentile ranks. Standardization and normal approximation. Basic probability theory focuses on application to statistical inference and binomial distribution. Laboratory required.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics in Social Sciences II
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical inference, sampling distribution, standard error.  Hypothesis tests for proportions and means. Inferential techniques for nominal variables including chi-square, study measures of strengths, significance of relationships between variables, assumptions, data requirements, and types of error in significance tests.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics in Social Sciences III
courses.desc: Focus on correlation, regression, and control for effects of variables. One-way and two-way factorial analysis of variance. A priori and a posteriori comparisons.  Introduction to repeated measures design and non-parametric statistics. Discuss use of statistics in newspapers and popular magazines.

courses.title: Barter to Bitcoin: Society, Technology and the Future of Money
courses.desc: Digital money has captured the broad imagination of speculators, coders, regulators, criminals and the mass media. Course puts this change in context: how do we understand money as a social, political and technological phenomenon?.

courses.title: Global Political Ideologies
courses.desc: An overview of the major political ideologies shaping the current world order and global conflict. Topics include liberalism, democracy, nationalism, capitalism, communism, socialism, fascism, neoliberalism, clash of civilizations, sectarian violence, populist nationalism, and de-globalization.

courses.title: Global Political Economy
courses.desc: The global economy as an integrated system. The rise of world trade, capitalism, national economies, market cycles, competing economic ideologies, development, globalization, transnational labor, multinational corporations, and the role of UN, World Bank, WTO, and the IMF in global governance.

courses.title: Human Rights and Global Governance
courses.desc: Historical development of civil, political rights and the rise of human rights in international law. Explores role, and limitations, of the UN, ICJ, and ICC in global governance. Reconceptualizing democracy and political representation in a postnational 21st century.

courses.title: Global Environmental Issues
courses.desc: Examines problems such as global climate change, growing human populations, fisheries depletion, ocean acidification, biodiversity loss, deforestation, and food security. Introduces political, social, and economic factors contributing to environmental issues and their disproportional impacts on the world’s poor and minorities.

courses.title: Model United Nations
courses.desc: Focuses on simulations of the foreign policy pursuits of selected countries in the international community. Emphasis placed on understanding the rules of debate, as well as the policy positions of the student's selected country in the United Nations.

courses.title: Social Science Perspectives on the Sustainability of Societies
courses.prereqs: EARTHSS H30C. EARTHSS H30C with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Introduces the perspectives of social science using examples from different countries to explore how social issues regarding sustainability are influenced by a society’s changing economic and political institutions, and how economic, political, and other social choices affect their sustainability.

courses.title: Social Policy and Public Service
courses.desc: An introduction to the basic theories and principles of public policy. Students examine various influences on the development of public policy and the principle actors in the process, and learn to identify tools and techniques employed in policy making.

courses.title: Introduction to Gangs
courses.desc: Introduces students to street gang subculture and explores risk factors associated with gang membership. Students develop a working definition for street gang and understand the difference between social and legal definitions. Also explores the connection between prison and street gangs.

courses.title: Comparing Cultures
courses.desc: Introduces students to the scope of cross-cultural comparisons by analyzing the theories, methodologies, and facts utilized by anthropologists, sociologists, social psychologists, political scientists, and historians in comparing cultures.

courses.title: Asian American Histories
courses.desc: Examines and compares diverse experiences of major Asian American groups since the mid-nineteenth century. Topics include origins of emigration; the formation and transformation of community; gender and family life; changing roles of Asian Americans in American society. Formerly ASIANAM 60A.

courses.title: Asian American Communities
courses.desc: Examines the renewal of Asian immigration following World War II. Explores contemporary Asian American populations and communities in the U.S., and the impact of contemporary Asian immigration on the U.S. political economy and social order.

courses.title: Asian Americans and Race
courses.desc: Analyzes the Asian American experience in comparative perspective, which includes comparisons of different ethnic and racial groups, and across gender and class. Possible topics include labor, economy, politics, migration, nation, popular culture, gender, family, sexuality, and multiraciality.

courses.title: Special Topics in Social Sciences
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Social Sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems
courses.desc: Hands-on laboratory course introduces students to the fundamentals of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) technology using social science applications.  Students will learn to organize, manipulate, and display spatial data leading to the design of their own GIS research project.

courses.title: Intermediate Geographic Information Systems
courses.desc: Expands Geographic Information Systems (GIS) skills to more advanced theories and concepts in the spatial analysis of social science issues and particularly to analyzing and interpreting spatial data.  Students develop and complete a GIS research project of their own choosing.

courses.title: Game Theory and Politics I
courses.desc: Introduction to game theory and a survey of its political applications. Examples of topics covered include voting in small committees, legislatures, and mass elections; interest group activities and environmental issues; institutional design, and the evolution of cooperative behavior.

courses.title: Game Theory and Politics II
courses.desc: More advanced game theory and its political applications, beginning where Game Theory and Politics I ends.  Examples of topics covered include revolutions; arms race; spatial models of party competition; political manipulation; political coalitions and their power.

courses.title: International Business
courses.desc: Introduction to conducting business in the international arena, decision making in the organization, and globalization of markets and production.  Topics covered range from tax and finance to ethics, marketing, and more.  Continuing corporate regulatory scandals discussed.

courses.title: Special Topics in Geography
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of geography. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Transnational Gangs
courses.desc: Examines the internationalization of U.S. domestic street gangs.  The relationship between California gangs Mara Salvatrucha and 18th Street and Mexico/Central American gangs is assessed.  Specified topics include:  mobilization, migration, territorialism, culture, organization, and use of technology.

courses.title: Voting and Political Manipulation
courses.desc: Introduction to social choice and cooperative games. Topics include majority rule, types of voting methods, apportionment and proportional representation, agenda manipulation, coalition formation, voting power, political consequences of electoral laws.

courses.title: Veterans in History and Society
courses.desc: Explores key concepts, issues, and trends in the interdisciplinary field of Veterans Studies. Students gain a deep understanding of the ways that social scientists and historians have analyzed the identities, experiences, and worldviews of U.S. military veterans.

courses.title: Non-Government Organization (NGO) Fundamentals
courses.desc: Introduction to non-governmental organizations, including their role in U.S. society and the international community. Explores varying definitions of NGOs and the characteristics held in common by all NGOs.

courses.title: American Public Policy
courses.desc: Focuses on the development and implementation of public policy in the United States. Lectures cover theoretical models of the policy process as well as significant problems facing contemporary American decision-makers.

courses.title: Urban America
courses.desc: Students examine the historical, social, political, and economic factors that contributed to the construction of the American urban context, one that is poverty concentrated and racially/ethnically segregated. Students also critically assess the consequence of growing up in America's urban neighborhoods.

courses.title: Domestic Gangs
courses.desc: Examines the history and development of California street gangs and the role of historical events in that development. Students will be able to contrast and compare gang cohort behaviors between some of the major gangs in California.

courses.title: Prison Gangs
courses.desc: Examines the growth and spread of prison gangs throughout the country. Relationships between prison and street gangs, and possible relationships with foreign drug trafficking organizations studied. Violence examined as the standard to establish dominance in and out of prison.

courses.title: Juvenile Gangs
courses.desc: Examines risk factors that can be used to predict gang membership. Compares generational with non-generational gangs and develops a working sociological definition that can be used to identify street gangs. Myths about juveniles, street gangs.

courses.title: Chicano/Latino Families
courses.desc: Introduction to the research, literature, and issues surrounding the topic of Chicano/Latino families including cultural history, contemporary issues, organization of family, traditions, lifestyles, values, beliefs, generational differences, gender issues, ethnic identity, evolution of demographic patterns, current economic and political standings.

courses.title: Immigration and Inequality
courses.desc: Explores immigration, ethnicity, and inequality as interconnected social forces. International migration, propelled by global inequalities, plays a central role in the formation of multinational societies, shapes inter-group relations and patterns of ethnic inequality, and transforms the immigrants themselves.

courses.title: Special Topics: Sociology
courses.desc: No description.

courses.title: Research Methods in the Social Sciences
courses.prereqs: SOC SCI 1A and SOC SCI 2A and SOC SCI 3A and (SOC SCI 10A or STATS 7)
courses.desc: Examines how interdisciplinary social science research questions are formulated and studies several research methods including: experimental method, quasi-experimental methods, survey research, field research, evaluation research, and meta-analysis. Parametric and non-parametric statistical methods are illustrated using the SPSS program.

courses.title: American Culture
courses.desc: A survey of the historical development of dominant American culture and society; emphasis on a close reading of key cultural texts, with weekly text as a model of writing examining its use of language and rhetoric.

courses.title: American Culture
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: A survey of the historical development of dominant American culture and society; emphasis on a close reading of key cultural texts, with weekly text as a model of writing, examining its use of language and rhetoric.

courses.title: Law in the Twenty-First Century
courses.desc: Examines the complex relationship between law, the social sciences, and modern society.  Lectures explore such issues as the interplay between technology and constitutional rights, the impact of science on law, and the evolving roles of attorneys and judges.

courses.title: Latinos in a Global Society
courses.desc: Examines interconnections between diverse Latino groups in the U.S. and the effects of globalization on their social, cultural, and political realities. Topics include immigration, demographics, socioeconomic differentiation, familial relations, political protest/resistance, law and policy, and links to "homeland" issues.

courses.title: Revolution in Latin America
courses.desc: Presents a comparative analysis of the causes, development, and consequences of selected revolutionary movements, focusing on outbreaks in Mexico, Bolivia, Cuba, Chile, Nicaragua, and Grenada.  Explores topics of state formation, economic nationalism, social justice, ethnicity, and role of international affairs.

courses.title: Asian American Women
courses.desc: Examines the representations and experiences of Asian American women from diverse perspectives. Explores the commonalities and differences among various groups of Asian American women, with particular focus on history, culture, values, and family roles.

courses.title: Korean American Studies
courses.desc: Explores the factors that have distinctly shaped the Korean American experience, including patterns of racial domination, the profile of immigrant flow, immigrant roles in the urban political economy, politics in Korea, and the role of the church.

courses.title: Vietnamese American Studies
courses.desc: Studies the resettlement of Vietnamese in the United States following their exodus from Southeast Asia. Topics include the Vietnam War, the 1975 evacuation, boat and land refugees, the shaping of Vietnamese communities, and Vietnamese American literature.

courses.title: Japanese American Studies
courses.desc: Studies the settlement of Japanese in Hawaii and the continental United States since the late 19th century. Topics include sugar plantations, development of rural Japanese America, World War II internment, post-War community development, and persistence of Japanese American identity.

courses.title: South Asian American Studies
courses.desc: Examines and compares the experiences of South Asian immigrants in the U.S. over time. Looks at the economic, political, and social positions of the immigrants, with special emphasis on religious changes and the changes in the second and later generations.

courses.title: Southeast Asian American Studies
courses.desc: Analyzes experiences of refugees and immigrants from Southeast Asia, which may include those from Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, and the Philippines. Examines political and economic factors for their exodus and how they reconstruct their identities, histories, and communities.

courses.title: Chinese American Studies
courses.desc: Analyzes the experiences of Chinese in the United States. Immigration, Chinese exclusion, racial and gender identity. Historical overview and contemporary issues covered.

courses.title: Filipina/Filipino American Studies
courses.desc: Explores the experience of Filipina/Filipino Americans from the era of Spanish colonization of the Philippines to present-day community formations in the United States, with special emphasis on the 20th century. Topics include colonialism, nation, migration, gender, and culture.

courses.title: Special Topics in Asian American Studies
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Asian American Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Ethical Leadership
courses.desc: Explores historical and contemporary theories of ethical and unethical leadership.  Examines models of "good leadership" such as cardinal and monastic virtues; and models of "bad leadership," such as Machiavelli's Prince.  Explores the philosophies, styles, and accomplishments of leaders.

courses.title: Global and International Studies Forum
courses.desc: A faculty-student forum featuring lectures from a variety of institutions with discussion issues related to Global and International Studies.

courses.title: Seminar in Mediation
courses.desc: Student develop mediation skills and refine knowledge in the practice and theory of conflict resolution. Students who complete this course may serve as mediators in the Campus Mediation Program. Course is a prerequisite to completing Indep Study as an intern.

courses.title: Seminar in Conflict Resolution
courses.desc: Designed for students pursuing the minor in Conflict Resolution and/or International Studies majors. Provides a forum in which students will refine skills and theory in the study of cooperation and conflict, from local to global arenas. Students write research paper.

courses.title: Seminar Conflict Resolution
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Designed for seniors who are pursuing the minor in Conflict Resolution and/or International Studies major. Provides a forum in which students will refine skills and theory in the study of cooperation and conflict, from local to global arenas.

courses.title: Conflict Resolution in Cross-Cultural Perspective
courses.desc: Examines theories of conflict management. Analyzes how conflict is mitigated in diverse cultures: at the interpersonal level, between groups, and on the international scale. Students discuss readings, hear from conflict management practitioners, and simulate negotiations.

courses.title: Sage Leader Research I
courses.desc: Participants in the SAGE Scholars Program learn to define leadership concepts, discover various leadership styles, and develop strong leadership and communication skills resulting in strengthened ability to contribute to and interact with UCI and the Orange County community.

courses.title: Sage Leader Research II
courses.desc: Provides a survey of contemporary topics and challenges in the fields of management and leadership. Case studies and text by leading authors are used to analyze key leadership issues in twenty-first century, with particular emphasis on current events.

courses.title: International Journalism
courses.desc: Studies and critically analyzes how the media covers international issues that have reshaped. American foreign coverage and the implications for Americans and U.S. foreign policy. Focuses on international reporting as a way of developing fundamental skills of journalism.

courses.title: Media Writing
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Designed to teach reporting and news writing basics.  Students learn how to gather and organize information, ask effective questions, develop story ideas, research facts, and write stories on deadline.

courses.title: People in Society
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Through readings about people in distinctly different societies throughout history, students learn concepts that cross the boundaries of the social science disciplines. Such themes as democracy, elitism, power, social class, and gender are the basis for discussion and writing.

courses.title: Twenty-First-Century Graduate Education
courses.desc: Graduate and professional education in twenty-first century United States. Examines  strategies for admission to postbaccalaureate programs and success in graduate study culture. Introduction to processes including planning and preparation, school selection, entrance examination preparation, submission of applications, writing personal statements.

courses.title: Introduction to Contemporary Middle East Politics
courses.desc: An overview of basic issues that shape the politics of the Middle East and North Africa. Themes include implication of the colonization era, nation-state formation, inter-Arab relations, nationalism, Arab-Israel conflict, Islamic resurgence, and more.

courses.title: Political Islam
courses.desc: Political Islamd is a diverse phenomenon. While noticeable barriers exist to "Islamist democracy," it is the Islamists who will define the political future of much of the Muslim world. Reviews the experience of Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Pakistan, Turkey, and Indonesia.

courses.title: Special Topics in Social Sciences
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of social sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Honors Research Workshop
courses.desc: Student develops a 10–15-page prospectus of research for the honors thesis which includes: the research question, literature review, methods of investigation, and bibliography. Student selects a faculty mentor who will supervise thesis research and writing in winter and spring.

courses.title: Honors Thesis Research
courses.prereqs: SOC SCI H190A or SPPS H190A
courses.desc: The student initiates and completes data collection for the honors thesis. A faculty mentor provides supervision and feedback on thesis chapters.

courses.title: Honors Thesis
courses.prereqs: SOC SCI H190B or SPPS H190B. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: The student completes, with the approval of the faculty mentor, an honors thesis containing: statement of the problem, literature review, research hypotheses, methods of investigation, results, discussion, and bibliography.

courses.title: Graduate-Mentored Study in the Social Sciences
courses.prereqs: Identification of a graduate student (who is in good standing) as a mentor.
courses.desc: Offers a hands-on research experience while increasing awareness of the various disciplines in the social sciences and of the requirements of graduate school.  Features graduate-mentored study under the supervision of the Associate Dean.

courses.title: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
courses.prereqs: SOC SCI 70C or SOCIOL 63. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and underserved communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.

courses.title: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
courses.desc: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and underserved communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.

courses.title: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
courses.desc: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and underserved communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.

courses.title: Field Studies in Social Policy and Public Service
courses.desc: Advanced training in qualitative and ethnographic research centered on community service. Students pursue field studies at nonprofit agencies (200 hours) to understand current social problems in underrepresented and under-served communities. Through field placement, students apply theory to practice.

courses.title: Public Service Internship
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Introduces the role of etiquette and leadership in the professional environment. With a two-unit (50 hours) or four-unit (100 hours) credit option, students intern at a nonprofit agency exploring their roles as community leaders and improving their professional skills.

courses.title: Management and Leadership Practicum-Social Science
courses.desc: Social Sciences Academic Resource Center (SSARC) Resource Mangers (RMs) report directly to the Director and Associate Director, serving as frontline resource consultants, assisting visitors with resume development, graduate and professional school planning, internship placement, and professional development.

courses.title: Educational Policy Field Studies
courses.desc: Integrates academic course work with experiential learning; examines the effects of educational policy on urban and suburban schools; explores the relationship between community service and personal academic interests; and develops awareness about the challenges of public education.

courses.title: Educational Policy Field Studies
courses.desc: Integrates academic course work with experiential learning; examines the effects of educational policy on urban and suburban schools; explores the relationship between community service and personal academic interests; and develops awareness about the challenges of public education.

courses.title: Educational Policy Field Studies
courses.desc: Integrates academic course work with experiential learning; examines the effects of educational policy on urban and suburban schools; explores the relationship between community service and personal academic interests; and develops awareness about the challenges of public education.

courses.title: Global Connect
courses.desc: Identifies factors of change that influence the twenty-first century. Students serve as mentors at high schools to introduce globalization issues through workshops and lectures. Students must submit an application and have a 3.0 or higher overall GPA.

courses.title: Professional Internship
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Students apply classroom knowledge through research projects in nonprofit agencies (local, state, and government) and the private sector. They pose solutions to agency-posed questions. Students gain field experience through 50 hours (for 2 units) or 100 (for 4 units).

courses.title: Directed Group Study
courses.desc: Directed study with Social Science faculty.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.desc: Opportunities to do research and learn new skills outside the normal classroom environment. Students participate in planned research and study activities under a written contract with a supervising UCI instructor. Students may enroll for only one 199 each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics in Mathematical Social Science
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of mathematical social science. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Mathematical Behavioral Sciences Colloquium
courses.desc: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors.

courses.title: Mathematical Behavioral Sciences Colloquium
courses.desc: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors.

courses.title: Mathematical Behavioral Sciences Colloquium
courses.desc: Weekly reports and colloquia by faculty, students, and visitors.

courses.title: Special Topics in Social Networks
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of social networks. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Population
courses.desc: Introduces the interrelationships between population and social organization. Considers measurement and explanation of historical and contemporary trends in birth rates, death rates, migration, and marriage and divorce. Case material is drawn primarily from the U.S. and other industrialized nations.

courses.title: Social Movements
courses.desc: A survey of the field of Social Movements, oriented around critical themes in the major theoretical traditions and contemporary exemplars.

courses.title: Race and Justice Studies Writing Seminar
courses.desc: A required writing-intensive seminar conducted by an instructor affiliated with the Race and Justice Studies emphasis. Students with manuscripts on relevant topics will read and critique peer manuscripts, and revise manuscripts toward completion of articles, dissertation chapters, and other publications.

courses.title: Classical Social Theory
courses.desc: Examines the development of classical sociological theory through the writings of Karl Marx, Emile Durkheim, Max Weber, Georg Simmel, and George Herbert Mead.

courses.title: Contemporary Social Theory
courses.desc: Familiarizes students with twentieth-century developments in social thought that have influenced sociological research, suggesting "what is living and what is dead" in the "classics" and offering an overview of the main outlines of recent sociological theorizing.

courses.title: Transnational Migration
courses.desc: Examines borders and boundaries as material and semiotic constructs. Drawing upon an array of literatures, but loosely situated in U.S. geo/biopolitics, explores transformative troublings of places, spaces, borders, and bodies of all sorts.

courses.title: Global Urbanization
courses.desc: Examines the spread of cities worldwide in the 20th century. What are the political and economic causes of this process? What are the social-cultural, political, and economic effects? How is contemporary urbanization linked to global restructuring of other kinds.

courses.title: Special Topics in Social Relations
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of social relations. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Origin and Evolution of Marxist Social Thought
courses.prereqs: Undergraduate course in political theory or equivalent.
courses.desc: Focuses on the genesis and evolution of Marxist social thought The "systemic" method of Marx and Engels to questions of economic production and reproduction is compared and contrasted with modern world-system grand visions, feminist-theoretic approaches, and postmodern critiques.

courses.title: Special Topics in Social Science
courses.desc: Current research in Social Science.

courses.title: Dissertation Research
courses.desc: Dissertation research with Social Science faculty.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Independent research with Social Science faculty.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Introduction to Sociology
courses.desc: Considers major sociological concepts, theories, and research findings illuminating processes of interpersonal interaction, social differentiation and stratification, integration and conflict, and change, with attention to variation in class, race/ethnic, gender, multicultural, and cross-national perspectives and experiences.

courses.title: Globalization and Transnational Sociology
courses.desc: Examines globalization and international issues from the perspective of sociology and related fields. Issues include economic globalization and global inequality, international environmental problems, international politics, trends in global culture, and global conflict.

courses.title: Social Problems
courses.desc: Focuses on how institutional and organizational features of societies generate problems for people. Particular attention directed at a set of problems related to political and economic inequality: poverty, racism, sexism, urban and population problems, the environment, the criminal justice system.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics
courses.desc: An introduction to probability and statistics. Emphasis on a thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Emphasizes examples from sociology, anthropology, and related social science disciplines.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics
courses.desc: An introduction to probability and statistics. Emphasis on a thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Emphasizes examples from sociology, anthropology, and related social science disciplines.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics
courses.desc: An introduction to probability and statistics. Emphasis on a thorough understanding of the probabilistic basis of statistical inference. Emphasizes examples from sociology, anthropology, and related social science disciplines.

courses.title: Special Topics: Methods
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of methods. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics: Theory
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Self-Identity and Society
courses.desc: Studies sociological contributions to theory and research in social psychology, with focus on the social influences on personality, attitudes, beliefs, and behavior; socialization, human groups, and social interaction.

courses.title: Special Topics: Social Psychology
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of social psychology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Small Group Dynamics
courses.desc: Deals with models for understanding behavior in small groups, including coalition formation, socialization, group norms and decision rules, leadership, conformity, group structure, and communication processes.

courses.title: City and Community
courses.desc: Examines nature, causes, and consequences of urbanization along with changing scale and complexity, demographic/ecological city growth patterns, quality of life in urban areas, processes of decision-making, and bearing of sociological investigation on public policy concerns in contemporary urban society.

courses.title: Births, Deaths, and Migration
courses.desc: Introduction to the analysis of human population including fertility, mortality dispersion, sex distribution. Attention is focused on the effects of these variables on, e.g., over-population, social disorganization, and the stability of social institutions.

courses.title: Special Topics: Structures
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of structures. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Asian American Family & Community
courses.desc: Briefly examines the history of different Asian American groups and provides an in-depth analysis of issues related to family composition, mate selection, changing gender roles, and intergenerational conflict.

courses.title: Religion and Society
courses.desc: A critical and personal examination of the varieties of religious and spiritual experiences human beings are undergoing in contemporary society. The role of conscious understanding and unconscious conditioning regarding religion and spirituality.

courses.title: Special Topics: Social Institutions and Culture
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of social institutions and culture. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Families and Intimate Relations
courses.desc: Sociological theories/research on marriage, kinship, intimacy, and divorce. Emphasis on comparing family patterns in different social classes, ethnic groups, and societies, and on relating family life to the economy and other social institutions. Topics include gender roles, child-rearing, historical change.  Materials fee.

courses.title: Race and Ethnicity
courses.desc: Focuses on racial and ethnic relations in the United States and compares them with those found in other societies. Analyzes the conditions that favor either cooperation and integration or rivalry, tension, and conflict. Appraises strategies for reducing and resolving conflicts.

courses.title: Sociology of Sexuality
courses.desc: Provides an introduction to and overview of the sociology of sex and sexuality. Considers the social meanings of sex and sexuality, the social contexts of sex and sexuality, and the social regulations of sex and sexuality.

courses.title: Gender and Race Inequality in the Workplace
courses.desc: Analysis of current state and trends in major inequality measures including the wage gap, occupational segregation, and access to managerial positions. Theories that purport to explain such differences, and the related empirical evidence, are also covered.

courses.title: Ethnic and Immigrant America
courses.desc: Focusing on Asian, Latino, and Black immigrant groups, examines the second generation's experience of straddling two cultures and growing up American. Covers topics such as assimilation, bilingualism, race relations, education, bicultural conflicts, interracial marriage, and multiracial identities.

courses.title: Special Topics: Age, Gender, Race, and Ethnicity
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of age, gender, race, and ethnicity. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics: Societies and Social Inequality
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of societies and social inequality. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Research Methods
courses.desc: Methods of data collection and analysis used by sociologists. Experimental methods, surveys, and interviews, field research and participant observation, demographic methods, historical and comparative approaches.

courses.title: Special Topics: Methods
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of methods. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Sociological Theory
courses.desc: What a theory of society is and is not. Historical and contemporary models, perspectives, and schools.

courses.title: Sociological Theory
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: What a theory of society is and is not. Historical and contemporary models, perspectives, and schools.

courses.title: Special Topics: Theory
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Game Theory and Politics I
courses.desc: Introduction to game theory and a survey of its political applications. Examples of topics covered include voting in small committees, legislatures, and mass elections; interest group activities and environmental issues; institutional design, and the evolution of cooperative behavior.

courses.title: Social Psychology of Networks
courses.desc: Review of network methods used in small group and organizational research. Discussion of social psychological literature relevant to the network of study of cognitive social structure, exchange/communication, identity negotiation, and social control. Case study of network datasets exemplifies research issues.

courses.title: Religious Traditions of Asian Americans
courses.desc: Studies the religious traditions of Asian Americans, focusing on the transplantation of religious institutions, establishment of sacred spaces, celebration of religious holidays, socialization of children, as well as birth, marriage, gender relations, death, family.

courses.title: Business Decisions
courses.prereqs: (ANTHRO 10A and ANTHRO 10B and ANTHRO 10C) or (SOCIOL 10A and SOCIOL 10B and SOCIOL 10C) or (SOC SCI 10A and SOC SCI 10B and SOC SCI 10C) or (MATH 2A and MATH 2B and (STATS 7 or MGMT 7))
courses.desc: Surveys normative and descriptive models of decision-making behavior, with an emphasis on organizational and policy contexts. Topics include rational choice theory, biases and heuristics, framing effects, and overconfidence. Management fads, panics, and herd behavior are also discussed.

courses.title: Special Topics: Social Psychology
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of social psychology. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Organizations
courses.desc: How bureaucracies, formal organizations, and voluntary associations work, how/why they grow, and where they are going. History and structure of organizational rationality; dynamics of organized groups; behavior in organizations; limits of bureaucratization and attempts to overcome these limits through decentralization.

courses.title: White-Collar Crime
courses.desc: Examines criminal activity in business and corporate enterprise, organizations, and the professions. Theories regarding the causes and control of white-collar and corporate crime are covered as well as the numerous definitions of these terms.

courses.title: Social Networks and Social Support
courses.desc: Examines the manner in which behaviors/attitudes of individuals are affected by their network ties to others. How are peoples' opportunities and well-being increased/decreased by their social networks? May include studies in mental/physical health, job seeking, separation and loss, and aging.

courses.title: Politics, Power, and Society
courses.desc: Includes an examination of the major theoretical approaches to political sociology, and the application of these ideas to the politics of advanced capitalist societies. Also considers stability and change in power structures.

courses.title: Occupations and Professions
courses.desc: What makes some jobs satisfying and others boring? How does technology influence the workplace? What changes are coming in the U.S. job market? Sociology and psychology of occupations. Students interview workers and study aspects of their occupations.

courses.title: Occupations and Professions
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: What makes some jobs satisfying and others boring?  How does technology influence the workplace?  What changes are coming in the U.S. job market?  Sociology and psychology of occupations. Students interview workers and study aspects of their occupations.

courses.title: Special Topics: Structures
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of structures. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Sociological Lens on Religion
courses.desc: Examines the effects of religious beliefs, belonging, and institutions on social dynamics, including class, gender, and racial stratification, politics, and social movements. Additional topics: the sociological significance of conversion, commitment, and secularization/sacralization.

courses.title: Medical Sociology
courses.desc: Current problems in U.S. health-care system and proposals for reform. Examines  financial barriers to access; problem of patient dumping; underinsurance; prenatal and perinatal care; child services; preventative care and needs of the elderly; minorities; low-income people; undocumented.

courses.title: Medical Sociology
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Current problems in U.S. health-care system and proposals for reform. Examines  financial barriers to access; problem of patient dumping; underinsurance; prenatal and perinatal care; child services; preventative care and needs of the elderly; minorities; low-income people; undocumented.

courses.title: Baseball and Society
courses.desc: An examination of baseball's role in American social life over the last 150 years. Issues of fraternal organizations, national development, capitalism, rationalization, race and ethnicity, gender, economic organization, labor relations, and politics are discussed.

courses.title: Baseball and Society
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: An examination of baseball's role in American social life over the last 150 years. Issues of fraternal organizations, national development, capitalism, rationalization, race and ethnicity, gender, economic organization, labor relations, and politics are discussed.

courses.title: Deviance
courses.desc: Perspectives on deviance and criminality in behavior, institution, community, and myth. The suitability of contemporary theories of deviant behavior.

courses.title: Sociology of Education
courses.desc: Focuses on education’s role in creating and redressing inequality, and in shaping how we understand our place in society. Education from cross-national and historical perspectives, and education as a vehicle for examining and solving social problems.  Course may be offered online.

courses.title: Sociology of Education
courses.desc: Focuses on education’s role in creating and redressing inequality, and in shaping how we understand our place in society. Education from cross-national and historical perspectives, and education as a vehicle for examining and solving social problems.

courses.title: Comparing European and US Societies
courses.desc: Society, culture, institutions of U.S. and European countries. Fertility to football, guns to government, work to welfare, health to housework. Cross-national approaches for understanding the world and thinking critically about taken-for-granted practices. Policies the U.S. might borrow for social issues.

courses.title: Money, Work, and Social Life
courses.desc: Sociological perspective on issues related to money and work. Consumption practices and lifestyles, jobs and organizations, issues of money in intimate relations, marriage, and households, illegal work, discrimination, economic globalization are discussed.

courses.title: Money, Work, and Social Life
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Sociological perspective on issues related to money and work. Consumption practices and lifestyles, jobs and organizations, issues of money in intimate relations, marriage, and households, illegal work, discrimination, economic globalization are discussed.

courses.title: Special Topics: Social Institutions and Culture
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of social institutions and culture. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Sociology of Sex and Gender
courses.desc: Explores complex processes contributing to social construction of gender and sexuality in the U.S. with focus on intersection of gender, race, ethnicity, sexuality, and class; evaluates how men and women are differentially constituted in family, education, work, politics, media, language.

courses.title: Sociology of Sex and Gender
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Explores complex processes contributing to social construction of gender and sexuality in the U.S. with focus on intersection of gender, race, ethnicity, sexuality, and class; evaluates how men and women are differentially constituted in family, education, work, politics, media, language.

courses.title: Sociology of Aging
courses.desc: Introduction to sociology of age, aging, and the aged. Problems posed by aging population. Life course transitions and how social organizations influence the life course. Addresses work, health, and family in later life.

courses.title: Sociology of Aging
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Introduction to sociology of age, aging, and the aged. Problems posed by aging population. Life course transitions. How social organizations influence the life course. Work, health, family in later life.

courses.title: Immigration and Inequality
courses.desc: Explores immigration, ethnicity, and inequality as interconnected social forces. International migration, propelled by global inequalities, plays a central role in the formation of multinational societies, shapes inter-group relations and patterns of ethnic inequality, and transforms the immigrants themselves.

courses.title: Racial and Ethnic Relations in the United States
courses.desc: Examines central questions and issues in the field of race and ethnicity; the emergence, maintenance, and consequences of the ethnic and racial stratification system in the United States; the future of racial and ethnic relations; and relevant public policy issues.

courses.title: Racial and Ethnic Relations in the United States
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Examines central questions and issues in the field of race and ethnicity; the emergence, maintenance, and consequences of the ethnic and racial stratification system in the United States; the future of racial and ethnic relations; and relevant public policy issues.

courses.title: Special Topics in Age, Gender, Race, and Ethnicity
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of age, gender, race, and ethnicity. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Vietnam War
courses.desc: Examines social structures and social changes in Vietnamese and U.S. societies through the study of the Vietnam War.

courses.title: U
courses.desc: Analyzes the United States war on terrorism by focusing on terrorism, the U.S. wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and changes in police powers through the Patriot Act, as well as the political leadership which directs the war.

courses.title: Environment and Society
courses.desc: Examines society's changing relationship to the natural world. Delineates different models of "nature" and then explores their institutional roots, the social responses they have generated, and their implications for social inequality.

courses.title: Revolution and Social Transformation in China
courses.desc: Introduces the major political events in Mao’s communist revolution and the social transformations afterward. Helps students understand the historic and political landscape from which China is now departing.

courses.title: Social Inequality
courses.desc: Sources, functions, and dynamics of the unequal distribution of wealth, prestige, knowledge, and power in American and other societies.

courses.title: Social Inequality
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Sources, functions, and dynamics of the unequal distribution of wealth, prestige, knowledge, and power in American and other societies.

courses.title: Protests, Movements, and Revolutions
courses.prereqs: SOCIOL 1 or POL SCI 6A or ECON 1
courses.desc: A survey of models of collective action drawn from sociology, economics, psychology, and political science. Focus on areas such as social movements, strikes, crowd psychology, cults, fads, fashions, public opinion, and symbolic and mythical elements in collective culture.

courses.title: China in the Global Age
courses.desc: Chinese society from 1949 to present. Social change in the context of political control and ideological considerations. Focus on the power structure, political decision processes, and ideological legitimation, and interplay with the Chinese community and its culture.

courses.title: International Divided Cities
courses.desc: Investigates urban divisions in international cities where deep-seated nationalistic ethnic differences create pressures for intergroup conflicts, autonomy, or territorial separation, and can incite violence. Urban political polarization as it is manifest in the urban setting.

courses.title: Immigration and Social Policy
courses.desc: Explains how people decide to migrate and how they are incorporated into a host society (both historically and currently), examines the effects of immigration on the U.S., analyzes how the framing of immigration shapes the discourse about the issue.

courses.title: Undocumented Immigrant Experiences
courses.desc: Examines the experiences of undocumented immigrants and the policies that structure their educational, economic, social, and political participation.

courses.title: Immigration and Social Policy
courses.prereqs: Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Explains how people decide to migrate and how they are incorporated into a host society (both historically and currently), examines the effects of immigration on the U.S., analyzes how the framing of immigration shapes the discourse about the issue.

courses.title: Special Topics: Societies and Social Inequality
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of societies and social inequality. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Sociology Majors Seminar
courses.desc: Students learn sociology by doing it. A modest-sized research project is planned and implemented by each student.

courses.title: Sociology Majors Seminar
courses.prereqs: SOCIOL 110. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Students learn sociology by doing it. A modest-sized research project is planned and implemented by each student.

courses.title: Honors Research and Thesis
courses.prereqs: SOCIOL H188A. Satisfactory completion of the Lower-Division Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Focuses on the design and implementation of individual research projects undertaken by senior Sociology majors. Writing projects consist of a proposal and paper on some empirical research.

courses.title: Honors Research and Thesis
courses.desc: Focuses on the design and implementation of individual research projects undertaken by senior Sociology majors. Writing projects consist of a proposal and paper on some empirical research.

courses.title: Special Topics: Honors Sequence
courses.desc: Independent honors research with Social Sciences faculty.

courses.title: Field Study
courses.desc: Field study with Sociology faculty.

courses.title: Directed Group Study
courses.desc: Directed study with Sociology faculty.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Independent research with Sociology faculty.

courses.title: Proseminar I in Sociology
courses.desc: Introduces first-year graduate students in Sociology to the current research interests of Sociology faculty, as well as to other aspects of graduate life at UCI and to the profession of sociology more generally.

courses.title: Proseminar II in Sociology
courses.desc: Focus is on second-year research projects, design, development, data gathering, analysis, and preparing oral and written presentations of the results. Students learn analytic and writing skills, gain experience with research processes, and become socialized about professional standards, customs, and institutions.

courses.title: Classical Social Theory
courses.desc: Examines the development of classical sociological theory through the writings of Karl Marx, Emile Durkheim, Max Weber, Georg Simmel, and George Herbert Mead.

courses.title: Contemporary Social Theory
courses.desc: Familiarizes students with twentieth-century developments in social thought that have influenced sociological research, suggesting "what is living and what is dead" in the "classics" and offering an overview of the main outlines of recent sociological theorizing.

courses.title: Sociology of Gender
courses.desc: An introduction to the sociology of gender in the U.S. and globally. The social construction of gender and sexuality; theoretical perspectives and feminist frameworks. Theories of economy, patriarchy, and race, and the social positions of women and men.

courses.title: Network Theory
courses.desc: An introduction to theoretical work in the field of social networks. Topics include baseline models, homphily, and propinquity, exchange and power, balance theory, diffusion and social influence, equivalence, and cohesion. Deductive use of theory to make novel predictions is emphasized.

courses.title: Special Topics: Theory
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of theory. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Research Design
courses.desc: Data collection, organization, and analysis in ethnographic or quasi-experimental settings, including interviewing, participant observations, behavior observations, and questionnaires. Research design issues include sampling, longitudinal research, and comparative research. Emphasis on the integration of qualitative and quantitative data.

courses.title: Graduate Statistics I
courses.desc: Statistics with emphasis on applications in sociology and anthropology. Examines exploratory uses of statistical tools in these fields as well as univariate, bivariate, and multivariate applications in the context of the general linear model.

courses.title: Graduate Statistics II
courses.desc: Statistics with emphasis on applications in sociology and anthropology. Examines exploratory uses of statistical tools in these fields as well as univariate, bivariate, and multivariate applications in the context of the general linear model.

courses.title: Graduate Statistics III
courses.desc: Statistics with emphasis on applications in sociology and anthropology. Examines exploratory uses of statistical tools in these fields as well as univariate, bivariate, and multivariate applications in the context of the general linear model.

courses.title: Comparative and Historical Sociological Methods
courses.desc: Topics include the logic of comparative and historical analysis techniques and the examination of exemplar works in representative problem areas.

courses.title: Interview Methods
courses.desc: Hands-on introduction to the use of interviews in social scientific research. Topics include when to use interviews and/or focus groups; how to design an interview-based study, how to conduct interviews, analyze interview data, and write up and publish interview-based results.

courses.title: Methods of Demographic Analysis
courses.desc: Introduces basic demographic methods used in social science and public health research. Topics include sources and limitations of demographic data; components of population growth; measures of nuptiality, fertility, mortality, and population mobility projection methods; and demographic models.

courses.title: Seminar Ethnographic & Qualitative Field Methods
courses.desc: Comprehensive and critical discussion of the traditions of qualitative fieldwork; detailed examination of the collection, coding, analysis, and presentation of ethnographic/qualitative field data; and close mentoring of student projects culminating in an original research paper.

courses.title: Seminar Ethnographic & Qualitative Field Methods
courses.desc: Comprehensive and critical discussion of the traditions of qualitative fieldwork; detailed examination of the collection, coding, analysis, and presentation of ethnographic/qualitative field data; and close mentoring of student projects culminating in an original research paper.

courses.title: Special Topics: Methods
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of methods. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Race and Ethnicity
courses.desc: An examination of central questions and issues in the field of race and ethnicity through a critical analysis and discussion of the principal theoretical perspectives and paradigms that have framed much of the scholarship in the area.

courses.title: Inequality
courses.desc: Theoretical and empirical approaches to the study of social and economic inequality, with special attention to race/ethnicity, class, and gender.

courses.title: Ethnic America
courses.desc: Examines critically the meaning and measurement of ethnicity, race, and nation in sociological theory and research. Theories of ethnicity are explored, along with empirical studies of the construction of ethnic and pan-ethnic identities in historical and contemporary contexts.

courses.title: Poverty and Development
courses.desc: Examines competing conceptualizations, methods of measurement, and poverty alleviation strategies widely used in developing countries. Focuses on poverty conceptualized as economic deprivation, well-being, vulnerability, and social exclusion.

courses.title: Educational Inequality
courses.desc: Focuses on macro-level explanations of inequality of schooling, particularly in the U.S. context. Explores traditional models, such as conflict, functionalism, status-attainment, cultural reproduction, and newer synthetic accounts. Emphasis on higher education access and the intersection of education and work.

courses.title: Special Topics: Social Inequality
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of social inequality. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Social Movements
courses.desc: A survey of the field of Social Movements, oriented around critical themes in the major theoretical traditions and contemporary exemplars.

courses.title: Political Sociology
courses.desc: Begins with an examination of the three major orientations to the State (Pluralist, Elitist, and Class). Next considers current topics in political sociology including the Welfare State, the New Deal, political behavior, social movements, participation, and democracy.

courses.title: Sociology of Culture
courses.desc: Major perspectives in the sociology of culture. Topics include the role of cultural dynamics in the reproduction of inequality, collective action, political and organizational decision making, emotional experience, and the social impacts of new technologies.

courses.title: Special Topics: Political Sociology and Social Movements
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of political sociology and social movements. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Global Urbanization
courses.desc: Examines the spread of cities worldwide in the 20th century. What are the political and economic causes of this process? What are the social-cultural, political, and economic effects? How is contemporary urbanization linked to global restructuring of other kinds.

courses.title: Special Topics: Global Studies and Comparative Development
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of global studies and comparative development. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Population
courses.desc: Introduces the interrelationships between population and social organization. Considers measurement and explanation of historical and contemporary trends in birth rates, death rates, migration, and marriage and divorce. Case material is drawn primarily from the U.S. and other industrialized nations.

courses.title: Immigrant America
courses.desc: The study of the causes and consequences of international migration has become one of the most vital fields of sociological theory and research. Examines principal theoretical perspectives and empirical research on contemporary immigration flows and the processes of incorporation.

courses.title: DASA Research Design
courses.desc: Data collection, organization, and analysis in population studies and demography. Research design issues include sampling, longitudinal research, and comparative research.

courses.title: Immigration and Globalization
courses.desc: Examines immigration to three leading immigrant-receiving nations: the United States, Canada, and Australia, as both cause and consequence of globalization. Specific attention to Asian migration, as well as assimilation and its relationship to multiculturalism.

courses.title: Special Topics: Social Demography
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of social demography. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Special Topics: Social Organizations and Institutions
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of social organizations and institutions. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Analysis of Social Network Data
courses.desc: Overview and application of methods for analyzing social network data. Topics include: data structures, visualization, graph theory, centrality, subgroups, positions, blockmodels, local properties, and statistical models. Social network analysis software is used to analyze a range of examples.

courses.title: Introduction to Social Networks
courses.desc: Provides a broad overview of the history, concepts, and applications of social networks. Students have the opportunity to delve deeply into applications of the network approach in their individual areas of interest.

courses.title: Theorizing Illegality and the Experiences of Undocumented Immigrants
courses.desc: Examines theories of illegality and citizenship, historical and contemporary undocumented immigrant experiences, and methodological concerns in this area of study.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Social Sciences. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Dissertation Research
courses.desc: Dissertation research with Sociology faculty.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Independent research with Sociology faculty.

courses.title: Software Engineering
courses.desc: Study of the concepts, methods, and tools for the analysis, design, construction, and measurement of complex software-intensive systems. Underlying principles emphasized. State-of-the-art software engineering and promising research areas covered, including project management.

courses.title: Analysis of Programming Languages
courses.desc: Concepts in modern programming languages, their interaction, and the relationship between programming languages and methods for large-scale, extensible software development. Empirical analysis of programming language usage.

courses.title: Requirements Engineering and Specification
courses.desc: Rigorous techniques in requirements engineering - the requirements definition phase of software development - with a focus on modeling and specification. Topics include notations and models for requirements specification; and methods, tools, and processes for software requirements elicitation, representation, analysis.

courses.title: Software Analysis and Testing
courses.desc: Studies techniques for developing confidence in software from traditional testing schemes to integrated, multitechnique analytic approaches. Considers strengths and weaknesses and explores opportunities for synergistic technique application. Emphasis is on approaches integrated into the software process.

courses.title: Software Environments
courses.desc: Study of the requirements, concepts, and architectures of comprehensive, integrated, software development and maintenance environments. Major topics include process support, object management, communication, interoperability, measurement, analysis, and user interfaces in the environment context.

courses.title: Software Architecture
courses.desc: Study of the concepts, representation techniques, development methods, and tools for architecture-centric software engineering. Topics include domain-specific software architectures, architectural styles, architecture description languages, software connectors, and dynamism in architectures.

courses.title: Applied Software Design Techniques
courses.desc: Study of concepts, representations, techniques, and case studies in structuring software systems, with an emphasis on design considerations. Topics include static and dynamic system structure, data models, abstractions, naming, protocols and application programmer interfaces.

courses.title: Information Retrieval, Filtering, and Classification
courses.prereqs: COMPSCI 161 and COMPSCI 171 and (I&C SCI 6N or MATH 3A or MATH 6G)
courses.desc: Algorithms for the storage, retrieval, filtering, and classification of textual and multimedia data. The vector space model, Boolean and probabilistic queries, and relevance feedback. Latent semantic indexing; collaborative filtering; and relationship to machine learning methods.

courses.title: Applied Data Structures and Algorithms
courses.desc: Exploration of strategies to tackle computational problems whose solutions include well-known algorithms and data structures. Topics include sorting, searching, indexing, among others.

courses.title: Network Programming
courses.desc: Exploration of networking principles and concepts for the development of distributed software. Topics include programming against well-known network protocols, ports and sockets, and network APIs.

courses.title: Database Programming
courses.desc: Exploration of software development with substantial reliance on a database for storage and retrieval of data. Topics include relational databases, structured query language, relational database management systems, APIs and libraries for database programming, among others.

courses.title: Concurrent Programming
courses.desc: Exploration of concepts and mechanisms for the development of concurrent software.  Topics include threads, locks, race conditions, and deadlocks, among others.

courses.title: GUI Programming
courses.desc: Exploration of interactive software with substantial graphical user interface elements.  Topics include libraries and frameworks for GUI programming, layout design and alternatives, event-driven programming, among others.

courses.title: Mobile Programming
courses.desc: Exploration of contemporary libraries and frameworks for construction of mobile applications. Topics include emulators, mobile development standards and patterns, energy consumption issues, screen layout, among others.

courses.title: Applied Information Retrieval
courses.desc: Exploration of principles and concepts for textual information retrieval. Topics include tokenization, inverted indexes, scored retrieval, and precision and recall.

courses.title: Neural Network Programming
courses.desc: Exploration of the concepts, terminology, and processes for training and using deep neural networks for classification problems.  Topics include tensors and tensor operations, gradient-based optimization, feature engineering and learning, and workflow of learning systems.

courses.title: Software Testing and Debugging
courses.desc: Designed to teach students how to ensure high-quality software by means of testing, debugging, and other quality assurance activities. Students learn a combination of both theoretical and practical skills, including hands-on experience with modern tools and approaches.

courses.title: Programming Styles
courses.desc: Designed to teach students the various ways software can be decomposed and put back together. Students are exposed to a variety of different programming styles and composition mechanisms.

courses.title: User Experience and Interaction
courses.desc: Provides an introduction to the basic principles of human-computer interaction (HCI) and the pragmatic aspects of usability engineering. Topics include the fundamentals of interaction, user experience, design for usability, and evaluation of products for their usability.

courses.title: Distributed Software Architecture
courses.desc: Study of software system architectures and architectural styles for large-scale distributed applications, and contemporary technologies and standards for their construction. Topics include client-server, peer-to-peer, publish-subscribe, REST, cloud computing, content distribution networks, scalability, latency, caching, and security, among others.

courses.title: Reverse Engineering and Modeling
courses.desc: Introduces theories, concepts, representations, techniques, and case studies in understanding large-scale, complex software systems. Topics include static and dynamic modeling notations, manual and (semi-)automated reverse engineering techniques, APIs, patterns, and styles. A significant, hands-on project is included.

courses.title: Software Security and Dependability
courses.desc: Principles and concepts for the design and construction of secure software. Topics include common types of software security vulnerabilities, methods for detecting vulnerabilities, design and process methodologies to improve security of software, and techniques for assessing security properties of software.

courses.title: Career and Entrepreneurship
courses.desc: Teaches practical skills for spoken, written, and electronic communication in a range of business and technical contexts, including promoting project ideas and portfolio development. Students practice their skills in classroom presentations and written exercises.

courses.title: Project Management
courses.desc: Provides an introduction to project management in software engineering from several perspectives. Topics include team behavior; globally distributed work; resource estimation, scheduling, and budgeting. Students apply their knowledge in an ongoing class project.

courses.title: Curricular Practical Training
courses.desc: Mandatory internship in which students individually work at an outside organization to gain experience with the challenges involved in the practice of software engineering.

courses.title: Capstone Project in Software Engineering
courses.desc: Quarter-long software-intensive project focusing on the design and implementation of a novel software system. Students are expected to bring to bear the concepts acquired during the program.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Spanish
courses.desc: Communicative approach with emphasis on conversational skills: the students and their environment, their experiences, and their opinions about issues. Reading and writing skills also introduced.

courses.title: Fundamentals Intensive Spanish
courses.desc: An intensive, proficiency-oriented, and task-based approach, designed to develop basic oral communicative abilities in Spanish.  Reading and writing skills, along with an an introduction to Hispanic cultures.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 1A. SPANISH 1A with a grade of C or better. Placement into SPANISH 1B is also accepted.
courses.desc: Communicative approach with emphasis on conversational skills: the students and their environment, their experiences, and their opinions about issues.  Reading and writing skills also introduced.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 1AB or SPANISH 1B or SPANISH S1AB. SPANISH 1AB with a grade of C or better. SPANISH 1B with a grade of C or better. SPANISH S1AB with a grade of B or better. Placement into SPANISH 1C is also accepted.
courses.desc: Communicative approach with emphasis on conversational skills: the students and their environment, their experiences, and their opinions about issues.  Reading and writing skills also introduced.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Spanish
courses.desc: First half of first-year Spanish in an intensified form. Communicative approach with emphasis on conversational skills.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPANISH S1AB or SPANISH 1A or SPANISH 1B. SPANISH S1AB with a grade of C or better. SPANISH 1A with a grade of C or better. SPANISH 1B with a grade of C or better. Placement into SPANISH 1B or SPANISH 1C is also accepted.
courses.desc: Second half of first-year Spanish in an intensified form. Communicative approach with emphasis on conversational skills.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 1C or SPANISH S1BC. SPANISH 1C with a grade of C or better. SPANISH S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into SPANISH 2A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Conversation, reading, and composition skills are developed using texts of literary and social interest. Emphasis on grammar review.

courses.title: Intermediate Intensive Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 1C or SPANISH S1BC. SPANISH 1C with a grade of C or better. SPANISH S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into SPANISH 2A is also accepted.
