courses.desc: Intensive intermediate course designed to improve student's abilities in reading, writing, speaking, and comprehension, including a thorough introduction to Hispanic cultures. Grammatical component of the language is gradually reviewed and tested.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 2A. SPANISH 2A with a grade of C or better. Placement into SPANISH 2B is also accepted.
courses.desc: Conversation, reading, and composition skills are developed using texts of literary and social interest. Emphasis on grammar review.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 2AB or SPANISH 2B or SPANISH S2AB. SPANISH 2AB with a grade of C or better. SPANISH 2B with a grade of C or better. SPANISH S2AB with a grade of B or better. Placement into SPANISH 2C is also accepted.
courses.desc: Conversation, reading, and composition skills are developed using texts of literary and social interest. Emphasis on grammar review.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 1C or SPANISH S1BC. SPANISH 1C with a grade of C or better. SPANISH S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into SPANISH 2A is also accepted.
courses.desc: First half of second-year Spanish in an intensified form. Conversation, reading, and composition skills are developed using texts of literary and social interest. Emphasis on grammar review.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 2B or SPANISH S2AB or SPANISH 2A. SPANISH 2B with a grade of C or better. SPANISH S2AB with a grade of C or better. SPANISH 2A with a grade of B or better. Placement into SPANISH 2B or SPANISH 2C is also accepted.
courses.desc: Second half of second-year Spanish in an intensified form. Conversation, reading, and composition skills are developed using texts of literary and social interest. Emphasis on grammar review.

courses.title: US Latino Communities
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 2C or SPANISH S2BC. SPANISH 2C with a grade of C or better. SPANISH S2BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into SPANISH 3 is also accepted.
courses.desc: Focuses on intermediate to advanced grammar and composition. Emphasis is placed on key elements of grammar, which constitutes about 70 percent of the curriculum, and composition writing, which constitutes the remaining 30 percent.

courses.title: Composition and Grammar
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 2 or SPANISH 2C or SPANISH S2BC
courses.desc: Focuses on intermediate to advanced grammar and composition in an orderly fashion.  Emphasis is placed on key elements of grammar, to constitute about 30 percent of the course, and composition writing, to constitute about 70 percent of the workload.

courses.title: Heritage Spanish: Latinidad
courses.desc: Designed for students who grew up speaking Spanish in their homes/communities, whose schooling has been primarily in English, and need additional practice writing in Spanish.

courses.title: Spanish for Heritage Speakers: Researching U
courses.desc: Designed for students who grew up speaking Spanish in their homes/communities, but whose education has been primarily in English. Focus will be on research and writing on U.S. Latino issues.

courses.title: Advanced Spanish Conversation
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 2 or SPANISH 2C or SPAN 2BC. SPANISH 2 with a grade of C or better. SPANISH 2C with a grade of C or better. SPAN 2BC with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Designed to improve the fluency of non-native speakers of Spanish.  Concentrates on the expansion of vocabulary, as well as listening and speaking skills.  Not open to native or semi-native speakers of Spanish.

courses.title: Hispanic Literatures for Nonmajors
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 2 or SPANISH 2C or SPANISH S2BC
courses.desc: Focuses on major Spanish and Latin American literary texts within a historical and theoretical perspective. Taught in English with literary texts read in the original language.

courses.title: Latin America, U
courses.desc: Introduction (for non-majors) to the culture of the Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking worlds (Europe, Latin America, U.S., Africa).  May focus on any time period.  Taught in english.

courses.title: Mexico and Central America: A Survey
courses.desc: Panoramic view of Mexico and Central America examining key texts throughout history. Shows the richness of the culture, and an appraisal of various forms of representation, including images, chronicles, novels, essays, poems, and  a film. Taught in English.

courses.title: Mexico and Central America: A Survey
courses.prereqs: Placement into SPANISH 2A or higher via Spanish Placement Test B is required.
courses.desc: Panoramic view of Mexico and Central America examining key texts throughout history. Shows the richness of the culture, and an appraisal of various forms of representation, including images, chronicles, novels, essays, poems, and a film. Taught in Spanish.

courses.title: The Culture of the Visual Image in Latin America
courses.desc: A survey of visual forms of expression which have endured through more than five centuries of pre-colonial, colonial, and independent Latin America. Forms to be treated in the class include painting, monuments, sculpture, urban planning, graffiti, comics, and photography.

courses.title: Latinx, Multilingualism, and Social Justice
courses.desc: Explores the role of multilingualism (Spanish, indigenous languages, Latino English) in Latinx social justice movements in the United States with an emphasis on California. Course is taught in English.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Spanish (with Emphasis on Reading)
courses.prereqs: Does not serve as prerequisite for any higher-level Spanish courses.
courses.desc: Designed for students interested in acquiring a solid reading knowledge of Spanish, and to facilitate the understanding and translating of Spanish texts covering a variety of disciplines.  Does not fulfill any undergraduate foreign language requirement.  Taught in English.

courses.title: Introduction to Iberian Literature and Culture
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Introduction to the major authors and movements of Iberian literature and culture from the Middle Ages to the present.

courses.title: Introductory Studies to Latin American Literature and Culture
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: A historical overview of Latin American literature and culture mainly focused on canonical texts. Topics include colonialism and postcolonialism, the nation, indigenismo, gender, and literary movements. Also introduces literary analysis, research methods, and cultural critique.

courses.title: Writing in Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Focuses on the use of writing as a medium to encourage critical thinking and the practical analysis of literary texts, as well as the study of historical and social issues in the Spanish-speaking world.

courses.title: Spanish Communication
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Designed to help students develop Spanish oral skills by exposing them to different verbal Spanish language registers. Special emphasis placed on abilities essential to professional or academic careers. Intended for Spanish majors as an important component of their overall education.

courses.title: Advanced Spanish Grammar
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Designed for students who have demonstrated a substantial level of proficiency in their studies of the Spanish language. Takes thorough approach to advanced grammatical problems, in order to assist students in their mastery of the elements of the Spanish language.

courses.title: Topics in Peninsular Literature and Cultures
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Topics in Peninsular literature and cultures.

courses.title: Topics in Latin American Literature and Cultures
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Topics in Latin American literature and cultures.

courses.title: U
courses.desc: Focuses on aspects of literature, art, cultural production, and history of the multifaceted Latino cultures that have developed within the United States.  Focuses on one group, such as Caribbean Americans, Chicanos, Central Americans, or a comparative perspective of several groups.

courses.title: Spanish Phonetics
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Introduction to fundamental notions of Spanish phonetics. Particular attention paid to problems of pronunciation that arise in native and non-native speakers of Spanish due to interference between Spanish and English. Phonology (the system that underlies phonetics) and Spanish dialectology included.

courses.title: Introduction to Spanish Linguistics
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Application of basic notions of linguistics to Spanish, Spanish phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics. Special attention to the application of linguistics to the teaching of Spanish.

courses.title: Topics in Medieval Spanish Literature and Culture
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Medieval literature in Spain from the ninth century to 1500. Works of lyric and epic poetry, prose fiction, and nonfiction. Substantial historical and cultural background explored.

courses.title: Textual Analysis and Interpretation
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Focus on analysis and interpretation of literary texts. Emphasis on narrative, poetry, theater/performance, and visual media. Introduces students to major currents in theoretical thought, such as cultural studies, postmodernism, and others. Oral presentations and short essays required. Taught in Spanish.

courses.title: Topics in Golden Age Literature and Culture
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Golden Age Literature in Spain, including the Renaissance and Baroque periods. Works of poetry, narrative, and theater. Historical and cultural background.

courses.title: Topics in 18th and 19th Century Spanish Literature and Culture
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: The main literary and ideological trends in 18th and 19th century Spain, including the enlightenment, romanticism, realism, and naturalism.

courses.title: Topics in 20th and 21st Century Spanish Literature and Culture
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: 20th century Spanish authors. Works of poetry, narrative, or theater. Historical context of the period and principles of literary theory.

courses.title: Topics in Latin American Colonial Literature and Culture
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Topics in Latin American colonial literature and culture.

courses.title: Topics in Latin American Literature and Culture of the 19th Century
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Topics in Latin American literature and culture of the 19th century.

courses.title: Topics in Latin American Literature and Culture of the 20th Century
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Topics in Latin American literature and culture of the 20th century.

courses.title: Topics in Chicano Literature and Culture
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of Chicano/Latino Studies. Topics addressed vary each quarter. Taught in English.

courses.title: Topics in Literature in Translation
courses.desc: Study of texts by modern and contemporary Peninsular, Latin American, and/or U.S. Latino writers in translation. Taught in English. Not applicable toward Spanish major or minor requirements.

courses.title: Topics in Luso-Hispanic Film Studies
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Study of Peninsular, Latin-American, and/or U.S. Latino film. Taught in English or Spanish.

courses.title: Selected Topics in Peninsular Literature and Culture
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Selection of representative topics in Spanish and/or Portuguese literature and culture.

courses.title: Selected Topics in Latin American Literature and Culture
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Selection of representative topics in the history of Latin American literature and culture.

courses.title: Selected Topics in Spanish Linguistics
courses.prereqs: SPANISH 3 or SPANISH 3H. Placement into SPANISH 101A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Major topics in Spanish linguistics.

courses.title: Colloquium
courses.desc: Specialized, discussion-based course dealing primarily with a research topic that reflects the instructor's current intellectual interests. Required oral presentation(s) and final research paper. Limited to 15 students.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.desc: Research paper required.

courses.title: History of the Spanish Language
courses.desc: Diachronic survey of phonological changes from Latin to Old Spanish to Modern Spanish. Focuses in Castilian including Romance languages and other peninsula dialects for comparative purposes. Morphological changes.

courses.title: Spanish in Contact
courses.desc: Sociohistorical and linguistic overview of Spanish in contact with Basque, Catalan, English, German, American Indian, and African languages in Spain, Latin America, and the United States. Examines theories about language contact, and linguistic changes in Spanish phonology and grammar.

courses.title: Spanish Dialectology
courses.desc: Phonological, morphological, and syntactic variations in Spanish as spoken in the Hispanic world, from synchronic and diachronic points of view.  The study of Spanish as spoken in the United States.

courses.title: Topics in Medieval Iberia
courses.desc: Topics in medieval Spanish literature.

courses.title: Topics in Golden Age Literature and Culture
courses.desc: Topics in Golden Age literature and culture.

courses.title: Topics  in Enlightenment and Romanticism
courses.desc: Topics in Enlightenment and Romanticism.

courses.title: Topics  in Nineteenth Century
courses.desc: Topics in nineteenth-century Spanish literature and culture.

courses.title: Topics in Twentieth Century
courses.desc: Topics in twentieth-century Spanish literature and culture.

courses.title: Topics in Iberian Studies
courses.desc: Cross-cultural connections and interactions between different ethnicities in the Iberian Peninsula.

courses.title: Topics in Colonial Latin America
courses.desc: Topics in Colonial Latin America.

courses.title: Topics in Nineteenth-Century Latin America
courses.desc: Topics in nineteenth-century Latin America.

courses.title: Topics in Twentieth-Century Latin America
courses.desc: Topics in twentieth-century Latin America.

courses.title: Topics in Latin America
courses.desc: Topics in Latin America.

courses.title: Topics in Trans-Oceanic Studies
courses.desc: Focuses on meaningful connections between different geographical and cultural areas.

courses.title: Topics in Literary Theory I
courses.desc: Traces the development of Western literary critical principles from Aristotle to the twentieth century through selected readings of key figures in intellectual history (Aristotle, St. Augustine, Descartes, Kant, Hegel, Marx, Nietzsche, William James, Freud).

courses.title: Topics in Literary Theory II
courses.desc: Study of major critical movements of the twentieth century, from Modernism's varied trends to those of the Postmodern/Postcolonial period. Emphasis on the development of prior critical discourses as well as revisionary theories.

courses.title: Special Topics in Theory
courses.desc: Focus on issues related to critical theory, theory of literature, cultural criticism and visual arts as they pertain specifically to Latin America, Spain, Portugal, and Brazil. Topics vary. Examples: Latin American cultural studies; theory, film, and media in post-war Spain.

courses.title: Topics in Luso-Hispanic Film
courses.desc: Topics in Luso-Hispanic Film.

courses.title: Topics in Chicano Literature and Culture
courses.desc: Topics in Chicano Literature and Culture.

courses.title: Topics in U
courses.desc: Topics in U.S. Latino Literature and Culture.

courses.title: Seminar in Spanish
courses.desc: Topics in Spanish.

courses.title: Creative Writing Workshop in Spanish/English
courses.desc: Discussion of theory and practice of creative writing.  Focus on critical analysis of participant's work in progress.  Texts may be written in Spanish and/or English and may be written in poetry or prose format.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.desc: Individual Study.

courses.title: Directed Reading
courses.desc: Directed Reading in Spanish.

courses.title: Teaching Practicum
courses.desc: Teaching Practicum.

courses.title: Dissertation Research
courses.desc: Dissertation Research.

courses.title: University Teaching
courses.desc: Limited to Teaching Assistants.

courses.title: Seminar in Data Science
courses.desc: An introduction to the field of Data Science; intended for entering freshman and transfers.

courses.title: Basic Statistics
courses.desc: Introduces basic inferential statistics including confidence intervals and hypothesis testing on means and proportions, t-distribution, Chi Square, regression and correlation. F-distribution and nonparametric statistics included if time permits.

courses.title: Introduction to Biological Statistics
courses.desc: Introductory statistical techniques used to collect and analyze experimental and observational data from health sciences and biology. Includes exploration of data, probability and sampling distributions, basic statistical inference for means and proportions, linear regression, and analysis of variance.

courses.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics for Computer Science
courses.desc: Introduction to the basic concepts of probability and statistics with discussion of applications to computer science.

courses.title: Statistical Computing and Exploratory Data Analysis
courses.desc: Introduces key concepts in statistical computing. Techniques such as exploratory data analysis, data visualization, simulation, and optimization methods, will be presented in the context of data analysis within a statistical computing environment.

courses.title: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis I
courses.prereqs: STATS 7 or STATS 8 or AP90 or (STATS 120A and STATS 120B and STATS 120C). AP90 with a minimum score of 3
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing data from experiments and surveys. Methods covered include two-sample procedures, analysis of variance, simple and multiple linear regression.

courses.title: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis II
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing data from surveys or experiments. Emphasizes application and understanding of methods for categorical data including contingency tables, logistic and Poisson regression, loglinear models.

courses.title: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis III
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing longitudinal data from experiments and cohort studies. Topics covered include survival methods for censored time-to-event data, linear mixed models, non-linear mixed effects models, and generalized estimating equations.

courses.title: Introduction to Bayesian Data Analysis
courses.desc: Basic Bayesian concepts and methods with emphasis on data analysis. Special emphasis on specification of prior distributions. Development for one-two samples and on to binary, Poisson, and linear regression. Analyses performed using free OpenBugs software.

courses.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics I
courses.prereqs: MATH 2A and MATH 2B and (MATH 2D or MATH 4)
courses.desc: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Axiomatic definition of probability, random variables, probability distributions, expectation.

courses.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics II
courses.desc: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Point estimation, interval estimating, and testing hypotheses, Bayesian approaches to inference.

courses.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics III
courses.prereqs: STATS 120B and (MATH 3A or MATH 6G or I&C SCI 6N)
courses.desc: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Linear regression, analysis or variance, model checking.

courses.title: Multivariate Statistical Methods
courses.desc: Theory and application of multivariate statistical methods. Topics include statistical inference for the multivariate normal model and its extensions to multiple samples and regression, use of statistical packages for data visualization and reduction, discriminant analysis, cluster analysis, and factor analysis.

courses.title: Project in Data Science I
courses.prereqs: STATS 68 and STATS 112 and IN4MATX 43 and COMPSCI 122A and COMPSCI 161 and COMPSCI 178
courses.desc: Problem definition and analysis, data representation, algorithm selection, solution validation, and results presentation. Students do team projects and lectures cover analysis alternatives, project planning, and data analysis issues. First quarter emphasizes approach selection, project planning, and experimental design.

courses.title: Project in Data Science II
courses.prereqs: STATS 170A. In Progress (IP) grade for STATS 170A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Problem definition and analysis, data representation, algorithm selection, solution validation, and results presentation. Students do team projects and lectures cover analysis alternatives, project planning, and data analysis issues. Second quarter emphasizes project execution and analysis, and presentation of results.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.desc: Individual research or investigations under the direction of an individual faculty member.

courses.title: Intermediate Probability and Statistical Theory
courses.desc: Basics of probability theory, random variables and basic transformations, univariate distributions—discrete and continuous, multivariate distributions.

courses.title: Intermediate Probability and Statistical Theory
courses.desc: Random samples, transformations, limit laws, normal distribution theory, introduction to stochastic processes, data reduction, point estimation (maximum likelihood).

courses.title: Intermediate Probability and Statistical Theory
courses.desc: Interval estimation, hypothesis testing, decision theory and Bayesian inference, basic linear model theory.

courses.title: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis I
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing data from experiments and surveys. Methods covered include two-sample procedures, analysis of variance, simple and multiple linear regression.

courses.title: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis II
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing data from surveys or experiments. Emphasizes application and understanding of methods for categorical data including contingency tables, logistic and Poisson regression, loglinear models.

courses.title: Statistical Methods for Data Analysis III
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing longitudinal data from experiments and cohort studies. Topics covered include survival methods for censored time-to-event data, linear mixed models, non-linear mixed effects models, and generalized estimating equations.

courses.title: Introduction to Bayesian Data Analysis
courses.desc: Basic Bayesian concepts and methods with emphasis on data analysis.  Special emphasis on specification of prior distributions.  Development for one-two samples and on to binary, Poisson and linear regression.  Analyses performed using free OpenBugs software.

courses.title: Statistical Methods I: Linear Models
courses.prereqs: Knowledge of basic statistics, calculus, linear algebra.
courses.desc: Statistical methods for analyzing data from surveys and experiments. Topics include randomization and model-based inference, two-sample methods, analysis of variance, linear regression and model diagnostics.

courses.title: Statistical Methods I: Linear Models
courses.prereqs: Knowledge of basic statistics (at the level of STATS 7), calculus, and linear algebra.
courses.desc: Statistical methods for analyzing data from surveys and experiments. Topics include randomization and model-based inference, two-sample methods, analysis of variance, linear regression, and model diagnostics.

courses.title: Statistical Methods II: Categorical Data
courses.prereqs: STATS 210. May not be taken for graduate credit by Ph.D. students in Statistics.
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing discrete and non-normal outcomes. Emphasizes the development and application of methods for categorical data, including contingency tables, logistic and Poisson regression, loglinear models.

courses.title: Statistical Methods III: Longitudinal Data
courses.prereqs: STATS 210B. May not be taken for graduate credit by Ph.D. students in Statistics.
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical methods for analyzing longitudinal outcomes. Emphasizes the development and application of regression methods for correlated and censored outcomes. Methods for continuous and discrete correlated outcomes, as well as censored outcomes, are covered.

courses.title: Statistical Methods II: Generalized Linear Models
courses.desc: Development of the theory and application of generalized linear models. Topics include likelihood estimation and asymptotic distributional theory for exponential families, quasi-likelihood and mixed model development. Emphasizes methodological development and application to real scientific problems.

courses.title: Statistical Methods III: Methods for Correlated Data
courses.desc: Development and application of statistical methods for analyzing corrected data. Topics covered include repeated measures ANOVA, linear mixed models, non-linear mixed effects models, and generalized estimating equations.  Emphasizes both theoretical development and application of the presented methodology.

courses.title: Advanced Probability and Statistics Topics
courses.desc: Advanced topics in probability and statistical inference including measure theoretic probability, large sample theory, decision theory, resampling and Monte Carlo methods, nonparametric methods.

courses.title: Advanced Probability and Statistics Topics
courses.desc: Advanced topics in probability and statistical inference, including measure theoretic probability, large sample theory, decision theory, resampling and Monte Carlo methods, nonparametric methods.

courses.title: Bayesian Statistical Analysis
courses.desc: Introduction to the Bayesian approach to statistical inference. Topics include univariate and multivariate models, choice of prior distributions, hierarchical models, computation including Markov chain Monte Carlo, model checking, and model selection.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Modern Bayesian Statistical Inference
courses.desc: Modern Bayesian Statistics: selected topics from theory of Markov chains, application of theory to modern methods of Markov chain Monte Carlo sampling; Bayesian non-parametric and semiparametric modeling, including Dirichlet Process Mixtures; Mixtures of Polya Trees.

courses.title: Statistical Computing Methods
courses.prereqs: Two quarters of upper-division or graduate training in probability and statistics.
courses.desc: Numerical computations and algorithms with applications in statistics. Topics include optimization methods including the EM algorithm, random number generation and simulation, Markov chain simulation tools, and numerical integration.

courses.title: Modern Data Analysis Methods
courses.prereqs: STATS 120C and STATS 205 and (STATS 201 or STATS 210)
courses.desc: Introduces selected modern tools for data analysis. Emphasizes use of computational and resampling techniques for data analyses when the data do not conform to standard toolbox of regression models and/or complexity of modeling problem threatens validity of standard methods.

courses.title: Multivariate Statistical Methods
courses.desc: Theory and application of multivariate statistical methods. Topics include statistical inference for the multivariate normal model and its extensions to multiple samples and regression, use of statistical packages for data visualization and reduction, discriminant analysis, cluster analysis, and factor analysis.

courses.title: Time Series Analysis
courses.desc: Statistical models for analysis of time series from time and frequency domain perspectives. Emphasizes theory and application of time series data analysis methods. Topics include ARMA/ARIMA models, model identification/estimation, linear operators, Fourier analysis, spectral estimation, state space models, Kalman filter.

courses.title: Biostatistics
courses.desc: Statistical methods commonly used to analyze data arising from clinical studies. Topics include analysis of observational studies and randomized clinical trials, techniques in the analysis of survival and longitudinal data, approaches to handling missing data, meta-analysis, nonparametric methods.

courses.title: Introduction to Statistical Genetics
courses.prereqs: Two quarters of upper-division or graduate training in statistical methods.
courses.desc: Provides students with knowledge of the basic principles, concepts, and methods used in statistical genetic research. Topics include principles of population genetics, and statistical methods for family- and population-based studies.

courses.title: Inference with Missing Data
courses.desc: Statistical methods and theory useful for analysis of multivariate data with partially observed variables. Bayesian and likelihood-based methods developed. Topics include EM-type algorithms, MCMC samplers, multiple imputation, and general location model. Applications from economics, education, and medicine are discussed.

courses.title: Theory and Practice of Sample Surveys
courses.desc: Basic techniques and statistical methods used in designing surveys and analyzing collected survey data. Topics include simple random sampling, ratio and regression estimates, stratified sampling, cluster sampling, sampling with unequal probabilities, multistage sampling, and methods to handle nonresponse.

courses.title: Causal Inference
courses.desc: Various approaches to causal inference focusing on the Rubin causal model and propensity-score methods. Topics include randomized experiments, observational studies, non-compliance, ignorable and non-ignorable treatment assignment, instrumental variables, and sensitivity analysis. Applications from economics, politics, education, and medicine.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes
courses.desc: Introduction to the theory and application of stochastic processes. Topics include Markov chains, continuous-time Markov processes, Poisson processes, and Brownian motion. Applications include Markov chain Monte Carlo methods and financial modeling (for example, option pricing).

courses.title: Statistical Consulting
courses.prereqs: STATS 203 or STATS 212 or STATS 210C. STATS 203 with a grade of B or better. STATS 212 with a grade of B or better. STATS 210C with a grade of B or better
courses.desc: Training in collaborative research and practical application of statistics. Emphasis on effective communication as it relates to identifying scientific objectives, formulating a statistical analysis plan, choice of statistical methods, and interpretation of results and their limitations to non-statisticians.

courses.title: Seminar in Statistics
courses.desc: Periodic seminar series covering topics of current research in statistics and its application.

courses.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics I
courses.desc: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Axiomatic definition of probability, random variables, probability distributions, expectation.

courses.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics II
courses.desc: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Point estimation, interval estimating, and testing hypotheses, Bayesian approaches to inference.

courses.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics III
courses.desc: Introduction to basic principles of probability and statistical inference. Contingency table analysis, linear regression, analysis of variance, model checking.

courses.title: Special Topics in Statistics
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas of statistics. Topics addressed vary each quarter.

courses.title: Thesis Supervision
courses.desc: Individual research or investigation conducted in preparation for the M.S. thesis option or the dissertation requirements for the Ph.D. program.

courses.title: Individual Study
courses.desc: Individual research or investigation under the direction of an individual faculty member.

courses.title: Washington DC Internship
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: UCDC 180
Selected for Washington DC Center Program.
courses.desc: Supervised internship (20-40 hours per week) in Washington DC government, nonprofit, or private institution consistent with student's interest.

courses.title: Washington-Themed Seminar
courses.prereqs: Selected for Washington DC Center Program.
courses.desc: UCDC core course (multiple topics offered each quarter). Enhances students' experiential learning and imparts knowledge and skills to help them transition into public service/private sector positions. One core course per quarter mandatory for all participants in Washington DC Center Program.

courses.title: Washington DC Elective
courses.prereqs: Selected for Washington DC Center Program.
courses.desc: Studies in selected areas related to the UC Washington, DC Center Program (UCDC).

courses.title: Student Participation
courses.prereqs: Project must be approved by a Student Affairs Department head and the instructor.
courses.desc: Campus projects with a University department to enrich academic growth and development as well as academic growth and development of UCI. Includes 30 hours per quarter working on proposed project under faculty/staff supervision. Paper required.

courses.title: Student Participation
courses.desc: Campus projects with a University department to enrich academic growth and development as well as academic growth and development of UCI. Includes 30 hours per quarter working on proposed project under faculty/staff supervision. Paper required.

courses.title: Student Participation
courses.desc: Campus projects with a University department to enrich academic growth and development as well as academic growth and development of UCI. Includes 30 hours per quarter working on proposed project under faculty/staff supervision. Paper required.

courses.title: Freshman Experience
courses.desc: An introduction to the freshman experience provides an overview of the University's aims and resources and exploration of developmental theories and skills necessary for academic success. Attention is also paid to questions of personal development and major choice.  Materials fee.

courses.title: Mini-Seminars
courses.desc: Designed primarily for freshmen as introduction to scholarly inquiry. Each section is taught by a faculty member from one of the academic disciplines and presents interesting and challenging topics representing the instructor's interest. Students participate in discussions, presentations, and projects.

courses.title: Transfer Student Seminars
courses.desc: Designed primarily for transfer students during their first year at UCI. Each section is taught by a faculty member from one of the academic disciplines as introduction to scholarly inquiry in their discipline. Students participate in discussions, presentations, and projects.

courses.title: University Studies International Village Seminar
courses.desc: Seminars held in International Village that are specifically designed to either (a) introduce visiting international students to the U.S. and/or local area and institutions or (b) engage both international and U.S. students in discussion of topics of international interest.

courses.title: UTeach: Student-Taught Seminar
courses.desc: Student-taught seminar courses on selected topics. Topics vary each year according to the interest of the students teaching the classes.

courses.title: Introduction to Civic and Community Engagement
courses.desc: Provides a foundation for understanding the role of public scholarship, civic engagement, and social action, and the relationship between service learning and engaged citizenship. Introduces key theoretical and research methodologies on the traditions and innovations of civic and community engagement.

courses.title: Introduction to Global Sustainability I
courses.desc: Introduces Earth as a system and living planet. Examines physical and biological resources as well as energy, water, climate, and ecosystems. Introduces and applies analytic lens of environmental, social, and economic sustainability to examine human impacts and resource use.

courses.title: Introduction to Global Sustainability II
courses.desc: Introduces Earth as a system and living planet. Examines physical and biological resources as well as energy, water, climate, and ecosystems. Introduces and applies analytic lens of environmental, social, and economic sustainability to examine human impacts and resource use.

courses.title: Introduction to Global Sustainability III
courses.desc: Introduces Earth as a system and living planet. Examines physical and biological resources as well as energy, water, climate, and ecosystems. Introduces and applies analytic lens of environmental, social, and economic sustainability to examine human impacts and resource use.

courses.title: Consciousness I
courses.prereqs: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Introduces students to the theory of consciousness in the disciplines of cognitive science, philosophy, literature, psychoanalysis, and fine arts as represented in the genres of poetry, fiction, and film.

courses.title: Consciousness II
courses.prereqs: UNI STU 15A. Prerequisite or corequisite: WRITING 39B. WRITING 39B with a grade of C or better.
courses.desc: Introduces students to the theory of consciousness in the disciplines of cognitive science, philosophy, literature, psychoanalysis, and fine arts as represented in the genres of poetry, fiction, and film.

courses.title: Consciousness III
courses.prereqs: UNI STU 15B and WRITING 39B. WRITING 39B with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Introduces students to the theory of consciousness in the disciplines of cognitive science, philosophy, literature, psychoanalysis, and fine arts as represented in the genres of poetry, fiction, and film.

courses.title: How Race Is Made I
courses.prereqs: Satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing requirement.
courses.desc: Introduces students to an examination of how race is "made" in America and the consequences of this construction through a variety of lenses: historical, legal, anthropological, sociological, and pop culture.

courses.title: How Race Is Made II
courses.prereqs: UNI STU 16A. Prerequisite or corequisite: WRITING 39B. WRITING 39B with a grade of C or better.
courses.desc: Introduces students to an examination of how race is "made" in America and the consequences of this construction through a variety of lenses: historical, legal, anthropological, sociological, and pop culture.

courses.title: How Race Is Made III
courses.prereqs: UNI STU 16B and WRITING 39B. WRITING 39B with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Introduces students to an examination of how race is "made" in America and the consequences of this construction through a variety of lenses: historical, legal, anthropological, sociological, and pop culture.

courses.title: Water III
courses.prereqs: UNI STU 17B and (WRITING 39B or HUMAN 1B). WRITING 39B with a grade of C or better. HUMAN 1B with a grade of C or better
courses.desc: Introduces students to water as a global and contested resource across space, time, and peoples from a scientific, historical and policy perspective.  Wherever possible, examples are drawn from the local environment.

courses.title: Sankofa Project
courses.desc: The purpose of this course is to strengthen intercultural understanding and cooperation among UCI students.

courses.title: Topics in Illuminations
courses.desc: This course connects students to Illuminations, the Chancellor’s Arts and Culture Initiative. Students will attend five Illuminations-sponsored events and engage in brief preparatory and reflective activities in response to these events.

courses.title: Graduate School Opportunities and Preparation
courses.desc: Explores the opportunities associated with graduate school by considering a wide range of disciplines and career paths. Reviews professional and academic paths in graduate school and the ways to prepare for a chosen path.

courses.title: Pathways to University Success
courses.desc: Helps first-year students transition to UC Irvine and promotes a successful University experience. Students learn about academic resources and programs that support acclimation to the campus and enhance academic development through lectures, discussions, and a range of co-curricular activities.

courses.title: Bridges to University Success
courses.desc: Helps first-year students transition to UC Irvine and promotes a successful University experience. Students learn about academic resources/programs that support acclimation to the campus and enhance academic development through lectures, writing laboratories, discussions, and a range of co-curricular activities.

courses.title: Leading from Within
courses.desc: Students examine characteristics and behaviors of effective leaders. Study the history and theoretical framework for understanding effective leadership. In addition, examine their own leadership strengths and weakness and become familiar with the theory behind and use of comprehensive self-assessment tools.

courses.title: Leading Others
courses.desc: Students examine best practices within a team environment. They learn goal setting, diagnosing performance problems, designing solutions, and recognizing relevant differences in culture, priorities, and values within a team through lectures, writing, discussions, and practical activities.

courses.title: Leading Change
courses.desc: Focused on a global viewpoint, students learn the theoretical framework behind innovation and change management. Develop innovative solutions to real-world challenges, design strategies to bring an expansive vision into fruition, and learn to communicate a vision and strategies.

courses.title: Strategies for Success
courses.desc: Designed to develop good study skills in technical fields and the participation of students as active learners in their education. Topics include time management, analytical thinking, text analysis, academic survival strategies, and goal setting.

courses.title: Doing Research in the Community
courses.desc: Critically reimagines the research endeavor and its participants/outcomes. Grapples with methods, values, and relationships involved in research. Explores alternative conceptions of research; focus is community-based. Students work in teams on real-world community research projects with faculty mentors and community partners.

courses.title: Introduction to Research
courses.desc: Introduces new transfer students to research culture of the University. Students learn about the importance of research and creative activities as they are framed in a broad range of disciplines and are introduced to general research methods and approaches.

courses.title: Advanced Internship in Undergraduate Education
courses.prereqs: UNI AFF 1A and UNI AFF 1B and UNI AFF 1C
courses.desc: Advanced interns have a year's internship experience and return to contribute to Undergraduate Education programs in a leadership position. Students work three-five hours per week in a DUE office to coordinate or lead less-experienced interns and/or events.

courses.title: Methods and Application in Small Group Instruction
courses.desc: Explores various theories and methods of learning and development and their practical application in small group settings. Peer tutors receive instruction in the design, implementation, and evaluation of an effective learning environment for undergraduate students.

courses.title: Pedagogy of Small Group Facilitation - LAs
courses.desc: Overview and readings in evidence-based instruction for undergraduate learning assistants. LAs receive instruction, training, and feedback on effective small group facilitation and active learning. To be taken while serving as a learning assistant in a course.

courses.title: Campuswide Honors Thesis Seminar
courses.desc: Supports the honors thesis research activities of Campuswide Honors Program students. Students set research goals, discuss, and develop their research interests.

courses.title: Campuswide Honors Thesis Seminar
courses.prereqs:
Corequisite: Students must sign up separately for 8 units of independent study with faculty mentors.
UNI STU H176A
courses.desc: Supports the honors thesis research activities of Campuswide Honors Program students. Students work with each other to improve both written and spoken presentations of their results.

courses.title: Internship in Civic and Community Engagement
courses.desc: Provides an opportunity to extend learning into a community-based setting addressing important social, environmental, and public issues. The internship project has a creative and scholarly component where students initiate their own action or inquiry experience.

courses.title: Teaching Seminar: Theory and Practice
courses.desc: For students selected to be discussion leaders for University Studies 2. Models of teaching, developmental theory applied to college freshmen, curriculum development. Practice of teaching techniques and group management skills.

courses.title: Group Project for Discussion Leaders
courses.desc: For discussion leaders for University Studies 2. Weekly discussion group training for leading effective groups in addition to evaluations of weekly discussion sections and completion of a special project on issues of freshman development.  Materials fee.

courses.title: Internship
courses.desc: Enables students from all majors to receive credit for an approved internship on or off-campus.  Internship sites may be public or private, for profit or non-profit agencies, organizations, companies, or corporations offering paid or unpaid learning experiences.

courses.title: Engaged Leadership
courses.desc: Three-quarter series on civic education theory, the civic mission of higher education, and community-based action research methods. Provides students with a solid grounding in civic education theory while also creating opportunities for students to practice civic habits.

courses.title: Engaged Leadership
courses.desc: Three-quarter series on civic education theory, the civic mission of higher education, and community-based action research methods. Provides students with a solid grounding in civic education theory while also creating opportunities for students to practice civic habits.

courses.title: Engaged Leadership
courses.desc: Three-quarter series on civic education theory, the civic mission of higher education, and community-based action research methods. Provides students with a solid grounding in civic education theory while also creating opportunities for students to practice civic habits.

courses.title: Directed Studies in Undergraduate Education
courses.desc: Students do directed study (research, readings, etc.) on a topic related to Undergraduate Education under the supervision of one of the faculty who serve as Deans or Faculty Directors in the Division of Undergraduate Education.

courses.title: UTeach Special Study
courses.desc: Students accepted to teach a UTeach course in spring quarter enroll in Special or Independent Study with their faculty mentor during the preceding fall quarter to develop their detailed course syllabus.

courses.title: UTeach: Teaching Theory and Practice
courses.desc: Students accepted to teach a UTeach course in spring quarter enroll during the winter to develop their teaching skills in preparation for teaching the following quarter.

courses.title: UTeach: Teaching Practicum
courses.desc: Students selected to teach in the UTeach Program teach their courses and meet weekly in a seminar to continue to develop and enhance their teaching skills.

courses.title: Study Abroad Experiential Learning
courses.desc: Study abroad on an approved program. Complete critical reflection (written paper, blog, etc.) submitted no later than the end of the quarter following the completion of the study abroad program. Enroll while studying abroad or the quarter immediately following return.

courses.title: Reflections While Abroad
courses.desc: For students while they are studying abroad; maximizing learning outcomes by critically reflecting on learning experiences while abroad. Topics include cultural observations, professional issues, cultural competence, etc. Participants are located in different countries around the world.

courses.title: Internship Plus
courses.desc: Provides training and development of career readiness competencies in parallel with a student’s internship experience. Internship sites may be public or private, for profit or non-profit agencies, organizations, companies, or corporations offering paid or unpaid learning experiences.

courses.title: Mentored Learning Assistant Field Work
courses.desc: Oversight of trained learning assistants by the course instructor, including training in the discipline and responsibilities associated with supporting active group work. Instructor mentors LAs in how assisting small groups supports their career goals.

courses.title: Graduate Legal Studies
courses.desc: Monthly faculty/student colloquium to present and discuss socio-legal related research/issues. Course convened by Law School faculty with other faculty participation. Required for PLGS students enrolled in Law portion of degree.

courses.title: California Community College Internship
courses.desc: The California Community College Internship offers graduate students the opportunity to learn about faculty life, governance, and teaching at local community colleges. Structures fieldwork for students to participate in and reflect on the educational mission of community colleges.

courses.title: Advanced Pedagogy and Academic Job Preparation
courses.desc: Focuses on advanced pedagogical research and practices. Students design and implement an integrated curriculum in the context of the TA Professional Development Program. Prepare for the academic job market by developing application materials and reviewing Pedagogical Fellow applicants.

courses.title: Advanced Pedagogy and Academic Job Preparation
courses.desc: Focuses on advanced pedagogical research and practices. Students design and implement an integrated curriculum in the context of the TA Professional Development Program. Prepare for the academic job market by developing application materials and reviewing Pedagogical Fellow applicants.

courses.title: Advanced Pedagogy and Academic Job Preparation
courses.desc: Focuses on advanced pedagogical research and practices. Students design and implement an integrated curriculum in the context of the TA Professional Development Program. Prepare for the academic job market by developing application materials and reviewing Pedagogical Fellow applicants.

courses.title: Developing Teaching Excellence
courses.desc: An introduction to evidence-based instructional design and methods, specifically for higher education courses. Students practice, observe, and design instruction based on pedagogical literature. Meets most of the requirements for the Certificate in Teaching Excellence Program.

courses.title: Seminar for Teaching as Research
courses.desc: Preparation and implementation of a teaching as research project in higher education. Participants learn research, experimental design, human subjects, and statistical analysis.

courses.title: Introduction to Urban Studies
courses.desc: Introduces the substantive areas, concepts, and tools in the field of urban studies.  Acquaints students with physical, environmental, social, economic, and political dimensions of cities.  Examines the challenges facing cities, including poverty, sustainability, development, globalization, and others.

courses.title: Introduction to Urban Planning and Policy
courses.desc: Introduces students to the basic issues in urban planning and public policy.

courses.title: Introduction to Environmental Analysis and Design
courses.desc: Overview of general concepts, theoretical principles, and analytical techniques for investigating environmental systems. Integrates tools from natural and social sciences to analyze contemporary environmental challenges such as pollution, resource acquisition, facility and ecosystem design, impact assessments, formulation of environmental policy.

courses.title: Cities: Focal Point for Sustainability Problems and Solutions I
courses.desc: Explores the nature of cities, focusing on the challenges facing cities today, their possible solutions, and the technical and social constraints on those solutions.

courses.title: Cities: Focal Point for Sustainability Problems and Solutions II
courses.desc: Explores the nature of cities, focusing on the challenges facing cities today, their possible solutions, and the technical and social constraints on those solutions.

courses.title: Urban Sociology
courses.desc: Overview of theoretical, substantive, and policy issues in urban sociology.  History of urbanization, the school of human ecology, and recent trends regarding urbanism.  Time is devoted to understanding the causes and possible solutions to urban problems.

courses.title: Special Topics in Urban Studies
courses.desc: Course content varies with interest of the instructor.

courses.title: History of Cities
courses.desc: Surveys the global and historical co-evolution of cities and social institutions, including religion, the economy, governance, the arts, technology, and family life.

courses.title: Urban Inequality
courses.desc: Examines structural inequality and the influence that urbanization has in affecting race, ethnic, and class relations. Explores how race/ethnicity, class, urban space, housing, economic development, public education, and land policy intersect in cities, both historically and today.

courses.title: Comparative Approaches to Urban Regions
courses.desc: An introduction to comparative urbanization in developing countries. Introduces students to the geography, history, and theories of urbanization, and then reviews urban planning, public policy, and governance.

courses.title: Urban America
courses.desc: Students examine the historical, social, political, and economic factors that contributed to the construction of the American urban context, one that is poverty concentrated and racially/ethnically segregated. Students also critically assess the consequence of growing up in America's urban neighborhoods.

courses.title: California's Population
courses.desc: Surveys California's human population (past, present, and future) and its interactions with trends in society, government, the economy, and the environment.

courses.title: Urban and Regional Planning
courses.desc: Important substantive areas, concepts, tools in the field of urban and regional planning. Topics include: forces that have historically guided and are currently guiding U.S. urbanization; land use, economic development, housing and community development, environmental planning; legal, environmental, governmental contexts.

courses.title: Cities and Transportation
courses.desc: The relationship between urban areas and transportation systems. Economic analysis of cities, transportation and urban form, highway congestion, environmental impacts of transportation, public transit, land use and transportation, and political influences on transportation planning.

courses.title: Housing and Urban Development Policy
courses.prereqs: Recommended: Previous course work in economics.
courses.desc: Surveys public policy issues and develops analytic techniques in the areas of housing and urban development. Examines a range of policy topics including housing assistance to low- and moderate-income families, housing finance system, incentives for economic development, and neighborhood preservation.

courses.title: Urban Economic Development Policy
courses.desc: Theoretical and practical perspectives on local economic development policy.  Integrates economic, planning, and political perspectives. Overview of economic role of cities and metropolitan areas. Specific development issues include: link between taxes, regulation, job growth; redevelopment planning; evaluation economic development policy.

courses.title: Foundations of Community Health
courses.desc: A social ecological framework for understanding community health is presented. Measures of individual and community health are compared, and the influence of personal and environmental factors on individual, group, and population health is examined. Community health promotion strategies are discussed.

courses.title: Poverty and Change in Developing Countries
courses.desc: Focuses on poverty in developing countries.  Analyzes the magnitude and changing nature of poverty in the global south. Critically examines poverty conceptualized in terms of economic deprivation, well-being, and social exclusion.

courses.title: Global Poverty and Inequality in the 21st Century
courses.desc: Explores a multidisciplinary understanding of poverty and inequality in the 21st century and assesses impact of education, health, technology, and other interventions. Course offered online only.

courses.title: American Public Policy
courses.desc: Focuses on the development and implementation of public policy in the United States. Lectures cover theoretical models of the policy process as well as significant problems facing contemporary American decision-makers.

courses.title: Cities and Food
courses.desc: Explores the role of cities in transforming global diets: how urbanization has shaped what and how we eat, and what the co-evolution of diets and city life portend for the future.

courses.title: Environmental Sustainability I
courses.desc: Provides an introduction to sustainability from different points of view; historical, scientific, political, ethical, and economic.

courses.title: Environmental Sustainability II
courses.desc: Investigates how sustainability can be implemented in a variety of contexts including water, energy, non-renewable resources, biodiversity, and urban policy, and also how it could be measured.

courses.title: Environmental Law and Policy
courses.desc: Environmental law as a combination of traditional legal principles and newly created statutes, rules, and decisions applied to environmental protection. Investigates roles of courts, legislature, executive branch and administrative agencies, and private citizens attempting to regulate environmental quality.

courses.title: Water Resource Policy
courses.desc: Examination of contemporary water problems worldwide, with particular attention to the competing water demands in the western U.S., and water demand by the poor in developing countries. History and analysis of U.S. water policies at local, state, and federal levels.

courses.title: Environmental Hazards in an Urbanizing World
courses.desc: Development patterns, including urbanization, can contribute to environmental hazard severity. Humans can plan, mitigate, and prepare to reduce costly hazard losses. Students learn about environmental hazards and human response to these threats.

courses.title: Environmental Governance
courses.desc: How should the environment be managed and who should be responsible? What is effective environmental management, and for whom? These questions are answered by exploring traditional and emerging theoretical frameworks and applying them to real world environmental challenges.

courses.title: Principles of Economics for Planning and Policy
courses.desc: Provides an introduction into economics for planning and policy students.

courses.title: Cultural Ecology and Environmental Design
courses.desc: Introduction to cultural ecology and environmental and architectural design. Addresses the understanding of people’s relationships with their built environments, the basic elements of architecture, architectural analysis, and cultural analysis are covered. Examines values in design and design for multicultural societies.

courses.title: Elements of Environmental Design
courses.desc: Basic elements of environmental design such as scale, proportion, rhythm, color, sound, lighting, surfaces, texture, architectural definition of spaces, volumes, massing volumetric analysis, solids and voids, and cultural aspects of design. Excitement and creativity in design, imageability.

courses.title: Urban Design Principles
courses.desc: Introduction to principles of urban design and its applications.  Study of contemporary and traditional theories of urban design formulated to improve physical characteristics of built environment to facilitate an enhanced quality of life.  A variety of case studies are discussed.

courses.title: Urban Design and Graphics Studio
courses.desc: Introductory course organized around a variety of assignments to encourage learning by design in a studio setting.  Students work on design projects and graphic representation assignments to learn practical aspects of urban design.

courses.title: Urban Politics and Policy
courses.desc: Examines why and how urban policies are enacted and carried out in contemporary U.S. cities and regions. Topics include evolution and organization of city governments and policymaking over the past century; who directs public policy and controls how cities develop.

courses.title: Public Policy and Management
courses.desc: Exposes students to best management practices that assure effective planning and implementation of policies and programs in government, business, and nonprofit sectors. Includes guest lecturers who are proven leaders in four principal institutions of community: business, education, government, and nonprofit.

courses.title: Public Policy Analysis
courses.desc: Examines different approaches to the analysis of public policy, what constitutes good policy, the role of government, and citizen participation in policy-making. Suggests a policy-design perspective which builds upon other frameworks but concentrates on goals, implementation structures, tools, and rationales.

courses.title: Health Policy
courses.desc: Considers social and economic aspects of health and disease in the United States.  What are the proper roles of the individual, community, and government in improving health and health care?  International comparisons will be made wherever possible.

courses.title: Latino Metropolis
courses.desc: Explores the processes of Latino urbanization in the United States and the spatialization of Latino identities, particularly in the context of Southern California with selected comparisons drawing from other cities.

courses.title: Chicano Movement
courses.desc: Explores the history of Mexicans in the U.S. with particular attention paid to their integration into the U.S. capitalist economy.  Examines this economic history and the Chicano movement, "El Movimiento," within the wide context of socio-economic change.

courses.title: International Divided Cities
courses.desc: Investigates urban divisions in international cities where deep-seated nationalistic ethnic differences create pressures for intergroup conflicts, autonomy, or territorial separation, and can incite violence. Urban political polarization as it is manifest in the urban setting.

courses.title: History of Urban Planning
courses.desc: Introduction to the historical roots and fundamental perspectives of urban and regional planning.  Exploration of the significant historical phases and personalities which have shaped the profession.  The roles and responsibilities, the limitations and potential, of urban planning.

courses.title: Theoretical Foundations of Planning
courses.desc: Intellectual excursion into central themes in policy and planning, including philosophy of the market, institutionalization of space, hypostatizations of policy, constructions of communities, logics of spatial analysis. Objective is engagement of the professional in thoughtful reflections on practice and institutions.

courses.title: Plan Development and Communication
courses.desc: Graphic representation and communication of physical place characteristics, design and physical planning ideas, and concepts using a variety of graphic techniques of free hand drawing, sketching, orthographic representations, scale drawings, 3D representations, maps, photo-documentation, and various media.

courses.title: Environmental Economics and Policy
courses.desc: Provides a broad introduction to environmental economics and to environmental policy.  Environmental problems facing the United States and Europe are analyzed, and whenever possible, the environmental problems facing developing countries.

courses.title: Microeconomic Analysis for Urban Planning
courses.desc: Provides students with a working knowledge of basic microeconomic concepts.  Emphasizes applications related to urban planning and policy analysis.  Topics covered include demand analysis, firm behavior, market structure, public goods, externalities, and the role of economics in land markets.

courses.title: Land-Use Law
courses.desc: Investigates legal and institutional frameworks for development control. Review of constitutional issues implicated in land-use regulation. Traces development control historically and analyzes contemporary approaches to land-use control which reflect environmental and economic development concerns.

courses.title: Qualitative Research Methods: Overview
courses.desc: Introduction to fundamentals of “qualitative” research and non-positivistic inquiry. Formulation of research questions, selection of method, data collection techniques, and analysis (briefly). Overview of selected methods from ethnography, naturalistic field research, phenomenology, ethnoarchaeology, critical approaches, and others.

courses.title: Practice Experience
courses.desc: Provides Master of Urban and Regional Planning students an opportunity to link classroom knowledge with real planning situations through a 10-week unpaid practice experience.

courses.title: Transportation Planning
courses.desc: Introduces current topics in transportation planning.  Includes an analysis of the economic role of transportation in urban areas, land-use impacts of transportation projects, traffic congestion, air quality, alternatives to the automobile, and other transportation topics.

courses.title: Advanced Qualitative Methods: Analyzing Qualitative Data
courses.desc: Introduction to the theory and practice of analyzing qualitative data. Students must have already learned about data collection and research design for qualitative research and must have qualitative data they can analyze.

courses.title: Quantitative Analysis for Planners
courses.desc: Introduces students to the basic statistical concepts used to address issues of public concern.  Prepares students to perform, interpret, and evaluate quantitative data analyses commonly used in professional studies.

courses.title: Analytical Methods for Planning
courses.desc: Emphasizes the development of analytical techniques proven useful in the fields of management and administration.  Topics include multiple regression, cost-benefit analysis and discounting, decision trees, and other techniques useful for the purposes of community analysis and planning.

courses.title: Qualitative Methods: Fieldwork and Data Collection
courses.desc: Covers fieldwork, data collections techniques, and related issues for anti-positivistic research. Data collection techniques include observation, physical traces, participation, in-depth interview. Data checks include veracity, detail, completeness, rigor.

courses.title: Public Policy
courses.desc: Explores different approaches to public policy analysis, the diverse conceptions of the goals and objectives that should be served by policy, and the appropriate role of the policy analyst.  Policy consequences are traced to indirect and subtle incentives and disincentives.

courses.title: Environmental Politics and Policy
courses.desc: Reviews and critiques literature on discussion topics including: the nature and effectiveness of environmental movements and policies; the role of science and technology; the use of economic incentives in policy; decentralization of decision making; and creating arenas for public involvement.

courses.title: Demographics for Planning and Policy
courses.desc: Provides planning and policy practitioners with a condensed, nonspecialist orientation to the sources, applications, and interpretation of population statistics, and conveys the steps used in constructing local-area population forecasts and projections.

courses.title: Transportation and Environmental Health
courses.desc: Critically evaluates how transportation can promote sustainable, healthy, and equitable cities. Examines the interaction of transportation systems with urban form, land use, community health, and environmental quality.

courses.title: Water Policy and Planning
courses.desc: Examines major issues in global water management including privatization, emerging water quality challenges, water system planning, affordability, conservation strategies, and flood resilience.  Emphasizes integrated understanding of economics, governance, environmental health, technology, and development.

courses.title: Geographic Information Systems (GIS) Problem Solving in Planning
courses.desc: Explores the application of geographic information systems (GIS) in urban planning.  Steps through a GIS-based planning procedure that balances housing, jobs, tax base, utilities, transportation, and the natural environment.

courses.title: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems
courses.desc: Application of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) to the field of urban and regional planning.  Emphasizes current issues that occur in actual implementation settings. Lecture/discussion followed by laboratory demonstrating the area of GIS discussed.  Offers "hands-on" student usage of GIS software.

courses.title: Urban Design Theories and Applications
courses.desc: Introduction to contemporary and traditional theories of urban design and their applications.  Organized around one question:  How might planning and design of built environment contribute to making a good city?  National and international case studies are introduced.

courses.title: Health Policy and Management
courses.desc: Multidisciplinary inquiry into theory and practice concerned with delivery, quantity, costs of health care for individuals and populations. Explores managerial and policy concerns regarding structure, process, outcomes of health services including the costs, financing, organization, outcomes, and accessibility of care.

courses.title: Land-Use Policy
courses.desc: Examination of the role of public policy in guiding growth and development in urban and suburban environments.  Description of a wide-ranging set of growth policies, the rationales underlying their use, controversies and legal constraints, and evaluation of their effectiveness.

courses.title: Housing Policy
courses.prereqs: Familiarity with basic statistics is required.
courses.desc: Examines theories and practices of housing policy and the relationship of housing to larger neighborhood, community, and regional development issues. Considers the roles of private for-profit and not-for-profit developers, lenders, and all levels of government in the provision of housing.

courses.title: Poverty and Development
courses.desc: Examines competing conceptualizations, methods of measurement, and poverty alleviation strategies widely used in developing countries. Focuses on poverty conceptualized as economic deprivation, well-being, vulnerability, and social exclusion.

courses.title: Issues in Environmental Law and Policy
courses.desc: Treatment of legal and policy strategies for promoting environmental protection and deterring environmental degradation within the context of other societal objectives. Topical approach with a focus on problems of special interest to criminologists and to environmental policy specialists.

courses.title: Urban Planning and Public Policy Seminar
courses.desc: For first- and second-year doctoral students.  Topics include professional development; journal publication process; academic conference presentations; and the job market for doctoral students in and out of academia.

courses.title: Urban and Community Development Seminar
courses.desc: For first- and second-year doctoral students.  Topics include scholarship related to the urban and community development area.  Discussion of assigned articles and book chapters and how they relate to urban and community development.

courses.title: Economic Democracy
courses.desc: Explores a wide range of radical democratic and egalitarian visions (including but not limited to the Marxist tradition) for a more sane, just, and sustainable future.

courses.title: Environmental Ethics
courses.desc: Introduction to major themes and debates in environmental ethics, with application to contemporary environmental issues.

courses.title: Global Urbanization
courses.desc: Examines the spread of cities worldwide in the 20th century. What are the political and economic causes of this process? What are the social-cultural, political, and economic effects? How is contemporary urbanization linked to global restructuring of other kinds.

courses.title: Special Topics in Urban Planning
courses.desc: Special topics in urban and regional planning are offered from time to time, but not on a regular basis. Course content varies with interest of the instructor.

courses.title: Culture, Community, and Space
courses.desc: Covers how cultures relate to natural and built physical environments.  Ways in which culture influences space; ways space influences culture.  Concepts for understanding the interrelationship, including values, norms, traditions, religion, and place attachment.  Culture and cities, urban form, ethnic communities.

courses.title: Theories of Power and Empowerment
courses.desc: Studies different ways of thinking about power and its uses. Explores theories of power that inform various notions of empowerment, including resistance, participatory democracy, and workplace empowerment.

courses.title: Advanced Theory
courses.desc: Provides urban planning and public policy students with an introduction to advanced theory. Addresses broad theoretical approaches that cut across disciplinary and topical boundaries. Designed primarily for Ph.D. students.

courses.title: Urban Design Studio for Planners: An Introduction
courses.desc: Introductory urban design for planners.  Organized around a variety of assignments to encourage learning by design in a studio setting. Students work on design projects and drawing assignments to learn practical aspects of urban design.

courses.title: Collaborative Governance and Public Management
courses.desc: Introduction to inclusive management. To make effective use of public resources, public managers are inventing ways of managing that alter relationships within organizations, between organizations, between sectors, and with the public. Requires rethinking fundamentals such as leadership and motivation.

courses.title: Professional Report
courses.desc: Workshop designed to assist M.U.R.P. students in conducting their professional reports.  Students select topics, design projects, conduct professional investigations, and write up reports.

courses.title: Urban Planning Practicum I
courses.desc: Engages students in practical planning projects in the community under a central theme within Planning. Students take a problem-solving approach and employ and further develop data gathering, analysis, graphic and oral communication, public engagement, and report writing skills.

courses.title: Urban Planning Practicum II
courses.desc: Engages students in practical planning projects in the community under a central theme within Planning. Students take a problem-solving approach and employ and further develop data gathering, analysis, graphic and oral communication, public engagement, and report writing skills.

courses.title: Doctoral Dissertation Research and Writing
courses.desc: Dissertation research with Urban Planning and Public Policy faculty.

courses.title: Research Design
courses.desc: Provides training in research design and methods. Students learn how to evaluate the strength of research findings based on the methods used by a researcher and learn to use lessons from the course to develop a research proposal.

courses.title: Directed Studies in Urban Planning
courses.desc: Directed studies in Urban Planning.

courses.title: Independent Study in Urban Planning
courses.desc: Independent Study in Urban Planning.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Vietnamese
courses.desc: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Vietnamese. Natural approach with emphasis on four fundamental skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Conducted in Vietnamese.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Vietnamese
courses.prereqs: VIETMSE 1A. VIETMSE 1A with a grade of C or better. Placement into VIETMSE 1B is also accepted.
courses.desc: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Vietnamese. Natural approach with emphasis on four fundamental skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Conducted in Vietnamese.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Vietnamese
courses.prereqs: VIETMSE 1B or VIETMSE S1AB. VIETMSE 1B with a grade of C or better. VIETMSE S1AB with a grade of C or better. Placement into VIETMSE 1C is also accepted.
courses.desc: Designed for students with little or no exposure to Vietnamese. Natural approach with emphasis on four fundamental skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Conducted in Vietnamese.

courses.title: Intermediate Vietnamese
courses.prereqs: VIETMSE 1C and VIETMSE S1BC. VIETMSE 1C with a grade of C or better. VIETMSE S1BC with a grade of C or better. Placement into VIETMSE 2A is also accepted.
courses.desc: Designed for students to advance their Vietnamese language skills from introductory to intermediate level.
